description: This series explores the practical application of DNS, the Domain Naming System.  We demonstrate using DNS records to support websites, mail servers, and other services.  Other topics addressed include DNS security, replication, and popular server software including BIND and Microsoft Windows DNS.
name: DNS
subtitle: Maintaining the Domain Name System

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don discuss how to obtain information from a DNS server with the NSLookup command. They explain the different modes interactive and non-interactive that an administrator can use and what these modes are used for.
episodes.title: nslookup
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:01.352
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.352 --> 00:00:07.871
I'm your host, Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.871 --> 00:00:08.381
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.381 --> 00:00:12.016
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.016 --> 00:00:14.906
>> Welcome back to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.906 --> 00:00:18.920
I'm your host, Wes Bryan, and today, we've
got a really good subject coming at you.

7
00:00:18.920 --> 00:00:22.904
We're gonna be talking about one of the
most important services on the Internet

8
00:00:22.904 --> 00:00:25.233
that really makes us get
around the Internet.

9
00:00:25.233 --> 00:00:28.216
And joining me in the studios today for
that topic is none other than Mr.

10
00:00:28.216 --> 00:00:28.730
Don Pezet.

11
00:00:28.730 --> 00:00:29.740
Don, how are you doing sir?

12
00:00:29.740 --> 00:00:30.740
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

13
00:00:30.740 --> 00:00:32.272
Ready to dive right back into DNS.

14
00:00:32.272 --> 00:00:35.736
In this episode, we're moving on
with our command line utilities,

15
00:00:35.736 --> 00:00:38.076
some of our utilities
that we can use with DNS.

16
00:00:38.076 --> 00:00:40.843
And in this particular episode,
we're gonna look at nslookup,

17
00:00:40.843 --> 00:00:44.164
which is probably one of the most useful
command line utilities when it comes to

18
00:00:44.164 --> 00:00:45.540
working with DNS.

19
00:00:45.540 --> 00:00:47.160
Anytime you're doing
configuration changes,

20
00:00:47.160 --> 00:00:49.790
anytime you're putting entries in, we
need to be able to verify that they work.

21
00:00:49.790 --> 00:00:53.010
You need to be able to test to make
sure that our names are resolving, and

22
00:00:53.010 --> 00:00:54.800
that's where nslookup comes in.

23
00:00:54.800 --> 00:00:58.010
So, just a real brief
synopsis on nslookup.

24
00:00:58.010 --> 00:01:00.552
The name stands for name server lookup.

25
00:01:00.552 --> 00:01:03.895
Just a command line utility that we can
reach out and it talks to DNS servers, so

26
00:01:03.895 --> 00:01:06.986
that we can recreate the queries that
all of our other servers are doing in

27
00:01:06.986 --> 00:01:08.310
the background.

28
00:01:08.310 --> 00:01:13.630
Nice thing about nslookup, it's present
on Windows, Linux, Unix, MacOS.

29
00:01:13.630 --> 00:01:16.876
Pretty much every system these
days has nslookup baked in.

30
00:01:16.876 --> 00:01:17.903
And to be honest with you,

31
00:01:17.903 --> 00:01:21.360
I can't remember the last time that I
encountered a system that didn't have it.

32
00:01:21.360 --> 00:01:24.590
There's some of those really stripped
down Linux distros that might not have it

33
00:01:24.590 --> 00:01:28.360
installed by default, but you can throw it
right on there pretty easily through one

34
00:01:28.360 --> 00:01:30.990
of the repositories and have access to it.

35
00:01:30.990 --> 00:01:35.270
The other nice thing about nslookup
is the command line syntax

36
00:01:35.270 --> 00:01:37.890
is pretty much identical between
all the operating systems.

37
00:01:37.890 --> 00:01:41.410
So, if you know how to use it on Windows,
then, you know how to use it on a Mac.

38
00:01:41.410 --> 00:01:43.780
And if you know how to use it on a Mac,
you know how to use it on Unix and Linux.

39
00:01:43.780 --> 00:01:47.490
So, it's all kinda tied together and
that makes this one really robust.

40
00:01:47.490 --> 00:01:50.425
So, that's what we're gonna take
a look at right here in this episode.

41
00:01:50.425 --> 00:01:52.062
All right, so, enough talking about it.

42
00:01:52.062 --> 00:01:54.550
All right, let's get in here and
take a look and see it.

43
00:01:54.550 --> 00:01:57.900
You know you have nslookup, well,
it's actually pretty easy to see.

44
00:01:57.900 --> 00:02:00.640
We know we have it in pretty much
every operating systems out there.

45
00:02:00.640 --> 00:02:03.320
You can just run it and see.

46
00:02:03.320 --> 00:02:06.270
If you don't have it for some reason,
which really would just be like kind of

47
00:02:06.270 --> 00:02:09.765
some Linux distributions that
might not have it, most of us,

48
00:02:09.765 --> 00:02:11.940
we should have this, no big deal, right?

49
00:02:11.940 --> 00:02:15.550
But if you just run it, what you should
see is basically what I got right here.

50
00:02:15.550 --> 00:02:19.030
It's gonna jump in and you should end up
with a greater than prompt like that,

51
00:02:19.030 --> 00:02:19.970
all right?

52
00:02:19.970 --> 00:02:24.780
What I just did is I entered what's called
the interactive command line for nslookup.

53
00:02:24.780 --> 00:02:29.070
So, once I'm in here, I'm technically
still in the nslookup utility.

54
00:02:29.070 --> 00:02:30.920
And now,
I can start running commands against it,

55
00:02:30.920 --> 00:02:33.570
as many commands as I want, all right.

56
00:02:33.570 --> 00:02:36.320
But for most of us, we're not gonna
go with the interactive mode.

57
00:02:36.320 --> 00:02:38.379
We're going to stick with
the non-interactive mode,

58
00:02:38.379 --> 00:02:41.375
where we run a command, it does what we
ask it to do, and then it's done, right?

59
00:02:41.375 --> 00:02:43.372
It just gets in, gets out,
and in, that's it.

60
00:02:43.372 --> 00:02:45.896
So, let me exit out of that,
back to my prompt.

61
00:02:45.896 --> 00:02:49.830
And the non-interactive mode
is the most straight forward.

62
00:02:49.830 --> 00:02:51.120
It is the one I use most of the time.

63
00:02:51.120 --> 00:02:53.540
We're just trying to do something
like simple name resolution.

64
00:02:53.540 --> 00:02:58.900
So, if I wanna find out what the IP
address of the ITProTV website is, right?

65
00:02:58.900 --> 00:03:05.134
What I can do is I can jump in here and
I can just say, nslookup itpro.tv.

66
00:03:05.134 --> 00:03:09.244
And it's gonna reach out to that DNS
server and it's gonna do a lookout, okay.

67
00:03:09.244 --> 00:03:13.678
Now, when it did the lookup, notice I
got this DNS request timed out, right?

68
00:03:13.678 --> 00:03:15.003
Timeout was 2 seconds.

69
00:03:15.003 --> 00:03:16.190
What does that mean?

70
00:03:16.190 --> 00:03:20.930
Well, whatever my main DNS
server is wasn't answering.

71
00:03:20.930 --> 00:03:23.070
And so,
it skipped forward to the next one, right?

72
00:03:23.070 --> 00:03:25.784
I can see that progression
that just happened and

73
00:03:25.784 --> 00:03:29.036
it moved forward to a Google server,
to 8.8.8.8.

74
00:03:29.036 --> 00:03:30.680
Right, so, I hit that one and
that one was fine.

75
00:03:30.680 --> 00:03:33.120
And then,
I was able to resolve my address.

76
00:03:33.120 --> 00:03:37.160
So, I get some feedback about that
query process and what happened.

77
00:03:37.160 --> 00:03:39.830
But it's not terribly detailed, right?

78
00:03:39.830 --> 00:03:42.830
It didn't tell me what it timed out on.

79
00:03:42.830 --> 00:03:45.134
So, what was my primary DNS server?

80
00:03:45.134 --> 00:03:46.040
I don't know.

81
00:03:46.040 --> 00:03:48.856
It also says here that it's
a non-authoritative answer.

82
00:03:48.856 --> 00:03:50.340
Now, remember, with non-authoritative,

83
00:03:50.340 --> 00:03:54.830
that means the server that I asked
didn't actually have the answer for me.

84
00:03:54.830 --> 00:03:57.820
It had to do a recursive lookup
against some other server.

85
00:03:57.820 --> 00:04:02.380
And so, it reached out and talked to other
servers and hid all that from me and

86
00:04:02.380 --> 00:04:03.590
gave me this answer.

87
00:04:03.590 --> 00:04:07.750
When we use the non-interactive mode, you
get a really simplified output like this.

88
00:04:07.750 --> 00:04:11.580
If we want really detailed output
where we see all the different steps,

89
00:04:11.580 --> 00:04:13.880
that's where the interactive
mode comes in.

90
00:04:13.880 --> 00:04:15.830
So, that's a real simple
lookup right there.

91
00:04:15.830 --> 00:04:20.810
You provided a domain name or a host name,
and it gives you back an IP address.

92
00:04:20.810 --> 00:04:24.270
There's really only one other thing we can
do here from the non-interactive mode.

93
00:04:24.270 --> 00:04:27.400
Notice how I get the server that
I did a lookup against, right?

94
00:04:27.400 --> 00:04:29.500
I can override that server.

95
00:04:29.500 --> 00:04:33.107
I can say instead of looking
up against 8.8.8.8, maybe,

96
00:04:33.107 --> 00:04:36.069
I wanna lookup against 4.2.2.1, all right?

97
00:04:36.069 --> 00:04:39.330
And when we do that,
we're overriding the server.

98
00:04:39.330 --> 00:04:40.820
Now, why would we wanna do that?

99
00:04:40.820 --> 00:04:43.803
Well, have you ever made
a change to a public DNS record?

100
00:04:43.803 --> 00:04:46.326
So, if you go on GoDaddy or
Hover or Register,

101
00:04:46.326 --> 00:04:49.262
or whatever it is that you
purchase your domain name.

102
00:04:49.262 --> 00:04:52.040
You log in to the website and
you make a change to an A record.

103
00:04:52.040 --> 00:04:55.420
The real message it'll say, this could
take up to 48 hours to take effect.

104
00:04:56.420 --> 00:04:57.630
But what does that mean?

105
00:04:57.630 --> 00:04:59.330
In computers, what takes 48 hours?

106
00:04:59.330 --> 00:05:02.923
Well, your change actually takes effect
immediately, right the moment you do it.

107
00:05:02.923 --> 00:05:07.101
But people around the world will cache
your DNS record and they can cache it for

108
00:05:07.101 --> 00:05:08.070
up to 48 hours.

109
00:05:08.070 --> 00:05:09.140
So, that's why they warn you about that.

110
00:05:09.140 --> 00:05:11.570
Hey, it can take up to two days for
everybody to purge their cache and

111
00:05:11.570 --> 00:05:13.180
learn your new address.

112
00:05:13.180 --> 00:05:15.950
So, if you ever wanna see how
far you've propagated out,

113
00:05:15.950 --> 00:05:17.670
you might do what I just did.

114
00:05:17.670 --> 00:05:19.550
Do a lookup against Google server.

115
00:05:19.550 --> 00:05:21.360
Do a lookup against Level Three server.

116
00:05:21.360 --> 00:05:23.948
Do a lookup against your ISP,
other people's ISPs and

117
00:05:23.948 --> 00:05:27.951
see whether they've received the change
already or not, and you'd be surprised.

118
00:05:27.951 --> 00:05:31.980
It's a rare change that takes more than
like an hour to propagate out these days.

119
00:05:31.980 --> 00:05:36.360
>> Don, now, when you said override,
is that taking the interface assigned

120
00:05:36.360 --> 00:05:38.670
DNS server and saying,
hey we're not gonna use this.

121
00:05:38.670 --> 00:05:41.250
We're gonna use the IP address of
what you've just put there at the end

122
00:05:41.250 --> 00:05:42.065
of nslookup?

123
00:05:42.065 --> 00:05:43.900
>> Yeah, on Windows,

124
00:05:43.900 --> 00:05:46.740
it's whatever DNS server you have
assigned to your network adapter.

125
00:05:46.740 --> 00:05:48.451
If you're running Mac or Linux,

126
00:05:48.451 --> 00:05:51.517
it's whatever DNS servers
are in your resolve.com file.

127
00:05:51.517 --> 00:05:53.392
So, that's what a stuff's defined, and

128
00:05:53.392 --> 00:05:56.130
that's all nslookup does is
it looks up those things.

129
00:05:56.130 --> 00:05:58.950
I guess, important thing to mention
here is that some operating

130
00:05:58.950 --> 00:06:01.245
systems have a DNS cache built in to them,
right?

131
00:06:01.245 --> 00:06:05.844
Windows has it, it's super annoying,
where [LAUGH] Windows will do a lookup and

132
00:06:05.844 --> 00:06:07.230
it will cache a record.

133
00:06:07.230 --> 00:06:09.650
And then,
when you go to browse that webpage again,

134
00:06:09.650 --> 00:06:11.804
it doesn't actually go
out to the DNS server.

135
00:06:11.804 --> 00:06:13.151
It just uses its own cache, right?

136
00:06:13.151 --> 00:06:15.185
This is where the whole
40-hour thing comes in.

137
00:06:15.185 --> 00:06:17.915
So, if we wanna override that,
well, in Windows,

138
00:06:17.915 --> 00:06:19.835
some of you guys might be
familiar with the command.

139
00:06:19.835 --> 00:06:20.735
Let me show you.

140
00:06:20.735 --> 00:06:26.940
It's ipconfig /flushdns and
that will wipe your DNS cache, right?

141
00:06:26.940 --> 00:06:31.050
Well, nslookup doesn't use
the DNS cache in Windows.

142
00:06:31.050 --> 00:06:32.950
So, it's actually bypassing that cache.

143
00:06:32.950 --> 00:06:37.950
Now, the reason I bring that up is
you might fire up a web browser, and

144
00:06:37.950 --> 00:06:40.160
try and go to web page,
and you can't get there.

145
00:06:40.160 --> 00:06:44.170
And you drop to a command prompt and
use nslookup, but it show us the right IP.

146
00:06:44.170 --> 00:06:48.578
And the problem is that Chrome,
Firefox, Internet Explorer,

147
00:06:48.578 --> 00:06:52.832
whatever, might be using the DNS cache and
NSlookup isn't.

148
00:06:52.832 --> 00:06:54.351
And so, they have two different records.

149
00:06:54.351 --> 00:06:56.232
That's where you might have
to flush the cache here.

150
00:06:56.232 --> 00:06:59.160
But nslookup does not use
the DNS cache on your system.

151
00:06:59.160 --> 00:07:01.680
>> So, if you want just a quick
answer from a DNS server,

152
00:07:01.680 --> 00:07:05.000
you can just use nslookup, you said,
in the non-interactive mode.

153
00:07:05.000 --> 00:07:07.150
Now, you mentioned that term
interactive mode, you said,

154
00:07:07.150 --> 00:07:08.460
that's where the actions at.

155
00:07:08.460 --> 00:07:09.890
Tell us a little bit about that, Don.

156
00:07:09.890 --> 00:07:12.940
>> All right, so,
pretty limited options here, right?

157
00:07:12.940 --> 00:07:16.150
I can provide a host name or DNS name and
I can override the server, and

158
00:07:16.150 --> 00:07:17.590
that's really about it.

159
00:07:17.590 --> 00:07:20.500
But if we get into the interactive mode,
there are a ton

160
00:07:20.500 --> 00:07:23.610
of options that we can jump in there and
start to manipulate it and change.

161
00:07:23.610 --> 00:07:27.510
So, if I just run nslookup by itself,
that's gonna take me

162
00:07:27.510 --> 00:07:30.800
into that interactive prompt and
I'll get my DNS timed out again.

163
00:07:30.800 --> 00:07:32.990
[LAUGH] So
i'll just switch over to the other server.

164
00:07:32.990 --> 00:07:37.090
So, anyhow, once I'm in there, now, I
could start to change the way things work.

165
00:07:37.090 --> 00:07:41.900
If you just do a question mark, you'll get
a list of all the different commands and

166
00:07:41.900 --> 00:07:43.570
things that we can put in there.

167
00:07:43.570 --> 00:07:47.590
And right off the bat, you'll notice
that you can do a lookup for a name or

168
00:07:47.590 --> 00:07:49.180
a host name just by typing it in.

169
00:07:49.180 --> 00:07:50.322
So, I just type in whatever that name is.

170
00:07:50.322 --> 00:07:52.580
Type in ITProTV and it will resolve it.

171
00:07:52.580 --> 00:07:55.723
But then, there's all these
set options that we can do.

172
00:07:55.723 --> 00:07:58.814
To override the way that
things are working.

173
00:07:58.814 --> 00:08:03.150
And way down here we'll see where
we can set the server also.

174
00:08:03.150 --> 00:08:07.220
So earlier I was overriding
the server from the command line.

175
00:08:07.220 --> 00:08:11.237
From here, anytime I do a look up,
right now it's using 8.8.8.8, right?

176
00:08:11.237 --> 00:08:16.390
So if I do a look up for
itpro.tv It's using 8.8.8.8.

177
00:08:16.390 --> 00:08:20.824
But if I do server 4.2.2.1, right?

178
00:08:20.824 --> 00:08:23.220
Now it's changing my resolver.

179
00:08:23.220 --> 00:08:25.610
I'm now changed over to 4.2.2.1,

180
00:08:25.610 --> 00:08:29.850
and every look up I do from here on out,
it's gonna do against that resolver.

181
00:08:29.850 --> 00:08:32.530
So if I look up itpro.tv.

182
00:08:32.530 --> 00:08:35.256
There we go, it ran it, and
it ran it against 4.2.2.1 and

183
00:08:35.256 --> 00:08:36.375
I didn't have to tell it.

184
00:08:36.375 --> 00:08:42.910
And then I could jump in and say cnn.com,
and there it goes, again off of 4.2.2.1.

185
00:08:42.910 --> 00:08:48.359
If I do a server, let's see 8.8.

186
00:08:48.359 --> 00:08:49.917
What's the other one, 8.8.4.4?

187
00:08:49.917 --> 00:08:51.935
>> 4.4
>> That's it, the other Google one.

188
00:08:51.935 --> 00:08:53.790
There we are,
I'll switch to the other Google one.

189
00:08:53.790 --> 00:08:56.681
And now I can run that lookup for
itpro.tv, and

190
00:08:56.681 --> 00:08:58.690
there it goes doing that lookup.

191
00:08:58.690 --> 00:09:01.570
And it didn't make me have to
provide the server every time.

192
00:09:01.570 --> 00:09:03.970
>> Now Don, with all those options,
who are the demographic?

193
00:09:03.970 --> 00:09:08.714
Who would really be using this with all
those, all that flexibility and power?

194
00:09:08.714 --> 00:09:12.634
>> All right, so an end user or
a Help Desk technician might use the basic

195
00:09:12.634 --> 00:09:17.730
NsLookup just to test DNS resolution or
to find out the IP of a host, all right?

196
00:09:17.730 --> 00:09:21.820
But beyond that,
it's really gonna be DNS administrators.

197
00:09:21.820 --> 00:09:25.840
If you're administering a DNS server,
NS lookup has some incredible features in

198
00:09:25.840 --> 00:09:28.064
it that will let us
troubleshoot the server.

199
00:09:28.064 --> 00:09:29.420
Let me just give you an example.

200
00:09:29.420 --> 00:09:33.260
So there are some denial of service
attacks that can be pulled off against DNS

201
00:09:33.260 --> 00:09:35.560
servers using TCP.

202
00:09:35.560 --> 00:09:39.170
And so you might decide to block TCP and
only allow UDP

203
00:09:39.170 --> 00:09:41.800
lookups against your server, or vice
versa, you might want to go the other way.

204
00:09:41.800 --> 00:09:45.587
So maybe you configure your server to only
answer on UDP, or only answer on TCP.

205
00:09:45.587 --> 00:09:47.380
How do you test that?

206
00:09:47.380 --> 00:09:50.300
Well, in NS lookup, let me just
do that question mark again, or

207
00:09:50.300 --> 00:09:51.950
actually you can do,
well there's a few ways.

208
00:09:51.950 --> 00:09:52.559
I'll do the question mark.

209
00:09:53.850 --> 00:09:57.010
If you look,
there's all these set OPTIONs in here.

210
00:09:57.010 --> 00:09:59.940
And if you look at the set OPTIONs,
and kinda look down at the list,

211
00:09:59.940 --> 00:10:03.750
you'll see where you can override
all sorts of different things.

212
00:10:03.750 --> 00:10:07.920
How you do the transfer, the class, the
type of query, the timeout, the domain,

213
00:10:07.920 --> 00:10:09.300
the search list.

214
00:10:09.300 --> 00:10:12.400
And just all sorts of really
interesting things here to tweak.

215
00:10:12.400 --> 00:10:15.520
And so, you can see how you're
talking to that server.

216
00:10:15.520 --> 00:10:18.820
One of my favorite options
is this debug option.

217
00:10:18.820 --> 00:10:24.030
The debug option gives you a ton of
output about that lookup, right?

218
00:10:24.030 --> 00:10:26.040

>> Don, that's a lot of great information,
in fact now I'm gonna be using that set

446
00:21:49.250 --> 00:21:50.810
command now that I know
it a little bit better.

447
00:21:50.810 --> 00:21:54.030
It does look like we're gonna wrap
this one up soon, but before we do,

448
00:21:54.030 --> 00:21:56.790
do you got any additional
words on using NS lookup?

449
00:21:56.790 --> 00:21:58.280
Any tips or tricks?

450
00:21:58.280 --> 00:22:00.810
>> There are more commands in there,
and you probably notice like when I did

451
00:22:00.810 --> 00:22:03.400
the question mark there were
a handful like setting the class and

452
00:22:03.400 --> 00:22:05.030
setting route and so on.

453
00:22:05.030 --> 00:22:09.746
Those are useful in very,
very few scenarios.

454
00:22:09.746 --> 00:22:10.938
Class is pretty much useless.

455
00:22:10.938 --> 00:22:13.060
There's really only one class these days.

456
00:22:13.060 --> 00:22:14.540
The IN, or the internet class.

457
00:22:14.540 --> 00:22:17.777
The other ones are like the chaos class,
the class, the test class.

458
00:22:17.777 --> 00:22:19.890
Those are all way back in
the early days of DNS, and

459
00:22:19.890 --> 00:22:21.790
they aren't really used anymore.

460
00:22:21.790 --> 00:22:26.380
Other ones like manipulating how
the internet transfers work,

461
00:22:26.380 --> 00:22:28.730
again there's really only
one way in use anymore, so

462
00:22:28.730 --> 00:22:31.160
there's not really a reason
to override those.

463
00:22:31.160 --> 00:22:34.970
Root can be kind of handy, if you're
overriding the root hint servers on

464
00:22:34.970 --> 00:22:38.320
the internet, if you're not using those,
you can connect to any server and

465
00:22:38.320 --> 00:22:40.190
use the set root command.

466
00:22:40.190 --> 00:22:43.560
To flag it as the root and
you won't use root hints anymore.

467
00:22:43.560 --> 00:22:45.610
Everything will go
against that one server.

468
00:22:45.610 --> 00:22:49.730
Not something I've ever had to use
in production, but it is there.

469
00:22:49.730 --> 00:22:53.500
So the commands that I
didn't show are ones that

470
00:22:53.500 --> 00:22:55.820
just we're not really gonna use that much.

471
00:22:55.820 --> 00:22:58.480
There's the search list command,
where you can create

472
00:22:58.480 --> 00:23:01.670
a suffix search list if you want,
right there inside of NSLookup.

473
00:23:01.670 --> 00:23:03.470
We've usually already got
that defined on our systems,

474
00:23:03.470 --> 00:23:05.050
we don't necessarily need it there.

475
00:23:05.050 --> 00:23:08.530
And then timeouts and retries.

476
00:23:08.530 --> 00:23:11.380
You can override the timeout time and
the retry time.

477
00:23:11.380 --> 00:23:15.740
They're the amount of retries,
and the interval of the timeout,

478
00:23:15.740 --> 00:23:18.770
to use the right terminology
to kinda manipulate those.

479
00:23:18.770 --> 00:23:20.960
Again, less common use scenario.

480
00:23:20.960 --> 00:23:24.576
What we saw through the whole beginning of
this is really kinda the important meat

481
00:23:24.576 --> 00:23:25.809
and potatoes of NS hookup.

482
00:23:25.809 --> 00:23:28.136
>> Well, Don, that's a wealth of
information and we appreciate it.

483
00:23:28.136 --> 00:23:32.108
We appreciate the viewers, so we're gonna
go ahead and sign out here at ITProTV.

484
00:23:32.108 --> 00:23:33.619
I've been your host, Wes Brian.

485
00:23:33.619 --> 00:23:34.493
>> And I'm Don Pozet.

486
00:23:34.493 --> 00:23:36.747
>> And we'll see you next time.

487
00:23:36.747 --> 00:23:42.694
[MUSIC]

488
00:23:42.694 --> 00:23:46.127
>> Thank you for watching, IT Pro TV.

489
00:23:46.127 --> 00:23:48.960
[BLANK AUDIO]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explain how to use the Domain Internet Groper utility more commonly known as dig. They explain some of the command line arguments that can be utilized with dig.
episodes.title: dig
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.180
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.180 --> 00:00:06.993
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.993 --> 00:00:08.297
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.297 --> 00:00:11.822
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.822 --> 00:00:15.325
>> Welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.325 --> 00:00:17.495
I'm your host, Wes Bryan,
and in today's episode,

7
00:00:17.495 --> 00:00:18.985
we've got an exciting one coming at you.

8
00:00:18.985 --> 00:00:21.045
We're gonna be digging into DNS.

9
00:00:21.045 --> 00:00:23.865
And joining me in the studios today
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:23.865 --> 00:00:24.725
Don, how you doing, sir?

11
00:00:24.725 --> 00:00:27.805
>> I think that might be the best pun
I'm gonna hear all day right there.

12
00:00:27.805 --> 00:00:29.035
Wes, you nailed it on the head.

13
00:00:29.035 --> 00:00:31.695
We're gonna be taking a look
at the Dig utility today.

14
00:00:31.695 --> 00:00:34.515
And some of you may be familiar with this,
some of you may not.

15
00:00:34.515 --> 00:00:37.680
Some of you may have never heard of
Dig before, and it's kind of a shame.

16
00:00:37.680 --> 00:00:43.240
If you come from the Windows world, well,
Wes, if you come from the Windows world,

17
00:00:43.240 --> 00:00:46.160
what's the standard tool we use for
troubleshooting DNS?

18
00:00:46.160 --> 00:00:48.132
>> You know,
the first thing I think of is NsLookup.

19
00:00:48.132 --> 00:00:51.340
>> Exactly, and
that's what you have in the Windows world.

20
00:00:51.340 --> 00:00:53.960
But in the UNIX world,
there's a little known fact.

21
00:00:53.960 --> 00:00:55.860
And we'll just continue to test you Wes.

22
00:00:55.860 --> 00:00:57.850
Did you know that NsLookup is deprecated?

23
00:00:57.850 --> 00:00:59.380
>> No, I did not, no, not at all.

24
00:00:59.380 --> 00:01:01.020
>> Yeah, it's pretty surprising,
so I mean,

25
00:01:01.020 --> 00:01:03.020
I guess Microsoft didn't get the memo or
whatever.

26
00:01:03.020 --> 00:01:05.150
So we still have NsLookup on that side.

27
00:01:05.150 --> 00:01:08.870
But when you jump into a Linux or
a macOS system,

28
00:01:08.870 --> 00:01:13.360
you usually still have NsLookup, but
you're supposed to be moving away from it.

29
00:01:13.360 --> 00:01:14.960
You're not supposed to
be using it anymore.

30
00:01:14.960 --> 00:01:18.030
And instead we have another
utility called Dig.

31
00:01:18.030 --> 00:01:23.170
And Dig does a lot of the same things
that NsLookup does, but it does

32
00:01:23.170 --> 00:01:26.790
some extra things that are actually
pretty handy for us to see and use.

33
00:01:26.790 --> 00:01:29.570
That's what we're gonna take a look
at right here, is the Dig utility.

34
00:01:29.570 --> 00:01:32.170
Let me start with one important thing,

35
00:01:32.170 --> 00:01:34.300
if you're a Windows user
don't turn off the TV, right?

36
00:01:34.300 --> 00:01:37.470
You're like well forget it, I've got
NsLookup, I'm going to turn this off.

37
00:01:37.470 --> 00:01:39.390
You can run Dig on Windows.

38
00:01:39.390 --> 00:01:42.970
Dig is actually part of the BIND
distribution, and BIND is the open source

39
00:01:42.970 --> 00:01:46.360
DNS server that is used by the majority
DNS servers on the planet.

40
00:01:46.360 --> 00:01:48.390
Microsoft's DNS is kind
of in second place.

41
00:01:48.390 --> 00:01:53.230
But with BIND, they actually
package Dig as a part of BIND.

42
00:01:53.230 --> 00:01:55.400
And they have a Windows version
of BIND that you could run,

43
00:01:55.400 --> 00:01:57.790
you don't have to run Microsoft's DNS
server if you don't want.

44
00:01:57.790 --> 00:01:59.360
So let me just show you real quick here,

45
00:01:59.360 --> 00:02:01.150
I think I've got it pulled
up in the background.

46
00:02:01.150 --> 00:02:05.510
Here we go, so BIND is distributed by
the Internet Systems Consortium, the ISC.

47
00:02:05.510 --> 00:02:07.405
And if you go to their website,

48
00:02:07.405 --> 00:02:14.160
www.isc.org/downloads/BIND You can go
in and see all the different downloads.

49
00:02:14.160 --> 00:02:18.220
Now, most of the downloads over
here are the source code downloads,

50
00:02:18.220 --> 00:02:22.380
the files that were used on Linux and
on macOS.

51
00:02:22.380 --> 00:02:24.440
But if you keep scrolling down,
you'll find a link.

52
00:02:24.440 --> 00:02:26.646
It's not the most amazingly
organized website, but

53
00:02:26.646 --> 00:02:28.910
you can find a link to the FTP server.

54
00:02:28.910 --> 00:02:31.320
And when you connect to the FTP server,

55
00:02:31.320 --> 00:02:33.280
you can browse right into
the current version of BIND.

56
00:02:33.280 --> 00:02:36.590
And you can find all of the different
files that are available there for

57
00:02:36.590 --> 00:02:38.990
Linux as well as for Windows.

58
00:02:38.990 --> 00:02:41.950
And so right here I can find
this 64-bit version of BIND,

59
00:02:41.950 --> 00:02:43.540
that's this guy right here.

60
00:02:43.540 --> 00:02:46.580
And I can find the 32-bit
version of BIND for Windows.

61
00:02:46.580 --> 00:02:49.590
And you can download those and
once you got them downloaded,

62
00:02:49.590 --> 00:02:52.680
what you're going to see
is a bunch of files.

63
00:02:52.680 --> 00:02:55.760
All these little files that I've got
pulled up here that are in that zip file.

64
00:02:55.760 --> 00:02:59.280
And it actually has the full version
of BIND, you can run the DNS server,

65
00:02:59.280 --> 00:03:00.530
but let's ignore that.

66
00:03:00.530 --> 00:03:04.020
If you can just scroll down a bit,
you'll find dig.exe.

67
00:03:04.020 --> 00:03:07.750
There's the Dig utility ready for
Windows, okay?

68
00:03:07.750 --> 00:03:11.240
It does require the Visual C runtime,
which I believe they package in here also.

69
00:03:11.240 --> 00:03:12.580
Let me see, yeah, right there.

70
00:03:12.580 --> 00:03:15.980
The Visual C Redistributable package but

71
00:03:15.980 --> 00:03:19.270
that Dig utility is what's
replacing Nslookup.

72
00:03:19.270 --> 00:03:21.370
And eventually Microsoft
will work that into the os.

73
00:03:21.370 --> 00:03:25.120
To my knowledge, they haven't done it yet,
but eventually it'll come in, right?

74
00:03:25.120 --> 00:03:28.250
So if you don't have it on Windows,
you can go out there and get it and

75
00:03:28.250 --> 00:03:29.140
load it on there.

76
00:03:29.140 --> 00:03:31.540
If you're on a Mac, like I am right now or

77
00:03:31.540 --> 00:03:35.040
if you're on a Linux box,
the odds are you've already got Dig.

78
00:03:35.040 --> 00:03:39.750
If you did a minimal distribution install,
it might be missing and you can just

79
00:03:39.750 --> 00:03:42.870
install it from your repository and
you'll have it pretty quick.

80
00:03:42.870 --> 00:03:45.140
You can test if you have Dig real quick,
easily,

81
00:03:45.140 --> 00:03:47.840
just by running Dig and there you go.

82
00:03:47.840 --> 00:03:50.370
Now Dig is different than
Nslookup in that we don't

83
00:03:50.370 --> 00:03:53.150
get a interactive command prompt with it.

84
00:03:53.150 --> 00:03:56.680
Dig takes everything on the command
line and that's just how it is and

85
00:03:56.680 --> 00:03:58.660
that does make it a little bit
easier to use in my opinion.

86
00:03:58.660 --> 00:04:01.740
>> The one thing I noticed right away,
Don, is when you hit Dig the first thing

87
00:04:01.740 --> 00:04:05.030
it did is that it went out and
it returned the root hint servers there.

88
00:04:05.030 --> 00:04:07.880
>> What it actually did here,
it didn't actually go out anywhere.

89
00:04:07.880 --> 00:04:11.040
What it did is it looked at
my current configuration.

90
00:04:11.040 --> 00:04:14.800
So just running Dig by itself, like you
said, that can be our first lesson, right?

91
00:04:14.800 --> 00:04:20.590
Just running Dig, by itself, will show you
how your client is configured for DNS.

92
00:04:20.590 --> 00:04:21.890
So when I look at it,

93
00:04:21.890 --> 00:04:25.930
I can see that mine pulled the global
options from my system, right?

94
00:04:25.930 --> 00:04:29.030
The options for
how my workstation is configured.

95
00:04:29.030 --> 00:04:30.770
And as I scroll down a little bit here,

96
00:04:30.770 --> 00:04:34.509
I can see,
what are my root hint servers set at?

97
00:04:35.590 --> 00:04:38.040
Most everybody is going to have
the same root hint servers, right?

98
00:04:38.040 --> 00:04:42.500
a through m and just kind of laid
out right there that we reference.

99
00:04:42.500 --> 00:04:45.970
Some people do override the roots,
but it's a pretty uncommon thing.

100
00:04:45.970 --> 00:04:49.000
And then after that I can see
the server that I am configured to use.

101
00:04:49.000 --> 00:04:51.140
I'm said to use 8.8.8.8 and
that's who I'm set to.

102
00:04:51.140 --> 00:04:57.700
And it's got a quarry time against that
server of 13 milliseconds and there we go.

103
00:04:57.700 --> 00:05:01.650
So if you just wanted to quickly verify
how you're configured you can just run Dig

104
00:05:01.650 --> 00:05:03.570
right there by itself, all right?

105
00:05:03.570 --> 00:05:05.710
Now we can also use Dig
just like we used NsLookup.

106
00:05:05.710 --> 00:05:08.320
If I wanna find out
the IP address of a host,

107
00:05:08.320 --> 00:05:12.320
I can just run Dig followed
by the host name, right?

108
00:05:12.320 --> 00:05:18.660
So if I wanna find itpro.tv's IP address,
I can run it and I'll get it back.

109
00:05:18.660 --> 00:05:21.710
Now you'll notice we get a lot more
information than we do with NsLookup.

110
00:05:21.710 --> 00:05:24.370
With NsLookup it told me what
server I looked up against,

111
00:05:24.370 --> 00:05:26.610
what the IP was that I got as a result.

112
00:05:26.610 --> 00:05:31.450
And it told me if it was a recursive
lookup or an authoritative lookup.

113
00:05:31.450 --> 00:05:35.150
When I look here, I can see
the question that I asked, right?

114
00:05:35.150 --> 00:05:37.860
So that's the query that I looked up.

115
00:05:37.860 --> 00:05:40.060
And the answer that I got back.

116
00:05:40.060 --> 00:05:43.850
And that's important cuz you can
override parts of the question.

117
00:05:43.850 --> 00:05:47.350
It defaults to an a record lookup,
and so it's telling me that.

118
00:05:47.350 --> 00:05:51.620
But I can override that and say I'm going
to look up a four a record or a mx record,

119
00:05:51.620 --> 00:05:53.780
and it would show that value right here.

120
00:05:53.780 --> 00:05:56.460
And this IN, that's the class.

121
00:05:56.460 --> 00:05:58.980
And everything uses
the internet class these days.

122
00:05:58.980 --> 00:06:01.690
There's a handful of other classes but
they really just don't get used.

123
00:06:01.690 --> 00:06:03.770
So you're normally gonna see IN,
just like that.

124
00:06:03.770 --> 00:06:08.170
And then when I got my response back,
it comes back with the information and

125
00:06:08.170 --> 00:06:11.510
what I ultimately wanted,
which was the IP address.

126
00:06:11.510 --> 00:06:15.170
And I just see the server I communicated
with, the message size that I sent,

127
00:06:15.170 --> 00:06:16.420
the query time.

128
00:06:16.420 --> 00:06:21.390
So a few extra things I can see that
it was not an authoritative lookup.

129
00:06:21.390 --> 00:06:26.470
My authority is zero, but that I did get
my answer, in that it was recursive.

130
00:06:26.470 --> 00:06:31.320
We sent our query, recursive desired and
recursive available.

131
00:06:31.320 --> 00:06:33.787
So those were all things
we saw with NsLookup,

132
00:06:33.787 --> 00:06:35.290
too, all kind of being laid out in Dig.

133
00:06:35.290 --> 00:06:40.476
All right, now by itself,
Dig is really just like NsLookup,

134
00:06:40.476 --> 00:06:47.180
but where it gets more powerful is that
we can add additional things into it.

135
00:06:47.180 --> 00:06:48.970
We can override what server we're using.

136
00:06:48.970 --> 00:06:51.030
I did my look up against 8.8.8.8.

137
00:06:51.030 --> 00:06:56.010
Well Dig takes a lot of command line
modifiers that we can use to change

138
00:06:56.010 --> 00:06:57.230
the way it behaves.

139
00:06:57.230 --> 00:07:00.480
If you run a man Dig,
It'll pull up here and

140
00:07:00.480 --> 00:07:02.940
show you some of the different
things you can specify.

141
00:07:02.940 --> 00:07:07.630
Like we can overwrite the server,
we can specify a class,

142
00:07:07.630 --> 00:07:11.040
a filename,
we can specify a port number to use.

143
00:07:11.040 --> 00:07:14.240
We can overwrite all sort of
interesting things as we reach out and

144
00:07:14.240 --> 00:07:17.490
we do that query, and you'll see
some things kind of overlap a bit.

145
00:07:17.490 --> 00:07:20.610
But we've got a ton of options
that are stuck in here also and

146
00:07:20.610 --> 00:07:21.870
I'm gonna show you some of those.

147
00:07:21.870 --> 00:07:23.580
>> Now Don,
when we were talking about NSLookup,

148
00:07:23.580 --> 00:07:24.990
you had mentioned the interactive mode and

149
00:07:24.990 --> 00:07:27.640
that's how we really dug
into the power of NSLookup.

150
00:07:27.640 --> 00:07:29.530
So here we don't have
the interactive mode,

151
00:07:29.530 --> 00:07:32.980
we just have to know those arguments
to add to it to really gain the power.

152
00:07:32.980 --> 00:07:34.220
>> Yeah, and if you think about it,

153
00:07:34.220 --> 00:07:35.700
when you're in the interactive
mode of NSLookup,

154
00:07:35.700 --> 00:07:37.240
you have to know the arguments anyway.

155
00:07:37.240 --> 00:07:40.900
You're still typing them in, so here it's
just consolidating all into one line, so

156
00:07:40.900 --> 00:07:41.920
it works really well.

157
00:07:41.920 --> 00:07:44.910
It's also handy if you need to
use this programmatically, right.

158
00:07:44.910 --> 00:07:45.720
As part of a script,

159
00:07:45.720 --> 00:07:48.540
you need it to determine an IP address and
output some value, you

160
00:07:48.540 --> 00:07:52.160
can do that programmatically a lot easier
with Dig than you can with NsLookup.

161
00:07:52.160 --> 00:07:55.855
It's really hard to script something
when it's got an interactive prompt.

162
00:07:55.855 --> 00:07:57.637
So let's take a look at
a few of the options.

163
00:07:57.637 --> 00:08:03.131
Maybe I wanna override
the server that I'm looking up.

164
00:08:03.131 --> 00:08:08.150
So for example, if I do a dig for
www.google.com, I can look that up and

165
00:08:08.150 --> 00:08:12.390
there's all my results and
it ran against 8.8.8.8.

166
00:08:12.390 --> 00:08:15.100
And I got all my A records that came back,

167
00:08:15.100 --> 00:08:18.310
there's the information and
it all worked, okay?

168
00:08:18.310 --> 00:08:24.920
Well, I could have added an @ and
then 8.8.4.4, right?

169
00:08:24.920 --> 00:08:29.100
I'm overriding the server that I'm
gonna perform the lookup against.

170
00:08:29.100 --> 00:08:33.914
And now when I did the lookup,
I can see that server was 8.8.4.4.

171
00:08:33.914 --> 00:08:37.280
Now why did I have to stick
an @ at the beginning?

172
00:08:37.280 --> 00:08:42.112
So that it knew that that was a server and
not just another host to lookup, right?

173
00:08:42.112 --> 00:08:46.886
Cuz if I did a lookup against 8.8.8.8,
it might think that's a PTR record, right?

174
00:08:46.886 --> 00:08:49.180
An IP to resolve back to an name.

175
00:08:49.180 --> 00:08:51.413
The @ symbol is what lets it
know that it's a server, right?

176
00:08:51.413 --> 00:08:53.870
So we can quickly override that server.

177
00:08:53.870 --> 00:08:55.800
You can also override the type.

178
00:08:55.800 --> 00:08:57.192
I did an A record.

00:20:45.510 --> 00:20:50.330
If I do retry equals 2,
that 2 doesn't count the first try.

404
00:20:50.330 --> 00:20:54.580
The first try is the first attempt,
and if it fails, then we have a retry.

405
00:20:54.580 --> 00:20:58.740
Just the name retry, indicates there
was already one try before hand.

406
00:20:58.740 --> 00:21:00.620
So this would try one time.

407
00:21:00.620 --> 00:21:03.240
And if I get a response from the service
that says the record doesn't exist,

408
00:21:03.240 --> 00:21:04.290
that's kinda the end of it, right?

409
00:21:04.290 --> 00:21:06.190
That kills off the try, but

410
00:21:06.190 --> 00:21:10.220
if I can't contact the server
then I shift into the retries.

411
00:21:10.220 --> 00:21:13.470
And I start to move forward on that,
and I'll see if I can't find it.

412
00:21:13.470 --> 00:21:16.120
So if I do a lookup for database.itpro.tv,

413
00:21:16.120 --> 00:21:20.780
when I go to look that up,
see how it didn't do any retries?

414
00:21:20.780 --> 00:21:24.320
That's because the server I was able
to contact it, it informed me, and

415
00:21:24.320 --> 00:21:25.290
it let me know.

416
00:21:25.290 --> 00:21:28.110
But if I were to put in a fake server,
right?

417
00:21:28.110 --> 00:21:33.177
So at the very beginning of this if I
were to throw in a @10.10.10.10 right?

418
00:21:33.177 --> 00:21:35.580
Something on our local network.

419
00:21:35.580 --> 00:21:37.000
That server doesn't exist.

420
00:21:37.000 --> 00:21:39.510
It's going to try to contact it.

421
00:21:39.510 --> 00:21:42.810
And the server doesn't exist and
so, that's gonna fail.

422
00:21:42.810 --> 00:21:46.960
And then it's gonna retry two more
times to contact the server, all right,

423
00:21:46.960 --> 00:21:49.280
before moving on to the next
server in the list.

424
00:21:49.280 --> 00:21:52.170
Did I say three times or two?

425
00:21:52.170 --> 00:21:54.680
It's gonna retry two
times before moving on.

426
00:21:54.680 --> 00:21:57.160
So in this case, it couldn't reach,
connection timed out and

427
00:21:57.160 --> 00:21:58.090
that's the end of it.

428
00:21:58.090 --> 00:22:02.270
And I had to wait a little while there so
I could add a little more to this.

429
00:22:02.270 --> 00:22:09.180
And if I add for example +time=1, we
learned a minute ago that was in seconds.

430
00:22:09.180 --> 00:22:11.090
Now it's gonna do one second and

431
00:22:11.090 --> 00:22:14.656
if it doesn't get a response back from
that server in one second, there it fails.

432
00:22:14.656 --> 00:22:15.940
See, it timed out a lot faster.

433
00:22:15.940 --> 00:22:19.527
So when you're trouble shooting with DiG
that can shorten the window of time you're

434
00:22:19.527 --> 00:22:20.800
havint to sit there and wait.

435
00:22:20.800 --> 00:22:24.160
>> Does the time affect each one of those
whether it's how many times we try, and

436
00:22:24.160 --> 00:22:25.060
how many retries?

437
00:22:25.060 --> 00:22:27.010
Does it apply that to every option there?

438
00:22:27.010 --> 00:22:28.200
>> Yeah, it applies to both.

439
00:22:28.200 --> 00:22:30.980
Each of the tries and each of the retries.

440
00:22:30.980 --> 00:22:34.890
So if you think about it,
if you have three DNS servers to find, and

441
00:22:34.890 --> 00:22:37.970
you've got a five second time out,
and it fails on all of them.

442
00:22:37.970 --> 00:22:39.880
And it's doing three retries.

443
00:22:39.880 --> 00:22:41.880
Three servers, three retries each.

444
00:22:41.880 --> 00:22:44.060
That's nine look ups at five seconds each.

445
00:22:44.060 --> 00:22:45.940
Should have picked
something with easier math.

446
00:22:45.940 --> 00:22:47.140
Then it's 45 seconds.

447
00:22:47.140 --> 00:22:50.050
That's a long time to sit there and
wait for that record to fail.

448
00:22:50.050 --> 00:22:52.810
And that's not something
an end user would wanna see.

449
00:22:52.810 --> 00:22:55.760
So operating systems normally
have that number tuned down.

450
00:22:55.760 --> 00:22:58.900
But when you're trouble shooting with dig
you may wanna tune that number down too to

451
00:22:58.900 --> 00:23:00.150
just get a faster check.

452
00:23:00.150 --> 00:23:02.790
If you don't get a response back
from that server in under a second,

453
00:23:02.790 --> 00:23:05.550
either the server's not available or
the server is performing so

454
00:23:05.550 --> 00:23:09.240
badly it doesn't matter if it's available
you wouldn't wanna use it, right.

455
00:23:09.240 --> 00:23:12.580
DNS look ups over a second
are just not really reasonable.

456
00:23:12.580 --> 00:23:15.740
So you can shorten that down really easy.

457
00:23:15.740 --> 00:23:17.370
>> Very good.
That's a lot of great information.

458
00:23:17.370 --> 00:23:20.040
I know this Windows user has
learned a lot today, and

459
00:23:20.040 --> 00:23:21.250
I'm glad I didn't change the channel.

460
00:23:21.250 --> 00:23:23.260
But it does look like we're
gonna wrap this one up, Don.

461
00:23:23.260 --> 00:23:25.460
Any final words that you'd like to
give somebody about the Dig and

462
00:23:25.460 --> 00:23:26.830
the power of Dig?

463
00:23:26.830 --> 00:23:29.060
>> Yeah,
just remember that NSLookup is deprecated.

464
00:23:29.060 --> 00:23:30.340
So it's supposed to be going away.

465
00:23:30.340 --> 00:23:33.370
It is still present in almost every
operating system that I've seen.

466
00:23:33.370 --> 00:23:36.470
So you can keep using
NSLookup if you want.

467
00:23:36.470 --> 00:23:38.530
Dig can do everything that nslookup can.

468
00:23:38.530 --> 00:23:41.530
So that there's really no
reason to stick with nslookup.

469
00:23:41.530 --> 00:23:43.820
And if you're on Windows,
remember that you can download dig.

470
00:23:43.820 --> 00:23:45.860
It's part of the BIND distribution.

471
00:23:45.860 --> 00:23:49.070
So it's not just available by itself, but
you can go out, find it, download it.

472
00:23:49.070 --> 00:23:49.700
Install it.

473
00:23:49.700 --> 00:23:52.860
Runs great, does its job, and
that will get you taken care.

474
00:23:52.860 --> 00:23:54.300
>> Don, that's a lot of great information.

475
00:23:54.300 --> 00:23:54.900
We appreciate it.

476
00:23:54.900 --> 00:23:57.200
We appreciate you, the viewer, but
we're going to wrap this one up.

477
00:23:57.200 --> 00:24:00.290
Signing out for ITPro TV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

478
00:24:00.290 --> 00:24:01.010
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

479
00:24:01.010 --> 00:24:03.446
>> And we'll see you next time.

480
00:24:03.446 --> 00:24:09.344
[MUSIC]

481
00:24:09.344 --> 00:24:12.588
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don take a look a a couple of powerful DNS utilities to help keep your DNS infrastructure running efficiently. They explain how to do DNS zone debugging with dnswalk. They will also look at using dnsrecon to analyze and enumerate a DNS zone.
episodes.title: dnswalk and dnsrecon
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:01.190 --> 00:00:03.280
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:03.280 --> 00:00:05.323
>> Live from San Francisco

3
00:00:05.323 --> 00:00:08.239
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.239 --> 00:00:11.918
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.918 --> 00:00:15.270
Welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.270 --> 00:00:16.604
I'm your host Wes Bryan and

7
00:00:16.604 --> 00:00:19.911
in today's episode, we are continuing
through our series on DNS.

8
00:00:19.911 --> 00:00:21.409
That's right, DNS tech skills.

9
00:00:21.409 --> 00:00:23.428
And joining me back in
the studios today for

10
00:00:23.428 --> 00:00:25.970
this very endeavor is none other than Mr.
Don Pezet.

11
00:00:25.970 --> 00:00:26.930
Don, how you doing, sir?

12
00:00:26.930 --> 00:00:29.388
>> I'm doing great, Wes.
Ready to dive right back into DNS, and

13
00:00:29.388 --> 00:00:33.080
we're gonna continue on with our
little adventure in DNS utilities.

14
00:00:33.080 --> 00:00:34.880
We've seen some of the more
common ones that are out there.

15
00:00:34.880 --> 00:00:38.050
I wanna cover some of the less common
ones that are out there, and so

16
00:00:38.050 --> 00:00:41.880
in this episode we're gonna take
a look at DNSWalk and DNSRecon.

17
00:00:41.880 --> 00:00:48.110
Two tools that have been around awhile but
are a little less known because, mostly

18
00:00:48.110 --> 00:00:50.460
cuz they're not included in the majority
of distributions that are out there.

19
00:00:50.460 --> 00:00:55.160
So if you have Windows, Mac OS,
pretty much any Linux distro, they're not

20
00:00:55.160 --> 00:00:58.670
normally gonna have DNSRecon and
DNSWalk, you got to go out and get them.

21
00:00:58.670 --> 00:01:01.140
But there is one place where
they come prepackaged,

22
00:01:01.140 --> 00:01:04.130
a great collection of
utilities called Kali Linux.

23
00:01:04.130 --> 00:01:06.630
Kali Linux, or Kali Linux, whatever.

24
00:01:06.630 --> 00:01:11.550
Kali Linux is a,
it's really a penetration testing suite.

25
00:01:11.550 --> 00:01:13.740
So if you're a security engineer,
you've used it.

26
00:01:13.740 --> 00:01:16.780
It's got tons of software in there that
lets you examine servers and look for

27
00:01:16.780 --> 00:01:19.760
vulnerabilities and
all sorts of other stuff.

28
00:01:19.760 --> 00:01:23.090
Well, as part of that,
we've got information gathering.

29
00:01:23.090 --> 00:01:26.655
And when we do information gathering,
we can use that to troubleshoot and

30
00:01:26.655 --> 00:01:27.467
locate issues.

31
00:01:27.467 --> 00:01:29.488
The same goes for DNS.

32
00:01:29.488 --> 00:01:30.997
The inside of Kali Linux,

33
00:01:30.997 --> 00:01:34.300
we've got a number of tools
that are focused just on DNS.

34
00:01:34.300 --> 00:01:36.860
And DNSWalk and DNSRecon are two of those.

35
00:01:36.860 --> 00:01:39.890
Now, we don't have to use them as
a hacker to just break into a network.

36
00:01:39.890 --> 00:01:42.940
We can use them ourselves just to gather
information about our systems and

37
00:01:42.940 --> 00:01:45.400
even check for errors and so
that's what I'm gonna do.

38
00:01:45.400 --> 00:01:49.510
Now, before we really get going on these
tools though, one good thing to do

39
00:01:49.510 --> 00:01:52.520
is to set it up so that we'll be
able to query our entire zone.

40
00:01:52.520 --> 00:01:57.190
Now when you query a zone,
normally we reach out to a DNS server, and

41
00:01:57.190 --> 00:01:57.800
what do we do?

42
00:01:57.800 --> 00:02:01.090
We give it a name, and
it returns an IP, it's very simple.

43
00:02:01.090 --> 00:02:03.774
But if you reach out to a DNS server and
you say, hey,

44
00:02:03.774 --> 00:02:05.858
can you give me all the records you have?

45
00:02:05.858 --> 00:02:07.657
What's the DNS server gonna say?

46
00:02:07.657 --> 00:02:10.470
It's gonna say, no,
I'm not gonna do that, right?

47
00:02:10.470 --> 00:02:13.038
And that's because some attackers will
try and do that to get all your records,

48
00:02:13.038 --> 00:02:14.392
try and identify servers on the network.

49
00:02:14.392 --> 00:02:18.360
It's not true security,
it's just security through obscurity.

50
00:02:18.360 --> 00:02:20.380
But if we're gonna be troubleshooting and

51
00:02:20.380 --> 00:02:22.338
diagnosing our network,
we need to be able to pull that.

52
00:02:22.338 --> 00:02:25.210
So by pulling all the records from a zone,

53
00:02:25.210 --> 00:02:28.060
that's called a zone transfer and
we need to enable that.

54
00:02:28.060 --> 00:02:30.048
You don't always have
that enabled by default.

55
00:02:30.048 --> 00:02:32.600
In fact, the majority of time you
don't cuz you don't want that

56
00:02:32.600 --> 00:02:33.840
enabled by default.

57
00:02:33.840 --> 00:02:36.548
So what I need to do is, I need to get
my system set up to be able to do that.

58
00:02:36.548 --> 00:02:38.147
If I try and
use some of these tools without it,

59
00:02:38.147 --> 00:02:40.220
I'm gonna have a little bit of a problem,
right?

60
00:02:40.220 --> 00:02:42.290
So the first thing I need to do is,
here on my workstation,

61
00:02:42.290 --> 00:02:46.410
so I'm booted into Kali Linux, and
I'm gonna fire up a web browser.

62
00:02:46.410 --> 00:02:48.800
And I just need to find out
what my IP address is, so

63
00:02:48.800 --> 00:02:53.570
I'm gonna go to showmemy.info, and
it'll tell me what my IP address is.

64
00:02:53.570 --> 00:02:59.310
And I need to get that address added
to my zone transfer list, right?

65
00:02:59.310 --> 00:03:01.667
And my machine's running a little
slow there, but there we go.

66
00:03:01.667 --> 00:03:08.198
So, my public IP is 209.251.131.98 and
if I jump over to my DNS server and

67
00:03:08.198 --> 00:03:14.670
I take a zone like lab.ITProv.TV,
it's gonna pull up its properties here.

68
00:03:14.670 --> 00:03:18.190
And I jump into zone transfers.

69
00:03:18.190 --> 00:03:20.130
Look at these default settings.

70
00:03:20.130 --> 00:03:23.390
I'll do zone transfers but only to
servers listed on the name servers tab.

71
00:03:23.390 --> 00:03:24.162
In other words,

72
00:03:24.162 --> 00:03:27.266
I'll only allow zone transfers to
other DNS servers in this zone.

73
00:03:27.266 --> 00:03:30.650
And that's what we want,
that's what makes sense, right?

74
00:03:30.650 --> 00:03:34.354
But I need to add my workstation so
that I can reach out and query it too.

75
00:03:34.354 --> 00:03:38.130
So I'm gonna come in and say,
only to the following servers.

76
00:03:38.130 --> 00:03:42.280
And I would need to add in my DNS servers,
but I can also go in and

77
00:03:42.280 --> 00:03:43.286
add my workstation.

78
00:03:43.286 --> 00:03:49.700
So, 209.251.131.98, I believe is what
it was, let me just verify that.

79
00:03:50.730 --> 00:03:51.280
And it was, okay.

80
00:03:52.400 --> 00:03:53.229
So I've got that added in.

81
00:03:53.229 --> 00:03:55.938
It's gonna try and resolve it, but
I don't have a reverse lookup zone, so

82
00:03:55.938 --> 00:03:57.530
I'm just gonna hit OK on that.

83
00:03:57.530 --> 00:03:58.190
And there we go.
So

84
00:03:58.190 --> 00:04:00.720
now, I'm gonna be allowed to do
a zone transfer on this machine.

85
00:04:00.720 --> 00:04:05.010
And that's going to enable DNSRecon and
DNSWalk to work.

86
00:04:05.010 --> 00:04:07.700
If you've got BIND or Unbound or
a different DNS server,

87
00:04:07.700 --> 00:04:10.852
you'll need to do it's steps to enable
a zone transfer for this to work.

88
00:04:10.852 --> 00:04:15.897
Al right, but now I can jump back over to
Kali and I can start to use my utilities.

89
00:04:15.897 --> 00:04:19.402
Now, Kali Linux already has them
baked in so it's easy to go and

90
00:04:19.402 --> 00:04:23.120
get an iso image of it, fire it up,
and run these utilities.

91
00:04:23.120 --> 00:04:26.031
But you can get DNSWalk and
DNSRecon for your system.

92
00:04:26.031 --> 00:04:30.535
So, for example, if you have Ubuntu or
Debian, you can do an apt-get dnswalk and

93
00:04:30.535 --> 00:04:32.116
it will go in and install it.

94
00:04:32.116 --> 00:04:35.518
I'm just using this cuz it's
already got it built in.

95
00:04:35.518 --> 00:04:37.820
All right, you can check and
see if you've got it.

96
00:04:37.820 --> 00:04:39.700
We'll start with DNSWalk.

97
00:04:39.700 --> 00:04:44.010
What DNSWalk does, it's a DNS debugger.

98
00:04:44.010 --> 00:04:45.190
So it'll look at your zone.

99
00:04:45.190 --> 00:04:47.400
It'll download your zone file and
it'll parse through it and

100
00:04:47.400 --> 00:04:48.510
it'll look for errors.

101
00:04:48.510 --> 00:04:51.290
So it's a great way to spot
problems in your file.

102
00:04:51.290 --> 00:04:54.180
And if you've got problems in your zone,
it'll help you identify and

103
00:04:54.180 --> 00:04:56.480
tell you what they are so
you can go in and and you can fix them.

104
00:04:56.480 --> 00:04:58.180
It does some really neat stuff.

105
00:04:58.180 --> 00:05:01.508
If you're running dnswalk -h,
it'll give you the help output.

106
00:05:01.508 --> 00:05:04.680
Well, normally it'll give you the help
output, though in my case it won't.

107
00:05:04.680 --> 00:05:08.650
So, there we go,
I'll just do a little man dnswalk.

108
00:05:08.650 --> 00:05:11.120
We can pull up the help output here and

109
00:05:11.120 --> 00:05:13.130
see the different options
that we can provide.

110
00:05:13.130 --> 00:05:14.810
The default options are probably enough.

111
00:05:14.810 --> 00:05:19.570
We usually just do dnswalk And
then provide a domain name to run against.

112
00:05:19.570 --> 00:05:20.490
But you can go in and

113
00:05:20.490 --> 00:05:24.770
tell it to do other things like
recursively descend subdomains.

114
00:05:24.770 --> 00:05:26.910
That's really useful if
you have SRV records.

115
00:05:26.910 --> 00:05:30.260
SRV records will always be tucked into
subfolders and this will scan through and

116
00:05:30.260 --> 00:05:31.790
check your SRV records also.

117
00:05:31.790 --> 00:05:37.260
You can tell it to do other things like
Perform fascist checking, which means,

118
00:05:37.260 --> 00:05:41.640
make sure that every forward
entry has a reverse entry also.

119
00:05:41.640 --> 00:05:43.900
Every name to an IP also
has an IP to a name.

120
00:05:43.900 --> 00:05:45.600
It'll look for reverse look-up entries.

121
00:05:45.600 --> 00:05:48.520
We don't always have that on the internet,
so that's turned off by default.

122
00:05:48.520 --> 00:05:51.780
You can tell it to suppress checking for
invalid characters.

123
00:05:51.780 --> 00:05:55.883
This is kind of important because they've
loosened the rules on DNS recently, so

124
00:05:55.883 --> 00:05:58.261
that you can have foreign or
UTFA characters and

125
00:05:58.261 --> 00:06:00.772
international characters
in your domain names.

126
00:06:00.772 --> 00:06:03.802
And so, if you are using those,
that can cause problems.

127
00:06:03.802 --> 00:06:05.885
If you're in an English
speaking country or

128
00:06:05.885 --> 00:06:10.060
you're just using the regular character
set then we can leave that turned on.

129
00:06:10.060 --> 00:06:13.730
You can also look for
lame delegations, lame delegations.

130
00:06:13.730 --> 00:06:17.776
That's where I have a delegation entered
where I'm pointing to another server and

131
00:06:17.776 --> 00:06:20.334
that server doesn't exist or
it doesn't respond.

132
00:06:20.334 --> 00:06:25.020
It'll actually check to make sure that any
kind of delegation actually does work.

133
00:06:25.020 --> 00:06:28.620
So it's gonna scan to my zone and
look for errors.

134
00:06:28.620 --> 00:06:30.351
And in order for it to work,
it's gotta be able to pull the zone.

135
00:06:30.351 --> 00:06:32.241
So that's why I had to do
the zone transfer entry at

136
00:06:32.241 --> 00:06:33.279
the beginning of the show.

137
00:06:33.279 --> 00:06:37.455
Then, once I've got that set up,
I can do a DNSWalk, and

138
00:06:37.455 --> 00:06:40.680
I can specify who it is
I wanna walk against.

139
00:06:40.680 --> 00:06:42.454
Actually, there's one more
thing I need to pull from here.

140
00:06:42.454 --> 00:06:47.040
When you see all the stuff here that we're
specifying, the zone transfer and so

141
00:06:47.040 --> 00:06:50.338
on, I need to override
the server that I'm pointing to.

142
00:06:50.338 --> 00:06:53.277
And so I'll need to specify that in
the command line in order to do it.

143
00:06:53.277 --> 00:06:57.290
And they've got a command line option
buried in here, after I get past it.

144
00:06:57.290 --> 00:06:59.960
Actually, all this stuff I am scrolling
past, let me talk about this real quick.

145
00:07:01.010 --> 00:07:06.569
Way up here, it's got all the different
errors that can come back.

146
00:07:06.569 --> 00:07:11.203
And so it is just highlighting
unknown hosts, a record not found,

147
00:07:11.203 --> 00:07:16.360
CNAME to Z, it's looking for all these
entries that it can respond back.

148
00:07:16.360 --> 00:07:19.410
And just kind of giving you, kind of an
idea of what it does, how it checks, and

149
00:07:19.410 --> 00:07:20.480
what it looks for.

150
00:07:20.480 --> 00:07:24.280
So great way to kind of punch through and
specify and find that information.

151
00:07:25.650 --> 00:07:30.250
Now, in my case, I need to be doing this
look up against my own DNS server which is

152
00:07:30.250 --> 00:07:31.310
out there in the Cloud.

153
00:07:31.310 --> 00:07:33.790
So I need to make sure that
my system is using it.

154
00:07:33.790 --> 00:07:36.890
So I'm gonna go into my
network settings here.

155
00:07:37.940 --> 00:07:40.650
And I'm gonna override my DNS server.

156
00:07:40.650 --> 00:07:43.760
Right now, I'm set to use Google's DNS
servers and that's not what I want.

157
00:07:43.760 --> 00:07:46.290
So I need to get in here and
kinda fix that.

158
00:07:46.290 --> 00:07:47.470
I'm set to Automatic.

159
00:07:47.470 --> 00:07:50.770
So I'm gonna turn Automatic off and
specify my server.

160
00:07:50.770 --> 00:07:53.944
So my server IP is something weird,
which I've got written down here.

161
00:07:53.944 --> 00:07:57.159
It's 38., something creative.

162
00:07:57.159 --> 00:08:03.268
So it is, I was close, 34,
I'm glad I didn't guess it,

163
00:08:03.268 --> 00:08:08.490
.193.248.100, that's my DNS server.

164
00:08:08.490 --> 00:08:12.479
So I'm gonna set that up so that that's
what I'm doing my lookups against.

165
00:08:12.479 --> 00:08:14.915
And we'll give that a second.

166
00:08:14.915 --> 00:08:19.652
That should have kicked in already but
didn't.

167
00:08:19.652 --> 00:08:20.848
We'll give that just a moment.

168
00:08:20.848 --> 00:08:23.680
Let me, I'm gonna turn my wired
connection off and turn it back on again.

169
00:08:23.680 --> 00:08:26.955
Give that just a moment
while it resets itself.

170
00:08:26.955 --> 00:08:32.900
And I wanna make sure that I'm doing
lookups against the right server.

171
00:08:32.900 --> 00:08:34.040
There's a good way to make a mistake.

172
00:08:34.040 --> 00:08:37.120
If this were just a publicly hosted zone,
I could just run right off against it.

173
00:08:37.120 --> 00:08:38.440
But I've got mine private right now, so

174
00:08:38.440 --> 00:08:40.702
I gotta make sure I'm
looking at the right server.

175
00:08:40.702 --> 00:08:45.260
And DNSWalk is just gonna use whatever
I am set to look for by default so

176
00:08:45.260 --> 00:08:47.430
that's why I'm trying to
get that set real quick.

177
00:08:47.430 --> 00:08:51.055
And then once I've got it, then I'll
be able to go in and override it.

178
00:08:51.055 --> 00:08:53.086
And so, there we go.
Now I can see that my DNS server is set

179
00:08:53.086 --> 00:08:53.695
correctly.

180
00:08:53.695 --> 00:08:56.113
All right, so let's jump in here and
fire this thing back up.

181
00:08:56.113 --> 00:08:58.234
I'm gonna do dnswalk lab.itpro.tv and

182
00:08:58.234 --> 00:09:02.450
I'm gonna throw that little dot right
there on the end as we know we need.

183
00:09:02.450 --> 00:09:04.183
And when I run that, it's gonna reach out.

184
00:09:04.183 --> 00:09:09.072
And right off the bat, I get checking
lab.itpro.tv, that's kinda what I wanted.

185
00:09:09.072 --> 00:09:12.150
And then I get BAD,
there's a problem, right?

186
00:09:12.150 --> 00:09:16.213
Lab.itpro.tv has only one
authoritative name server.

187
00:09:16.213 --> 00:09:18.407
Well, all right, so I got an issue here.

188
00:09:18.407 --> 00:09:20.347
I only have one authoritative name server.

189
00:09:20.347 --> 00:09:24.178
If I were to go and look at my
DNS records over here, I can see,

190
00:09:24.178 --> 00:09:28.100
sure enough, under name server,
I've only got one.

191
00:09:28.100 --> 00:09:30.571
For redundancy,
I should have at least two.

192
00:09:30.571 --> 00:09:31.600
That's a problem, right?

193
00:09:31.600 --> 00:09:33.370
So DNSWalk spotted that.

194
00:09:33.370 --> 00:09:35.670
It's also going on to
do the zone transfer.

195
00:09:35.670 --> 00:09:38.770
So it found that even before
doing the zone transfer, right?

196
00:09:38.770 --> 00:09:41.600
So then it does the zone transfer and
now it's finding other issues.

197
00:09:41.600 --> 00:09:44.510
Here's my SOA data, and
then I got three warnings.

198
00:09:44.510 --> 00:09:45.770
That's not too bad, right?

199
00:09:45.770 --> 00:09:47.904
It's not gonna list all
the good stuff that happens.

200
00:09:47.904 --> 00:09:49.407
So, I might have done great things but
here,

201
00:09:49.407 --> 00:09:51.160
I just see everything I've done wrong.

202
00:09:51.160 --> 00:09:54.919
The first thing
files.lab,itpro.tv is a CNAME and

203
00:09:54.919 --> 00:10:00.776
it's pointing to fileserver01.lab.itpro.tv
and that's an unknown host.

204
00:10:00.776 --> 00:10:05.687
I've got a CNAME pointing to
somebody that doesn't exist, right?

205
00:10:05.687 --> 00:10:09.120
So that CNAME either needs to go away or
I need create whoever is missing.

206
00:10:09.120 --> 00:10:15.755
My next two warnings are www.lab.itpro.tv
with an IP and no PTR record.

207
00:10:15.755 --> 00:10:17.880
Now, that may or may not be a problem.

208
00:10:17.880 --> 00:10:21.130
That's why this is a warning
instead of a bad because,

209
00:10:21.130 --> 00:10:24.710
just because I don't have a reverse
lookup record doesn't mean it's an issue.

210
00:10:24.710 --> 00:10:26.910
Email servers, it's usually a big deal,
everything else,

211
00:10:26.910 --> 00:10:27.990
we usually don't worry about it.

212
00:10:27.990 --> 00:10:30.590
But these two guys are missing
their PTR records.

213
00:10:30.590 --> 00:10:32.620
So I got three warnings, one error.

214
00:10:32.620 --> 00:10:35.900
DNSWalk scanned through my zone and
that's all it found.

215
00:10:35.900 --> 00:10:38.640
Now if you have a massive zone
file with thousands of entries,

216
00:10:38.640 --> 00:10:41.370
this is a heck of a lot easier than going
through line by line and looking for

217
00:10:41.370 --> 00:10:42.590
these types of mistakes.

218
00:10:42.590 --> 00:10:44.780
That's what DNSWalk is all about.

219
00:10:44.780 --> 00:10:48.080
And we can tweak it's settings with
the extensions we saw a moment ago,

220
00:10:48.080 --> 00:10:51.300
the command line arguments, to get
it to look for additional things and

221
00:10:51.300 --> 00:10:53.665
make it more strict or
less strict to meet our needs.

222
00:10:53.665 --> 00:10:55.183
DNSWalk's a pretty cool utility.

223
00:10:55.183 --> 00:10:57.873
It does make it a lot easier to scan for
these errors.

224
00:10:57.873 --> 00:11:04.205
All right now, along the same lines,
is the DNSRecon utility.

225
00:11:04.205 --> 00:11:08.415
DNSRecon will scan through your DNS and
try and

226
00:11:08.415 --> 00:11:10.805
find as much information as it can.

227
00:11:10.805 --> 00:11:14.730
If you have the ability to do a zone
transfer, it'll get a lot of data.

228
00:11:14.730 --> 00:11:16.270
If you don't, it'll get less.

229
00:11:16.270 --> 00:11:20.296
But, it's a Recon tool, so it's still
gonna try and get as much as it can out of

230
00:11:20.296 --> 00:11:24.217
your domain even if you don't provide
it with the additional information.

231
00:11:24.217 --> 00:11:27.656
Now DNSRecon has several different
modes that it runs in and

232
00:11:27.656 --> 00:11:31.580
they're listed somewhere
here in the documentation.

233
00:11:31.580 --> 00:11:34.610
My word wrap is really
making this look terrible.

234
00:11:34.610 --> 00:11:37.570
Let me stretch this out so
you can see the different modes.

235
00:11:37.570 --> 00:11:39.891
So, these are the modes right here, that.

236
00:11:39.891 --> 00:11:44.440
[LAUGH] The standard mode is
what we're running by default.

237
00:11:44.440 --> 00:11:48.976
And it's gonna look for Start Of
Authority, Name Server, A, AAAA, MX, SRV,

238
00:11:48.976 --> 00:11:51.600
and AXRF, which are our four transfers.

239
00:11:51.600 --> 00:11:54.580
It's gonna look for
all that stuff to report back to me, and

240
00:11:54.580 --> 00:11:56.790
get me all the information it can.

241
00:11:56.790 --> 00:11:59.534
But we can change it to do
reverse lookups, if we want.

242
00:11:59.534 --> 00:12:02.874
If we wanted to brute force,
you could provide a dictionary of terms so

243
00:12:02.874 --> 00:12:04.585
it can look to see if servers exist.

244
00:12:04.585 --> 00:12:08.057
You can look just for SRV records,
if that's all I wanna find.

245
00:12:08.057 --> 00:12:10.936
AXFR, if we've got
a separate zone transfer.

246
00:12:10.936 --> 00:12:13.962
It's a great way to spot if you got DNS
servers on your network where you left

247
00:12:13.962 --> 00:12:16.430
zone transfers turned on and
you meant to have it turned off.

248
00:12:17.520 --> 00:12:19.030
GOO, that's Google.

249
00:12:19.030 --> 00:12:21.500
It'll actually do a Google search,
it'll pop up a window and

250
00:12:21.500 --> 00:12:23.700
do a Google search on
every name that it finds.

251
00:12:23.700 --> 00:12:26.490
You don't want to do that on a big zone,
that's bad news.

252
00:12:26.490 --> 00:12:28.720
You can do cache snooping
where you try and

253
00:12:28.720 --> 00:12:32.940
find out what's in the cache
on the server and TLDs can

254
00:12:32.940 --> 00:12:36.550
let us exclude certain top level domains
if we don't want to query all that.

255
00:12:36.550 --> 00:12:39.160
So these are all different
little tweaks that we can do.

256
00:12:39.160 --> 00:12:40.418
I left off one, zonewalk.

257
00:12:40.418 --> 00:12:44.419
If you're troubleshooting DNSSEC,
the secure DNS zonewalk will actually go

258
00:12:44.419 --> 00:12:48.177
through and follow the DNSSEC entries
to make sure they're all intact and

259
00:12:48.177 --> 00:12:51.290
show you what servers
are involved in that.

260
00:12:51.290 --> 00:12:54.960
So, those are all functions
inside of DNSRecon.

261
00:12:54.960 --> 00:12:57.070
And if you wanna use it,
the easiest way is just say,

262
00:12:57.070 --> 00:13:01.460
dnsrecon -d and
the domain that you want to scan.

263
00:13:01.460 --> 00:13:06.516
So, I'm gonna do lab.itpro.tv.

264
00:13:06.516 --> 00:13:08.245
And I'm gonna run a scan on it.

265
00:13:08.245 --> 00:13:11.313
Now, if I wanted, I could go through and
change the mode that it's running in but

266
00:13:11.313 --> 00:13:12.770
I'll just run it in the default mode.

267
00:13:12.770 --> 00:13:15.280
And when it runs, it's gonna reach out.

268
00:13:15.280 --> 00:13:18.140
I don't have DNSSEC on my domain,
haven't configured it yet.

269
00:13:18.140 --> 00:13:20.820
But it found my SOA and my name server.

270
00:13:20.820 --> 00:13:23.150
It could not resolve any MX Records.

271
00:13:23.150 --> 00:13:23.820
I don't have any.

272
00:13:23.820 --> 00:13:25.584
Well, I don't think I have any, let's see.

273
00:13:25.584 --> 00:13:27.910
Nope, no MX Records.

274
00:13:27.910 --> 00:13:29.750
So that's probably why we got that one.

275
00:13:29.750 --> 00:13:30.830
But I wasn't able to find that.

276
00:13:30.830 --> 00:13:34.770
And then enumerating SRV Records,
they didn't find all my SRV records but

277
00:13:34.770 --> 00:13:35.900
it did find some.

278
00:13:35.900 --> 00:13:38.470
It found the sip values that I created.

279
00:13:38.470 --> 00:13:40.370
And so it's turning those up and
showing them here.

280
00:13:40.370 --> 00:13:44.840
It's parsing through and
showing me everything that it could find.

281
00:13:44.840 --> 00:13:48.210
Now it didn't necessarily do every check
in the book to find things out, but

282
00:13:48.210 --> 00:13:51.920
it did the standard ones and I can go
through and manipulate it if I needed to.

283
00:13:51.920 --> 00:13:55.140
Another great way to scan across your
servers and just kinda see what's what,

284
00:13:55.140 --> 00:14:00.290
see if your exposing information or not.

285
00:14:00.290 --> 00:14:03.450
If I were to take an actual public domain,
so

286
00:14:03.450 --> 00:14:06.640
maybe itpro.tv itself,
which we host with Amazon.

287
00:14:06.640 --> 00:14:11.213
If I were to point against that one and
run it, well it's not going to allow zone

288
00:14:11.213 --> 00:14:14.632
transfers so it's going to
have a much more limited view.

289
00:14:14.632 --> 00:14:19.307
But, it's gonna reach and it's gonna find
those name servers, which are Amazon's,

290
00:14:19.307 --> 00:14:22.860
and it's gonna come out and
show me any bit of data that it can find.

291
00:14:22.860 --> 00:14:25.425
So it's finding IPv6 servers and IPv4.

292
00:14:25.425 --> 00:14:29.300
It found our MX Records and
so it's gonna lay those out.

293
00:14:29.300 --> 00:14:32.870
It found a TXT record for SPF,
that's our sender policy framework.

294
00:14:32.870 --> 00:14:36.580
And now it's trying to enumerate our
SRV records, it didn't find any.

295
00:14:36.580 --> 00:14:40.360
Now, I know for
a fact we have two for our Skype for

296
00:14:40.360 --> 00:14:43.880
Business server but it wasn't able
to find those and it returns it.

297
00:14:43.880 --> 00:14:47.450
This is all publicly available
information that it was able to scrape

298
00:14:47.450 --> 00:14:49.660
without doing a zone transfer, right?

299
00:14:49.660 --> 00:14:52.500
If zone transfers were enabled,
it would be able to get even more.

300
00:14:52.500 --> 00:14:56.280
But it was able to find things
including the A record for itpro.tv and

301
00:14:56.280 --> 00:15:00.040
a couple of other well knowns that it
will look for in the background too.

302
00:15:00.040 --> 00:15:03.589
DNSWalk, same thing,
I could have pointed DNSWalk at itpro.tv.

303
00:15:03.589 --> 00:15:09.485
And if we do that, see how the zone
transfers are all disabled?

304
00:15:09.485 --> 00:15:10.670
It wasn't able to do a zone transfer.

305
00:15:10.670 --> 00:15:13.341
And so
it tried to get other information, but

306
00:15:13.341 --> 00:15:16.574
everything else it was able
to see checked out okay so,

307
00:15:16.574 --> 00:15:21.035
there weren't anything to report other
than the errors of querying at it.

308
00:15:21.035 --> 00:15:23.430
So, that's all we got back on this one.

309
00:15:23.430 --> 00:15:25.178
So both cool utilities.

310
00:15:25.178 --> 00:15:26.232
If you wanna run them,

311
00:15:26.232 --> 00:15:29.117
the easiest way to run them is just
to fire up Kali Linux in a VM,

312
00:15:29.117 --> 00:15:33.560
because they've got DNSRecon and DNSWalk
already installed, already ready to go.

313
00:15:33.560 --> 00:15:36.800
But if you've got a Linux box or
Mac OS, you can install them,

314
00:15:36.800 --> 00:15:38.360
they just aren't installed by default.

315
00:15:38.360 --> 00:15:41.290
Just quick ways to check your zone and
look for errors.

316
00:15:41.290 --> 00:15:43.310
>> Don, great information,
great utilities there.

317
00:15:43.310 --> 00:15:46.750
Does look like we're coming to the end of
another episode but before we sign out,

318
00:15:46.750 --> 00:15:51.158
Don, do you got any additional pieces
of advice about our two utilities here,

319
00:15:51.158 --> 00:15:52.860
DNSWalk and DNSRecon?

320
00:15:52.860 --> 00:15:55.080
>> Number one thing is, if you want
DNSWalk to really be effective,

321
00:15:55.080 --> 00:15:57.690
you need to turn on zone transfers.

322
00:15:57.690 --> 00:16:00.240
The temptation is there to just
open up zone transfers to anybody.

323
00:16:00.240 --> 00:16:02.590
If you do that, make sure you turn it off.

324
00:16:02.590 --> 00:16:05.630
You gotta turn off that zone transfer
stuff afterwards when you're done,

325
00:16:05.630 --> 00:16:07.610
otherwise you're leaving
yourself vulnerable.

326
00:16:07.610 --> 00:16:10.870
I prefer to just add my individual IP but

327
00:16:10.870 --> 00:16:13.350
the IP that I had to add was
the NAT'd IP for the building.

328
00:16:13.350 --> 00:16:16.300
So technically everybody in this building
can do a zone transfer off of that zone

329
00:16:16.300 --> 00:16:17.860
right now I don't wanna leave that there.

330
00:16:17.860 --> 00:16:21.210
So be careful, don't leave your
servers open to zone transfers,

331
00:16:21.210 --> 00:16:22.580
make sure you turn that
off when you're done.

332
00:16:22.580 --> 00:16:23.560
>> Words of wisdom.

333
00:16:23.560 --> 00:16:25.570
Lock down those zone files, that's right.

334
00:16:25.570 --> 00:16:28.060
So we're gonna go ahead and
sign out here for ITProTV.

335
00:16:28.060 --> 00:16:30.210
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

336
00:16:30.210 --> 00:16:31.250
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

337
00:16:31.250 --> 00:16:32.481
>> And we'll see you next time.

338
00:16:32.481 --> 00:16:39.843
[MUSIC]

339
00:16:39.843 --> 00:16:42.604
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:03.910
Well come back to ITPRO.TV [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:03.910 --> 00:00:07.988
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:07.988 --> 00:00:12.070
You are watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:12.070 --> 00:00:16.055
Welcome to another exciting episode here,
right, ITProTV, I'm your host Wes Bryan.

5
00:00:16.055 --> 00:00:19.315
And in today's episode we're continuing
through a series on one of the most

6
00:00:19.315 --> 00:00:23.345
important services out there on
the backbone of the internet, that is DNS.

7
00:00:23.345 --> 00:00:27.315
And joining us in the studios today for
this subject is Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:27.315 --> 00:00:28.390
Don, how you doing, sir?

9
00:00:28.390 --> 00:00:29.230
I'm doing great, Wes.

10
00:00:29.230 --> 00:00:31.783
Ready to dive right back into DNS and
in this episode,

11
00:00:31.783 --> 00:00:34.640
we're going to be talking about
host records inside a DNS.

12
00:00:34.640 --> 00:00:38.364
This is kind of the bread and
butter of the way DNS functions.

13
00:00:38.364 --> 00:00:42.280
So these are the critical components
that make up that basic functionality.

14
00:00:42.280 --> 00:00:46.103
And there's several different kinds and we
need to understand which ones are used for

15
00:00:46.103 --> 00:00:47.282
which purposes and so on.

16
00:00:47.282 --> 00:00:50.199
That's what we're going to run
through right here in this episode and

17
00:00:50.199 --> 00:00:52.780
I'm gonna kick things off with
the most basic of host record.

18
00:00:52.780 --> 00:00:54.240
It's called an A Record.

19
00:00:54.240 --> 00:00:57.040
An A Record stands for an Address Record.

20
00:00:57.040 --> 00:01:00.800
And as the name would imply,
well, we store an address there.

21
00:01:00.800 --> 00:01:03.330
So, [LAUGH] Not a great transition for
that one.

22
00:01:03.330 --> 00:01:07.930
But anyhow, the point being that in DNS
we normally expect it to take a name and

23
00:01:07.930 --> 00:01:09.650
convert it to an IP address, right?

24
00:01:09.650 --> 00:01:11.210
That's what we expect.

25
00:01:11.210 --> 00:01:13.160
And that's exactly what an A record does,

26
00:01:13.160 --> 00:01:15.750
so their functionality is
pretty straight forward.

27
00:01:15.750 --> 00:01:17.260
Now, let me show you how it works.
