that's a PTR record.

474
00:24:36.360 --> 00:24:40.200
PTRs are pointer records and
they're the opposite of a host record.

475
00:24:40.200 --> 00:24:44.500
So that the A records that we've
been working with, A, 4A, and CNAME.

476
00:24:44.500 --> 00:24:48.420
Those are all name to IP,
or name to name to IP.

477
00:24:48.420 --> 00:24:51.680
But a PTR is the other way around,
it's IP to name.

478
00:24:51.680 --> 00:24:55.220
So if I want to resolve an IP address
to figure out who the heck it is,

479
00:24:55.220 --> 00:24:56.600
I need a PTR record.

480
00:24:56.600 --> 00:24:59.110
And all along the way,
you see me creating these things, and

481
00:24:59.110 --> 00:25:02.550
it keeps asking me if it wants
me to create the PTR record.

482
00:25:02.550 --> 00:25:03.594
So when I create a host,

483
00:25:03.594 --> 00:25:06.639
I've got the option right here to
create the Associated PTR record.

484
00:25:06.639 --> 00:25:09.554
The thing about PTRs,
is they don't go in for

485
00:25:09.554 --> 00:25:12.711
lookup one,
they go in the reverse lookup zone.

486
00:25:12.711 --> 00:25:15.298
And if you don't have
a reverse lookup zone created,

487
00:25:15.298 --> 00:25:17.540
then these don't get created, right?

488
00:25:17.540 --> 00:25:21.390
Now, on a private network you can
make your own reverse lookup zones.

489
00:25:21.390 --> 00:25:23.670
You can make them, chuck them in there,
and they work great.

490
00:25:23.670 --> 00:25:24.790
But out on the internet,

491
00:25:24.790 --> 00:25:29.540
you can only make a reverse lookup zone
if actually own your IP addresses.

492
00:25:29.540 --> 00:25:30.660
Most of us don't.

493
00:25:30.660 --> 00:25:35.642
So for example, our IP address's here
at the office, we go through an ISP and

494
00:25:35.642 --> 00:25:37.880
the ISP is assigned 32 IPs to us.

495
00:25:37.880 --> 00:25:43.110
Now, we pay for those IPs but
we don't own them, the ISP does.

496
00:25:43.110 --> 00:25:47.206
So the ISP,
controls the reverse lookup for those.

497
00:25:47.206 --> 00:25:49.990
And then, we,
if we need to change the reverse look ups,

498
00:25:49.990 --> 00:25:52.750
we have to reach out to them and ask them
to do it, because we don't own those IPs.

499
00:25:53.860 --> 00:25:57.980
Unlike the domain name, where we do own
the domain name, we don't own the IPs.

500
00:25:57.980 --> 00:25:59.280
Now some companies do own their IPs.

501
00:25:59.280 --> 00:26:02.383
If you have a BGP autonomous system and
you own your IPs, and

502
00:26:02.383 --> 00:26:06.123
in that case you're responsible for
supporting reverse lookup zone.

503
00:26:06.123 --> 00:26:09.730
And you need to be able
to map IPs to a name.

504
00:26:09.730 --> 00:26:13.480
And so I've got a couple of
reverse lookup zones created here,

505
00:26:13.480 --> 00:26:17.965
like 10.in-ader.arvo,
which means these are internet addresses.

506
00:26:17.965 --> 00:26:21.375
And remember that the way the networks
have written is kind of backwards,

507
00:26:21.375 --> 00:26:23.355
because the way they look up is performed.

508
00:26:23.355 --> 00:26:29.520
If I get a host who's in 192.168.1.100,
.100 is a host ID, so I ignore that.

509
00:26:29.520 --> 00:26:35.800
And then .0 is the next octet, .168 is
the next octet, .192 is the first octet.

510
00:26:35.800 --> 00:26:39.060
And so,
it's written backwards to reflect that.

511
00:26:39.060 --> 00:26:41.720
And so, if I wanna create an entry
in here from web server 01,

512
00:26:41.720 --> 00:26:43.930
I can do a new pointer record.

513
00:26:43.930 --> 00:26:48.960
And I would specify the address,
the address is 192.168.0.100.

514
00:26:48.960 --> 00:26:53.250
But look what just happened,
just like when I do four lookup zones, it

515
00:26:53.250 --> 00:26:57.740
assumes that I'm already in that network,
because I'm in that reverse lookup zone.

516
00:26:57.740 --> 00:26:59.650
And so now, I'm screwing up my address.

517
00:26:59.650 --> 00:27:02.490
So I need to just put the Host, and

518
00:27:02.490 --> 00:27:06.460
now it's my address written backwards,
192.168.0.100.

519
00:27:06.460 --> 00:27:09.510
And then I can put the name
that it's mapped to.

520
00:27:09.510 --> 00:27:15.704
And in my case it's mapped
to webserver01.lab.itpro.tv.

521
00:27:15.704 --> 00:27:19.376
And I'll leave the trailing dot off,
I don't want to anger the Microsoft gods,

522
00:27:19.376 --> 00:27:21.923
but there is supposed to be
a little dot there at the end.

523
00:27:21.923 --> 00:27:23.410
And I'll go ahead and hit OK on that.

524
00:27:24.620 --> 00:27:30.733
Now that it's created, I've got something
that's going to resolve an IP to a name.

525
00:27:30.733 --> 00:27:33.147
Now be careful cuz these reverse
lookup zones can sometimes show up

526
00:27:33.147 --> 00:27:33.930
a little different.

527
00:27:33.930 --> 00:27:36.660
See this one here that
I created just 10 dot?

528
00:27:36.660 --> 00:27:38.760
Well, 10 dot is a class A.

529
00:27:38.760 --> 00:27:41.430
So, everything under 10 dot
would fall inside of it.

530
00:27:41.430 --> 00:27:44.654
So, when I create a PTR record in here,
it's gonna be a little bit different.

531
00:27:44.654 --> 00:27:48.427
For example, my workstation,

532
00:27:48.427 --> 00:27:53.048
my laptop, let's see what my- oops.

533
00:27:53.048 --> 00:27:57.370
[INAUDIBLE] get into a [LAUGH] I am
going to get into a terminal eventually.

534
00:27:57.370 --> 00:27:58.510
There we go.

535
00:27:58.510 --> 00:28:05.220
And if I take a look at my IP address,
I am 10 dot.

536
00:28:05.220 --> 00:28:07.190
I should have just grabbed
it from the beginning.

537
00:28:08.760 --> 00:28:11.552
I am unable to find my IP address.

538
00:28:11.552 --> 00:28:12.290
10.0.

539
00:28:12.290 --> 00:28:14.635
[LAUGH] Too many network
adapters is what I have.

540
00:28:14.635 --> 00:28:19.392
10.0.14.72 so
if I want to create an entry for me,

541
00:28:19.392 --> 00:28:22.481
my address is 10.0.14.72.

542
00:28:22.481 --> 00:28:26.180
But when I type that out,
look what it's doing down here,

543
00:28:26.180 --> 00:28:30.680
it's writing in the forward order,
which is incorrect, right?

544
00:28:30.680 --> 00:28:34.035
So need to know to reverse that and
write it the proper way.

545
00:28:34.035 --> 00:28:40.800
72.14.0, I'm writing it
backwards to match that.

546
00:28:40.800 --> 00:28:43.760
That can be a little tricky and
it can cause the zone not to work.

547
00:28:43.760 --> 00:28:46.640
And that's why Microsoft is
constantly pestering you to create

548
00:28:46.640 --> 00:28:48.330
these PTR records for you.

549
00:28:48.330 --> 00:28:51.703
So for example,
if I go up here to my lab, and

550
00:28:51.703 --> 00:28:56.921
I create a new host record and so
this is gonna be dpulaptop, right?

551
00:28:56.921 --> 00:29:00.330
And for the IP I put in 10.0.14.72.

552
00:29:00.330 --> 00:29:03.140
And I tell it to create
the associated pointer record.

553
00:29:03.140 --> 00:29:07.170
If I let it do it for me,
all right so it's gonna do it.

554
00:29:07.170 --> 00:29:12.040
Now, when I go into that zone, well it's
missing cuz I need to refresh my screen.

555
00:29:12.040 --> 00:29:15.730
But if I refresh my screen,
there it is, 10.0.14.72.

556
00:29:15.730 --> 00:29:19.580
And it made sure that it
got entered in properly, so

557
00:29:19.580 --> 00:29:23.160
that it didn't get it backwards or
mixed up, or whatever.

558
00:29:23.160 --> 00:29:26.280
Now the way this is being rendered here
makes it look like it's in one folder, but

559
00:29:26.280 --> 00:29:29.760
it does actually create little
subfolders for each octet down the line.

560
00:29:29.760 --> 00:29:33.200
And it's an interesting system, but
anyhow, so it'll create that and

561
00:29:33.200 --> 00:29:34.040
put it in place.

562
00:29:34.040 --> 00:29:37.700
But this'll let me
reverse an IP to a name.

563
00:29:37.700 --> 00:29:41.915
So if I go back to my command prompt and
I do an nslookup and

564
00:29:41.915 --> 00:29:44.352
I look up an IP instead, right?

565
00:29:44.352 --> 00:29:48.098
So I'll say 10.0.14.72,

566
00:29:48.098 --> 00:29:52.667
when I look that up it
resolves it to dplaptop.

567
00:29:52.667 --> 00:29:55.797
Now, I can map the IP to the name.

568
00:29:55.797 --> 00:29:56.617
All right,

569
00:29:56.617 --> 00:30:01.539
let's do one last look at the file
that is created out of all this stuff.

570
00:30:01.539 --> 00:30:05.328
This whole time we've been
editing DNS viz the GUI, but

571
00:30:05.328 --> 00:30:09.730
in the background it has been
working with that text file.

572
00:30:09.730 --> 00:30:13.740
And remember what I've said about www and
how was really has one entry?

573
00:30:13.740 --> 00:30:18.007
And here I can see it's one entry and
here's all the A records that I created or

574
00:30:18.007 --> 00:30:20.515
four A records that we created and
tied to it.

575
00:30:20.515 --> 00:30:23.870
Here you can see the FTP CNAME
that was created.

576
00:30:23.870 --> 00:30:27.350
And there's that little trailing
dot that the GUI hates so much.

577
00:30:27.350 --> 00:30:29.010
Remember that when you
create these domains,

578
00:30:29.010 --> 00:30:30.980
there is actually a little dot at the end.

579
00:30:30.980 --> 00:30:36.680
And that's denoting the root hint servers,
that the root of DNS.

580
00:30:36.680 --> 00:30:40.240
I don't know, Wes, do you remember the old
Sun Microsystem commercials back before-

581
00:30:40.240 --> 00:30:41.465
>> No, that's before my time.

582
00:30:41.465 --> 00:30:42.600
[LAUGH]
>> They had these tv commercials.

583
00:30:42.600 --> 00:30:45.710
They said Sun Microsystems,
we put the dot in dot net.

584
00:30:45.710 --> 00:30:50.420
And they actually started saying, we put
the dot in the internet, originally.

585
00:30:50.420 --> 00:30:53.732
Because all the route hint servers
were Sun Microsystems servers.

586
00:30:53.732 --> 00:30:56.521
And not that they own them, other
people own them, but the hardware, or

587
00:30:56.521 --> 00:30:57.680
Sun Microsystems.

588
00:30:57.680 --> 00:31:00.330
And then over time,
people migrated to other hardware.

589
00:31:00.330 --> 00:31:01.150
And so they can always say,

590
00:31:01.150 --> 00:31:04.530
we put the dot in dot NET because that
was the one they still controlled.

591
00:31:04.530 --> 00:31:07.150
But that's all long gone now.

592
00:31:07.150 --> 00:31:10.230
But that dot is the root, and so
that shows up in the config files,

593
00:31:10.230 --> 00:31:11.550
because it actually does exist.

594
00:31:11.550 --> 00:31:16.111
But we don't normally type it, our web
browsers just automatically do it for us.

595
00:31:16.111 --> 00:31:20.868
All right, and I've probably stalled long
enough that the PTRs have been created in

596
00:31:20.868 --> 00:31:22.520
that reverse look up.

597
00:31:22.520 --> 00:31:25.040
So if I take a look at that one,
like if I do,

598
00:31:25.040 --> 00:31:29.537
well here let's just look at at kind of
how this is laid out on my file system.

599
00:31:29.537 --> 00:31:37.140
There's that 10.inaddr file and if I
pull that one up and take a look at it.

600
00:31:37.140 --> 00:31:40.090
There's my pointer and
see how it is written backwards

601
00:31:40.090 --> 00:31:43.330
even though the GUI showed it to me
forwards, they did write it properly.

602
00:31:43.330 --> 00:31:45.521
In the backside here it's
written backwards and

603
00:31:45.521 --> 00:31:47.129
it's mapped to my laptop, right?

604
00:31:47.129 --> 00:31:49.925
So that's what those records are,
that's how they work, and

605
00:31:49.925 --> 00:31:52.540
we just punch them in and
let them do their thing.

606
00:31:52.540 --> 00:31:55.770
>> That's a lot of great information on
host records and I could've swore that

607
00:31:55.770 --> 00:31:58.980
you were gonna tell me that those quad-A
records, they were four times better.

608
00:31:58.980 --> 00:31:59.510
But you didn't.

609
00:31:59.510 --> 00:32:01.240
That's how they named them that.

610
00:32:01.240 --> 00:32:02.241
But it does, joking aside,

611
00:32:02.241 --> 00:32:04.431
it does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

612
00:32:04.431 --> 00:32:07.463
But before we do, Don,
do you have additional words with the host

613
00:32:07.463 --> 00:32:10.700
records that might help keep us out
of trouble, or get things right?

614
00:32:10.700 --> 00:32:15.190
>> So if you edit the text files directly,
everything is always done the same way.

615
00:32:15.190 --> 00:32:18.880
But if you use GUIs like I was doing,
sometimes vendors implement different

616
00:32:18.880 --> 00:32:21.630
graphical user interfaces that put
requirements and restrictions and

617
00:32:21.630 --> 00:32:22.170
changes on there.

618
00:32:22.170 --> 00:32:24.540
So always be sure to read
your vendor documentation.

619
00:32:24.540 --> 00:32:29.070
I'm using a self hosted server,
if you're doing a hosted server through

620
00:32:29.070 --> 00:32:32.590
like Amazon's AWS or
something like that, like route 53,

621
00:32:32.590 --> 00:32:36.010
they might have even more rules and
even special features, special records.

622
00:32:36.010 --> 00:32:40.276
I know AWS does, you can have your
records point to security groups and

623
00:32:40.276 --> 00:32:45.287
all sorts of VPC's and crazy things,
that's all stuff that Amazon has added on.

624
00:32:45.287 --> 00:32:49.419
Those are host records, but they are not
part of the standard, so there are ways

625
00:32:49.419 --> 00:32:53.760
to extend the functionality of DNS, just
be be aware that may not be standardized.

626
00:32:53.760 --> 00:32:56.873
>> Well Don, we appreciate taking the time
to show us all this good information and

627
00:32:56.873 --> 00:32:58.550
we appreciate you the viewer, watching.

628
00:32:58.550 --> 00:33:01.300
We're gonna be go ahead and
sign out for this one IT ProTV.

629
00:33:01.300 --> 00:33:03.070
I've been your host West Brian.

630
00:33:03.070 --> 00:33:03.720
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

631
00:33:03.720 --> 00:33:06.078
>> And we'll see you next time.

[MUSIC]

00:33:12.117 --> 00:33:15.586
>> Thank you for watching, ITPRO.TV.

episodes.title: SRV Records
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:06.832
Welcome to ITProTV I'm your
host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.832 --> 00:00:08.659
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.659 --> 00:00:11.839
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.839 --> 00:00:14.885
>> Welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

5
00:00:14.885 --> 00:00:16.496
I'm your host Wes Brian, and

6
00:00:16.496 --> 00:00:20.177
in today's episode we're coming
at you with more DNS tech skills.

7
00:00:20.177 --> 00:00:20.966
That's right.

8
00:00:20.966 --> 00:00:23.115
One of the most important services
is out there in the Internet.

9
00:00:23.115 --> 00:00:24.795
Just about, you know, to find anything.

10
00:00:24.795 --> 00:00:27.247
And joining us back in the studios
today is none other than Mr.

11
00:00:27.247 --> 00:00:28.719
Don Pezet, Don how you doing, sir?

12
00:00:28.719 --> 00:00:29.654
>> I'm doing swell, Wes.

13
00:00:29.654 --> 00:00:33.575
Ready to dive into an unusual
type of record for this episode.

14
00:00:33.575 --> 00:00:36.104
We're going to be taking
a look at SRV records,

15
00:00:36.104 --> 00:00:40.405
which are service locator records, and
these are I don't want to call them new,

16
00:00:40.405 --> 00:00:44.289
because they've been around a long time,
but they're newly popular?

17
00:00:44.289 --> 00:00:48.396
[LAUGH] Not the best way to describe it,
but it's a special type of DNS record that

18
00:00:48.396 --> 00:00:51.970
functions a little differently than
the host record we're used to.

19
00:00:51.970 --> 00:00:57.914
The host record normally is a name,
map to an IP, or an IP map to a name.

20
00:00:57.914 --> 00:01:01.156
And in either scenario you really have
a single destination you're going to,

21
00:01:01.156 --> 00:01:04.400
a particular server, and
that's who we're trying to find.

22
00:01:04.400 --> 00:01:08.874
In SRV records a little different though
cuz we're not necessarily trying to locate

23
00:01:08.874 --> 00:01:10.072
a particular server,

24
00:01:10.072 --> 00:01:13.424
we're trying to locate a service
that's running on a server.

25
00:01:13.424 --> 00:01:16.229
You might have more than one service
running on the same server and

26
00:01:16.229 --> 00:01:18.690
we need to find them and
reach out to them and locate them.

27
00:01:18.690 --> 00:01:22.627
Well, DNS wasn't really
designed to handle that and so

28
00:01:22.627 --> 00:01:25.743
in the early days of
DNS you couldn't do it.

29
00:01:25.743 --> 00:01:28.680
You could find a server but
you couldn't find services on it.

30
00:01:28.680 --> 00:01:29.860
And let me just give you an example.

31
00:01:31.130 --> 00:01:35.105
In the early days of the world wide web
that if you wanted to go to a web server

32
00:01:35.105 --> 00:01:38.333
you needed to know the IP address or
host name of the server.

33
00:01:38.333 --> 00:01:43.860
And you could type in http:// and
then punch in the IP or name.

34
00:01:43.860 --> 00:01:47.691
Well with SRV records, we could go
to DNS and we could just say, hey,

35
00:01:47.691 --> 00:01:49.687
I don't know who the web server is.

36
00:01:49.687 --> 00:01:51.924
Could you give me a list
of the web servers?

37
00:01:51.924 --> 00:01:56.350
Give me a list of each server
that's providing the HTTP service.

38
00:01:56.350 --> 00:01:59.380
And you could pull that information
back and locate those servers.

39
00:01:59.380 --> 00:02:01.490
Now we don't need that for the web,

40
00:02:01.490 --> 00:02:03.760
because that's kinda
the default functionality.

41
00:02:03.760 --> 00:02:07.040
But there's other protocols that are out
there that really benefit from this.

42
00:02:07.040 --> 00:02:10.808
And so we have SRV records
that help us to find them.

43
00:02:10.808 --> 00:02:14.052
Now SRV records can be a little complex,
so I want to show you guys a few different

44
00:02:14.052 --> 00:02:16.680
examples and how they can be used and
how they can work.

45
00:02:16.680 --> 00:02:19.945
But a key thing to remember is
that SRV records are not magic.

46
00:02:19.945 --> 00:02:22.175
They don't just work cuz you created them,
but

47
00:02:22.175 --> 00:02:26.135
as software clients have
to expect them to exist.

48
00:02:26.135 --> 00:02:30.255
So if whoever wrote your software isn't
checking for srv records it doesn't matter

49
00:02:30.255 --> 00:02:32.590
if they exist or not,
they're never going to get used.

50
00:02:32.590 --> 00:02:35.110
So make sure that your
software supports SRV records,

51
00:02:35.110 --> 00:02:37.410
before you exert a lot of
effort in creating them.

52
00:02:37.410 --> 00:02:40.770
So, one big example that I have is,
for example,

53
00:02:40.770 --> 00:02:46.040
Microsoft Exchange has this
auto-discovery protocol.

54
00:02:46.040 --> 00:02:49.300
When you fire up Microsoft Outlook,
you have to tell it an email server,

55
00:02:49.300 --> 00:02:52.140
you have to type in, you know,
the email server name and so on.

56
00:02:52.140 --> 00:02:55.470
Well with auto discovery,
somebody can type their email address.

57
00:02:55.470 --> 00:02:59.251
So I'm Don@ITPro.Tv, and
we can just go to ITPro.TV and

508
00:25:18.990 --> 00:25:22.430
I need to tell it that I'm
gonna be doing an SRV lookup.

509
00:25:22.430 --> 00:25:27.601
And NsLookup, I believe, is -tsrv, if not
we can do it from the interactive prompt.

510
00:25:27.601 --> 00:25:29.600
All right, well apparently it's not -t,
cuz I got an error.

511
00:25:29.600 --> 00:25:31.790
So let me just show up right
into the NsLookup utility,

512
00:25:31.790 --> 00:25:33.510
I'll go it the manual way.

513
00:25:33.510 --> 00:25:37.583
Inside nslookup,
we can just say set type=SRV.

514
00:25:37.583 --> 00:25:39.570
I'm telling it I wanna
look up an SRV record.

515
00:25:39.570 --> 00:25:43.422
I do need to override my server, so I'm
gonna point to my own server, all right?

516
00:25:43.422 --> 00:25:46.040
So let me do that, and
then I'm just gonna repeat that lookup.

517
00:25:46.040 --> 00:25:53.587
I'm gonna do a lookup for
x-puppet._tcp.lab.itpro.tv.

518
00:25:53.587 --> 00:25:56.710
And so when I do that lookup,
it knows that I wanna do an SRV lookup.

519
00:25:56.710 --> 00:25:58.740
And there we go,
that's what I was looking for.

520
00:25:58.740 --> 00:25:59.920
I get the three servers.

521
00:25:59.920 --> 00:26:01.590
Notice I get all three of them.

522
00:26:01.590 --> 00:26:05.340
Even though I've got one with
a higher priority, I get all three.

523
00:26:05.340 --> 00:26:06.370
Why?

524
00:26:06.370 --> 00:26:10.530
It's not up to puppet to do,
up to DNS to do the load balancing.

525
00:26:10.530 --> 00:26:12.310
DNS is just helping you resolve things.

526
00:26:12.310 --> 00:26:15.780
But now your client knows,
this is who I need to talk to.

527
00:26:15.780 --> 00:26:20.490
And if I can't get to that person,
then I can rotate between these other two.

528
00:26:20.490 --> 00:26:23.850
So, it's presented that way so we can
identify who to go to and reach out to.

529
00:26:23.850 --> 00:26:26.135
But I get those other SRV records back,
and

530
00:26:26.135 --> 00:26:28.135
I can see, here's the server host name.

531
00:26:28.135 --> 00:26:33.755
I need to go to pmaster03.lab.itpro.tv and
I can connect to it on port 8140,

532
00:26:33.755 --> 00:26:36.915
and that's where I'm gonna find my
puppet master that I'm gonna talk to.

533
00:26:36.915 --> 00:26:40.848
Or my my zip PVX that I need to
register with, so I can make and

534
00:26:40.848 --> 00:26:45.831
receive calls or my Microsoft Exchange
Server so I can configure my email.

535
00:26:45.831 --> 00:26:48.552
Whatever it is that this
service is telling us about,

536
00:26:48.552 --> 00:26:50.700
we now know where it is and we can.

537
00:26:50.700 --> 00:26:55.600
So that's basically the way that SRV
records work I had to use NSLookup,

538
00:26:55.600 --> 00:26:56.940
I don't normally use NSLookup for this,

539
00:26:56.940 --> 00:27:00.130
cuz I'm normally on a Linux or
a Unix based machine.

540
00:27:01.250 --> 00:27:02.180
I don't have the dig command.

541
00:27:02.180 --> 00:27:07.402
If you have dig it's a heck of
a lot easier, cuz you can just

542
00:27:07.402 --> 00:27:13.599
dig whatever the record is So
x-puppet._tcp.lab.itpro.tv.

543
00:27:13.599 --> 00:27:16.127
And you can just say SRV right at the end,
right?

544
00:27:16.127 --> 00:27:18.182
Dig makes it where you're prior,
and then it'll do the lookups.

545
00:27:18.182 --> 00:27:23.158
That's how I normally do it, but
NSlookup can do it there too.

546
00:27:23.158 --> 00:27:26.130
I think that's about all
I've got on SRV records.

547
00:27:26.130 --> 00:27:27.840
Anything else I want to mention?

548
00:27:27.840 --> 00:27:29.052
No, that's not it.

549
00:27:29.052 --> 00:27:31.360
>> All right.
Well very good there Don.

550
00:27:31.360 --> 00:27:34.617
Okay, he told us we're coming
to the end of another episode.

551
00:27:34.617 --> 00:27:39.502
Don, any final words about finding those
services within your network to these SRV

552
00:27:39.502 --> 00:27:40.144
records?

553
00:27:40.144 --> 00:27:40.690
>> That's about it.

554
00:27:40.690 --> 00:27:43.170
We did have a question in
the chat room about some

555
00:27:43.170 --> 00:27:45.660
DNS records they've seen like _uuu,
_k password.

556
00:27:45.660 --> 00:27:49.080
Sometimes you'll see other ones in there.

557
00:27:50.220 --> 00:27:52.290
Quick kind of just mention on those.

558
00:27:52.290 --> 00:27:55.050
Microsoft's Active Directory and
open ldap, and

559
00:27:55.050 --> 00:28:00.210
a few other directory servers out there do
use DNS records to locate the directories.

560
00:28:00.210 --> 00:28:03.295
Those technologies were developed
before RSV records existed though.

561
00:28:03.295 --> 00:28:07.865
So if you look at them, yes, they use
the _TCP folder, or _Kerbaros to whatever.

562
00:28:07.865 --> 00:28:10.025
But if you drill down into them,

563
00:28:10.025 --> 00:28:12.205
some of them have been
converted to use SRV records.

564
00:28:12.205 --> 00:28:14.732
But a lot of them still just
use regular old a records.

565
00:28:14.732 --> 00:28:18.161
So for example in the active directory if
you drill down you'll see site folders,

566
00:28:18.161 --> 00:28:19.862
and inside of them are just A records.

567
00:28:19.862 --> 00:28:22.652
They use them to find the servers but
it doesn't specify a port.

568
00:28:22.652 --> 00:28:25.462
But there are parts of the active
directory that have been switched over to

569
00:28:25.462 --> 00:28:27.744
SRV records too so
you'll see kind of mixture in some of it.

570
00:28:27.744 --> 00:28:30.359
But it just kind depends on when
that software was created and

571
00:28:30.359 --> 00:28:32.710
what they've developed to support and
so on.

572
00:28:32.710 --> 00:28:37.869
So just because it's in _tcp or
_udp, _kerboros or

573
00:28:37.869 --> 00:28:42.670
whatever doesn't guarantee it's an srv
record but the odds are it will be.

574
00:28:42.670 --> 00:28:44.130
>> Well that's a lot of
great information and

575
00:28:44.130 --> 00:28:46.980
it does look like we're gonna go ahead and
rap this one up.

576
00:28:46.980 --> 00:28:49.280
Don, we appreciate you
being here as always, and

577
00:28:49.280 --> 00:28:51.170
we appreciate you the viewer watching.

578
00:28:51.170 --> 00:28:54.320
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

579
00:28:54.320 --> 00:28:55.179
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

580
00:28:55.179 --> 00:28:56.516
>> And we'll see you next time.

581
00:28:56.516 --> 00:29:03.948
[MUSIC]

582
00:29:03.948 --> 00:29:06.390
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore using and configuring mail exchanger records also known as MX records. They talk about some of the components of the MX record type such as domain name, time-to-live or TTL as well as the priority or preference that can be set when using multiple servers are used.
episodes.title: Configuring MX Records
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.300 --> 00:00:01.493
Welcome to ITPro TV.

2
00:00:01.493 --> 00:00:06.868
I'm your host Don- [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.868 --> 00:00:08.483
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.483 --> 00:00:12.237
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

5
00:00:12.237 --> 00:00:15.109
>> Welcome back to another
exciting episode here at ITProTv.

6
00:00:15.109 --> 00:00:18.584
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and in today's
episode we're continuing through talking

7
00:00:18.584 --> 00:00:22.010
about one of the services, probably one of
the most important things on the internet

8
00:00:22.010 --> 00:00:24.650
to help you find information
that you're looking for.

9
00:00:24.650 --> 00:00:27.330
And joining us in the studios today
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:27.330 --> 00:00:28.290
Don, how you doing sir?

11
00:00:28.290 --> 00:00:30.170
>> Doing great Wes,
ready to dive right back into DNS.

12
00:00:30.170 --> 00:00:34.062
And in this episode we're gonna
be talking about MX records.

13
00:00:34.062 --> 00:00:37.430
You mentioned using or finding things.

14
00:00:37.430 --> 00:00:38.750
DNS is all about finding things.

15
00:00:38.750 --> 00:00:41.450
I wanna find where this server is or
that server is.

16
00:00:41.450 --> 00:00:42.720
MX records, they're so

17
00:00:42.720 --> 00:00:46.570
important because that's how we
figure out where to send email to.

18
00:00:46.570 --> 00:00:49.800
Whenever we setup a new mail server or
we purchase a domain and

19
00:00:49.800 --> 00:00:52.330
we wanna setup email for it,
setting up MX records is

20
00:00:52.330 --> 00:00:54.670
one of the first things we've
got to do to get that in place.

21
00:00:54.670 --> 00:00:56.980
That's what we're gonna
take a look at right here.

22
00:00:56.980 --> 00:01:00.380
Now before I create the MX record, let
me show you guys kind of the format and

23
00:01:00.380 --> 00:01:04.278
what makes up an MX record, and we'll see
how to create it and put it in place.

24
00:01:04.278 --> 00:01:07.580
Whenever you do an email,
you write an email up,

25
00:01:07.580 --> 00:01:10.060
you put in there that's it's
gonna be to somebody, so

26
00:01:10.060 --> 00:01:14.160
maybe you're gonna email
the President of the United States.

27
00:01:14.160 --> 00:01:20.320
So you draft up an email, and it's gonna
be sent to president@whitehouse.gov.

28
00:01:20.320 --> 00:01:22.400
Well how does that email know where to go?

29
00:01:22.400 --> 00:01:26.660
And the way it knows where to go,
is by doing a DNS lookup.

30
00:01:26.660 --> 00:01:32.203
It takes the domain, so
if I'm emailing president@whitehouse.gov,

31
00:01:32.203 --> 00:01:35.620
that's who I'm gonna email, it says,

32
00:01:35.620 --> 00:01:38.770
okay well I don't really care about
the president part cuz that's a user name.

33
00:01:38.770 --> 00:01:39.700
I'm just gonna get rid of that.

34
00:01:39.700 --> 00:01:44.050
And then whitehouse.gov,
that's the domain that I'm gonna email to.

35
00:01:44.050 --> 00:01:46.880
All right?
And if we just run a normal lookup against

36
00:01:46.880 --> 00:01:49.740
that, we'll see an IP address and
that's that.

37
00:01:49.740 --> 00:01:54.600
But if we change from the A record to the
MX record, I'm just going to tell it to

38
00:01:54.600 --> 00:02:00.480
look up MX record instead, now I see
the email servers that power that domain.

39
00:02:00.480 --> 00:02:03.140
If I have an email for
president@whitehouse.gov,

40
00:02:03.140 --> 00:02:06.920
I can send it right along to any
of these servers right here.

41
00:02:08.010 --> 00:02:10.590
Now why so many servers?

42
00:02:10.590 --> 00:02:12.860
Well typically it's redundancy.

43
00:02:12.860 --> 00:02:14.430
Redundancy is important with email.

44
00:02:14.430 --> 00:02:18.010
People love their email, and
people hate to lose email.

45
00:02:18.010 --> 00:02:22.060
If I only have one email server and
the server fails, I'm out of luck.

46
00:02:22.060 --> 00:02:23.072
I start losing email.

47
00:02:23.072 --> 00:02:25.740
Well there's little email
retry stuff that happens, but

48
00:02:25.740 --> 00:02:27.470
I could potentially lose email.

49
00:02:27.470 --> 00:02:30.320
But if I want redundancy I need
more than one mail server, so

50
00:02:30.320 --> 00:02:32.660
usually you're recommended to have two.

51
00:02:32.660 --> 00:02:34.507
Well, if you create two MX records,

52
00:02:34.507 --> 00:02:38.559
then the default is DNS will round-robin
between those two mail servers, and so

53
00:02:38.559 --> 00:02:42.660
half your mail will go to one server,
half your mail will go to the other.

54
00:02:42.660 --> 00:02:45.430
But in the MX record, when we create it,

55
00:02:45.430 --> 00:02:48.230
there's a few values that we can
specify that let us override that.

56
00:02:48.230 --> 00:02:50.640
Let me just run through
the pieces of the MX record.

57
00:02:50.640 --> 00:02:51.918
The first part is the domain.

58
00:02:51.918 --> 00:02:54.830
This is whitehouse.gov that I looked up.

59
00:02:54.830 --> 00:02:58.440
The next part is the time to live,
the TTL.

60
00:02:58.440 --> 00:03:03.268
Now, the time to live for a record is how
long a server is allowed to have it cached

61
00:03:03.268 --> 00:03:05.949
for, and this time is actually in seconds.

62
00:03:05.949 --> 00:03:09.060
And so I can see, this one's set
to be cached for 3,802 seconds.

63
00:03:09.060 --> 00:03:12.170
Actually, that's probably
just what's left on it.

64
00:03:12.170 --> 00:03:13.580
Yeah, see it's counting down.

65
00:03:13.580 --> 00:03:15.271
It's counting down right now.

66
00:03:15.271 --> 00:03:18.486
Eventually it will hit the bottom and
start over again.

67
00:03:18.486 --> 00:03:21.433
If this is gonna be cached for
3,700 seconds,

68
00:03:21.433 --> 00:03:24.458
I don't even know how many minutes or
hours that is.

69
00:03:24.458 --> 00:03:29.558
It seems like a day is 1,440 minutes,
and then you gotta multiply it by 60.

70
00:03:29.558 --> 00:03:31.199
Anyhow, it's at least an hour.

71
00:03:31.199 --> 00:03:33.586
So let's just pretend it's an hour,
cuz I'm bad at math.

72
00:03:33.586 --> 00:03:37.125
If that's cached for an hour, then the
next time I do a lookup it's already in

73
00:03:37.125 --> 00:03:39.290
the DNS cache so it happens faster.

74
00:03:39.290 --> 00:03:42.620
But let me give you a quick
warning about MX records.

75
00:03:42.620 --> 00:03:44.840
When it comes to mail servers,

76
00:03:44.840 --> 00:03:49.650
what happens if you decide you need
to move mail services one day?

77
00:03:49.650 --> 00:03:55.091
Maybe you have on-premises email servers
and you want to move to Office 365,

78
00:03:55.091 --> 00:03:58.720
or Google's G Suite,
or something like that.

79
00:03:58.720 --> 00:04:01.850
Well you gotta move your MX
records to point somewhere else.

80
00:04:01.850 --> 00:04:06.020
If you have a high time to live,
that's the amount of time it's gonna take

81
00:04:06.020 --> 00:04:09.180
people out there in the real
world to recognize your change.

82
00:04:09.180 --> 00:04:13.415
So if that's set to 24 hours, then it
could take an entire day before people

83
00:04:13.415 --> 00:04:16.220
stop sending email to your old server and
start sending to the new server.

84
00:04:16.220 --> 00:04:17.790
That's not a big of a deal.

85
00:04:17.790 --> 00:04:21.940
But it means that you need to remember,
hey, I'm might have switched over to

86
00:04:21.940 --> 00:04:26.170
Microsoft's Office 365 ,but I can't
shut off my mail server yet for

87
00:04:26.170 --> 00:04:27.310
like another 24 hours.

88
00:04:27.310 --> 00:04:29.670
I need to wait cuz email
might be still trickling in.

89
00:04:31.390 --> 00:04:34.040
Or you could shorten that time to live.

90
00:04:34.040 --> 00:04:37.700
Shortening the time to live will
increase the load on your DNS servers.

91
00:04:37.700 --> 00:04:40.960
It's usually negligible, but
you can increase that load.

92
00:04:40.960 --> 00:04:42.490
But the tradeoff is
you're much more agile.

93
00:04:42.490 --> 00:04:43.610
If you ever need to move or

94
00:04:43.610 --> 00:04:46.110
change your records people will
recognize it a lot faster.

95
00:04:46.110 --> 00:04:50.050
>> So in this case, by your example
that you explained, it would be roughly

96
00:04:50.050 --> 00:04:52.500
around 63 minutes if you were making that
change that you would have to wait for

97
00:04:52.500 --> 00:04:53.390
those to expire.

98
00:04:53.390 --> 00:04:55.200
>> Good, you did the math for
me, thank you.

99
00:04:55.200 --> 00:04:56.114
>> [CROSSTALK] Horrible at math.

100
00:04:56.114 --> 00:04:59.715
>> 63 minutes, it is just over an hour,
and this is counting down now, so

101
00:04:59.715 --> 00:05:02.690
actually, I don't know
what the upper level was.

102
00:05:02.690 --> 00:05:05.980
We'd have to go and pull the actual DNS
structure to find out what that is.

103
00:05:05.980 --> 00:05:09.169
But Google is serving up to me cache,
so I just see what their cache value is.

104
00:05:10.200 --> 00:05:14.860
That's kind of the warning to me
to let me know that it's cached.

105
00:05:14.860 --> 00:05:16.570
Here, we'll do itpro.tv.

106
00:05:16.570 --> 00:05:20.890
So if you were to send Wes or I an email,
we need to look it up against ours, well

107
00:05:20.890 --> 00:05:25.020
we have our mail server listed right here,
and see how short our time to live is?

108
00:05:25.020 --> 00:05:28.230
That 300 right there,
that's a much shorter one.

109
00:05:28.230 --> 00:05:29.160
300 seconds is 5 minutes.

110
00:05:30.490 --> 00:05:33.260
If I ever do a switchover, there's only
five minutes that I've got to wait for

111
00:05:33.260 --> 00:05:35.790
email to trickle over and
start to make it over to us.

112
00:05:37.240 --> 00:05:38.860
You might notice how I said boy,

113
00:05:38.860 --> 00:05:42.330
you really want to have more than one
DNS server and how many do we have?

114
00:05:42.330 --> 00:05:43.450
Just one.

115
00:05:43.450 --> 00:05:45.210
What does that mean?

116
00:05:45.210 --> 00:05:46.170
It either means that one,

117
00:05:46.170 --> 00:05:49.760
we're just super confident in the one
server we have, which we aren't.

118
00:05:49.760 --> 00:05:53.760
Or two, this pointer is actually
pointing to a load balancer with

119
00:05:53.760 --> 00:05:55.720
multiple servers behind it,
which is the case.

120
00:05:55.720 --> 00:05:59.185
We do use Office 365 and so
you'll see our MX record is pointed to

121
00:05:59.185 --> 00:06:05.850
protection.outlook.com, which
is the hosted Office 365 email.

122
00:06:05.850 --> 00:06:10.480
And it is a load balancer, and
behind it are over 100 different servers.

123
00:06:10.480 --> 00:06:12.235
I've actually traced
a lot of them out before.

124
00:06:12.235 --> 00:06:14.285
There's a bunch behind the scenes.

125
00:06:14.285 --> 00:06:18.485
Just because you see one record doesn't
necessarily mean that it's not redundant.

126
00:06:18.485 --> 00:06:22.135
It just means that it's tied
to some kind of balancer.

127
00:06:22.135 --> 00:06:23.565
Google.
Google has a ton of the things, so

128
00:06:23.565 --> 00:06:27.355
if we were to pull them up,
like for Gmail.

129
00:06:27.355 --> 00:06:29.185
Gmail's obviously a big service,

130
00:06:29.185 --> 00:06:31.790
so they've got several
different servers listed.

131
00:06:31.790 --> 00:06:34.800
Now, I mentioned round-robining.

132
00:06:34.800 --> 00:06:37.740
If I have a bunch of different
mail servers that are listed,

133
00:06:39.060 --> 00:06:43.580
technically they're all treated equally
and email's load-balanced across them.

134
00:06:43.580 --> 00:06:45.090
We typically don't want that.

135
00:06:45.090 --> 00:06:48.210
We typically have a primary and
the others are backups.

136
00:06:48.210 --> 00:06:51.700
And the way you designate that is
with what's called a priority.

137
00:06:53.340 --> 00:06:57.470
It is called a priority but you'll hear
a lot of text refer to it as a preference.

138
00:06:57.470 --> 00:07:01.040
In the early days of DNS, when this
stuff was kinda being solidified,

139
00:07:01.040 --> 00:07:05.380
they didn't really hard
set what that term was.

140
00:07:05.380 --> 00:07:07.790
And so you see them both,
priority and preference.

141
00:07:07.790 --> 00:07:09.250
But in this case they're
both the same thing, so

142
00:07:09.250 --> 00:07:10.910
it doesn't really matter what you call it.

143
00:07:10.910 --> 00:07:13.930
Basically it's a number that
you attach to the server.

144
00:07:13.930 --> 00:07:18.190
And that number tells you
which server to use first, and

145
00:07:18.190 --> 00:07:19.840
then second, and then third.

146
00:07:19.840 --> 00:07:22.920
If the first server is unreachable,

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:03.413
Welcome to ITProTV,

2

3

>> You're watching ITProTV.

5

>> Welcome to another great
episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.746 --> 00:00:17.692
I'm your host, Wes Bryan,
and in today's episode,

7
00:00:17.692 --> 00:00:20.265
we're continuing through
our DNS TXT skills.

8
00:00:20.265 --> 00:00:21.945
And joining me back in the studio's today,

9
00:00:21.945 --> 00:00:25.515
to lend his expertise on this subject
is non other than Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:25.515 --> 00:00:26.855
Don, how are you doing, sir?

11
00:00:26.855 --> 00:00:29.775
>> I'm doing great, Wes, ready to dive
in and talk about some SPF records,

12
00:00:29.775 --> 00:00:32.385
that's the Sender Policy Framework.

13
00:00:32.385 --> 00:00:34.815
And most of you, I'm sure, have already
heard of it, but if you haven't,

14
00:00:34.815 --> 00:00:37.500
it's just a simple
>> Technique that we can use to

15
00:00:37.500 --> 00:00:41.180
help prevent spam relays
out there in the world, and

16
00:00:41.180 --> 00:00:42.340
SPF records are what powers that.

17
00:00:42.340 --> 00:00:43.460
It's all kind of powered by DNS.

18
00:00:43.460 --> 00:00:46.980
So, first of all let's talk about
the problem that we're addressing here and

19
00:00:46.980 --> 00:00:48.840
we'll see how we kind of resolve it.

20
00:00:48.840 --> 00:00:54.070
One of the problems is that all email
sent on the internet today uses SMTP,

21
00:00:54.070 --> 00:00:58.540
the Simple Mail Transport Protocol and
SMTP was developed a very,

22
00:00:58.540 --> 00:01:00.000
very long time ago.

23
00:01:00.000 --> 00:01:02.900
Back in a much more trustworthy
environment where they didn't have to

24
00:01:02.900 --> 00:01:04.840
worry about a lot of
the stuff they do now.

25
00:01:04.840 --> 00:01:10.020
And as a result, when you write an email
and you send it through an SMTP server,

26
00:01:10.020 --> 00:01:14.160
it assumes that the from
address is accurate.

27
00:01:14.160 --> 00:01:17.040
And it does absolutely no
verification to figure that out.

28
00:01:17.040 --> 00:01:19.970
Right.
So, I can send an email and

29
00:01:19.970 --> 00:01:24.240
put that it was from President
out Whitehouse like golf.

30
00:01:24.240 --> 00:01:27.580
And when you receive I think it came
from President of the United States.

31
00:01:27.580 --> 00:01:31.700
And you can put wherever you want
it can be billgates@microsoft.com

32
00:01:31.700 --> 00:01:35.860
that's your from address and that you go
>> SMTP doesn't care.

33
00:01:35.860 --> 00:01:39.610
Well, with SPF records we can fix that.

34
00:01:39.610 --> 00:01:43.080
What an SPF record is a simple
entry we make in DNS and

35
00:01:43.080 --> 00:01:48.260
it says if you receive an email,
it says it's from my domain,

36
00:01:48.260 --> 00:01:51.180
then it should have come
from one of these servers,

37
00:01:51.180 --> 00:01:55.645
we basically list the email service that
are approved to relay for our domain.

38
00:01:55.645 --> 00:02:00.090
But if you need an email from
the sever that's not in this list

39
00:02:00.090 --> 00:02:01.430
then that's not us.

40
00:02:01.430 --> 00:02:05.450
That's somebody pretending to be us and
it's probably span I can think away.

41
00:02:05.450 --> 00:02:10.300
Right so SPF records let us
influence that is impact and

42
00:02:10.300 --> 00:02:15.980
what SPF record is a text
record a txt just a text record

43
00:02:15.980 --> 00:02:22.620
created inside of your NDS zone That lists
the approved servers for relaying email.

44
00:02:22.620 --> 00:02:24.510
And the way you do it is you
add each one of them in.

45
00:02:24.510 --> 00:02:27.500
And there's these little symbols,

46
00:02:27.500 --> 00:02:30.460
they're called qualifiers
that you put on each one.

47
00:02:30.460 --> 00:02:33.160
So for example, a plus sign.

48
00:02:33.160 --> 00:02:36.130
If there's a server with a plus sign
before it that means it's good,

49
00:02:36.130 --> 00:02:38.340
pass email that you
receive from that system.

50
00:02:38.340 --> 00:02:40.040
That's a good server.

51
00:02:40.040 --> 00:02:42.320
And a minus.

52
00:02:42.320 --> 00:02:43.190
That's bad.

53
00:02:43.190 --> 00:02:46.730
That means fail email from this server.

54
00:02:46.730 --> 00:02:49.490
There's a till right a squiggly line.

55
00:02:49.490 --> 00:02:53.010
The squiggly line that means,
we're not sure.

56
00:02:53.010 --> 00:02:54.950
Maybe it is, maybe it's not.

57
00:02:54.950 --> 00:02:56.630
we'll leave it to your discretion.

58
00:02:56.630 --> 00:02:59.240
So, that's just telling people
that we don't really have

59
00:02:59.240 --> 00:03:00.990
anything necessarily to say on that.

60
00:03:00.990 --> 00:03:03.250
And then it's called a soft fail.

61
00:03:03.250 --> 00:03:07.390
So, we may consider it to be bad,
we may consider it to be good, but

62
00:03:07.390 --> 00:03:09.930
we're not really kinda picking a side.

63
00:03:09.930 --> 00:03:13.870
And then the last was a question mark, and
the question mark is absolutely neutral.

64
00:03:13.870 --> 00:03:17.750
It's the equivalent of not having a record
at all and just saying no comment.

65
00:03:17.750 --> 00:03:23.910
It is like pleading the fifth on it, you
just, I don't have anything to sell off.

66
00:03:23.910 --> 00:03:25.820
And that what the question mark does.

67
00:03:25.820 --> 00:03:28.500
So we build our list of servers,

68
00:03:28.500 --> 00:03:32.180
we all gonna be using those four symbols
to dictate what we are telling people.

69
00:03:32.180 --> 00:03:32.760
Right.

70
00:03:32.760 --> 00:03:36.270
And as peer vacant will be very
simple they can build it small.

71
00:03:36.270 --> 00:03:39.820
Or they can very long depending on
what it is we're trying to provide.

72
00:03:39.820 --> 00:03:43.040
So, in this episode I wanna walk you
through some of the different things that

73
00:03:43.040 --> 00:03:44.970
we can put in there that will
differentiate whether we're gonna have

74
00:03:44.970 --> 00:03:48.320
a short and simple one or a longer one,
or something really crazy complex and

75
00:03:48.320 --> 00:03:52.000
we'll see how to build
that spf record by hand.

76
00:03:52.000 --> 00:03:53.240
All right.
So, let's get started.

77
00:03:54.380 --> 00:03:56.700
First off, let me just show you
an example of an SPF record.

78
00:03:56.700 --> 00:03:59.060
And I'll take ours with ITPro.tv.

79
00:03:59.060 --> 00:04:03.275
So, if I come in and
do a dig of ITPro.tv and

80
00:04:03.275 --> 00:04:07.280
I'm gonna pull txt records, T-X-T.

81
00:04:07.280 --> 00:04:11.100
Remember there isn't, well I shouldn't
say there isn't an SPF record,

82
00:04:11.100 --> 00:04:15.450
there actually is an SPF Not
every DNS server has it.

83
00:04:15.450 --> 00:04:18.650
But in your DNS server,
when you go and create a new record,

84
00:04:18.650 --> 00:04:23.050
you might actually see an option to
create a record type that's called SPF.

85
00:04:23.050 --> 00:04:23.970
All right?

86
00:04:23.970 --> 00:04:26.030
If you do, don't use it.

87
00:04:26.030 --> 00:04:28.920
In the very early days of SPF,

88
00:04:28.920 --> 00:04:34.110
they decided to create a dedicated
record type called SPF.

89
00:04:34.110 --> 00:04:34.810
All right?

90
00:04:34.810 --> 00:04:40.170
And they started to push that out but they
got a lot of resistance from DNS servers,

91
00:04:40.170 --> 00:04:43.910
from the people who write BIND and
Microsoft, their DNS server and

92
00:04:43.910 --> 00:04:47.050
other people, where they didn't
necessarily wanna adopt it right away.

93
00:04:47.050 --> 00:04:50.240
And so, eventually I decided,
you know what?

94
00:04:50.240 --> 00:04:50.950
Let's just not do that.

95
00:04:50.950 --> 00:04:52.960
Let's not have this SPC record anymore.

96
00:04:52.960 --> 00:04:55.400
And instead,
let's just use a regular old text record.

97
00:04:55.400 --> 00:04:57.530
Because everybody supports that right now.

98
00:04:57.530 --> 00:04:59.470
And DNS servers don't have to change.

99
00:04:59.470 --> 00:05:01.030
And so they switched.

100
00:05:01.030 --> 00:05:03.250
And when SPF version one was pushed.

101
00:05:03.250 --> 00:05:05.450
The center policy framework
version one was pushed.

102
00:05:05.450 --> 00:05:07.350
It just used regular TXT records.

103
00:05:07.350 --> 00:05:09.420
So, you will encounter some systems.

104
00:05:09.420 --> 00:05:11.270

00:28:47.493 --> 00:28:50.846
so if you work for
AVISPL.com, my apologies.

554
00:28:50.846 --> 00:28:56.000
[LAUGH] But so it's showing there and
it's saying hey, this is not valid.

555
00:28:56.000 --> 00:28:58.020
If it was failing because
of a corrupt record,

556
00:28:58.020 --> 00:28:59.430
it would tell me that it was corrupt.

557
00:28:59.430 --> 00:29:02.060
And they gave you some basic
information here about what to do.

558
00:29:02.060 --> 00:29:08.170
So it's just kind of an easy way to try
and determine why that's not resolving.

559
00:29:08.170 --> 00:29:11.990
So a simple test right there
on the openspf.org website.

560
00:29:11.990 --> 00:29:13.673
>> We appreciate that, Don, thank you.

561
00:29:13.673 --> 00:29:15.570
And we appreciate you,
the viewer, watching.

562
00:29:15.570 --> 00:29:18.580
We're gonna go ahead and
wrap this one up here at ITProTV.

563
00:29:18.580 --> 00:29:21.110
So signing out,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

564
00:29:21.110 --> 00:29:21.790
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

565
00:29:21.790 --> 00:29:23.158
>> And we'll see you next time.

566
00:29:23.158 --> 00:29:30.170
[MUSIC]

567
00:29:30.170 --> 00:29:33.074
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don discuss some of the important considerations when purchasing a domain for your company. They explain registrars as well as giving examples of popular domain registrars. They will also examine the records associated with a domain purchase such as registration, owner, administrator, and billing records. They also demonstrate using the ICANN WHOIS Lookup to verify the domain information and records.
episodes.title: Purchasing a Domain
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:04.393
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:04.393 --> 00:00:06.867
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.867 --> 00:00:08.286
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.286 --> 00:00:12.088
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.088 --> 00:00:14.544
>> Welcome to another
episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.544 --> 00:00:16.020
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and

7
00:00:16.020 --> 00:00:20.040
in today's episode we're continuing
through a very important series, well,

8
00:00:20.040 --> 00:00:23.765
on a service that helps us find just
about everything on the Internet.

9
00:00:23.765 --> 00:00:26.525
Joining us back in the studios today
is none other than Mr Don Pezet.

10
00:00:26.525 --> 00:00:27.635
Don, how are you doing sir?

11
00:00:27.635 --> 00:00:30.815
>> I'm doing great, Wes, ready to jump in
and spend some money on this show today.

12
00:00:30.815 --> 00:00:32.681
That's right, we're gonna make it rain.

13
00:00:32.681 --> 00:00:35.720
[LAUGH] We're gonna tackle
purchasing a domain.

14
00:00:35.720 --> 00:00:38.800
And for a lot of us,
when it comes to public DNS domains,

15
00:00:38.800 --> 00:00:42.030
this is kind of our first step,
is I want to get a domain.

16
00:00:42.030 --> 00:00:44.200
I wonder if it's even available.

17
00:00:44.200 --> 00:00:45.430
Somebody's probably already taken it,

18
00:00:45.430 --> 00:00:47.680
because domain squatting
is a very real problem.

19
00:00:47.680 --> 00:00:50.790
But even if it is available,
how do I go about buying it, right?

20
00:00:50.790 --> 00:00:53.530
What's that first step for
purchasing a domain?

21
00:00:53.530 --> 00:00:57.632
And I do wanna start, I mean, really,
really basic here, is that if I'm gonna go

22
00:00:57.632 --> 00:01:01.511
and buy a domain, decision number one
needs to be, who am I gonna buy it from?

23
00:01:01.511 --> 00:01:03.890
And there's a lot of choices out there.

24
00:01:03.890 --> 00:01:06.770
There's actually thousands of different
places you can go to buy it, and

25
00:01:06.770 --> 00:01:07.730
it's really confusing.

26
00:01:07.730 --> 00:01:11.120
So I wanna start with
the person who's in charge.

27
00:01:11.120 --> 00:01:14.840
And the person who's in charge
is an organization called ICANN.

28
00:01:14.840 --> 00:01:17.959
ICANN is the Internet Company,
or no, Internet Corporation for

29
00:01:17.959 --> 00:01:19.789
[LAUGH] I'm gonna screw this up, Wes.

30
00:01:19.789 --> 00:01:20.790
>> [LAUGH]
>> You got my back on this one?

31
00:01:20.790 --> 00:01:22.835
[LAUGH]
>> I do, it's the Internet Corporation for

32
00:01:22.835 --> 00:01:24.430
Assigned Names and Numbers.

33
00:01:24.430 --> 00:01:25.040
>> There we go.

34
00:01:25.040 --> 00:01:28.470
All right,
now like their name implies, names and

35
00:01:28.470 --> 00:01:29.960
numbers, right there at the end, right?

36
00:01:29.960 --> 00:01:33.200
So names, that's the domain names that
we're talking about in this series, and

37
00:01:33.200 --> 00:01:34.850
numbers, that's IP addresses.

38
00:01:34.850 --> 00:01:36.810
They do the IP addressing also.

39
00:01:36.810 --> 00:01:39.902
And then the Internet Corporation,
that means there's actually

40
00:01:39.902 --> 00:01:42.782
an organization that was put together for
this sole purpose.

41
00:01:42.782 --> 00:01:44.011
And they're a nonprofit,

42
00:01:44.011 --> 00:01:47.280
actually a nonprofit organization
that is just designed to manage DNS.

43
00:01:47.280 --> 00:01:51.380
Now, you don't go to ICANN and
buy a domain name.

44
00:01:51.380 --> 00:01:53.910
Actually I don't think it's even possible,
if you go to ICANN's website,

45
00:01:53.910 --> 00:01:55.098
it's just not there.

46
00:01:55.098 --> 00:01:57.640
But, what ICANN does is,

47
00:01:57.640 --> 00:02:03.260
they then kind of act as gatekeeper to a
system of organizations called registrars.

48
00:02:03.260 --> 00:02:05.870
And registrars are privately owned,

49
00:02:05.870 --> 00:02:12.380
usually for-profit companies that handle
registering your domain name with ICANN.

50
00:02:12.380 --> 00:02:15.900
All ICANN does is maintain
a big fat database,

51
00:02:15.900 --> 00:02:19.720
a database of all the domains that
are out there and who bought the things.

52
00:02:19.720 --> 00:02:24.280
The registrars are the ones who take care
of putting an entry into that database.

53
00:02:24.280 --> 00:02:26.050
And they charge you a fee for it.

54
00:02:26.050 --> 00:02:28.360
In the early days of the Internet,
they actually didn't even charge a fee.

55
00:02:28.360 --> 00:02:30.650
It was free to get a domain name and
you got it your whole life.

56
00:02:30.650 --> 00:02:31.690
That was kinda cool.

57
00:02:31.690 --> 00:02:34.370
Well, that ended pretty quick
as the Internet started to grow.

58
00:02:34.370 --> 00:02:37.539
So now you have to buy one, and when you
buy one, you buy it through a registrar.

59
00:02:37.539 --> 00:02:41.318
Now, if you go to ICANN's website,
I've got it pulled up here,

60
00:02:41.318 --> 00:02:43.340
it's just I-C-A-N-N .org.

61
00:02:43.340 --> 00:02:45.560
They have a registrar report, and

62
00:02:45.560 --> 00:02:48.800
they have their whole
accredited list of registrars.

63
00:02:48.800 --> 00:02:51.435
And I'm not even gonna
begin to run through this.

64
00:02:51.435 --> 00:02:56.520
But if I were to name these off, there are
hundreds of registrars that are out there.

65
00:02:56.520 --> 00:03:01.000
These are all companies that
have gone through the test to be

66
00:03:01.000 --> 00:03:04.820
approved by ICANN and
get listed into the system.

67
00:03:04.820 --> 00:03:07.707
Now you're gonna see
a bunch of dropcatch.com,

68
00:03:07.707 --> 00:03:09.175
see as I kinda scroll through?

69
00:03:09.175 --> 00:03:13.820
Dropcatch, blah, blah, blah, blah,
I don't actually know how many there are,

70
00:03:13.820 --> 00:03:14.760
there's at least 2,000 of them.

71
00:03:14.760 --> 00:03:20.020
So anyhow, there's a bunch of dropcatch,
they do this like a franchise type system.

72
00:03:20.020 --> 00:03:21.930
And every franchise has
its own company name,

73
00:03:21.930 --> 00:03:26.005
see how each one of these is a different
limited liability company or corporation?

74
00:03:26.005 --> 00:03:28.870
So they're all separate
companies with the same name.

75
00:03:28.870 --> 00:03:31.670
But as you look through, you'll see
some names that you do recognize, right?

76
00:03:31.670 --> 00:03:33.400
What are some of the bigger names?

77
00:03:33.400 --> 00:03:37.170
All right, Wes, just off the top of
your head, who would you think of for

78
00:03:37.170 --> 00:03:39.000
registering a domain?

79
00:03:39.000 --> 00:03:39.960
>> Microsoft?

80
00:03:39.960 --> 00:03:41.808
Are you talking about the actual
registrars themselves?

81
00:03:41.808 --> 00:03:43.620
>> Yeah, I wanna go and buy a domain.

82
00:03:43.620 --> 00:03:46.110
>> I think of, what is it, ARIN.

83
00:03:46.110 --> 00:03:50.047
The American Regional Internet
Name Registrar, I believe, ARIN.

84
00:03:50.047 --> 00:03:52.198
>> Right, so A-R-I-N.

85
00:03:52.198 --> 00:03:54.672
They're responsible for
IP addresses but not domain names.

86
00:03:54.672 --> 00:03:55.282
>> Okay, yeah.

87
00:03:55.282 --> 00:03:56.541
>> And they're just responsible for
North America.

88
00:03:56.541 --> 00:03:59.093
It get really confusing cuz
that's under the ICANN envelope.

89
00:03:59.093 --> 00:04:00.271
>> Sure, sure.
Right.

90
00:04:00.271 --> 00:04:01.700
>> But when we buy from a registrar,

91
00:04:01.700 --> 00:04:04.620
these aren't cool organizations
that are all official like that.

92
00:04:04.620 --> 00:04:07.472
These are usually cheesy fly-by-night
companies that just happen to be

93
00:04:07.472 --> 00:04:08.029
registrars.

94
00:04:09.220 --> 00:04:12.889
So, the one I always think of is the one
I see TV commercials for, GoDaddy, right?

95
00:04:12.889 --> 00:04:13.490
>> Absolutely.

96
00:04:13.490 --> 00:04:14.830
>> GoDaddy, they're,

97
00:04:14.830 --> 00:04:18.235
you know what, I'm not gonna comment
on the company itself very much, but.

98
00:04:18.235 --> 00:04:18.840
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

99
00:04:18.840 --> 00:04:20.940
they run a heck of a lot of commercials.

100
00:04:20.940 --> 00:04:23.810
So almost everybody's heard of GoDaddy,
I can find them right here in the list.

101
00:04:23.810 --> 00:04:25.187
And you can go and
you can register with them.

102
00:04:25.187 --> 00:04:28.219
They're not an officially
sanctioned nonprofit organization,

103
00:04:28.219 --> 00:04:31.501
they are a for-profit company that
happens to be a registrar of ICANN.

104
00:04:31.501 --> 00:04:32.700
And you can go and you can buy from them.

105
00:04:32.700 --> 00:04:34.406
I believe, now don't quote me on this, but

106
00:04:34.406 --> 00:04:37.090
I believe they sell more domains
than anyone else on the planet.

107
00:04:37.090 --> 00:04:38.890
That they do sell a ton.

108
00:04:38.890 --> 00:04:41.750
But they're not the only
ones you can go to, right?

109
00:04:41.750 --> 00:04:43.390
If you use Amazon Web Services,

110
00:04:43.390 --> 00:04:48.110
like I do, Amazon actually has
where they can sell domains.

111
00:04:48.110 --> 00:04:48.938
They are a registrar.

112
00:04:48.938 --> 00:04:51.200
They're way up here at the top,
cuz they start with A.

113
00:04:51.200 --> 00:04:54.130
So if we go up here and find them,
old Amazon will be right here in the list.

114
00:04:54.130 --> 00:04:56.753
There it is, the Amazon Registrar,
Incorporated, right?

115
00:04:56.753 --> 00:04:57.930
Now you mentioned Microsoft.

116
00:04:57.930 --> 00:05:00.138
Microsoft, massive IT company.

117
00:05:00.138 --> 00:05:01.820
Obviously, they make Windows.

118
00:05:01.820 --> 00:05:04.530
But does that mean
they're a name registrar?

119
00:05:04.530 --> 00:05:09.091
Not necessarily, but I believe they are,
because through Azure, yep there they are.

120
00:05:09.091 --> 00:05:12.320
So through Microsoft Azure you can
buy domains and they're on there.

121
00:05:12.320 --> 00:05:15.870
But just because they're an IT company
doesn't mean they're a registrar.

122
00:05:15.870 --> 00:05:19.150
So for example, Apple,
I'm just searching for the world Apple and

123
00:05:19.150 --> 00:05:19.860
it doesn't turn up.

124
00:05:19.860 --> 00:05:22.913
Apple sells computers, they have Mac OS,
they have iPhone and all that.

125
00:05:22.913 --> 00:05:24.940
But they don't sell domain names,
that's not their business.

126
00:05:24.940 --> 00:05:28.860
And the reality is, you can go to whoever
the heck you want, and buy a domain.

127
00:05:28.860 --> 00:05:30.550
Anybody in this list right here.

128
00:05:30.550 --> 00:05:33.930
And even people that aren't on the list,
in some cases.

129
00:05:33.930 --> 00:05:36.296
So for example, Media Temple.

130
00:05:36.296 --> 00:05:38.340
I'm just gonna do a search here for
Media Temple real quick.

131
00:05:38.340 --> 00:05:40.600
They don't turn up in the list,
they're not a registrar.

132
00:05:40.600 --> 00:05:42.720
Well if you've never heard of them,
they're a hosting company.

133
00:05:42.720 --> 00:05:46.600
If you need to bring up a server up on the
Internet, you can go to Media Temple and

134
00:05:46.600 --> 00:05:50.890
you can pay for a virtual server or
physical server that's co-located, and

135
00:05:50.890 --> 00:05:52.410
you can run it month after month.

136
00:05:52.410 --> 00:05:54.810
Well, if you need a domain name,
you can buy it from them.

137
00:05:54.810 --> 00:05:56.220
They'll sell you a domain.

138
00:05:56.220 --> 00:05:59.240
But they're just reselling
from one of these people.

139
00:05:59.240 --> 00:06:00.470
When you buy a domain,

140
00:06:00.470 --> 00:06:03.990
ultimately you are buying it from one
of these people right here on the list.

141
00:06:03.990 --> 00:06:04.500
Right?

142
00:06:04.500 --> 00:06:06.200
Now how do I make the choice?

143
00:06:06.200 --> 00:06:08.980
How do I pick which one I'm gonna go with?

144
00:06:08.980 --> 00:06:10.797
Two words of advice here.

145
00:06:10.797 --> 00:06:14.669
One, it's always better to buy from
somebody in this list than to buy it from

146
00:06:14.669 --> 00:06:16.310
somebody reselling.

147
00:06:16.310 --> 00:06:17.750
So, I like Media Temple.

148
00:06:17.750 --> 00:06:19.580
I host several things over there.

149
00:06:19.580 --> 00:06:20.750
The guys over there are great,

150
00:06:20.750 --> 00:06:23.410
their cloud tech support is second
to none, I like Media Temple.

151
00:06:23.410 --> 00:06:25.380
But I won't buy domains from them.

152
00:06:25.380 --> 00:06:28.400
Because when you buy a domain from them,
they're turning around and

153
00:06:28.400 --> 00:06:29.640
buying it from the registrar.

154
00:06:29.640 --> 00:06:31.672
So who owns the domain?

155
00:06:31.672 --> 00:06:32.650
They do.

156
00:06:32.650 --> 00:06:35.130
You don't own the domain, they do.

157
00:06:35.130 --> 00:06:39.320
And so, if they don't pay the bill,
and the domain gets turned back in and

158
00:06:39.320 --> 00:06:41.030
somebody else registers it,
you're out of luck.

159
00:06:41.030 --> 00:06:42.740
Or if you decide you want to
move to another provider,

160
00:06:42.740 --> 00:06:45.100
now you gotta go through the process
of getting it transferred over to you.

161
00:06:45.100 --> 00:06:46.650
That's a challenge, right?

162
00:06:46.650 --> 00:06:51.500
So, I always prefer to have domains
registered to me, so that I own them.

163
00:06:51.500 --> 00:06:52.650
Or that my company, at least,

164
00:06:52.650 --> 00:06:56.590
owns them, not a third party
that's an intermediary, right?

165
00:06:56.590 --> 00:06:59.760
When you register from somebody here in
this list, you know they're accredited,

166
00:06:59.760 --> 00:07:05.409
you know they're authorized through ICANN,
and you know it's tied to you, all right?

167
00:07:06.960 --> 00:07:11.070
Second word of advice is not every
company on this list is created equal.

168
00:07:11.070 --> 00:07:14.460
Some of them are very new, and
you've got over here when they registered.

169
00:07:14.460 --> 00:07:17.450
So you'll notice that a ton of these
things have entries in here that

170
00:07:17.450 --> 00:07:18.590
are all dated.

171
00:07:18.590 --> 00:07:21.040
Or actually, you know what,
that's the RAA version, shoot.

172
00:07:21.040 --> 00:07:22.570
That's not when they registered.

173
00:07:22.570 --> 00:07:24.170
But if you drill into the individual data,

174
00:07:24.170 --> 00:07:26.420
you'll actually see when
they were registered.

175
00:07:26.420 --> 00:07:28.394
And some of them have been in there for
20 years,

176
00:07:28.394 --> 00:07:29.959
others have been in there for one year.

177
00:07:29.959 --> 00:07:32.437
If they've only been in there for
one year and they go out of business,

178
00:07:32.437 --> 00:07:33.420
what's gonna happen?

179
00:07:33.420 --> 00:07:35.048
Well, two things.

180
00:07:35.048 --> 00:07:36.560
One, you actually do keep your domain.

181
00:07:36.560 --> 00:07:40.040
The domain is registered to you,
and it's in ICANN's database, so

182
00:07:40.040 --> 00:07:42.325
it doesn't matter if the registrar
goes out of business.

183
00:07:42.325 --> 00:07:46.225
But, two,
it becomes a real challenge, because

184
00:07:46.225 --> 00:07:49.065
how do you renew your domain if it's stuck
in a company that's out of business?

185
00:07:49.065 --> 00:07:50.305
And how do you transfer it out?

186
00:07:50.305 --> 00:07:53.795
And part of the registrar agreement is
that ICANN can take that back over again,

187
00:07:53.795 --> 00:07:54.845
but it's a hassle.

188
00:07:54.845 --> 00:07:56.314
So you want to deal with
a reputable company.

189
00:07:56.314 --> 00:08:00.138
So I kind of make fun of GoDaddy a little
bit cuz of their cheesy commercials, but

190
00:08:00.138 --> 00:08:01.804
they've been around a long time.

191
00:08:01.804 --> 00:08:03.095
They register more domains
than anybody else.

192
00:08:03.095 --> 00:08:05.678
They're pretty safe to register
from if you wanna go that route.

193
00:08:05.678 --> 00:08:07.305
All right, I don't.

194
00:08:07.305 --> 00:08:10.019
I don't register a single thing with them,
but many people do and there's nothing

195
00:08:10.019 --> 00:08:12.260
wrong with that, but there's other
providers that are out there.

196
00:08:12.260 --> 00:08:15.110
Amazon is probably one of your
safest bets, because they're so

197
00:08:15.110 --> 00:08:17.830
steeped in Internet infrastructure.

198
00:08:17.830 --> 00:08:20.890
Another favorite of mine is Hover.com,
I use Hover a lot.

199
00:08:20.890 --> 00:08:25.180
I use Hover here in the show, not because
they have some amazing technology that

200
00:08:25.180 --> 00:08:28.660
blows everybody away, but because they
have human beings that answer their phone.

201
00:08:28.660 --> 00:08:31.070
That's literally the selling point for
hover.com,

202
00:08:31.070 --> 00:08:33.290
is that if I have
something wrong I can call.

203
00:08:33.290 --> 00:08:37.350
And an actual DNS tech answers the phone
and knows what the heck I'm talking about,

204
00:08:37.350 --> 00:08:39.200
and that's got value to me.

205
00:08:39.200 --> 00:08:40.980
But that's just me,
if you don't value that,

206
00:08:40.980 --> 00:08:43.160
you can certainly find cheaper
prices somewhere else.

207
00:08:43.160 --> 00:08:45.900
GoDaddy probably has some of
the best prices that are out there.

208
00:08:45.900 --> 00:08:50.460
So when it comes down to making that
decision, my main word of advice is,

209
00:08:50.460 --> 00:08:53.440
make sure it's somebody on
ICANN's official registrar list.

210
00:08:53.440 --> 00:08:55.970
Don't buy from a reseller
if you can avoid it.

211
00:08:55.970 --> 00:08:56.980
And then number two,

212
00:08:56.980 --> 00:09:00.700
after that, is look for features and
