00:30:39.790 --> 00:30:42.780
And for those of you who may be wondering
out there that are playing network

661
00:30:42.780 --> 00:30:47.640
trivial pursuit right now, IO, that is
the British Indian Ocean territory.

662
00:30:47.640 --> 00:30:50.290
Apparently they're so
expensive because maybe they've got one or

663
00:30:50.290 --> 00:30:52.280
two DNS servers floating on buoys,
out there.

664
00:30:52.280 --> 00:30:54.570
>> Yeah
>> It's in the Indian Ocean,

665
00:30:54.570 --> 00:30:55.320
that's interesting.

666
00:30:55.320 --> 00:30:56.880
>> Yeah, that's very interesting.

667
00:30:56.880 --> 00:30:58.750
So anyways, for

668
00:30:58.750 --> 00:31:01.310
those of you guys that are sitting
around playing network Trivial Pursuit.

669
00:31:01.310 --> 00:31:04.190
Don, it does look like we're coming to the
end of another episode, but before we do,

670
00:31:04.190 --> 00:31:06.450
when it comes to purchasing domains,
got any tips, tricks,

671
00:31:06.450 --> 00:31:08.370
or maybe just words of advice?

672
00:31:08.370 --> 00:31:10.730
>> You'll probably learn over
the years which providers you like and

673
00:31:10.730 --> 00:31:11.360
which ones you don't.

674
00:31:11.360 --> 00:31:13.420
Some of them are really great,
some not so much.

675
00:31:13.420 --> 00:31:15.660
Network Solutions,
I probably should have mentioned them.

676
00:31:15.660 --> 00:31:17.620
There's a lot of people
out there who are diehard.

677
00:31:17.620 --> 00:31:21.250
They say, I'm gonna register with Network
Solutions cause they're the ones who run

678
00:31:21.250 --> 00:31:22.690
the domain naming system.

679
00:31:22.690 --> 00:31:26.010
That was true 15 years ago,
it's not true today.

680
00:31:26.010 --> 00:31:30.298
So back in the early days when ICANN
first started to do paid registrations,

681
00:31:30.298 --> 00:31:32.911
they gave the contract
to Network Solutions.

682
00:31:32.911 --> 00:31:36.681
And so NetSolve, they had the exclusive
contract form the beginning, so for

683
00:31:36.681 --> 00:31:40.180
a period of five or six years,
yes, they were the head honchos.

684
00:31:40.180 --> 00:31:43.430
Now they're just like any other registrar
out there, so they're not really special.

685
00:31:43.430 --> 00:31:46.390
So if you're still clinging to that one,
don't let that be your hold up.

686
00:31:46.390 --> 00:31:48.070
But also remember that
you can easily switch.

687
00:31:48.070 --> 00:31:51.140
If you want to move to a different
provider, that one's out there too.

688
00:31:51.140 --> 00:31:52.520
It's easy enough to move along.

689
00:31:52.520 --> 00:31:54.410
Well Don,
we appreciate that great information.

690
00:31:54.410 --> 00:31:56.140
We appreciate you, the viewer, watching.

691
00:31:56.140 --> 00:31:59.450
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

692
00:31:59.450 --> 00:32:00.180
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

693
00:32:00.180 --> 00:32:01.615
>> And we'll see you next time.

694
00:32:01.615 --> 00:32:08.843
[MUSIC]

695
00:32:08.843 --> 00:32:10.230
>> Thank you for watching.

696
00:32:10.230 --> 00:32:12.026
ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explain the task of changing the DNS server or servers that are authoritative for a domain. They demonstrate the process as well as discuss DNS NS records.
episodes.title: Changing Name Servers
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:07.394
Welcome to ITProTV, I"m your host-
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:07.394 --> 00:00:08.188
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.188 --> 00:00:11.988
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.988 --> 00:00:16.176
>> Welcome to another great episode here
at ITProTV, I'm your host Wes Bryan.

5
00:00:16.176 --> 00:00:20.009
And in today's episode, we're continuing
through our series and probably one of

6
00:00:20.009 --> 00:00:23.470
the most important services on
the Internet today and that is DNS.

7
00:00:23.470 --> 00:00:26.480
Joining us back in the studios for
this very endeavor is none other than Mr.

8
00:00:26.480 --> 00:00:27.030
Don Pezet.

9
00:00:27.030 --> 00:00:28.010
Don, how are you doing, sir?

10
00:00:28.010 --> 00:00:28.740
>> I'm doing great, Wes,

11
00:00:28.740 --> 00:00:31.430
ready to dive right back into
the wonderful world of DNS.

12
00:00:31.430 --> 00:00:34.180
In fact, you mentioned how
important this service is, so

13
00:00:34.180 --> 00:00:36.340
let's take a look at how
we can really screw it up.

14
00:00:36.340 --> 00:00:39.260
[LAUGH] So,
I wanna take a look at in this episode

15
00:00:39.260 --> 00:00:42.550
is how to change our DNS server and
if you're watching these in order,

16
00:00:42.550 --> 00:00:46.130
in our last episode we saw how we
can go and register a domain name.

17
00:00:46.130 --> 00:00:47.740
And now that we've got it,

18
00:00:47.740 --> 00:00:50.640
we need to tell it where we're
gonna store all of our records.

19
00:00:50.640 --> 00:00:54.740
Now every provider out there that
I've ever worked with, when you go to

20
00:00:54.740 --> 00:01:00.060
the registrar and buy the domain, they
always offer to host the domain for you.

21
00:01:00.060 --> 00:01:03.080
So if I register
the domain with hover.com,

22
00:01:03.080 --> 00:01:07.140
they'll host the DNS domain for me, so
I can put records there and off I go.

23
00:01:07.140 --> 00:01:10.930
Same thing with Amazon's Route 53,
and GoDaddy, and Register.com, and

24
00:01:10.930 --> 00:01:13.090
everybody else that you
might use out there.

25
00:01:13.090 --> 00:01:14.490
That's all part of their service, right?

26
00:01:14.490 --> 00:01:15.450
It's part of what you pay for.

27
00:01:16.510 --> 00:01:20.260
But just because they offer you the
service doesn't mean you have to use it,

28
00:01:20.260 --> 00:01:21.970
or even want to use it in some scenarios.

29
00:01:21.970 --> 00:01:23.900
It might not work out for you.

30
00:01:23.900 --> 00:01:27.530
So let me show you kinda what's involved
with that, and how we can adjust that.

31
00:01:27.530 --> 00:01:28.910
The key thing to remember here, and

32
00:01:28.910 --> 00:01:33.670
this something a lot of people don't think
about, is where you register the domain

33
00:01:33.670 --> 00:01:38.970
and where you host the domain
don't have to be the same thing.

34
00:01:38.970 --> 00:01:41.180
The registrar's job is very simple.

35
00:01:41.180 --> 00:01:45.760
They put a database entry in
the ICAN database, that's it.

36
00:01:45.760 --> 00:01:49.030
After they've done that, you really
don't need the registrar anymore.

37
00:01:49.030 --> 00:01:50.303
You just need them once a year, or

38
00:01:50.303 --> 00:01:52.620
every couple of years depending
on how much you pay, to go and

39
00:01:52.620 --> 00:01:55.674
make sure your database entries are up
to date, that's all you need them to do.

40
00:01:55.674 --> 00:01:58.369
You don't need them to
host the records for you,

41
00:01:58.369 --> 00:02:01.100
you can host them anywhere you want.

42
00:02:01.100 --> 00:02:03.380
All right, so
what do I mean when I say that?

43
00:02:03.380 --> 00:02:06.600
Well, let's start with Amazon, right?

44
00:02:06.600 --> 00:02:10.540
So in the last episode,
I bought itprotvdemo.net.

45
00:02:10.540 --> 00:02:13.660
And I bought it through Amazon,
through Route53.

46
00:02:13.660 --> 00:02:16.260
And so
it's now a HostedZone with Route53 and

47
00:02:16.260 --> 00:02:19.960
they've got it sitting right here,
itprotvdemo.net, okay?

48
00:02:19.960 --> 00:02:23.405
And it even says right here,
HostedZone created by Route53 Registrar.

49
00:02:23.405 --> 00:02:26.594
I bought it from them, registered it
with them and now, it's stored and

50
00:02:26.594 --> 00:02:28.030
hosted by them.

51
00:02:28.030 --> 00:02:32.089
And if I click on that ITPro.TV demo,
I can see my record set and

52
00:02:32.089 --> 00:02:34.704
there's already some records in here.

53
00:02:34.704 --> 00:02:37.580
Not many but two, right?

54
00:02:37.580 --> 00:02:40.140
And these records each
serve an important purpose.

55
00:02:40.140 --> 00:02:43.390
This bottom one I don't really
want to mess with it, right?

56
00:02:43.390 --> 00:02:44.890
This is my start of authority.

57
00:02:44.890 --> 00:02:48.090
The start of authority is who
is it that's responsible for

58
00:02:48.090 --> 00:02:50.280
answering questions about this domain?

59
00:02:50.280 --> 00:02:52.920
And typically,
that is going to be your registrar.

60
00:02:52.920 --> 00:02:58.452
Notice mine is set to
ns-648.awsdns-17.net and so on, right?

61
00:02:58.452 --> 00:03:00.970
So that's what it's set to.

62
00:03:00.970 --> 00:03:05.180
I could override that and point my
start of authority somewhere else.

63
00:03:05.180 --> 00:03:07.590
But that can cause some problems
when the registrar is right here.

64
00:03:07.590 --> 00:03:10.160
So we don't normally
dink with that too much.

65
00:03:10.160 --> 00:03:15.080
But the one above it, NS,
those are my nameserver records.

66
00:03:15.080 --> 00:03:19.479
When I go to actually look for
an a record, a c name, mx records,

67
00:03:19.479 --> 00:03:23.877
all the other records we store in DNS,
these are the servers that

68
00:03:23.877 --> 00:03:28.870
are allowed to give an authoritative
response about those names to IPs.

69
00:03:28.870 --> 00:03:31.712
Or if it's a reverse lookup zone,
it would be IPs to names, right?

70
00:03:31.712 --> 00:03:33.668
But these are the nameservers
that are responsible for it.

71
00:03:33.668 --> 00:03:38.935
Then they've got four,
ns-648.awsdns-17.net.

72
00:03:38.935 --> 00:03:42.330
There's a .org, a .co.uk, and a .com.

73
00:03:42.330 --> 00:03:44.320
Why the different top level domains?

74
00:03:44.320 --> 00:03:45.250
Redundancy.

75
00:03:45.250 --> 00:03:47.800
If one of them goes down,
I can switch over to another.

76
00:03:47.800 --> 00:03:51.219
Each top level domain is handled
by different registrars.

77
00:03:51.219 --> 00:03:53.162
And so that gives me redundancy and

78
00:03:53.162 --> 00:03:57.525
reliability across these different ones
in the event one were to go offline.

79
00:03:57.525 --> 00:03:58.984
I can change these.

80
00:03:58.984 --> 00:04:01.640
I could change these to
point wherever I want.

81
00:04:01.640 --> 00:04:04.710
Maybe I have my own DNS server somewhere.

82
00:04:04.710 --> 00:04:06.440
And I want to go and point those there.

83
00:04:06.440 --> 00:04:09.730
So for example if I go into EC2,

84
00:04:09.730 --> 00:04:14.150
I actually do have a couple
of DNS servers sitting here.

85
00:04:14.150 --> 00:04:19.170
So I can switch over and
I've got these DNS servers that I parked.

86
00:04:19.170 --> 00:04:23.137
One's a Red Hat Linux box, the other
one's a Microsoft Windows box and

87
00:04:23.137 --> 00:04:25.916
I've got these two, dns2.lab.itpro.tv and

88
00:04:25.916 --> 00:04:29.680
dns1.lab.itpro.tv and
they're kinda sitting there.

89
00:04:29.680 --> 00:04:34.570
And if I look over here, somewhere, I can
find out what their IP addresses are.

90
00:04:34.570 --> 00:04:35.740
It's actually down here at the bottom.

91
00:04:36.820 --> 00:04:39.460
Hidden away,
way down here at the bottom of the screen.

92
00:04:39.460 --> 00:04:41.500
I can find out what their
IP addresses are and

93
00:04:41.500 --> 00:04:44.350
if they've got a name that's able to
be looked up and I've got that too.

94
00:04:44.350 --> 00:04:46.510
So I can come in and I can find these and
I could say, you know what?

95
00:04:46.510 --> 00:04:50.950
Those are my DNS servers,
I wanna host the zone myself.

96
00:04:50.950 --> 00:04:51.810
I've got some DNS servers,

97
00:04:51.810 --> 00:04:55.040
I've got it set up, I've got the zone
created, that's where I want people to go.

98
00:04:55.040 --> 00:04:57.340
I don't want them to go to Amazon,
I don't want them to go to Hover.

99
00:04:57.340 --> 00:04:59.130
I want them to go right here.

100
00:04:59.130 --> 00:05:05.330
So all I have to do is go up to my zone
and I'll switch back over to Route 53.

101
00:05:05.330 --> 00:05:08.002
And go into my zone, and in the zone,

102
00:05:08.002 --> 00:05:11.900
I can change those nameservers and
I can modify them.

103
00:05:11.900 --> 00:05:17.420
And so over here on the right side, I'll
see the nameservers and I can change them.

104
00:05:17.420 --> 00:05:20.420
Now, when I go to specify it,
I can take what's in there and

105
00:05:20.420 --> 00:05:22.880
just delete them out and
change it to my own.

106
00:05:22.880 --> 00:05:25.000
They give some examples down here but
these are just kinda fake.

107
00:05:25.000 --> 00:05:27.300
You're supposed to use the ones
that are already in there.

108
00:05:27.300 --> 00:05:28.750
So I can come in and

109
00:05:28.750 --> 00:05:33.750
I can change in that way or I can just
leave them the way they are, right?

110
00:05:33.750 --> 00:05:36.330
But the whole point here is
that I do wanna change them.

111
00:05:36.330 --> 00:05:41.861
So I can just take these out and
I can put in dns1.lab.itpro.tv and

112
00:05:41.861 --> 00:05:44.820
dns2.lab.itpro.tv.

113
00:05:44.820 --> 00:05:47.460
If I don't like doing domain names,
I can do IP addresses.

114
00:05:47.460 --> 00:05:51.030
But domain names are nicer in case the IPs
change, these'll resolve to it, but

115
00:05:51.030 --> 00:05:52.533
it's up to me how I wanna do that.

116
00:05:52.533 --> 00:05:57.710
Now when I change that,
it's not gonna take effect right away.

117
00:05:57.710 --> 00:05:59.730
Notice my time to live.

118
00:05:59.730 --> 00:06:02.060
Every record in DNS has a TTL.

119
00:06:02.060 --> 00:06:05.240
And the time to live is
how long these record's

120
00:06:05.240 --> 00:06:08.052
allowed to be cached somewhere else.

121
00:06:08.052 --> 00:06:11.530
And nameserver records
are guaranteed to be cached

122
00:06:11.530 --> 00:06:15.640
anytime somebody performs a lookup for
any record inside of the domain.

123
00:06:15.640 --> 00:06:17.752
That means the odds are these are cached.

124
00:06:17.752 --> 00:06:21.332
And look at that time to live, 172800.

125
00:06:21.332 --> 00:06:23.520
These records don't change very often.

126
00:06:23.520 --> 00:06:27.480
And so
Amazon is defaulted to a really big timer.

127
00:06:27.480 --> 00:06:29.220
So if I were to figure that out,

128
00:06:29.220 --> 00:06:32.630
I actually have no idea what
that works out to in time.

129
00:06:32.630 --> 00:06:36.678
So let's divide that by 60,
so that's 2,880 hours.

130
00:06:36.678 --> 00:06:38.955
And let's divide that by 24.

131
00:06:38.955 --> 00:06:41.579
120 days, that can't be right.

132
00:06:41.579 --> 00:06:43.649
I must've done bad math there, right?

133
00:06:43.649 --> 00:06:46.310
Help me out, Wes,
is that bad math or was that good?

134
00:06:46.310 --> 00:06:47.160
>> I think that was right on.

135
00:06:47.160 --> 00:06:48.288
That's what I've got.
I've got 288-

136
00:06:48.288 --> 00:06:50.710
>> [CROSSTALK] Sorry, these are seconds.

137
00:06:50.710 --> 00:06:51.879
>> Seconds, not minutes.

138
00:06:51.879 --> 00:06:55.040
>> So I convert it to minutes, and
then I need to convert to hours.

139
00:06:55.040 --> 00:06:57.470
And then,
I can divide that out into two days.

140
00:06:57.470 --> 00:06:58.840
All right,
that's more realistic, two days.

141
00:06:58.840 --> 00:06:59.790
>> Shows you how good my math is.

142
00:06:59.790 --> 00:07:02.740
>> I know, so, all right, so two days.

143
00:07:02.740 --> 00:07:08.490
So this NS record could be cached on
other DNS servers around the planet for

144
00:07:08.490 --> 00:07:09.490
up to two days.

145
00:07:09.490 --> 00:07:12.880
So when I make this change,
some people might see it right away.

146
00:07:12.880 --> 00:07:14.697
Other people might see
it 48 hours from now.

147
00:07:14.697 --> 00:07:15.970
Two days later.

148
00:07:15.970 --> 00:07:18.350
So I need to be prepared for that.

149
00:07:18.350 --> 00:07:23.520
When you change this, I need to
go to dns1 and dns2.lab.itpro.tv.

150
00:07:23.520 --> 00:07:28.582
And I need to create ITProTVdemo.net.

151
00:07:28.582 --> 00:07:30.630
I need to create that zone.

152
00:07:30.630 --> 00:07:35.520
And then once the zone is created, I need
to take all my a records and c names and

153
00:07:35.520 --> 00:07:38.580
all of the other things that I've created,
and put them in the new zones.

154
00:07:38.580 --> 00:07:41.370
And I need these two to be identical.

155
00:07:41.370 --> 00:07:45.790
I need to have the same records here on my
current registrar that I have on my new

156
00:07:45.790 --> 00:07:47.354
one, my new nameservers.

157
00:07:47.354 --> 00:07:50.120
If this is a brand new domain,
nothing to move over.

158
00:07:50.120 --> 00:07:50.920
What do I care, right?

159
00:07:50.920 --> 00:07:52.106
Mine's empty.

160
00:07:52.106 --> 00:07:54.325
But what if this was a production domain?

161
00:07:54.325 --> 00:07:56.425
What if I already had stuff going?

162
00:07:56.425 --> 00:07:58.685
Well, let me show you how
that process would work.

163
00:07:58.685 --> 00:08:01.640
Now I'm gonna leave this one be,
cuz it's sitting right here.

164
00:08:01.640 --> 00:08:04.090
So I'm not gonna mess with that.

165
00:08:04.090 --> 00:08:06.790
But let me go over to hover.

166
00:08:06.790 --> 00:08:10.560
And on hover,
I have itprotvdemo.com right?

167
00:08:10.560 --> 00:08:11.900
So I purchase that.

168
00:08:11.900 --> 00:08:14.261
And if I go to the DNS
records I can look at it, and

169
00:08:14.261 --> 00:08:16.160
I actually do have some entries here.

170
00:08:16.160 --> 00:08:21.626
I've got mail1, mail2, I got a client
in place, I've got some MX records,

171
00:08:21.626 --> 00:08:26.600
www, I've got all sorts of
entries that are over here, okay?

172
00:08:26.600 --> 00:08:31.130
And I decide that, hey,
I don't wanna use Hover as my DNS server.

173
00:08:31.130 --> 00:08:32.479
Now, why would I choose that?

174
00:08:32.479 --> 00:08:34.095
I like the company, and
I'm happy with them,

175
00:08:34.095 --> 00:08:36.110
why wouldn't I want to use
them as my DNS server?

176
00:08:36.110 --> 00:08:38.480
Well, there's some things
they don't support.

177
00:08:38.480 --> 00:08:42.404
So for example, if I wanna do subdomains,
I've got ITProTVdemo.com.

178
00:08:42.404 --> 00:08:47.230
I want to create lab.ITProTVDemo.com,
and I wanna put stuff inside of the lab.

179
00:08:47.230 --> 00:08:50.790
Well, I can't do that,
they don't let you create subdomains.

180
00:08:50.790 --> 00:08:53.570
You can create individual
records that are in a subdomain.

181
00:08:53.570 --> 00:08:56.200
But I can't actually
create a subdomain folder.

182
00:08:56.200 --> 00:08:58.590
Which means I can't redirect
a subdomain anywhere.

183
00:08:58.590 --> 00:08:59.937
I can only redirect host names.

184
00:08:59.937 --> 00:09:02.040
So that's a limitation.

185
00:09:02.040 --> 00:09:05.720
I'm getting it as part of their service,
kind of just as an add on benefit so

186
00:09:05.720 --> 00:09:07.230
I can't complain.

187
00:09:07.230 --> 00:09:09.370
But it's not as robust
as what I might want.

188
00:09:09.370 --> 00:09:12.270
Or maybe I want to use this for
an active directory and

189
00:09:12.270 --> 00:09:16.610
I want to have dynamic DNS registration

delete the old stuff out.

414
00:20:36.130 --> 00:20:37.590
Normally I would wait.

415
00:20:38.930 --> 00:20:40.630
There It updated, right?

416
00:20:40.630 --> 00:20:43.935
So just a moment ago, you guys saw where
I did the look up and it was the old IP.

417
00:20:43.935 --> 00:20:47.710
Now I did the look up, same exact look up,
same exact server, and I got the new IP.

418
00:20:47.710 --> 00:20:49.840
The time to live expired,
I got lucky on this one.

419
00:20:49.840 --> 00:20:55.013
So now that I know that, over here on
Hover I can go under DNS and I can take

420
00:20:55.013 --> 00:21:00.375
all these records that are created
in here, I'm just gonna delete them.

421
00:21:00.375 --> 00:21:01.620
I'm gonna delete them all.

422
00:21:01.620 --> 00:21:05.440
Really you just need an NS record and
an SOA and

423
00:21:05.440 --> 00:21:07.910
Hover won't let me delete those,
they don't even show up here.

424
00:21:07.910 --> 00:21:08.790
So, I am just going to go through and

425
00:21:08.790 --> 00:21:12.900
delete these you can even reset
them to default if you want.

426
00:21:12.900 --> 00:21:16.413
And that's another great way to just
kinda purge this and reset them.

427
00:21:16.413 --> 00:21:19.320
And so now they all start to go away, but
then it kinda put some dummy records in.

428
00:21:19.320 --> 00:21:21.820
So, you might want to get rid of those too
I'm just going to toast all of this stuff.

429
00:21:22.910 --> 00:21:25.825
And that way if anybody
comes along behind me,

430
00:21:25.825 --> 00:21:28.978
they're going to come in here and
see no records.

431
00:21:28.978 --> 00:21:30.670
That doesn't make any sense.

432
00:21:30.670 --> 00:21:31.660
There's no records.

00:21:31.660 --> 00:21:36.280
And then if you go to the domain details,
they'll notice, I see.

434
00:21:36.280 --> 00:21:38.120
It's all pointing to Amazon, right?

435
00:21:38.120 --> 00:21:39.240
So that's where I need to go.

436
00:21:39.240 --> 00:21:43.175
And if they go over to Amazon and log in,
assuming they have access, they come into

437
00:21:43.175 --> 00:21:47.780
ITProTVdemo.com, and there's all
the records laid out right there, okay?

438
00:21:47.780 --> 00:21:52.310
So in this scenario,
I'm still hosted by hover.com.

439
00:21:52.310 --> 00:21:55.830
That's where I registered, that's where

440
00:21:55.830 --> 00:21:59.302
If I have problems with my domain I might
call them up, but usually you don't have

441
00:21:59.302 --> 00:22:03.160
problems with a registration beyond
maybe needing to transfer it out.

442
00:22:03.160 --> 00:22:07.220
But I support it on my own DNS servers or

443
00:22:07.220 --> 00:22:11.340
in this case route 53 in Amazon and
now I can start to create sub domains.

444
00:22:11.340 --> 00:22:13.470
If I want a sub domain I can create one.

445
00:22:13.470 --> 00:22:16.690
Because Route 53 supports it,
Hover didn't, right?

446
00:22:16.690 --> 00:22:19.180
So now I get that functionality and
I can go that way.

447
00:22:19.180 --> 00:22:20.520
But I didn't have to transfer it out.

448
00:22:20.520 --> 00:22:22.650
Doesn't mean that we never
wanna transfer it out.

449
00:22:22.650 --> 00:22:25.180
There are some scenarios
where we might want to.

450
00:22:25.180 --> 00:22:27.390
Maybe I just like having
everything in one place.

451
00:22:27.390 --> 00:22:31.160
I don't like the idea of having to go and
pay a bill over at Hover and now I gotta

452
00:22:31.160 --> 00:22:34.220
come and pay a bill over here at Amazon,
let's just roll it all into one thing.

453
00:22:34.220 --> 00:22:35.620
It's one less bill on the table, right?

454
00:22:35.620 --> 00:22:38.500
It's not a lot of money, so
let's just make it easier.

455
00:22:38.500 --> 00:22:42.460
In that case, I might wanna transfer my
domain from one registrar to another.

456
00:22:42.460 --> 00:22:44.550
But if I just wanna use
different DNS servers,

457
00:22:44.550 --> 00:22:46.170
it's as easy as changing those NS records.

458
00:22:46.170 --> 00:22:50.271
And it's all knocked down,
so pretty straightforward.

459
00:22:50.271 --> 00:22:52.919
I'm trying to think if I
left anything out on this.

460
00:22:52.919 --> 00:22:56.800
Do you remember that manually creating
the records is kind of a pain?

461
00:22:56.800 --> 00:23:00.610
So it is faster to just call in and
ask for a copy of your zone files.

462
00:23:00.610 --> 00:23:01.671
They'll email it right to you.

463
00:23:01.671 --> 00:23:05.549
Your zone files, there's no sensitive
data in them and it's public information

464
00:23:05.549 --> 00:23:08.990
because it's a stinking zone file
anybody can look up against it right.

465
00:23:08.990 --> 00:23:12.950
So it's public info they'll give
it to you they'll email it to you.

466
00:23:12.950 --> 00:23:15.800
They don't have to encrypt it or
anything cuz again it's public info.

467
00:23:15.800 --> 00:23:17.670
So they just email it
to you as a text file.

468
00:23:17.670 --> 00:23:21.180
It's in a standard format,
we'll see it when we do the bind episodes.

469
00:23:21.180 --> 00:23:24.360
And you can just go to your other
provider and import it right in.

470
00:23:24.360 --> 00:23:28.980
Doesn't matter if it's Unix bind, if
it's unbound, if it's Amazon's route 53,

471
00:23:28.980 --> 00:23:32.750
if it's Microsoft's DNS, they can all
import the standard text files, and

472
00:23:32.750 --> 00:23:34.310
they can all export
the standard text files.

473
00:23:34.310 --> 00:23:36.890
So that makes it easy to
move all your records.

474
00:23:36.890 --> 00:23:39.340
The hard part is moving
the actual registration.

475
00:23:39.340 --> 00:23:41.070
And so
we're gonna do a separate episode on that,

476
00:23:41.070 --> 00:23:44.660
actually transferring a domain
from one registrar to another.

477
00:23:44.660 --> 00:23:48.758
And that's what we would do normally if
we bought a domain from somebody else, or

478
00:23:48.758 --> 00:23:50.642
if we were just changing ownership.

479
00:23:50.642 --> 00:23:53.750
Maybe I registered a domain, but
I want the company to own it, so

480
00:23:53.750 --> 00:23:55.890
I'm gonna transfer it over to the company.

481
00:23:55.890 --> 00:23:58.707
That kind of stuff is where we end up
usually moving things around between

482
00:23:58.707 --> 00:23:59.270
registrars.

483
00:23:59.270 --> 00:24:01.183
It's a little bit of an involved process,
though, so

484
00:24:01.183 --> 00:24:02.770
we'll do that in a separate episode.

485

>> I definitely call you on that one, cuz

>> [LAUGH]
>> And he didn't,

so we're gonna hold him to that.

489
00:24:08.918 --> 00:24:11.530
But joking aside, Don, great episode here.

490
00:24:11.530 --> 00:24:14.280
Does look like we're coming to
the end of another great episode.

491
00:24:14.280 --> 00:24:16.958
But before we do, do you have any parting
words on changing name servers and

492
00:24:16.958 --> 00:24:18.162
maybe the complexity behind it?

493
00:24:18.162 --> 00:24:20.760
>> Yeah.
Well, I mean, the break it part, right?

494
00:24:20.760 --> 00:24:26.010
If I had changed the NS records
prior to populating all those fields

495
00:24:26.010 --> 00:24:27.360
I would've broke it.

496
00:24:27.360 --> 00:24:29.150
So you gotta make sure you do that.

497
00:24:29.150 --> 00:24:32.437
And then if I had deleted the old
records prior to waiting for

498
00:24:32.437 --> 00:24:35.477
everybody's caches to purge,
I would've broke it.

499
00:24:35.477 --> 00:24:38.020
So there's multiple
opportunities to break it.

500
00:24:38.020 --> 00:24:39.170
And it's nothing you couldn't fix.

501
00:24:39.170 --> 00:24:41.190
It's easy enough to go back.

502
00:24:41.190 --> 00:24:43.580
But the problem is that time to live.

503
00:24:43.580 --> 00:24:48.087
And so you could break it and it would be

504
00:24:48.087 --> 00:24:52.360
Most companies can't stand for
a two day outage like that.

505
00:24:52.360 --> 00:24:53.646
So you don't want that to happen.

506
00:24:53.646 --> 00:24:55.319
You definitely don't want
it to be your fault, right?

507
00:24:55.319 --> 00:24:57.051
If it happens that's a different story,
but

508
00:24:57.051 --> 00:24:59.330
if it's your fault that's
a whole new ball field.

509
00:24:59.330 --> 00:25:02.370
So you don't want that to happen,
but there are opportunities,

510
00:25:02.370 --> 00:25:05.590
easy to avoid if you just take your time,
follow the procedure in order.

511
00:25:05.590 --> 00:25:09.490
>> Standard operating procedure, Don, we
appreciate you being in the studios here

with us, and

Signing out for ITPro.TV,

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:08.404
Welcome to ITPRO.TV I am
your host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:08.404 --> 00:00:12.102
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:12.102 --> 00:00:14.996
>> Welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:14.996 --> 00:00:16.414
I am you host Wes Bryan.

5
00:00:16.414 --> 00:00:19.950
And in today's episode,
we're continuing through our track on DNS.

6
00:00:19.950 --> 00:00:23.298
That's right, a very important service
that we need to find just about anything

7
00:00:23.298 --> 00:00:24.441
on the Internet out there.

8
00:00:24.441 --> 00:00:27.612
And joining us back in the studios for
this topic is none other than Mr.

9
00:00:27.612 --> 00:00:28.161
Don Pezet.

10
00:00:28.161 --> 00:00:28.971
Don, how are you doing, sir?

11
00:00:28.971 --> 00:00:31.520
>> I'm doing just swell,
Wes, ready to dive right in.

12
00:00:31.520 --> 00:00:35.843
In this episode, we're going to take a
look at how to transfer a domain from one

13
00:00:35.843 --> 00:00:37.428
registrar over to another.

14
00:00:37.428 --> 00:00:41.357
So if you've been watching this series,
I have a domain,

15
00:00:41.357 --> 00:00:44.840
itprotvdemo.com, that
I bought on hover.com.

16
00:00:44.840 --> 00:00:49.869
And now, I've got itprotvdemo.net that I
bought on Route 53 with Amazon, right?

17
00:00:49.869 --> 00:00:51.455
Well, that's fine.

18
00:00:51.455 --> 00:00:52.110
I can leave it that way.

19
00:00:52.110 --> 00:00:54.307
Both services are perfectly good.

20
00:00:54.307 --> 00:00:56.800
I know there's some
limitations to Hover's DNS.

21
00:00:56.800 --> 00:01:01.153
So in, in another episode, we move the DNS
servers from Hover over to Route 53.

22
00:01:01.153 --> 00:01:05.580
So both of my zones are actually
being controlled by Route 53.

23
00:01:05.580 --> 00:01:10.337
But the actual registration for
itprotv.com is still sitting over on

24
00:01:10.337 --> 00:01:14.215
Hover, and maybe I want that,
maybe I don't want that.

25
00:01:14.215 --> 00:01:17.493
Maybe I want to transfer
from Hover over to Amazon or

26
00:01:17.493 --> 00:01:20.580
the other way around from
Amazon over to Hover.

27
00:01:20.580 --> 00:01:23.941
By doing a transfer like that,
I can set it so,

28
00:01:23.941 --> 00:01:27.749
that my zones are all managed
by the same registrar.

29
00:01:27.749 --> 00:01:30.602
And that's a pretty handy thing to have
everybody kinda registered in one place.

30
00:01:30.602 --> 00:01:34.182
It makes it easier to tracking domains
are expiring and to minimize and

31
00:01:34.182 --> 00:01:35.958
simplify billing.

32
00:01:35.958 --> 00:01:39.798
Another scenario where I might transfer
domain is where somebody already has

33
00:01:39.798 --> 00:01:40.750
the domain I want.

34
00:01:40.750 --> 00:01:43.987
And so I make them an offer,
an offer they can't refuse.

35
00:01:43.987 --> 00:01:46.630
And you pay them some money, whatever
it is and they sell you the domain.

36
00:01:46.630 --> 00:01:49.330
Now they need to transfer
the domain from them to you, and so

37
00:01:49.330 --> 00:01:52.361
there's a process you have to go
through to transfer that domain.

38
00:01:52.361 --> 00:01:57.538
Now, there has been a huge upsurge
in fraudulent domain transfers,

39
00:01:57.538 --> 00:02:00.940
where people try and steal your domain.

40
00:02:00.940 --> 00:02:03.824
And that can be really bad because
it takes a long time to fix and

41
00:02:03.824 --> 00:02:07.711
the whole time you're waiting for it, your
site is now being redirected somewhere

42
00:02:07.711 --> 00:02:10.394
that you don't control and
that's really bad, right?

43
00:02:10.394 --> 00:02:12.300
You'll lose email,
you'll lose website access.

44
00:02:12.300 --> 00:02:13.777
It's not a good thing.

45
00:02:13.777 --> 00:02:18.325
So all of the DNS hosting providers
out there have implemented security

46
00:02:18.325 --> 00:02:22.796
procedures to make sure that everything
is nice and safe and stable and

47
00:02:22.796 --> 00:02:25.249
kind of difficult to transfer it out.

48
00:02:25.249 --> 00:02:29.777
[LAUGH] So it's not exactly an easy task
to move a registration from one registrar

49
00:02:29.777 --> 00:02:32.220
to another, but it certainly can be done.

50
00:02:32.220 --> 00:02:36.145
Because at the end of the day, all the
registrar does is reach out to Ican and

51
00:02:36.145 --> 00:02:38.156
add a little entry in their database.

52
00:02:38.156 --> 00:02:40.788
And so when you transfer from
one registrar to another,

53
00:02:40.788 --> 00:02:44.330
you're just putting someone else
in charge of your database entry.

54
00:02:44.330 --> 00:02:48.626
Your database entry itself, stays in
there regardless who it's tied too,

55
00:02:48.626 --> 00:02:51.119
registrar wise and continues to function.

56
00:02:51.119 --> 00:02:52.890
So let's see how we want
to transfer things.

57
00:02:52.890 --> 00:02:56.932
So for me, I've got a zone,
well, I've got two zones.

58
00:02:56.932 --> 00:03:02.247
One zone, itprotvdemo.net,
I just bought on Amazon today,

59
00:03:02.247 --> 00:03:05.165
so it's still in the hold period.

60
00:03:05.165 --> 00:03:06.586
I can't transfer that one.

61
00:03:06.586 --> 00:03:10.950
But the itprotvdemo.com,
I bought that on Hover months ago.

62
00:03:10.950 --> 00:03:13.876
And so that one is full and
clear and ready to transfer.

63
00:03:13.876 --> 00:03:16.130
Now what do I mean by that
when I say full and clear?

64
00:03:16.130 --> 00:03:19.794
Well, almost every registrar
has a holding period.

65
00:03:19.794 --> 00:03:23.610
When you buy a domain, they don't
immediately let you transfer it out.

66
00:03:23.610 --> 00:03:24.744
And thereâ€™s a few reasons for that.

67
00:03:24.744 --> 00:03:29.521
The main reason is a lot of them offer
you discounts, so when you register your

68
00:03:29.521 --> 00:03:33.580
first domain, you come in and
it might give it you for five bucks.

69
00:03:34.750 --> 00:03:37.181
But year two, it's 12 or 15 bucks, right.

70
00:03:37.181 --> 00:03:38.900
It starts to go up and it costs more.

71
00:03:38.900 --> 00:03:42.300
So they don't want you to get their cheap
promotion and then move away before you

72
00:03:42.300 --> 00:03:44.746
pay the full price and
they can actually make some money.

73
00:03:44.746 --> 00:03:45.790
So that's one reason.

74
00:03:45.790 --> 00:03:48.617
But the main reason is
fraudulent transfers.

75
00:03:48.617 --> 00:03:53.237
That when you buy a domain,
there's usually a transfer lock put on it,

76
00:03:53.237 --> 00:03:57.705
and that transfer lock can be
anywhere from 10 days to 120 days.

77
00:03:57.705 --> 00:03:59.165
It's up to the registrar to set it,

78
00:03:59.165 --> 00:04:02.440
although the standard seems to have
settled down to about 60 days.

79
00:04:02.440 --> 00:04:04.234
So most providers have a 60 day one.

80
00:04:04.234 --> 00:04:08.290
I bought a domain on Amazon, and i can't
really mess with it for two months.

81
00:04:08.290 --> 00:04:10.778
This one I registered back in January.

82
00:04:10.778 --> 00:04:11.760
Wow, i said a few months ago.

83
00:04:11.760 --> 00:04:13.706
That's like almost a year ago now.

84
00:04:13.706 --> 00:04:17.330
So i registered this one a long time ago,
and it's just sitting there.

85
00:04:17.330 --> 00:04:19.717
It does renew on January 4th.

86
00:04:19.717 --> 00:04:21.900
Now, I need to think about that, okay.

87
00:04:21.900 --> 00:04:24.156
Right now it is December 5th.

88
00:04:24.156 --> 00:04:28.033
So I'm one month out from renewal,
just a hair under one month.

89
00:04:28.033 --> 00:04:31.620
Now, when I renew,
I normally buy a year or whatever.

90
00:04:31.620 --> 00:04:36.020
When I transfer this,
what happens there, right?

91
00:04:36.020 --> 00:04:36.869
Where do I renew?

92
00:04:36.869 --> 00:04:38.551
Well usually when you transfer,

93
00:04:38.551 --> 00:04:41.800
whoever you're transferring
to makes you buy a year.

94
00:04:41.800 --> 00:04:45.105
So I'm about to expire, January 4th, 2017.

95
00:04:45.105 --> 00:04:48.225
But when I transfer this to Amazon,
I'll have the opportunity to buy,

96
00:04:48.225 --> 00:04:49.892
I shouldn't call it an opportunity.

97
00:04:49.892 --> 00:04:51.742
I will be forced to buy at least one year,
but

98
00:04:51.742 --> 00:04:54.390
I'll have the opportunity to
buy more years if I want.

99
00:04:54.390 --> 00:04:56.269
And I can extend out that registration.

100
00:04:56.269 --> 00:05:00.444
So it's kinda cool, cuz I'll transfer and
renew at the same time.

101
00:05:00.444 --> 00:05:05.480
Now, if I already had more time,
here I've got less than 30 days.

102
00:05:05.480 --> 00:05:08.820
But let's say I had three years
of registration time left.

103
00:05:08.820 --> 00:05:12.500
When I move to the other provider, they'll
still make me buy at least one year, but

104
00:05:12.500 --> 00:05:14.410
it'll add onto my current registration.

105
00:05:14.410 --> 00:05:17.399
So if I have three years to go now
I would have four years, right?

106
00:05:17.399 --> 00:05:19.208
So you never lose time when you transfer.

107
00:05:19.208 --> 00:05:21.840
You can transfer whenever you
want as long you're not locked.

108
00:05:21.840 --> 00:05:24.058
Now, my transfer lock here,

109
00:05:24.058 --> 00:05:29.134
there's a mandatory transfer lock and
an optional transfer lock.

110
00:05:29.134 --> 00:05:30.436
We'll start with the mandatory one.

111
00:05:30.436 --> 00:05:32.670
The mandatory one's like that
60 day window I talked about.

112
00:05:32.670 --> 00:05:36.616
If I just bought this, I might be
locked and I can't transfer out, okay?

113
00:05:36.616 --> 00:05:40.020
And so if that happens,
I'm not gonna have any control.

114
00:05:40.020 --> 00:05:44.701
But after 60 days, it becomes an optional
lock, and I then gain control.

115
00:05:44.701 --> 00:05:47.119
Youâ€™ll notice way over here,
that we've got this,

116
00:05:47.119 --> 00:05:50.060
let me get this little
support thing out of the way.

117

Here's the itprotvdemo.com
lookup I did earlier, right?

566
00:28:01.620 --> 00:28:04.700
And if I look down here I'll see
it's registered through Tucows.

567
00:28:04.700 --> 00:28:09.370
TUCOWS is the company that owns Hover so
tucowsdomains.com and

568
00:28:09.370 --> 00:28:14.420
if I redo that lookup,
that database should be updated and

569
00:28:14.420 --> 00:28:18.720
so now when I look at it,
Amazon Registrar, Inc.

570
00:28:18.720 --> 00:28:22.650
So this domain is now fully off
of Hover and fully on Amazon,

571
00:28:22.650 --> 00:28:26.810
I've got Amazon from the DNS servers
as well as the registration authority.

572
00:28:26.810 --> 00:28:29.710
They're in there, and
they're now in control of that domain.

573
00:28:29.710 --> 00:28:31.550
I do all my renewals and
everything through Amazon.

574
00:28:31.550 --> 00:28:32.650
It's all in one place.

575
00:28:32.650 --> 00:28:36.320
So moving a domain from one registrar
to another, not a big deal.

576
00:28:36.320 --> 00:28:40.250
It's more of an exercise in patience,
really, than anything else.

577
00:28:40.250 --> 00:28:41.270
Once it's moved over, it's done,

578
00:28:41.270 --> 00:28:44.690
and that's transferring
a domain in a nutshell.

579
00:28:44.690 --> 00:28:45.930
>> That's a lot of great information.

580
00:28:45.930 --> 00:28:47.620
Now Don, looking at the clock here,

581
00:28:47.620 --> 00:28:49.620
it does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

582
00:28:49.620 --> 00:28:50.417
Now you've-
>> Six hours.

583
00:28:50.417 --> 00:28:52.810
>> Six hours later,
that's right, six hours later.

584
00:28:52.810 --> 00:28:53.562
I forgot about that.

585
00:28:53.562 --> 00:28:56.840
We should had you come back unshaven or
something like that, you know.

586
00:28:56.840 --> 00:28:58.811
But before we do go.

587
00:28:58.811 --> 00:29:01.607
You mentioned some things throughout this
episode that people need to take into

588
00:29:01.607 --> 00:29:02.240
consideration.

589
00:29:02.240 --> 00:29:03.864
Got any parting words
you'd like to impart?

590
00:29:03.864 --> 00:29:08.420
>> The main thing is after the transfer
make sure that you re-lock your domain.

591
00:29:08.420 --> 00:29:11.140
You definitely want that
transfer lock turned on.

592
00:29:11.140 --> 00:29:14.360
Also, make sure you keep your emails
secure, cuz if somebody can get into

593
00:29:14.360 --> 00:29:17.220
your email account,
they can answer that verification email.

594
00:29:17.220 --> 00:29:18.460
So those are important things and

595
00:29:18.460 --> 00:29:22.840
that's why we also have the EPP code on
top of that, that authorization code.

596
00:29:22.840 --> 00:29:26.500
Those three components are needed
to transfer a domain in and out.

597
00:29:26.500 --> 00:29:30.660
The only other thing is if you're buying a
domain from somebody who already has one,

598
00:29:30.660 --> 00:29:33.740
you're doing one of those auction things,
be really careful.

599
00:29:33.740 --> 00:29:36.610
Cuz they can take your money and not
transfer it to you and you're out of luck.

600
00:29:36.610 --> 00:29:39.550
So there's a number of domain
name escrow services that are out

601
00:29:39.550 --> 00:29:40.935
there to help with that transfer.

602
00:29:40.935 --> 00:29:43.770
Registar.com runs one and
a couple of other companies run them.

603
00:29:43.770 --> 00:29:47.162
To help make sure that the domain name
goes in escrow, you pay the money, and

604
00:29:47.162 --> 00:29:48.975
then it's released from escrow to you.

605
00:29:48.975 --> 00:29:52.206
And not just released from some
third-party vendor or domain squatter, or

606
00:29:52.206 --> 00:29:54.330
somebody that's not
necessarily trustworthy.

607
00:29:54.330 --> 00:29:55.960
So always keep an eye out for that.

608
00:29:55.960 --> 00:29:57.540
>> All right, Don,
well wealth of information.

609
00:29:57.540 --> 00:29:59.550
We appreciate you being in
the studios watching us.

610
00:29:59.550 --> 00:30:01.370
And we appreciate you watching us.

611
00:30:01.370 --> 00:30:05.623
How about Imparting knowledge to us, and
we do appreciate the viewers out there,

612
00:30:05.623 --> 00:30:07.110
signing out for ITPro.TV.

613
00:30:07.110 --> 00:30:08.461
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

614
00:30:08.461 --> 00:30:09.285
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

615
00:30:09.285 --> 00:30:10.405
>> And we'll see you next time.

616
00:30:10.405 --> 00:30:18.088
>> [MUSIC]

617
00:30:18.088 --> 00:30:22.950
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don start the journey through securing DNS Zones on an NSD server. In the first part they will demonstrate getting the prerequisites installed and configured
episodes.title: Configuring DNSSEC with NSD
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.029 --> 00:00:01.360
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.360 --> 00:00:03.469
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.469 --> 00:00:07.193
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:07.193 --> 00:00:11.902
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.902 --> 00:00:14.666
>> Welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.666 --> 00:00:15.970
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:15.970 --> 00:00:19.720
And in today's episode, we're
continuing through our DNS tech skills,

8
00:00:19.720 --> 00:00:21.490
we're actually coming
back with a part two.

9
00:00:21.490 --> 00:00:24.801
Joining us for this very endeavor
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:24.801 --> 00:00:25.452
Don, how you doing sir?

11
00:00:25.452 --> 00:00:28.040
>> I'm doing great, Wes,
ready to dive right back into DNSSEC.

12
00:00:28.040 --> 00:00:31.090
And if you watched our last episode, you
know we spent our time dealing with all

13
00:00:31.090 --> 00:00:36.250
the prerequisites of making sure
we were ready to implement DNSSEC.

14
00:00:36.250 --> 00:00:37.520
We set up our servers,

15
00:00:37.520 --> 00:00:42.120
we got everything put in place and
we never actually implemented DNSSEC.

16
00:00:42.120 --> 00:00:45.290
And that's what we're gonna kick off with
right here in this episode is the actual

17
00:00:45.290 --> 00:00:45.870
signing.

18
00:00:45.870 --> 00:00:48.330
So if you didn't watch the last episode,

19
00:00:48.330 --> 00:00:52.188
where we left off is I've got two
NSD servers that are up and running.

20
00:00:52.188 --> 00:00:55.280
They're replicating out a zone
between each other, but

21
00:00:55.280 --> 00:00:58.690
it's just a regular old zone
with regular old records.

22
00:00:58.690 --> 00:01:02.040
They're not digitally signed in any way,
there's no hashes or

23
00:01:02.040 --> 00:01:03.580
signatures attached to them.

24
00:01:03.580 --> 00:01:06.730
We need to start activating DNSSEC and
getting that pushed out.

25
00:01:06.730 --> 00:01:08.920
So that's where we are right now,

26
00:01:08.920 --> 00:01:13.170
with the actual beginning of the true
DNSSEC configuration, all right.

27
00:01:13.170 --> 00:01:16.640
Now, in order to get started,
the first thing I need

28
00:01:16.640 --> 00:01:19.380
to do is kind of figure out what
algorithms I'm gonna be using.

29
00:01:19.380 --> 00:01:20.610
I pointed that out in the last episode.

30
00:01:20.610 --> 00:01:23.760
There's more than one algorithm we can
use for generating the signature and

31
00:01:23.760 --> 00:01:25.680
generating the digest and all of that.

32
00:01:25.680 --> 00:01:28.310
And there's different
standards that are out there.

33
00:01:28.310 --> 00:01:32.460
Be careful because the one you pick
needs to be supported by your provider,

34
00:01:32.460 --> 00:01:33.670
whoever your registrar is.

35
00:01:33.670 --> 00:01:35.140
And so you've gotta check that.

36
00:01:35.140 --> 00:01:40.740
In my scenario, I'm using a registrar
which is Hover.com, right.

37
00:01:40.740 --> 00:01:45.860
And Hover, they're the registrar
of record for my itprotvdemo.org.

38
00:01:45.860 --> 00:01:49.100
And I know they support DNSSEC,
they've got support for that, so

39
00:01:49.100 --> 00:01:51.680
I can certainly come in here and
activate it.

40
00:01:51.680 --> 00:01:57.020
And when I activate it, I'm gonna have to
pick an algorithm and a digest algorithm.

41
00:01:57.020 --> 00:02:00.940
Now, there are many different
algorithms that are out there, and

42
00:02:00.940 --> 00:02:03.322
each one gets a number assigned to them.

43
00:02:03.322 --> 00:02:05.726
See how there's two, three,
five, six, seven, eight?

44
00:02:05.726 --> 00:02:10.239
See how it skips one, and
they skip four and they skip nine?

45
00:02:10.239 --> 00:02:12.220
Where did those numbers go?

46
00:02:12.220 --> 00:02:14.040
Well, Hover didn't make these numbers up.

47
00:02:14.040 --> 00:02:16.280
This is part of the DNSSEC standard.

48
00:02:16.280 --> 00:02:19.060
Each algorithm gets
a number assigned to it.

49
00:02:19.060 --> 00:02:22.990
And what they're telling me here
are which ones they support, right.

50
00:02:22.990 --> 00:02:25.292
They don't support
whatever number one was.

51
00:02:25.292 --> 00:02:27.200
Number one is actually MD5, right.

52
00:02:27.200 --> 00:02:30.788
So they don't support MD5 because MD5
is not considered secure anymore.

53
00:02:30.788 --> 00:02:33.072
If it's not secure,
why bother supporting it?

54
00:02:33.072 --> 00:02:35.643
And if we look at some of the others,
it's gonna be similar stuff to that.

55
00:02:35.643 --> 00:02:39.752
>> Now, Don, is this related next to that
key ID that you showed us in the first

56
00:02:39.752 --> 00:02:42.700
episode where you said these
numbers are important?

57
00:02:42.700 --> 00:02:45.830
I noticed, for instance, eight was
in the list a couple of times there.

58
00:02:45.830 --> 00:02:46.690
>> Yeah.

59
00:02:46.690 --> 00:02:49.350
And when we saw that,
there were usually two numbers, right.

60
00:02:49.350 --> 00:02:51.950
And the first number was
indicating the algorithm, and

61
00:02:51.950 --> 00:02:54.140
the other one was indicating
the digest algorithm.

62
00:02:54.140 --> 00:02:56.780
And so you'll see where I've
got those options, too.

63
00:02:56.780 --> 00:03:01.670
Now, when I pick an algorithm, I need to
make sure that my registrar supports it,

64
00:03:01.670 --> 00:03:03.750
and I need to make sure that I support it.

65
00:03:03.750 --> 00:03:10.377
So for example, on this digest, see how I
can do SHA-1, SHA-256 GOST and SHA-384?

66
00:03:10.377 --> 00:03:13.507
Well, I'm gonna use the ldns-utils.

67
00:03:13.507 --> 00:03:18.132
And the version of the utils that I have,
they don't support GOST or SHA-384.

68
00:03:18.132 --> 00:03:21.429
So I only support SHA-1 and
SHA-256 for the digest.

69
00:03:21.429 --> 00:03:23.476
So I'm the bottleneck there.

70
00:03:23.476 --> 00:03:26.233
But there may be something where your
registrar is a bottleneck, too, so

71
00:03:26.233 --> 00:03:27.720
you gotta check that out.

72
00:03:27.720 --> 00:03:30.810
I'm gonna go ahead and use SHA-256 for
everything that I do here today

73
00:03:30.810 --> 00:03:33.890
because that's considered secure and
almost everything supports it.

74
00:03:33.890 --> 00:03:35.600
So you're pretty safe going with it.

75
00:03:35.600 --> 00:03:39.160
But don't hesitate to move to a stronger
algorithm if you've got full support for

76
00:03:39.160 --> 00:03:40.990
it in your environment, all right.

77
00:03:40.990 --> 00:03:42.860
So I need to get this stuff generated.

78
00:03:42.860 --> 00:03:45.170
I need to get it made and put in place.

79
00:03:45.170 --> 00:03:47.870
So let me jump back over to my server.

80
00:03:47.870 --> 00:03:50.330
Now, I've got two servers,
dns1 and dns2, and

81
00:03:50.330 --> 00:03:52.440
they're replicating between each other.

82
00:03:52.440 --> 00:03:56.680
I'm gonna do all my work on one server,
on the master.

83
00:03:56.680 --> 00:04:00.240
And as I sign everything,
that's gonna replicate the other one.

84
00:04:00.240 --> 00:04:04.107
So I don't have to do all the work twice,
I can just do it once.

85
00:04:04.107 --> 00:04:07.624
But to help me make sure the work gets
done, I'm gonna jump over to number two.

86
00:04:07.624 --> 00:04:12.510
And I'm going to do a quick dig on my
local system here just to be able to

87
00:04:12.510 --> 00:04:17.172
verify that the records don't
have any kind of keys yet, right.

88
00:04:17.172 --> 00:04:22.172
So if I do a lookup against
my second server, and

89
00:04:22.172 --> 00:04:27.055
I'm gonna look for www.itprotvdemo.org.

90
00:04:27.055 --> 00:04:30.146
When I get that back, I get a nice,
normal record right there.

91
00:04:30.146 --> 00:04:32.408
And that's just an A record, right.

92
00:04:32.408 --> 00:04:37.705
I'm gonna query it again, and this time
I'm gonna tell it I want the DNSKEY.

93
00:04:37.705 --> 00:04:41.624
And I'm gonna use +multiline just to make
it look a little nicer on the screen.

94
00:04:41.624 --> 00:04:44.450
Otherwise, it word wraps
the thing all crazy.

95
00:04:44.450 --> 00:04:49.570
So I'm querying that record, and I'm
saying show me the DNSKEY for that record.

96
00:04:49.570 --> 00:04:50.970
Or actually, hang on, that's a record.

97
00:04:50.970 --> 00:04:52.880
A record would have an RRSIG.

98
00:04:52.880 --> 00:04:57.310
I'm gonna do the zone, so I'll pull
itprotvdemo.org, the zone, itself.

99
00:04:57.310 --> 00:05:00.430
And when I query that,
it doesn't have a key.

100
00:05:00.430 --> 00:05:01.920
Right, no key was returned for me.

101
00:05:01.920 --> 00:05:04.890
I got my SOA information, but no key.

102
00:05:04.890 --> 00:05:07.340
See how it says IN DNSKEY and
then nothing?

103
00:05:07.340 --> 00:05:09.010
Normally, the key would follow that.

104
00:05:09.010 --> 00:05:12.330
So, as of right now,
this server doesn't contain a key.

105
00:05:12.330 --> 00:05:17.130
And I'll run that same query later to
make sure that the key does show up and

106
00:05:17.130 --> 00:05:18.890
I'm querying the second server.

107
00:05:18.890 --> 00:05:21.590
Because I'll know it's working on
the first server cuz that's where

108
00:05:21.590 --> 00:05:22.350
I'm setting it up.

109
00:05:22.350 --> 00:05:24.360
I need to make sure it replicates, right.

110
00:05:24.360 --> 00:05:26.597
So on this server,
I can do that same thing,

111
00:05:26.597 --> 00:05:28.720
except I can look up against this server.

112
00:05:28.720 --> 00:05:35.857
So just using it to loop back to pull up
itprotvdemo.org, and ask for that DNSKEY.

113
00:05:35.857 --> 00:05:39.180
And I'll do multilining even though
that's not gonna return anything.

114
00:05:39.180 --> 00:05:40.440
But there we go, same thing.

115
00:05:40.440 --> 00:05:43.350
I get the IN DNSKEY followed by nothing.

116
00:05:43.350 --> 00:05:44.148
No key, all right.

117
00:05:44.148 --> 00:05:47.060
Let's fix that, let's generate a key.

118
00:05:47.060 --> 00:05:48.550
The command to generate a key.

119
00:05:48.550 --> 00:05:53.890
Well, we need to get into /etc/nsd,
that's where our zone is.

120
00:05:53.890 --> 00:05:58.000
So my zone is sitting right here,
itprotvdemo.org.dns.

121
00:05:58.000 --> 00:06:05.490
And by the time this is done, I'm going
to have generated three sets of keys.

122
00:06:05.490 --> 00:06:09.800
I need a zone signing key that
I'll use to sign the zone.

123
00:06:09.800 --> 00:06:14.780
Then I need a key signing key
that I use to sign the zone keys.

124
00:06:14.780 --> 00:06:16.650
Cuz I might have ten zones.

125
00:06:16.650 --> 00:06:20.560
Well, I need a different key for each
zone, so that will be ten different keys.

126
00:06:20.560 --> 00:06:22.100
And I can have one master key,

127
00:06:22.100 --> 00:06:25.360
the key signing key,
that signs all of them, right.

128
00:06:25.360 --> 00:06:28.590
So I need a zone signing key and
a key signing key.

129
00:06:28.590 --> 00:06:32.998
And you'll see this usually written as
ZSK and KSK, so I need those two keys.

130
00:06:32.998 --> 00:06:36.583
And then I need a DS key.

131
00:06:36.583 --> 00:06:38.322
And the DS is for
the designated signer, and

132
00:06:38.322 --> 00:06:40.769
that's what I'm gonna send up
to the registrar, all right.

133
00:06:40.769 --> 00:06:41.940
So that's the other one.

134
00:06:41.940 --> 00:06:44.540
So I'm gonna make three sets of keys.

135
00:06:44.540 --> 00:06:47.680
And the commands are all really similar so
they're easy to mix up.

136
00:06:47.680 --> 00:06:50.530
So let's kind of run
through this step by step.

137
00:06:50.530 --> 00:06:52.120
I'm gonna start with the zone signing key.

138
00:06:52.120 --> 00:06:55.470
I'm gonna sign itprotv.demo.org.dns.

139
00:06:55.470 --> 00:06:58.950
Now, if I need to make any changes
to the records I need to do it now

140
00:06:58.950 --> 00:07:03.310
because from now on,
every time I modify that zone,

141
00:07:03.310 --> 00:07:08.490
I need to go in and re-sign it, right.

142
00:07:08.490 --> 00:07:11.660
Every time I make a modification,
I've got to re-sign it cuz it'll change.

143
00:07:11.660 --> 00:07:13.920
So because I know I'm gonna do that,

144
00:07:13.920 --> 00:07:16.680
there is the matter of the serial
number that's in there.

145
00:07:16.680 --> 00:07:19.026
And if I want this to
replicate to the other side,

146
00:07:19.026 --> 00:07:20.983
I need to increment that serial number.

147
00:07:20.983 --> 00:07:26.348
I'm gonna increment the serial number now,
even though I haven't changed anything,

148
00:07:26.348 --> 00:07:30.132
so that when it signs it the new
serial number will be in there.

149
00:07:30.132 --> 00:07:34.910
So I'm gonna edit
/etc/nsd/itprotvdemo.org.dns.

150
00:07:34.910 --> 00:07:38.700
And I'm gonna go in here and
just take the serial number,

151
00:07:38.700 --> 00:07:43.370
which is a 1, and I'm gonna make it a 2,
right, just bump it up.

152
00:07:43.370 --> 00:07:45.319
I mean, you can make it 2,000,
it doesn't matter, but

153
00:07:45.319 --> 00:07:47.130
it has to be a number higher
than whatever it is right now.

154
00:07:47.130 --> 00:07:49.231
So that's gonna let the other
side know that it's different.

155
00:07:49.231 --> 00:07:54.893
Now, NSD doesn't actually load
the zone until I tell it to, right.

156
00:07:54.893 --> 00:07:56.471
So it's not gonna see that number changed,

157
00:07:56.471 --> 00:07:58.273
it's not gonna replicate
over to the other side.

158
00:07:58.273 --> 00:07:59.978
And that's perfectly fine with me, so.

159
00:07:59.978 --> 00:08:01.197
There we go.

160
00:08:01.197 --> 00:08:02.532
And I'll get out of that.

161
00:08:02.532 --> 00:08:07.457
All right, so as it stands, I've got my
regular old zone sitting right there and

162
00:08:07.457 --> 00:08:09.110
now I need to sign it.

163
00:08:09.110 --> 00:08:13.688
So I'm gonna run ldns-keygen.

164
00:08:13.688 --> 00:08:15.302
This is gonna generate the key.

165
00:08:15.302 --> 00:08:17.040
And we're gonna use this
utility a few times.

166
00:08:17.040 --> 00:08:19.960
And as far as options that go into it,

167
00:08:19.960 --> 00:08:24.820
we need to say -a and
tell it the algorithm to use.

168
00:08:24.820 --> 00:08:27.740
Now there's a lot that are supported and
depending on your distro,

169
00:08:27.740 --> 00:08:29.700
you may have some and
you may be missing others.

170
00:08:29.700 --> 00:08:32.350
What I recommend you do
is before you run it,

171
00:08:32.350 --> 00:08:35.210
just pull up the man file for
it, all right.

00:36:50.930 --> 00:36:56.670
These don't get cached and so
as long as my records are updated, and

709
00:36:56.670 --> 00:37:00.750
as long as hover does a good job updating
their registered data base which they do,

710
00:37:00.750 --> 00:37:02.800
this should take effect pretty quick.

711
00:37:02.800 --> 00:37:04.470
But the official lines it could 72 hours.

712
00:37:05.540 --> 00:37:08.140
So how do I know if it worked?

713
00:37:08.140 --> 00:37:08.680
Right.

714
00:37:08.680 --> 00:37:09.410
Technically we're done.

715
00:37:09.410 --> 00:37:12.620
We just setup DNS set, we,
end of the episode and walk away.

716
00:37:12.620 --> 00:37:13.320
Right.

717
00:37:13.320 --> 00:37:15.190
But we do need a test and
verify that it's working.

718
00:37:15.190 --> 00:37:16.790
It's just this part you
might have to wait awhile.

719
00:37:16.790 --> 00:37:19.470
Let's see if it's working already.

720
00:37:19.470 --> 00:37:22.650
So I'm gonna jump over to one
of my servers to test it out.

721
00:37:22.650 --> 00:37:26.800
To test it out you can
use the dig command.

722
00:37:26.800 --> 00:37:27.400
Right.

723
00:37:27.400 --> 00:37:29.600
And I can dig against
one of my servers but

724
00:37:29.600 --> 00:37:32.910
it's better to dig against
a public server out there, right.

725
00:37:32.910 --> 00:37:35.920
So I'll take like Google.

726
00:37:35.920 --> 00:37:37.800
And look to them.

727
00:37:37.800 --> 00:37:43.510
And I'll try and look up the DS record for
itprotvdemo.org.

728
00:37:43.510 --> 00:37:47.705
In fact, let me take one that
I know doesn't work, right?

729
00:37:47.705 --> 00:37:48.930
Itprotvdemo.com.

730
00:37:48.930 --> 00:37:50.700
We don't have dnssec turned on for that.

731
00:37:50.700 --> 00:37:53.880
So if I run that, it's going to reach out.

732
00:37:53.880 --> 00:37:56.540
I see that it reached out for a DS record.

733
00:37:56.540 --> 00:37:59.040
And there's no answer section afterwards.

734
00:37:59.040 --> 00:38:01.740
And it just goes right into
the authority and that;s the end of it.

735
00:38:01.740 --> 00:38:04.856
Let's do the same thing for .org.

736
00:38:04.856 --> 00:38:06.370
And this one should work.

737
00:38:06.370 --> 00:38:09.190
So in anticipation of that
I'm gonna add the +mulitiline

738
00:38:09.190 --> 00:38:10.990
just to make it look a little neater.

739
00:38:10.990 --> 00:38:13.630
And when I reach out to them, I get

740
00:38:14.910 --> 00:38:20.520
the DS record followed by an answer
section and right there I can see,

741
00:38:20.520 --> 00:38:25.810
key ID followed by algorithm and
digest followed by the actual

742
00:38:25.810 --> 00:38:30.810
digest after that and that is coming
right from hover not from my DNS server,

743
00:38:30.810 --> 00:38:33.860
so that is the secret sauce for
all of this, that's what makes this work.

744
00:38:33.860 --> 00:38:36.100
Is that the value is coming
from two different places.

745
00:38:36.100 --> 00:38:39.840
So if the hackers poison
the cache of my zone,

746
00:38:39.840 --> 00:38:42.460
they haven't messed with
my register records.

747
00:38:42.460 --> 00:38:42.990
Right.

748
00:38:42.990 --> 00:38:43.810
They're different.

749
00:38:43.810 --> 00:38:49.320
They would have to compromise both places,
in order to actually exploit my zone now.

750
00:38:49.320 --> 00:38:50.230
My zone is safe.

751
00:38:50.230 --> 00:38:53.040
If the cache gets poisoned,
the cache just gets thrown away and

752
00:38:53.040 --> 00:38:55.280
it does a new look up and
it gets the right value.

753
00:38:55.280 --> 00:39:00.450
So this effectively stops DNS cache
poisoning if we have DNS sec enabled.

754
00:39:00.450 --> 00:39:02.880
And if the clients
are bothering the check for it.

755
00:39:02.880 --> 00:39:05.570
If you got the DNS server
that's not gonna check for it,

756
00:39:05.570 --> 00:39:06.920
then it doesn't matter that
all the stuff is here.

757
00:39:06.920 --> 00:39:10.580
It's just gonna ignore the ds and the
other records, they're not gonna get used.

758
00:39:12.130 --> 00:39:14.690
But I can see right here it's
pulling off my registrar.

759
00:39:14.690 --> 00:39:15.440
I'm now good to go.

760
00:39:15.440 --> 00:39:18.280
I have a DNSsec enabled zone.

761
00:39:18.280 --> 00:39:19.930
And anybody looking up a record,

762
00:39:19.930 --> 00:39:24.490
like looking up www.itprotvdemo.org,
they will get the signature, and

763
00:39:24.490 --> 00:39:28.270
they'll be able to verify and
test that and see whether it works.

764
00:39:28.270 --> 00:39:31.290
>> Lot of great information Don there,
lot of steps to follow.

765
00:39:31.290 --> 00:39:34.120
Now it does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode but

766
00:39:34.120 --> 00:39:35.930
Don you've shown us a lot of stuff here.

767
00:39:35.930 --> 00:39:38.970
Is there any additional things you might
wanna throw in here before we call it

768
00:39:38.970 --> 00:39:39.850
quits on this one?

769
00:39:39.850 --> 00:39:41.090
>> Let me show you one more thing.

770
00:39:41.090 --> 00:39:43.060
As far as configuring
the server we're done,

771
00:39:43.060 --> 00:39:45.120
I don't really have much
else to show you there.

772
00:39:45.120 --> 00:39:48.175
But I do want to show you a quick
way of test whether this is working,

773
00:39:48.175 --> 00:39:52.348
Verisign has nice little
dnssec testing page.

774
00:39:52.348 --> 00:39:56.980
They have it linked on
the actual dnssec homepages, but

775
00:39:56.980 --> 00:40:02.150
if you go to, https, we're going to,

776
00:40:02.150 --> 00:40:08.180
let's see if I can merge this whole thing,
it's dnssec-debugger.

777
00:40:08.180 --> 00:40:09.680
Actually, it might not even be HTTPS.

778
00:40:09.680 --> 00:40:12.310
Let me get rid of that.

779
00:40:12.310 --> 00:40:18.286
So dnssec -debugger.verisignlabs.com and

780
00:40:18.286 --> 00:40:22.370
then do a / and
put in whatever your domain is.

781
00:40:22.370 --> 00:40:25.840
So my domain is itprotv, well,
let's do itprotvdemo.com.

782
00:40:25.840 --> 00:40:27.375
I'll try that one first.

783
00:40:27.375 --> 00:40:31.915
ITProTV.com doesn't have a sign,
DNS signatures,

784
00:40:31.915 --> 00:40:37.730
dnssec-debugger.verisignlabs.com/itprotvd-
emo.com and

785
00:40:37.730 --> 00:40:40.350
if I look, looks like the domain
is pretty healthy, right?

786
00:40:41.460 --> 00:40:45.990
When I scroll down a bit,
I'll start to see some problems.

787
00:40:45.990 --> 00:40:49.280
It found two DNS key records for it.

788
00:40:49.280 --> 00:40:50.830
And it had some signatures.

789
00:40:50.830 --> 00:40:57.360
So apparently it had DNS sec set up at
some point, right, And well, actually no.

790
00:40:57.360 --> 00:40:59.700
That's dot, that's the root.

791
00:40:59.700 --> 00:41:01.770
Yes the roots server are gonna have it.

792
00:41:01.770 --> 00:41:05.350
And then dot com, yeah, all right,
it found those records.

793
00:41:05.350 --> 00:41:08.920
But then by the time it
gets down to ITPROTV.com.

794
00:41:08.920 --> 00:41:10.480
Things aren't looking so good.

795
00:41:10.480 --> 00:41:11.250
It's not signed.

796
00:41:11.250 --> 00:41:13.070
You'll see that one's hosted by Amazon.

797
00:41:13.070 --> 00:41:16.650
Amazon refused the lookup and that's it.

798
00:41:16.650 --> 00:41:18.730
I don't have DNSSEC for that one.

799
00:41:18.730 --> 00:41:21.020
So I know that it's not functional.

800
00:41:21.020 --> 00:41:22.510
But if I change that and

801
00:41:22.510 --> 00:41:28.230
we do a lookup on org instead it'll
run through the same process.

802
00:41:28.230 --> 00:41:33.110
It looks up the dot and then it goes org
and it looks that one up, and then it gets

803
00:41:33.110 --> 00:41:37.910
to me, I got nice little green
checkmarks all the way down as it tests.

804
00:41:37.910 --> 00:41:43.030
And it's not only checking the DS,
it's also pulling the signatures

805
00:41:43.030 --> 00:41:47.690
of individual records to test it out, like
the name server records, and the SOA, so

806
00:41:47.690 --> 00:41:51.100
it's pulling that and checking to
make sure those records are valid.

807
00:41:51.100 --> 00:41:53.540
This is a great way to ensure
the DNSSEC is working, and

808
00:41:53.540 --> 00:41:56.770
it's being tested from
outside of your organization.

809
00:41:56.770 --> 00:41:59.470
So you know it's not
cached on your server, or

810
00:41:59.470 --> 00:42:01.420
you're hitting a local DNS server,
or something.

811
00:42:01.420 --> 00:42:02.600
This is a test from the outside world.

812
00:42:02.600 --> 00:42:03.960
So I use this all the time, and

813
00:42:03.960 --> 00:42:06.420
it is a great way to make sure
that things are set up right.

814
00:42:06.420 --> 00:42:07.050
>> All right, Don.

815
00:42:07.050 --> 00:42:10.610
Well as always, we appreciate you being
here with us, and we do appreciate you,

816
00:42:10.610 --> 00:42:11.860
the viewer watching.

817
00:42:11.860 --> 00:42:14.513
We're gonna go ahead and
sign out here for ITProTV.

818
00:42:14.513 --> 00:42:16.127
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

819
00:42:16.127 --> 00:42:16.940
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

820
00:42:16.940 --> 00:42:19.191
>> And we'll see you next time.

00:42:19.191 --> 00:42:25.262

822

>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don talk about the not to common DNS server implementation used in technologies like root hint servers and DNSSEC called NSD. They discuss the installation of NSD within a Linux system, considerations and demonstrate the process.
episodes.title: Installing NSD
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:01.170
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.170 --> 00:00:06.804
I'm your host [INAUDIBLE] [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.804 --> 00:00:08.316
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.316 --> 00:00:12.105
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.105 --> 00:00:15.222
>> Welcome back to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV,

6
00:00:15.222 --> 00:00:16.600
I'm your host Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:16.600 --> 00:00:20.770
And in today's episode, we're continuing
through our series on DNS tech skills.

8
00:00:20.770 --> 00:00:23.770
And I have to say, I think somebody
got an acronym wrong this morning.

9
00:00:23.770 --> 00:00:26.820
But before I steal his thunder,
welcoming back Don Pizet.

10
00:00:26.820 --> 00:00:27.640
Don, how you doing sir?

11
00:00:27.640 --> 00:00:28.930
>> I am doing great, Wes.

12
00:00:28.930 --> 00:00:30.930
Yeah just applying some
proper spelling skills.

13
00:00:30.930 --> 00:00:34.400
Instead of doing DNS today,
we're gonna do NSD.

14
00:00:34.400 --> 00:00:38.400
Now NSD it's kind of a,
is actually intended to be NSD

15
00:00:38.400 --> 00:00:41.390
is a name server that a lot of
you probably haven't heard of.

16
00:00:41.390 --> 00:00:46.100
It's not terribly popular out there,
most businesses or

17
00:00:46.100 --> 00:00:48.360
enterprises are not running NSD.

18
00:00:48.360 --> 00:00:51.780
And with this amazing lead in that I'm
doing here, your probably asking yourself

19
00:00:51.780 --> 00:00:54.750
Don why are you wasting our time with
this one if it's not very popular?

20
00:00:54.750 --> 00:00:58.290
And it's not to much the popularity
that's important about NSD

21
00:00:58.290 --> 00:01:01.210
it's about who does run it.

22
00:01:01.210 --> 00:01:02.490
And who runs it?

23
00:01:02.490 --> 00:01:04.210
Quite a few of the root hint servers.

24
00:01:04.210 --> 00:01:07.470
Quite a few of the big guys in
the DNS infrastructure world.

25
00:01:07.470 --> 00:01:11.410
NSD is kind of a newer player
in the name server market.

26
00:01:11.410 --> 00:01:15.490
But they really have kind of pushed
forward a lot of great technologies, and

27
00:01:15.490 --> 00:01:17.830
as a result they are taking over the core.

28
00:01:17.830 --> 00:01:19.700
And that just means over time
they're gonna slowly take

29
00:01:19.700 --> 00:01:20.700
over on the other way out.

30
00:01:20.700 --> 00:01:23.800
So NSD is a very powerful name server.

31
00:01:23.800 --> 00:01:27.830
It is designed with some really
cool features in mind and

32
00:01:27.830 --> 00:01:31.150
we haven't filmed many
episodes on DNSSEC yet.

33
00:01:31.150 --> 00:01:33.490
But a lot of you are familiar with DNSSEC.

34
00:01:33.490 --> 00:01:37.640
You know that the DNS environment is
actually kind of easy to exploit.

35
00:01:37.640 --> 00:01:38.630
DNS poison attacks.

36
00:01:38.630 --> 00:01:40.620
And man in the middle attacks,
and things like that.

37
00:01:40.620 --> 00:01:43.610
Can really endanger your clients.

38
00:01:43.610 --> 00:01:47.950
And DNS security or
DNSSEC is a way of digitally

39
00:01:47.950 --> 00:01:51.880
signing lookups that go in between
servers to make sure that doesn't happen.

40
00:01:51.880 --> 00:01:54.230
To make sure that somebody
can't poison our DNS cache.

41
00:01:54.230 --> 00:01:59.100
That we actually know the proper records
and the proper IPs and a like good stuff.

42
00:01:59.100 --> 00:02:00.840
DNSSEC is really important.

43
00:02:00.840 --> 00:02:03.240
Well, the people who designed it,

44
00:02:03.240 --> 00:02:09.010
they needed to create a reference server
a test pet to be able to test the DNSSEC.

45
00:02:09.010 --> 00:02:15.130
And so to do that they created an SD,
an SD is where DNSSEC was developed.

46
00:02:15.130 --> 00:02:17.850
And that's why you see root
servers running it today,

47
00:02:17.850 --> 00:02:21.110
cuz the root servers were the most
important ones to protect.

48
00:02:21.110 --> 00:02:25.050
So when DNSSEC became stable,
they had to make a choice.

49
00:02:25.050 --> 00:02:28.647
Do we stay with our other technologies
that don't support DNSSEC yet

50
00:02:28.647 --> 00:02:29.710
or do we move to NSD?

51
00:02:30.920 --> 00:02:34.555
Now, NSD wasn't just written by some
random Joe Schmo off the street it's

52
00:02:34.555 --> 00:02:37.900
actually written by the same
people who wrote Unbound.

53
00:02:37.900 --> 00:02:40.810
And so, Unbound we know is an excellent

54
00:02:40.810 --> 00:02:44.680
highly scaleable,very
fast modern name server.

55
00:02:44.680 --> 00:02:47.850
That really is designed for
caching and reversal lookups.

56
00:02:47.850 --> 00:02:50.170
It doesn't do so
good on the authoritative side.

57
00:02:50.170 --> 00:02:52.760
Well, NSD is the other side.

58
00:02:52.760 --> 00:02:55.770
It does authoritative lookups and
that's it.

59
00:02:55.770 --> 00:03:00.160
It doesn't do recursive lookups or
caching because it only answers for

60
00:03:00.160 --> 00:03:02.150
the zones that it contains.

61
00:03:02.150 --> 00:03:04.770
So if you run NSD combined with Unbound,

62
00:03:04.770 --> 00:03:07.490
you've got a great solution
that's very powerful.

63
00:03:07.490 --> 00:03:09.570
It can handle everything that you need.

64
00:03:09.570 --> 00:03:12.720
But if you just want to set up
an authoritative name server,

65
00:03:12.720 --> 00:03:14.010
an SD does a great job.

66
00:03:14.010 --> 00:03:16.452
And if you're a route hit server,
what are you?

67
00:03:16.452 --> 00:03:17.180
Well you're authoritative.

68
00:03:17.180 --> 00:03:19.874
There's nobody higher in
that structure than you.

69
00:03:19.874 --> 00:03:24.569
And there's even some TLDs,
some of the top layer domain names.

70
00:03:24.569 --> 00:03:28.406
Those servers that are running NSD also,
so it is very popular at the top.

71
00:03:28.406 --> 00:03:30.155
And over time we're gonna see
it popular down on our side.

72
00:03:30.155 --> 00:03:34.035
So in this episode what we're gonna do
is we're gonna run through getting NSD

73
00:03:34.035 --> 00:03:36.735
set up, seeing how to deploy it,
get it configured.

74
00:03:36.735 --> 00:03:39.405
And you'll find that it's not
actually that much different

75
00:03:39.405 --> 00:03:42.595
from the other guys that are out there and
it's very stable, very fast,

76
00:03:42.595 --> 00:03:44.340
and a great replacement for Bind.

77
00:03:44.340 --> 00:03:50.295
Now, remember that Bind by itself could
do what Unbound and NSD do together.

78
00:03:50.295 --> 00:03:53.654
So it's like replacing one product with
two, which is normally a bad thing.

79
00:03:53.654 --> 00:03:57.394
But Unbound and NSD use two different
databases that are optimized for

80
00:03:57.394 --> 00:03:58.980
their different roles.

81
00:03:58.980 --> 00:04:02.920
And that gives it much better performance
than Bind that has one database

82
00:04:02.920 --> 00:04:06.220
that's not really optimized for
either role and doesn't scale very well.

83
00:04:06.220 --> 00:04:09.980
So it's a great drop-in replacement,
and that's what we're starting to see,

84
00:04:09.980 --> 00:04:12.820
is Unbound and NSD taking that place.

85
00:04:12.820 --> 00:04:15.500
So, enough gabbing about it,
let's jump in and actually see it.

86
00:04:15.500 --> 00:04:17.830
As we're gonna take NSD and
get it installed on a machine, and

87
00:04:17.830 --> 00:04:19.830
bring it up, and get it up and going.

88
00:04:19.830 --> 00:04:22.810
So I've got a CentOS 7 box right here,

89
00:04:22.810 --> 00:04:26.400
this would be the same as
Red Hat Enterprise Linux or Fedora.

90
00:04:26.400 --> 00:04:30.410
If you're on Ubuntu or or
one of those other distros.

91
00:04:30.410 --> 00:04:33.570
Then you may need to use slightly
different installation commands.

92
00:04:33.570 --> 00:04:35.390
Instead of Yum,
you're going to use apt-get.

93
00:04:35.390 --> 00:04:37.850
But everything else beyond
that point will be the same.

94
00:04:37.850 --> 00:04:39.760
They actually do have NSD for Windows.

95
00:04:39.760 --> 00:04:41.430
You can go out and get it and
deploy it that way.

96
00:04:41.430 --> 00:04:44.140
Although most people are going
to deploy it on a Linux server,

97
00:04:44.140 --> 00:04:45.060
like what I'm doing here.

98
00:04:46.270 --> 00:04:49.000
Now getting it installed is pretty
much like any other software.

99
00:04:49.000 --> 00:04:51.990
Well, let me qualify that real quick.

100
00:04:51.990 --> 00:04:55.590
If I just do a Yum install NSD, there's
actually something weird going on right

101
00:04:55.590 --> 00:04:57.990
now, and
we're gonna get nothing to do, right?

102
00:04:57.990 --> 00:05:01.320
What happened is,
NSD is developing very fast.

103
00:05:01.320 --> 00:05:03.340
There's new things
coming out all the time.

104
00:05:03.340 --> 00:05:07.800
And NSD version 3 was the stable,
widely supported one.

105
00:05:07.800 --> 00:05:09.690
NSD 4 was in beta.

106
00:05:09.690 --> 00:05:15.460
Well when NSD 4 came out of beta,
they immediately yanked support for NSD 3.

107
00:05:15.460 --> 00:05:17.960
NL Labs,
the people that create all this stuff,

108
00:05:17.960 --> 00:05:19.700
they don't like to
support the old versions.

109
00:05:19.700 --> 00:05:22.795
They want you running on the latest,
cuz this is all about security and

110
00:05:22.795 --> 00:05:23.486
performance.

111
00:05:23.486 --> 00:05:26.511
Well, Red Hat doesn't move that fast.

112
00:05:26.511 --> 00:05:30.218
They're not ready to jump to NSD 4 the
moment it comes out of the beta they need

113
00:05:30.218 --> 00:05:32.000
to run to their testing.

114
00:05:32.000 --> 00:05:36.233
So as of right now, NSD version 3 is no
longer supported so Red Hat pulled it.
