00:27:57.848 --> 00:27:59.860
I've covered it in some of the other
shows, so you can jump and

560
00:27:59.860 --> 00:28:00.759
check that out if you want.

561
00:28:00.759 --> 00:28:05.159
Like in the bind and the unbound shows or
episodes, we've covered that, so

562
00:28:05.159 --> 00:28:06.899
I won't bore us with it here.

563
00:28:06.899 --> 00:28:10.820
But just be aware you do need to open that
up, or you won't be able to communicate.

564
00:28:10.820 --> 00:28:11.778
>> A lot of great information, Don.

565
00:28:11.778 --> 00:28:15.440
We appreciate you letting us know and
showing us how to install and

566
00:28:15.440 --> 00:28:16.780
get NSD up and running.

567
00:28:16.780 --> 00:28:19.730
I know that we are gonna,
in another episode, see those zones.

568
00:28:19.730 --> 00:28:22.930
But it does look like we're coming to the
end of another episode, and before we do,

569
00:28:22.930 --> 00:28:25.130
got any additional words about NSD?

570
00:28:25.130 --> 00:28:27.474
>> Definitely stay tuned because
it's not too fun without zones.

571
00:28:27.474 --> 00:28:29.178
So we're gonna come back and
create some zones.

572
00:28:29.178 --> 00:28:30.729
That's where we'll really see some action,

573
00:28:30.729 --> 00:28:32.366
and you'll definitely want to be here for
that.

574
00:28:32.366 --> 00:28:35.033
>> All right, Don, well, we appreciate
you stopping by the studio, and

575
00:28:35.033 --> 00:28:36.880
we appreciate you, the viewer, watching.

576
00:28:36.880 --> 00:28:39.950
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Brian.

577
00:28:39.950 --> 00:28:40.473
>> And I am Don Pazette.

578
00:28:40.473 --> 00:28:42.957
>> And we'll see you next time.

579
00:28:42.957 --> 00:28:49.142
[MUSIC]

580
00:28:49.142 --> 00:28:52.156
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don talk about the not to common DNS server implementation used in technologies like root hint servers and DNSSEC called NSD. They discuss the step-by-step process of configuring the DNS zone in NSD as well as demonstrate the SOA record configuration, BIND syntax of the zone file an
episodes.title: Configuring Zones in NSD
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:03.334
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host-
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:03.334 --> 00:00:04.878
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco.

3
00:00:04.878 --> 00:00:12.200
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.200 --> 00:00:15.758
>> Welcome to another great episode here
at ITProTV, I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

5
00:00:15.758 --> 00:00:20.001
And in today's episode we are continuing
through our series on DNS tech skills, and

6
00:00:20.001 --> 00:00:24.210
well, we're bringing him back, that's
right, none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

7
00:00:24.210 --> 00:00:25.190
Don, how are you doing, sir?

8
00:00:25.190 --> 00:00:27.560
>> I'm doing swell, Wes,
ready to dive right back into NSD.

9
00:00:27.560 --> 00:00:30.158
We had to end our last episode
kind of on a cliffhanger,

10
00:00:30.158 --> 00:00:32.880
I know you guys have been
waiting in anticipation.

11
00:00:32.880 --> 00:00:36.224
We got NSD installed, we saw how
that all worked, it was great, but

12
00:00:36.224 --> 00:00:38.761
without any zones,
NSD is absolutely worthless.

13
00:00:38.761 --> 00:00:43.277
Because it is authoritative only,
no caching, no recursive lookups,

14
00:00:43.277 --> 00:00:47.730
no forwarders, it either has the zone or
it doesn't, and that's it.

15
00:00:47.730 --> 00:00:51.065
So while we did have it up and running,
I was able to show that it was running,

16
00:00:51.065 --> 00:00:53.010
we didn't really get
to see it do anything.

17
00:00:53.010 --> 00:00:55.195
It's hard to feel like it's an impressive
product when it doesn't do anything.

18
00:00:55.195 --> 00:00:57.527
So in this episode,
we're gonna make it do something.

19
00:00:57.527 --> 00:00:59.083
We're gonna create a forward lookup zone.

20
00:00:59.083 --> 00:01:03.096
We're gonna get chucked in there and get
a chance to see it resolve some of that

21
00:01:03.096 --> 00:01:06.890
information and actually see it
do the stuff it's supposed to do.

22
00:01:06.890 --> 00:01:10.240
So instead of gabbing on about it like
I'm apparently doing, we'll go ahead and

23
00:01:10.240 --> 00:01:11.280
get started [LAUGH].

24
00:01:11.280 --> 00:01:15.337
The first thing I need to do is
I need to create a zone file,

25
00:01:15.337 --> 00:01:19.989
and when they created NSD,
remember that BIND far predates NSD,

26
00:01:19.989 --> 00:01:24.578
but the zone file system used in
BIND has been around a long time.

27
00:01:24.578 --> 00:01:28.232
People like it,
there's not really much to mess with, so

28
00:01:28.232 --> 00:01:33.610
when they created NSD, they just stuck
with the standard BIND format for a zone.

29
00:01:33.610 --> 00:01:34.970
If you create a forward lookup zone or

30
00:01:34.970 --> 00:01:38.920
a reverse lookup zone, the file formats
used in BIND are the same in NSD.

31
00:01:38.920 --> 00:01:43.030
Now, on a positive side, that makes it
really easy to migrate cuz you can just

32
00:01:43.030 --> 00:01:45.110
copy the zone files right over and
reuse them.

33
00:01:45.110 --> 00:01:48.670
Now, you just need to add it to
nsd.conf and you're in business, but

34
00:01:48.670 --> 00:01:52.275
if we need to write them by hand,
it's just the old familiar format

35
00:01:52.275 --> 00:01:56.450
that I'm sure you all have memorized
as well as I do, which is not at all.

36
00:01:56.450 --> 00:01:57.820
So anyhow, we're gonna get in here and

37
00:01:57.820 --> 00:02:01.800
write that zone file, I'm gonna
create a zone file for lab.itpro.tv.

38
00:02:01.800 --> 00:02:03.610
And on the Red-Hat-based distros,

39
00:02:03.610 --> 00:02:08.350
it's gonna go into /etc/nsd, that's
where it expects its zone files to be.

40
00:02:08.350 --> 00:02:10.800
That's where we have nsd.conf also,

41
00:02:10.800 --> 00:02:14.320
as well as all the various authentication
keys that our server can use.

42
00:02:14.320 --> 00:02:16.730
So that stuff's right there,
I'm gonna jump in, and

43
00:02:16.730 --> 00:02:18.830
I'm gonna create the zone file right here.

44
00:02:18.830 --> 00:02:21.710
Now, you do need to be an administrator
to write to this folder, so

45
00:02:21.710 --> 00:02:23.520
you'll either need to sudo these commands,
or

46
00:02:23.520 --> 00:02:26.180
do what I did which is use su
to elevate your privileges.

47
00:02:26.180 --> 00:02:30.620
And I'm gonna edit lab.itpro.tv.dns,

48
00:02:30.620 --> 00:02:33.110
the file name can be
whatever you want it to be.

49
00:02:33.110 --> 00:02:36.100
You can call it bob.text if you want,
the file name doesn't matter.

50
00:02:36.100 --> 00:02:39.500
Right, but I've gotten in the habit
of always using the domain name, so

51
00:02:39.500 --> 00:02:41.943
I'm doing lab.itpro.tv,
that's what I want.

52
00:02:41.943 --> 00:02:44.718
.dns, that's actually a carryover from
some other work I've done on Microsoft

53
00:02:44.718 --> 00:02:46.258
systems where they
always end them in .dns.

54
00:02:46.258 --> 00:02:50.064
I just do that for consistency across the
platform, so you don't have to do that,

55
00:02:50.064 --> 00:02:51.680
you can call it whatever you want.

56
00:02:52.960 --> 00:02:56.140
Then inside of the file,
I need to create my forward lookup zone.

57
00:02:56.140 --> 00:02:59.490
Now, if you're already familiar with this,
it's the standard BIND format, so

58
00:02:59.490 --> 00:03:02.320
feel free to fast forward if you want,
but if you're not familiar with these,

59
00:03:02.320 --> 00:03:04.530
let me show you what has to
go into one of these files.

60
00:03:04.530 --> 00:03:07.170
We'll kinda do the bare minimum,
and then I'll add on some bells and

61
00:03:07.170 --> 00:03:09.050
whistles to it to make it a little nicer.

62
00:03:09.050 --> 00:03:13.720
So let's start with the bare minimum just
so we can make sure the server works, and

63
00:03:13.720 --> 00:03:15.410
then we'll go and
add the others afterwards, okay?

64
00:03:15.410 --> 00:03:18.989
It'll give me a chance to show you how
cool NSD can do at updating zones,

65
00:03:18.989 --> 00:03:19.951
it's kinda neat.

66
00:03:19.951 --> 00:03:23.550
All right, the very first thing
that I need to enter in is, well,

67
00:03:23.550 --> 00:03:27.086
I'm gonna do the absolute bare minimum,
just the rock bottom,

68
00:03:27.086 --> 00:03:30.530
the bare minimum what I need to
do to get this put in place.

69
00:03:30.530 --> 00:03:33.334
So the very first thing I need to do
is I need to put in my default TTL.

70
00:03:33.334 --> 00:03:37.460
And that's the time to live,
how long I'll allow records to be cached.

71
00:03:37.460 --> 00:03:41.560
Now, remember NSD doesn't do caching, so
this isn't how long I'm caching stuff,

72
00:03:41.560 --> 00:03:44.410
it's how long other people
can cache my stuff.

73
00:03:44.410 --> 00:03:48.142
If I'm using Unbound in conjunction
with NSD, which is pretty common,

74
00:03:48.142 --> 00:03:49.068
[COUGH] Excuse me.

75
00:03:49.068 --> 00:03:52.933
If I'm doing that, then what's gonna
happen is Unbound will use this time to

76
00:03:52.933 --> 00:03:57.250
live to determine how long it can hold
a record before checking back in with me.

77
00:03:57.250 --> 00:04:01.250
So I'm gonna set it as 86400,
which is a pretty common value,

78
00:04:01.250 --> 00:04:06.640
I think that works out to 12 hours,
if I remember right, something like that.

79
00:04:06.640 --> 00:04:08.894
So it's a pretty decent time,
maybe too long for some records.

80
00:04:08.894 --> 00:04:11.322
Remember, you can always override time
to live on individual records, so

81
00:04:11.322 --> 00:04:13.029
if you have some that are more
critical than others.

82
00:04:13.029 --> 00:04:14.352
So I'm gonna throw that one in there.

83
00:04:14.352 --> 00:04:18.892
Then let me throw in our
start of authority record.

84
00:04:18.892 --> 00:04:25.230
The SOA record, you have to have it,
this is who is responsible for this zone.

85
00:04:25.230 --> 00:04:28.800
And so the start of authority is
going to be a DNS server somewhere

86
00:04:28.800 --> 00:04:30.350
who's in charge of this zone.

87
00:04:30.350 --> 00:04:34.740
Well, my box is gonna be
dns3.lab.itpro.tv, so

88
00:04:34.740 --> 00:04:37.220
I'm gonna set it up as
the start of authority.

89
00:04:37.220 --> 00:04:41.140
The @ symbol means that I'm
going to be referencing

90
00:04:41.140 --> 00:04:43.230
whatever this domain happens to be.

91
00:04:43.230 --> 00:04:47.391
And NSD will know what this domain is
because well, when I load it in NSD.com,

92
00:04:47.391 --> 00:04:50.985
I have to tell it the domain so
it'll know what that @ symbol is, and

93
00:04:50.985 --> 00:04:53.960
that's like an alias
that it'll explode out.

94
00:04:53.960 --> 00:04:58.459
I could type lab.itpro.tv.,
you have to have a dot at the end, and

95
00:04:58.459 --> 00:05:00.830
that would be the same thing.

96
00:05:00.830 --> 00:05:02.000
If you ever wanna override it,

97
00:05:02.000 --> 00:05:06.460
you can throw like a default domain
up at the top using a Origin command.

98
00:05:06.460 --> 00:05:10.943
I don't normally do that, but
you see it in a lot of textbooks'

99
00:05:10.943 --> 00:05:15.003
examples where they come in and
they say like $ORIGIN and

100
00:05:15.003 --> 00:05:19.676
then lab.itpro.tv., whoops,
lab.itpro.tv., there.

101
00:05:19.676 --> 00:05:24.838
And that way when we leave a domain off,
that it'll assume this one up here.

102
00:05:24.838 --> 00:05:29.146
But even that Origin command will get
overridden when you use the @ symbol

103
00:05:29.146 --> 00:05:32.344
because nsd.conf has
the domain specified there, so

104
00:05:32.344 --> 00:05:34.810
that'll override it with the @ symbol.

105
00:05:34.810 --> 00:05:37.338
This little alias here will really
only work on individual records,

106
00:05:37.338 --> 00:05:38.350
we'll see those later on.

107
00:05:39.530 --> 00:05:41.410
All right,
I know I said I'd do the bare minimum, but

108
00:05:41.410 --> 00:05:45.120
I'll leave the origin up there
just cuz some people like it.

109
00:05:45.120 --> 00:05:47.800
All right, when I do the start of
authority, it is a Internet record,

110
00:05:47.800 --> 00:05:49.850
which almost everything is these days.

111
00:05:49.850 --> 00:05:52.650
In fact,
in NSD it defaults to Internet class, and

112
00:05:52.650 --> 00:05:55.430
so you can leave the IN
off on some of them, but

113
00:05:55.430 --> 00:05:58.960
it's not good practice to do it cuz
we're trying to maintain BIND's format.

114
00:05:58.960 --> 00:06:00.810
And BIND hates it when
you leave stuff off,

115
00:06:00.810 --> 00:06:05.350
so while NSD is forgiving, BIND isn't,
so I still include the class.

116
00:06:05.350 --> 00:06:08.020
I'm gonna create an SOA record,
and it's gonna be for

117
00:06:08.020 --> 00:06:12.860
my server, dns3.lab.itpro.tv., all right?

118
00:06:12.860 --> 00:06:16.610
Now, and I'll throw my dot on the end,
right, it's a stickler about that.

119
00:06:16.610 --> 00:06:19.000
Now, that's the name server that's
gonna be the start of authority,

120
00:06:19.000 --> 00:06:21.140
the person who's authoritative for
this zone.

121
00:06:21.140 --> 00:06:25.473
And in NSD, NSD is an authoritative
server, so it's almost always the server

122
00:06:25.473 --> 00:06:28.770
that you're on,
unless you have more than one NSD server.

123
00:06:28.770 --> 00:06:31.622
If you have more than one NSD server,
it could be one of the other ones, but

124
00:06:31.622 --> 00:06:34.626
it's gonna be some server that you
control because you're authoritative.

125
00:06:34.626 --> 00:06:38.260
You can't be authoritative for somebody
else's domain unless you're spoofing it,

126
00:06:38.260 --> 00:06:41.171
which you could do, but a DNS cycle
will break that down pretty fast.

127
00:06:41.171 --> 00:06:44.220
Then we need to specify an admin,
now the admin,

128
00:06:44.220 --> 00:06:48.235
this is a throwback to the olden days
where this would help us query a record,

129
00:06:48.235 --> 00:06:51.790
you'd create a text record that would
tell you where to find this person.

130
00:06:51.790 --> 00:06:53.833
Most people don't use it anymore,
but you still have to have it, so

131
00:06:53.833 --> 00:07:00.890
I'm gonna put admin.lab.itpro.tv., and
then I'm ready to start my settings.

132
00:07:00.890 --> 00:07:03.100
The start of authority has
to provide five values,

133
00:07:03.100 --> 00:07:05.320
five numbers that identify
how it functions.

134
00:07:05.320 --> 00:07:08.640
The first one is a serial number,
and the serial number,

135
00:07:08.640 --> 00:07:12.210
I'm just gonna write the names out here so
I can remember what each one is.

136
00:07:12.210 --> 00:07:16.870
The serial number is identifying which
version of the database this is,

137
00:07:16.870 --> 00:07:19.570
I just created it, so this is version 1.

138
00:07:19.570 --> 00:07:23.820
If I only have one server, I don't really
care about the serial number at all.

139
00:07:23.820 --> 00:07:28.360
But if I have multiple servers, if I have
other like secondary or slave servers that

140
00:07:28.360 --> 00:07:32.090
are replicating this, they need to know
when the database has been updated so

141
00:07:32.090 --> 00:07:33.890
they can download the new database.

142
00:07:33.890 --> 00:07:35.906
If I've got version 2 and
they're sitting on version 1,

143
00:07:35.906 --> 00:07:38.385
they need to know to get the new one,
so we can bump that serial number up.

144
00:07:38.385 --> 00:07:40.735
In theory,
every time you edit your database,

145
00:07:40.735 --> 00:07:42.870
you should increment that number.

146
00:07:42.870 --> 00:07:45.840
Now, most people forget to do that,
so it doesn't happen.

147
00:07:45.840 --> 00:07:48.859
And while there's other technologies like
incremental transfers that can solve that

148
00:07:48.859 --> 00:07:51.516
problem and work around it, even though
the serial number is not changing.

149
00:07:51.516 --> 00:07:56.027
But as a general rule, you're supposed to
change that every time you edit the file.

150
00:07:56.027 --> 00:08:00.995
The next number is gonna be my refresh
interval, which is how often I check for

151
00:08:00.995 --> 00:08:02.683
changes in my zone files.

152
00:08:02.683 --> 00:08:03.880
So that's going to be my refresh.

153
00:08:03.880 --> 00:08:07.258
And then we'll come in and say my retry.

154
00:08:07.258 --> 00:08:11.002
If I try and forward out to another
server and I get a failure.

155
00:08:11.002 --> 00:08:14.170
How long ago would you retry?

156
00:08:14.170 --> 00:08:19.020
On a NSD server,
it doesn't really have much of an effect.

157
00:08:19.020 --> 00:08:21.480
But I need to have it there, because
I'm following the standard bind format.

158
00:08:22.550 --> 00:08:26.230
All right, and then lastly is my minimum
time to live or my negative time to live.

159
00:08:26.230 --> 00:08:29.490
So that if somebody tries to reduce
the TTL there are limits to how

160
00:08:29.490 --> 00:08:30.600
low we'll let it go.

161
00:08:30.600 --> 00:08:32.410
And so
I can specify what I want that to be.

162
00:08:32.410 --> 00:08:37.770
So we'll throw in something like 3600 and
I'll call that my negative TTL.

163
00:08:39.770 --> 00:08:40.270
All right.

164
00:08:40.270 --> 00:08:41.930
Actually, I have my formatting wrong.

165
00:08:41.930 --> 00:08:43.390
That's the last value.

166
00:08:43.390 --> 00:08:44.070
No, it's not.

167
00:08:44.070 --> 00:08:45.100
Shoot.
I only did four values.

168
00:08:45.100 --> 00:08:45.830
Who did I leave out?

169
00:08:45.830 --> 00:08:47.120
I left out expire.

170
00:08:47.120 --> 00:08:48.360
Shoot.

171
00:08:48.360 --> 00:08:50.340
See this is why we have notes.

172
00:08:50.340 --> 00:08:54.336
So the expiration, how long will I hold on
to records from a server I can no longer

173
00:08:54.336 --> 00:08:57.095
contact before I expire them out and,
and chuck them?

174
00:08:57.095 --> 00:09:03.384
So I'm gonna set my expire to 57,600 and
so that will be my expire.

175
00:09:03.384 --> 00:09:06.370
All right now 3600 that's my last number.

176
00:09:06.370 --> 00:09:09.620
The negative TTL and so
I need to close off my parenthesis.

177
00:09:09.620 --> 00:09:12.970
I open the parenthesis here and
I'm gonna close it off down here.

178
00:09:12.970 --> 00:09:15.280
And knows how I close it
off before that semicolon.

179
00:09:15.280 --> 00:09:19.180
And that's because the semicolon's
actually identifying the end of this whole

180
00:09:19.180 --> 00:09:21.170
line starting with the at symbol.

181
00:09:21.170 --> 00:09:22.120
All the way to there.

182
00:09:22.120 --> 00:09:23.630
That's what's getting closed off, right.

183
00:09:23.630 --> 00:09:24.630
So it's important to have that.

184
00:09:24.630 --> 00:09:26.861
If the syntax is wrong, don't worry,

185
00:09:26.861 --> 00:09:30.520
we've got a syntax checker that will help
us spot that and get in there and fix it.

186
00:09:30.520 --> 00:09:32.823
Making typos actually really
easy to do in these files.

187
00:09:35.410 --> 00:09:36.360
All right.

188
00:09:36.360 --> 00:09:40.730
Now, technically there is only three
things I have to have in a zone file.

189
00:09:40.730 --> 00:09:44.300
I need to have a time to live,
I need to have a start of authority and

190
00:09:44.300 --> 00:09:47.870
I need to have at least one name search.

191
00:09:47.870 --> 00:09:51.020
Preferably two, but
at least one to be syntactically correct.

192
00:09:51.020 --> 00:09:53.870
I don't know if that's a word but
I'm going to use it anyway.

193
00:09:53.870 --> 00:09:55.110
Syntactically correct.

194
00:09:55.110 --> 00:09:57.180

00:23:58.841 --> 00:24:02.287

00:24:05.490 --> 00:24:06.250

00:24:06.250 --> 00:24:08.810
And this is where my

00:24:08.810 --> 00:24:12.620
So now when a CNAME lookup goes to

00:24:12.620 --> 00:24:14.520

00:24:14.520 --> 00:24:17.760

Independently, they are of

00:24:23.832 --> 00:24:24.455
all right.

>> Other than a PTR record, but

00:25:17.450 --> 00:25:20.790
>> Yeah, yeah, so a PTR record,
if we want to do a reverse lookup zone,

00:25:20.790 --> 00:25:22.870
we'd actually have to create
a whole new zone file, right,

506
00:25:22.870 --> 00:25:24.820
cuz that's not gonna
be a part of this one.

00:25:24.820 --> 00:25:28.430
But I'm glad you asked, cuz we definitely
don't have time to jump into that one.

00:25:28.430 --> 00:25:32.260
But basically you'd create a zone
file that would be named with

00:25:32.260 --> 00:25:34.002
the reverse lookup format.

00:25:34.002 --> 00:25:37.509
So in my case,

00:25:37.509 --> 00:25:42.072

So you would say PTR, and

on the left side would be an IP, and on

00:26:21.120 --> 00:26:24.260
I'm doing where it's a name on
the left side and an IP on the right.

00:26:24.260 --> 00:26:27.910
So that would be it, but otherwise, the
reverse lookup zones are just like forward

00:26:27.910 --> 00:26:30.170
lookup zones, except for

00:26:30.170 --> 00:26:32.740
>> Would your SRV records

00:26:32.740 --> 00:26:34.360
>> Yeah, if I did SRV records.

00:26:34.360 --> 00:26:35.745
You had to pick the hardest one,

00:26:35.745 --> 00:26:36.318
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

00:26:36.318 --> 00:26:41.240
yeah, those would go in here
to if we had SRV records.

00:26:41.240 --> 00:26:43.110

00:26:43.110 --> 00:26:44.250

00:26:44.250 --> 00:26:49.250

00:26:54.240 --> 00:26:57.480
I actually don't remember the SRV

00:26:57.480 --> 00:26:59.590
I know we did an episode on SRV records.

So definitely check that out, we've

00:27:01.790 --> 00:27:02.960
you can just kinda see how to do that.

00:27:03.960 --> 00:27:07.040
All right, this is a pretty good run right

00:27:12.720 --> 00:27:15.050

00:27:15.050 --> 00:27:16.661

Now, earlier, I ran nsd-control reconfig.

00:27:25.020 --> 00:27:27.280

00:27:29.270 --> 00:27:32.840
So instead of running reconfig,

what I can run instead

00:27:39.950 --> 00:27:43.480
And that's gonna tell it the config
hasn't changed, that's the same.

00:27:43.480 --> 00:27:45.060
But let's just do a lookup or

00:27:45.060 --> 00:27:49.650
do a quick check on the zone file and
reload that, update our database.

555
00:27:49.650 --> 00:27:51.640
Cuz it is maintaining
a database in the back end.

556
00:27:51.640 --> 00:27:53.800
And that's not gonna affect
any of the other zones and

557
00:27:53.800 --> 00:27:55.840
it's gonna get those records put in place.

558
00:27:55.840 --> 00:28:00.980
And so now when I do a lookup
against my system I can come in and

00:28:00.980 --> 00:28:03.730
do like a dig on my server.

00:28:05.960 --> 00:28:11.140

00:28:11.140 --> 00:28:14.820

if this was unbound it

,and explodes that into the individual

00:28:21.180 --> 00:28:22.320

00:28:22.320 --> 00:28:24.466

00:28:33.683 --> 00:28:36.751

00:28:55.613 --> 00:28:57.440

00:29:34.278 --> 00:29:39.600

00:29:48.780 --> 00:29:51.532

00:29:51.532 --> 00:29:52.520

00:29:55.810 --> 00:29:56.640

00:29:56.640 --> 00:29:57.620
It's doing its job.

600
00:29:57.620 --> 00:30:00.965
And its really,
really good at doing that job.

601
00:30:00.965 --> 00:30:05.810
>> [LAUGH] Great explanation on getting

00:30:05.810 --> 00:30:08.020

00:30:14.300 --> 00:30:17.120
>> Never forget that NSD
is authoritative only.

00:30:17.120 --> 00:30:19.150
I get that question a lot
from people saying like hey,

00:30:19.150 --> 00:30:21.440

00:30:21.440 --> 00:30:24.380
It doesn't, there's no way to make
it do that, you just can't do it.

609
00:30:24.380 --> 00:30:28.430
And also remember that in real life most
people deploy NSD alongside unbound,

610
00:30:28.430 --> 00:30:30.290
they have both, right?

611
00:30:30.290 --> 00:30:34.780
That together, they can replace BIND or
Microsoft DNS or PowerDNS or

612
00:30:34.780 --> 00:30:35.410
one of those guys.

613
00:30:35.410 --> 00:30:39.410
They can replace it, but individually,
they're gonna rely on other things.

614
00:30:39.410 --> 00:30:43.980
So you might have BIND on the front
end and NSD on the back end,

615
00:30:43.980 --> 00:30:44.970
which is a terrible idea.

616
00:30:44.970 --> 00:30:46.050
But you can do it.

617
00:30:46.050 --> 00:30:48.860
Normally, you're gonna have unbound and
NSD working together.

618
00:30:48.860 --> 00:30:49.600

let me recheck that config.

693
00:35:57.140 --> 00:36:02.337
And actually still getting
a connection refused.

694
00:36:02.337 --> 00:36:05.371
That's interesting,
let me restart the service.

695
00:36:08.227 --> 00:36:08.982
See what I've broken.

696
00:36:15.101 --> 00:36:15.916
Working now, all right.

697
00:36:15.916 --> 00:36:20.200
So we should be good to go,
right, everything should be up.

698
00:36:20.200 --> 00:36:22.980
On the other side, let me go and
trigger that, right.

699
00:36:22.980 --> 00:36:26.284
So I'm gonna switch back over to my slave,
and

700
00:36:26.284 --> 00:36:30.201
I'm just gonna do a systemctl
restart nsd.service.

701
00:36:30.201 --> 00:36:34.163
All right, so it should be
reaching out to the other side and

702
00:36:34.163 --> 00:36:37.180
getting that zone and bringing it over.

703
00:36:37.180 --> 00:36:39.360
Okay, now how do I know if that worked?

704
00:36:39.360 --> 00:36:43.650
Well, we can look in /var/log/nsd.log.

705
00:36:43.650 --> 00:36:47.610
And I was getting errors before,
here's all my errors.

706
00:36:47.610 --> 00:36:49.680
But now we can see signal received,

707
00:36:49.680 --> 00:36:52.340
shutting down, so
that's me restarting the service.

708
00:36:52.340 --> 00:36:55.440
I can see the service starting,
and then right here,

709
00:36:55.440 --> 00:37:00.110
zone lab.itpro.tv serial 0,
which means I have no serial number.

710
00:37:00.110 --> 00:37:01.140
I don't have the zone.

711
00:37:01.140 --> 00:37:03.770
And then it says it's updated to 1.

712
00:37:03.770 --> 00:37:05.425
I just got the serial
number from the other side.

713
00:37:05.425 --> 00:37:07.290
I know I'm talking to the other side.

714
00:37:07.290 --> 00:37:11.120
And on the other side, now I sound like
that Crossing Over with John Edward J,

715
00:37:11.120 --> 00:37:13.000
we're talking to the other side.

716
00:37:13.000 --> 00:37:19.240
So now over here, I should be able to do
a look into the log files on this one.

717
00:37:19.240 --> 00:37:23.820
So if I go into /var/log/nsd.log.

718
00:37:23.820 --> 00:37:25.936
And I look at the end, no errors, right?

719
00:37:25.936 --> 00:37:27.650
Just starting up, that's it.

720
00:37:27.650 --> 00:37:29.460
No crazy errors to be found in here.

721
00:37:29.460 --> 00:37:32.770
On the other side,
if I jump back over to that guest,

722
00:37:32.770 --> 00:37:38.140
I can do an nsd-control
zonestatus lab.itpro.tv.

723
00:37:38.140 --> 00:37:42.270
Now earlier when I ran this,
the status was refreshing and

724
00:37:42.270 --> 00:37:46.920
then the other numbers were empty
cuz I never got a copy of the zone.

725
00:37:46.920 --> 00:37:51.470
Now the state is okay, and
I've got a serial number.

726
00:37:51.470 --> 00:37:53.770
Here's the serial number that I got and
how long I've had it.

727
00:37:53.770 --> 00:37:55.300
I've got a valid zone.

728
00:37:55.300 --> 00:38:00.100
And I should be able to do
a dig against this server.

729
00:38:00.100 --> 00:38:03.630
So this is my dns4, so .104, and

730
00:38:03.630 --> 00:38:08.430
I should be able to look up
something like www.lab.itpro.tv.

731
00:38:08.430 --> 00:38:09.672
And there's the records, okay?

732
00:38:09.672 --> 00:38:14.489
Now the neatest part about
all this is that if I look,

733
00:38:14.489 --> 00:38:19.440
I don't actually have
a lab.itpro.tv.dns file.

734
00:38:19.440 --> 00:38:21.360
The zone doesn't actually exist here.

735
00:38:21.360 --> 00:38:24.420
I'm copying it from the master and
I'm running it in my database.

736
00:38:24.420 --> 00:38:26.820
It actually does get tucked away in
a temporary folder somewhere but

737
00:38:26.820 --> 00:38:27.510
it's just temporary.

738
00:38:27.510 --> 00:38:29.720
If I restart the service it's gonna go and
retransfer it and

739
00:38:29.720 --> 00:38:30.520
get it over here again right.

740
00:38:30.520 --> 00:38:32.390
It's all coming down from the master.

741
00:38:32.390 --> 00:38:33.900
Those are temporary zones.

742
00:38:33.900 --> 00:38:36.790
There's a handful of
commands in nsd-control.

743
00:38:36.790 --> 00:38:38.530
I know I'm way out of time here.

744
00:38:38.530 --> 00:38:41.500
Where you can do add zones and
delete zones, and

745
00:38:41.500 --> 00:38:45.290
those are all for temporary zones, ones
that aren't stored in your hard drive,

746
00:38:45.290 --> 00:38:47.250
things like replication
that we're setting up here.

747
00:38:47.250 --> 00:38:50.500
But most of them aren't terribly effective
because these are really new commands that

748
00:38:50.500 --> 00:38:52.200
are still being incorporated.

749
00:38:52.200 --> 00:38:56.720
So the way that I've done it is kinda
the traditional way of doing it.

750
00:38:56.720 --> 00:38:59.010
Things like force transfer, well,

751
00:38:59.010 --> 00:39:01.500
I was forcing a transfer just
by restarting this service.

752
00:39:01.500 --> 00:39:03.360
If it's in production,
obviously you wanna minimize that.

753
00:39:03.360 --> 00:39:06.660
So you can force transfer
different things, and

754
00:39:06.660 --> 00:39:09.450
other activities right from here.

755
00:39:09.450 --> 00:39:13.760
But as far as I'm concerned,
I'm now up and running, I've got my zone.

756
00:39:13.760 --> 00:39:14.660
I'm a valid slave.

757
00:39:14.660 --> 00:39:17.570
It's gonna keep running,
and that's it, we're done.

758
00:39:17.570 --> 00:39:19.410
So now we've got a replica, and

759
00:39:19.410 --> 00:39:24.172
we can setup continual more replicas,
however we need, and we'll be in business.

760
00:39:24.172 --> 00:39:24.735
>> All right,

761
00:39:24.735 --> 00:39:27.839
Don, a lot of great information
getting that NSD server online.

762
00:39:27.839 --> 00:39:31.279
You've already mentioned it,
we're way out of time here, but

763
00:39:31.279 --> 00:39:34.276
we've always got some time for
some additional words or

764
00:39:34.276 --> 00:39:37.670
maybe considerations that you
might want to tell our viewers.

765
00:39:37.670 --> 00:39:40.534
>> The main thing is I never did get
around to setting security keys.

766
00:39:40.534 --> 00:39:43.297
I was hoping to do that here in this
episode but remember what I said,

767
00:39:43.297 --> 00:39:46.510
I just wanted to get it working first,
and then we'd apply the security keys.

768
00:39:46.510 --> 00:39:49.090
So that's what I'm going to do next,
and we're gonna do a part two on this.

769
00:39:49.090 --> 00:39:51.090
It might not be the longest
episode in the world but

770
00:39:51.090 --> 00:39:54.620
all we need to do is get in there and
apply secure keys to these so

771
00:39:54.620 --> 00:39:56.750
that somebody can't come and
perform a man in the middle attack.

772
00:39:56.750 --> 00:39:58.750
Intercept the zone transfer,
modify some records,

773
00:39:58.750 --> 00:40:01.590
chuck them in there,
all of the sudden I've got poisoned DNS.

774
00:40:01.590 --> 00:40:04.805
It's surprisingly easy to pull off that
type of attack, so we need to try and

775
00:40:04.805 --> 00:40:05.367
prevent it.

776
00:40:05.367 --> 00:40:09.330
Keys on zone transfers is the way
that we're gonna fix that.

777
00:40:09.330 --> 00:40:11.270
So stay tuned for part two.

778
00:40:11.270 --> 00:40:13.130
We're gonna jump in and
get a chance to see that.

779
00:40:13.130 --> 00:40:15.420
And after that you'll
have a nice stable and

780
00:40:15.420 --> 00:40:19.060
secure master slave
environment inside of NSD.

781
00:40:19.060 --> 00:40:19.643
All right, Don.

782
00:40:19.643 --> 00:40:22.870
Well, thank you for all that knowledge and
thank you to the viewer watching.

783
00:40:22.870 --> 00:40:23.980
Remember, stick around.

784
00:40:23.980 --> 00:40:25.660
We do have a part two coming.

785
00:40:25.660 --> 00:40:28.660
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

786
00:40:28.660 --> 00:40:29.300
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

787
00:40:29.300 --> 00:40:29.819
>> And we'll see you next time.

789

>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.210 --> 00:00:02.616
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.616 --> 00:00:06.104
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.104 --> 00:00:08.453
>> [MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.453 --> 00:00:12.140
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.140 --> 00:00:15.000
>> Welcome back to another
great episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.000 --> 00:00:15.940
I'm your host, Wes Bryan,

7
00:00:15.940 --> 00:00:19.850
and in today's episode we're
continuing through our DNS tech skills.

8
00:00:19.850 --> 00:00:23.945
We're actually coming back with a part
two on configuring replication in NBS.

9
00:00:23.945 --> 00:00:26.910
Joining us back in the studios is
none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:26.910 --> 00:00:27.820
Don, how you doing, sir?

11
00:00:27.820 --> 00:00:30.229
>> I'm doing swell, Wes,
ready to dive back into NSD.

12
00:00:30.229 --> 00:00:30.841
And in fact,

13
00:00:30.841 --> 00:00:34.820
this is part two to our last episode where
we were configuring replication, right?

14
00:00:34.820 --> 00:00:36.846
We set up a master slave model of NSD.

15
00:00:36.846 --> 00:00:39.880
If you haven't watched part one,
you definitely wanna check it out.

16
00:00:39.880 --> 00:00:40.800
We got everything running.

17
00:00:40.800 --> 00:00:44.380
We're replicating between the two, so we
successfully got the master slave model.

18
00:00:44.380 --> 00:00:48.350
The only thing is I didn't get
a chance to put security keys or

19
00:00:48.350 --> 00:00:50.500
authentication key on the replication.

20
00:00:50.500 --> 00:00:56.958
So as it stands now I'm replicating data
between my server DNS3 and my server DNS4.

21
00:00:56.958 --> 00:01:01.982
But without authentication anybody
could intercept traffic in the middle,

22
00:01:01.982 --> 00:01:06.628
due to the man in the middle attack,
modify the zone file and send it on.

23
00:01:06.628 --> 00:01:08.973
And the other side's gonna have no
idea that it's been tampered with or

24
00:01:08.973 --> 00:01:10.930
that it's coming from
an inappropriate source.

25
00:01:10.930 --> 00:01:14.880
And that means they can poison my DNS
records, that's not a good thing.

26
00:01:14.880 --> 00:01:19.460
So we need a little extra security,
and for that we're going to use keys.

27
00:01:19.460 --> 00:01:24.630
I'm gonna put keys on each of the settings
that lets the master talk to the slave

28
00:01:24.630 --> 00:01:27.710
to ensure that we can validate
the identity of who's on the other side.

29
00:01:27.710 --> 00:01:30.450
Now, MSD has this functionality built in.

30
00:01:30.450 --> 00:01:36.290
It actually uses its SHA-256 encrypted
hashes that it exchanges between the two.

31
00:01:36.290 --> 00:01:40.070
So very secure method of communicating,
and it's one of the reasons why a lot of

32
00:01:40.070 --> 00:01:44.100
people prefer MSD these days, cuz it's
got security built into it like that.

33
00:01:44.100 --> 00:01:48.470
So the hardest part about this
is coming up with a key, right?

34
00:01:48.470 --> 00:01:50.520
A lot of people will make up a key
right off the top of their head.

35
00:01:50.520 --> 00:01:54.520
Which is actually not a good idea because
humans are horrible at being random.

36
00:01:54.520 --> 00:01:56.090
Computers aren't so great at it either.

37
00:01:56.090 --> 00:01:58.300
But there's a few different
techniques we can generate for a key.

38
00:01:58.300 --> 00:02:01.430
And there's one standard kinda method
that we see in the Linux world.

39
00:02:01.430 --> 00:02:04.210
As long as you have good entropy
on your system, you can use DD,

40
00:02:04.210 --> 00:02:08.220
the disc duplicator to take
the contents of your disk or

41
00:02:08.220 --> 00:02:14.760
contents of /dev/random and
generate a key based on random data.

42
00:02:14.760 --> 00:02:18.290
Now the random number generator
inside of Linux is only as good

43
00:02:18.290 --> 00:02:20.550
as the disk trail that you're running,
and a lot of them have updates and

44
00:02:20.550 --> 00:02:21.900
things that have been pushed out.

45
00:02:21.900 --> 00:02:25.760
Some systems have hardware random number
generators, which are really awesome.

46
00:02:25.760 --> 00:02:27.934
But if you don't have that, you can
at least make use of what you've got.

47
00:02:27.934 --> 00:02:32.316
So that's what I'm gonna do here, is I'm
gonna generate as random a key as I can,

48
00:02:32.316 --> 00:02:34.742
and I will use it on
these different systems.

49
00:02:34.742 --> 00:02:37.906
Remember, if you've got 20 different
slaves out there you could have 20

50
00:02:37.906 --> 00:02:40.291
different keys if you want,
to keep it nice and granular,

51
00:02:40.291 --> 00:02:41.618
or you can re-use the same key.

52
00:02:41.618 --> 00:02:42.787
But if the key gets compromised,

53
00:02:42.787 --> 00:02:46.752
it's now compromised throughout the entire
environment, so always be aware of that.

54
00:02:46.752 --> 00:02:50.000
All right, let me show you the way that
I generate keys out there in the field.

55
00:02:50.000 --> 00:02:53.400
So if I need to get a key generated,
I use the DD utility.

56
00:02:53.400 --> 00:02:57.490
And I'm gonna do an interface,
I'm sorry, an input file.

57
00:02:57.490 --> 00:02:58.725
So where am I getting my data from?

58
00:02:58.725 --> 00:03:02.219
I'm gonna pull my data from /dev/random,
right?

59
00:03:02.219 --> 00:03:05.255
/dev/random is the random
number generator for Linux.

60
00:03:05.255 --> 00:03:07.630
So I'm just calling that,
and there's actually four or

61
00:03:07.630 --> 00:03:09.416
five different RNG's that are out there.

62
00:03:09.416 --> 00:03:12.450
And depending on your distro, it can
reference any number of different ones.

63
00:03:12.450 --> 00:03:16.800
So this is just kind of an alias that
points to whatever is your default.

64
00:03:16.800 --> 00:03:20.538
And then I'm gonna do
an output file of /dev,

65
00:03:20.538 --> 00:03:23.194
I'm gonna say it right and spell it wrong.

66
00:03:23.194 --> 00:03:25.163
/dev/stdout, right?

67
00:03:25.163 --> 00:03:26.897
I wanna be able to see it on the screen.

68
00:03:26.897 --> 00:03:29.890
So I'm gonna get some data
out of /tab/random and

69
00:03:29.890 --> 00:03:31.915
I'm gonna output it to my screen.

70
00:03:31.915 --> 00:03:35.762
And I'm gonna tell it just to do it
once and give me a block size of 32.

71
00:03:35.762 --> 00:03:38.665
So it's gonna give me,
it won't be 32 bits, and

72
00:03:38.665 --> 00:03:43.540
then I'm going to render it as base 64,
which is what I want my key to be in.

73
00:03:43.540 --> 00:03:47.950
This is gonna give me a nice
good random stream, right?

74
00:03:47.950 --> 00:03:49.345
And so I can see that right here.

75
00:03:49.345 --> 00:03:52.969
32 bytes were copied and here's my stream.

76
00:03:52.969 --> 00:03:55.520
Now could I have thought
of this on my own?

77
00:03:55.520 --> 00:03:58.850
Maybe, but the odds are by the time I
got to the eighth or ninth character,

78
00:03:58.850 --> 00:04:02.397
I'd start, you know, reusing things or
I have a habit of just picking numbers

79
00:04:02.397 --> 00:04:04.578
between one and five and
then higher than five.

80
00:04:04.578 --> 00:04:07.920
I don't know why I do that, but I do.

81
00:04:07.920 --> 00:04:09.780
But that's a good random
stream right there.

82
00:04:09.780 --> 00:04:14.680
So that's all I'm trying to is get
some random data that I didn't make.

83
00:04:14.680 --> 00:04:17.080
And once I've got that I can
just copy that to my clipboard.

84
00:04:17.080 --> 00:04:21.715
And I'm gonna put that key on both
sides of my replication, right?

85
00:04:21.715 --> 00:04:24.607
I need both sides to have it, so
that I know that it's gonna work and

86
00:04:24.607 --> 00:04:26.860
that everything's gonna function.

87
00:04:26.860 --> 00:04:30.350
So I'm on DNS3 which is my master.

88
00:04:30.350 --> 00:04:37.413
And so I'm gonna edit, /etc/nsd/nsd.conf.

89
00:04:37.413 --> 00:04:42.512
And I'm gonna go all the way down to
the bottom where I define my zone and

90
00:04:42.512 --> 00:04:43.989
my pattern, okay?

91
00:04:43.989 --> 00:04:48.450
It was in the pattern that
we actually set the key.

92
00:04:48.450 --> 00:04:49.620
And so when I configured this,

93
00:04:49.620 --> 00:04:53.360
I did it with no key,
just to get things done, right?

94
00:04:53.360 --> 00:04:56.350
Just because I didn't want
to have to mess with that.

95
00:04:56.350 --> 00:05:00.370
So what I'm gonna do now
is actually add a key.

96
00:05:00.370 --> 00:05:02.520
And so I'm gonna come up above this and

97
00:05:02.520 --> 00:05:06.980
I'm gonna add another line,
key, and I'll give it a name.

98
00:05:06.980 --> 00:05:11.380
And I'm gonna name this key, this is what
I do, you can name it whatever you want,

99
00:05:11.380 --> 00:05:15.390
but I like to name it based on
the servers that are gonna use it.

100
00:05:15.390 --> 00:05:18.611
This is the key I'm using for
DNS3 to DNS4.

101
00:05:18.611 --> 00:05:21.810
I might have other ones that connect to
different systems, but this is the one for

102
00:05:21.810 --> 00:05:22.700
DNS3 to DNS4.

103
00:05:22.700 --> 00:05:24.640
That's gonna be the name of my key.

104
00:05:24.640 --> 00:05:31.350
Then I can say the algorithm that I wanna
use, and I'm gonna use hmac-sha256.

105
00:05:31.350 --> 00:05:34.552
Right, that's a pretty good algorithm for
me.

106
00:05:34.552 --> 00:05:36.480
It will give me the level
of security that I need.

107
00:05:36.480 --> 00:05:41.737
And then I'll say, secret, and then,
here is where I paste in my key.

108
00:05:41.737 --> 00:05:46.306
So there's my key,
right there, layout, all right?

109
00:05:46.306 --> 00:05:48.560
So now that I've got that in place,

110
00:05:48.560 --> 00:05:52.530
I've got a key,
everywhere down here that I say NOKEY?

111
00:05:52.530 --> 00:05:54.980
Instead of saying NOKEY,
I can now provide a key name.

112
00:05:54.980 --> 00:05:56.650
So I can delete NOKEY and

113
00:05:56.650 --> 00:06:02.380
I can put dns3-dns4 and same thing
on this next line, dns3-dns4 right?

114
00:06:04.460 --> 00:06:08.955
So now when I provide a transfer,
or when I send a notification,

115
00:06:08.955 --> 00:06:14.801
I'm gonna send this hash to authenticate
myself and authenticate the other side.

116
00:06:14.801 --> 00:06:17.410
And if they don't match,
it's going to fail, right?

117
00:06:17.410 --> 00:06:22.100
So now I've got that setup right here
with something that I know is random,

118
00:06:22.100 --> 00:06:24.170
at least, as good as I'm gonna get, right?

119
00:06:24.170 --> 00:06:26.260
So that's the key setup right here.

120
00:06:26.260 --> 00:06:29.910
Now the key isn't gonna take
effect until I load that.

121
00:06:29.910 --> 00:06:32.520
So I'm gonna, well,
I've learned my lesson, right,

122
00:06:32.520 --> 00:06:38.262
I'm gonna do an nsd-control,
sorry, nsd-checkconf

123
00:06:38.262 --> 00:06:44.260
/etc/nsd/nsd.conf, so I wanna make
sure I didn't get any errors, right?

124
00:06:44.260 --> 00:06:51.067
And then I will do a nsd-control
reconfig so that we reload it.

125
00:06:51.067 --> 00:06:54.280
All right, so now I'm expecting those
keys when I reach out to the other side.

126
00:06:56.170 --> 00:06:59.990
On the other side,
my replication should be failing.

127
00:06:59.990 --> 00:07:02.132
I might not see that,
right, on the other side.

128
00:07:02.132 --> 00:07:04.790
On DNS4, if it tries to
replicate right now it's gonna

129
00:07:04.790 --> 00:07:07.001
fail cuz I don't have keys over here,
right?

130
00:07:07.001 --> 00:07:08.143
But I might not see that.

131
00:07:08.143 --> 00:07:12.312
If you do an nsd-control zone status and

132
00:07:12.312 --> 00:07:17.346
I pull it up for that zone,
everything's okay.

133
00:07:17.346 --> 00:07:18.757
Well, it's failing but

134
00:07:18.757 --> 00:07:22.460
it had good ones in the past which
is holding onto ones in the past.

135
00:07:22.460 --> 00:07:24.904
Eventually I'll hit the expiration for
that zone.

136
00:07:24.904 --> 00:07:28.211
I think I set my expiration
to 86,400 seconds.

137
00:07:28.211 --> 00:07:31.190
So after that time it will expire and
then I'll have a problem, but

138
00:07:31.190 --> 00:07:32.638
in the short term, I'm not gonna see it.

139
00:07:32.638 --> 00:07:34.040
If I wanna see the problem,

140
00:07:34.040 --> 00:07:36.220
probably the easiest thing to
do is just restart the thing.

141
00:07:36.220 --> 00:07:41.170
So if I do a systemctl
restart nsd.service,

142
00:07:41.170 --> 00:07:44.320
it's gonna restart, and
that's gonna dump what I've cached, and

143
00:07:44.320 --> 00:07:46.950
then it's gonna try and
retransfer it down.

144
00:07:46.950 --> 00:07:50.490
And so now when I look,
my state's refreshing.

145
00:07:50.490 --> 00:07:52.340
And it's failing, right?

146
00:07:52.340 --> 00:07:58.860
If I look in /var/log/nsd.log,
I can see my transfer is failing, right?

147
00:07:58.860 --> 00:08:02.090
I can see that I've received an error
code refused from the server,

148
00:08:02.090 --> 00:08:03.880
it's not getting through, right?

149
00:08:03.880 --> 00:08:06.618
And if I jump back over to the other
server, I should be seeing some errors,

150
00:08:06.618 --> 00:08:07.314
well, actually,

151
00:08:07.314 --> 00:08:10.463
I probably won't see the errors here cuz
it's just gonna refuse the stuff outright?

152
00:08:10.463 --> 00:08:11.715
But we can look.

153
00:08:11.715 --> 00:08:17.915
If I look at /var/log/nsd.log, let's see.

154
00:08:17.915 --> 00:08:20.712
We've got warning signals received,
that's just a restart, yeah.

155
00:08:20.712 --> 00:08:22.718
So no crazy errors to be found in here.

156
00:08:22.718 --> 00:08:26.480
Maybe in the assist log.

157
00:08:28.170 --> 00:08:29.340
Nope, nothing there either.

158
00:08:29.340 --> 00:08:31.640
So everything's looking fine on this side.

159
00:08:31.640 --> 00:08:32.650
Because we're sending a key.

160
00:08:32.650 --> 00:08:34.990
The other side doesn't match,
what do we care, right?

161
00:08:34.990 --> 00:08:37.220
We're the master, so
I don't care if they work or not.

162
00:08:37.220 --> 00:08:38.830
So that's what we're seeing right now.

163
00:08:38.830 --> 00:08:43.820
So what I need to do now is I need to go
and add the key to the other side, right?

164
00:08:43.820 --> 00:08:49.540
So I'm gonna go ahead and
edit, /etc/nsd/nsd.com.

165
00:08:49.540 --> 00:08:52.340
I'm gonna jump all the way
down to the bottom.

166
00:08:52.340 --> 00:08:56.200
And I'm gonna define the exact same key,
it needs to match.

167
00:08:56.200 --> 00:08:57.590
If it doesn't match,
it's not gonna work, right?

168
00:08:57.590 --> 00:08:59.040
So that's kind of important.

169
00:08:59.040 --> 00:09:00.490
So I'm gonna give it a name.

170
00:09:00.490 --> 00:09:02.430
And the name doesn't
actually have to match.

171
00:09:02.430 --> 00:09:03.950
The name can be whatever you want, right?

172
00:09:03.950 --> 00:09:05.090
The key is what has to match.

173
00:09:05.090 --> 00:09:07.660
But I'm gonna stick with
the same name because again

174
00:09:07.660 --> 00:09:09.760
that's what I do to make it
easier to troubleshoot stuff.

175
00:09:09.760 --> 00:09:15.980
So I'm gonna call this dns3-dns4,
cuz that's the name I want for my key.

176
00:09:15.980 --> 00:09:21.120
I want my algorithm to be hmac-sha256,

177
00:09:21.120 --> 00:09:26.194
which absolutely has to match,
too many dashes.

178
00:09:26.194 --> 00:09:34.880
Hmac-sha256, and then from there I need
to do secret, and then what my secret is.

179
00:09:34.880 --> 00:09:37.071
And I'm just gonna paste it right
into the same as the other side, so

180
00:09:37.071 --> 00:09:37.889
they both have the same.

181
00:09:37.889 --> 00:09:41.880
It's a preshared key that we're using,
and it's got it in place.

182
00:09:41.880 --> 00:09:45.380
And now I can go down here and
take anywhere where I've got NOKEY and

183
00:09:45.380 --> 00:09:48.460
change that to the right values.

184
00:09:51.230 --> 00:09:54.190
All right, and
now that I've got that in place,

185
00:09:54.190 --> 00:09:56.770
I'm set to use that key when
I talk to the other side.

186
00:09:56.770 --> 00:10:00.180
When I get a notification, I'll allow the
notification, assuming the key matches,

187
00:10:00.180 --> 00:10:01.690
and same thing when requesting a transfer.

188
00:10:01.690 --> 00:10:03.290
I'll request it with this key.

189
00:10:03.290 --> 00:10:06.299
>> Now in the first part of that where you
said the key, you said the name doesn't

190
00:10:06.299 --> 00:10:09.660
matter, but when you call on it in pattern
at that point the name does matter, right?

191
00:10:09.660 --> 00:10:11.480
>> Sure, yeah, within the file it matters.

192
00:10:11.480 --> 00:10:15.717
But what I meant was I might have called
the key Fred on the other server and

193
00:10:15.717 --> 00:10:17.790
on this server I called it Bob.

194
00:10:17.790 --> 00:10:18.385
>> Okay.
>> And

195
00:10:18.385 --> 00:10:20.651
that's okay,
cuz they don't exchange names.

196
00:10:20.651 --> 00:10:21.500
But you're absolutely right.

197
00:10:21.500 --> 00:10:22.330
Right here in the file,

198
00:10:22.330 --> 00:10:25.840
when I define it in the key,
that's gotta match what I do right here.

199
00:10:25.840 --> 00:10:27.030
That absolutely has to match.

200
00:10:27.030 --> 00:10:30.480
But I could use different names,
like on here I might call it dns4-dns3.

201
00:10:30.480 --> 00:10:33.430
But for me that gets confusing,
I like to use the same

202
00:10:33.430 --> 00:10:36.730
key name across the different servers so I
can remember what the heck it was, right?

203
00:10:36.730 --> 00:10:39.580
The key's the same, might as well make
the name the same, and there you go,

204
00:10:39.580 --> 00:10:40.790
all right?

205
00:10:40.790 --> 00:10:43.394
So now that I've got that
in place I can get out,

206
00:10:43.394 --> 00:10:45.428
assuming that I didn't screw it up.

207
00:10:45.428 --> 00:10:51.238
We can do a quick check config,
/etc/nsd/nsd.com,

208
00:10:51.238 --> 00:10:55.239
and it at least thinks that it's okay.

209
00:10:55.239 --> 00:11:01.230
And then we can do an nsd-control,
reconfig, all right?

210
00:11:01.230 --> 00:11:02.110
So it's gonna reload.

211
00:11:03.280 --> 00:11:04.010
I didn't get any errors.

212
00:11:04.010 --> 00:11:04.977
That's good, right?

213
00:11:04.977 --> 00:11:06.871
But I didn't get any errors last time.

214
00:11:06.871 --> 00:11:09.100
It just tried to replicate and
failed a bunch.

215
00:11:09.100 --> 00:11:12.010
And so, how do I know if it worked?

216
00:11:12.010 --> 00:11:15.860
Well, the easiest way is to pull up
the zone status, and see what I get.

217
00:11:15.860 --> 00:11:18.970
If I have refreshing,
that means I haven't synced.

218
00:11:18.970 --> 00:11:20.720
I haven't gotten it yet, okay?

219
00:11:20.720 --> 00:11:23.990
Well, I've seen this before where
sometimes it takes a little while or

220
00:11:23.990 --> 00:11:25.420
it doesn't quite sync up.

221
00:11:25.420 --> 00:11:27.350
That can cause a problem.

222
00:11:27.350 --> 00:11:30.400
Also sometimes you just have to wait.

223
00:11:30.400 --> 00:11:31.490
Sometimes you get inpatient.

224
00:11:31.490 --> 00:11:32.720
I know I do.

225
00:11:32.720 --> 00:11:37.720
The other thing is it's possible
that one side hasn't taken the key

226
00:11:37.720 --> 00:11:38.970
versus the other side.

227
00:11:38.970 --> 00:11:45.285
So worst case scenario, you can always
do a systemctl restart and restart nsd.

228
00:11:45.285 --> 00:11:48.890
I did a reconfig, which should load the
key, but if I already have an established

229
00:11:48.890 --> 00:11:52.860
session that's failed too many times,
I might not restart that session.

230
00:11:52.860 --> 00:11:56.880
I do generally like to restart
the master first if I'm gonna do that.

231
00:11:56.880 --> 00:12:01.460
So if I wanna restart nsd, I can
restart it over here and I can jump and

232
00:12:01.460 --> 00:12:02.542
restart it over here.

233
00:12:02.542 --> 00:12:05.730
And so that's gonna kick it off and
tell it to reach out and talk again, and

234
00:12:05.730 --> 00:12:12.880
then I can monitor/var/log/nsd.log and
see if it works, right?

235
00:12:12.880 --> 00:12:16.850
And, look at that, I got a sync, right?

236
00:12:16.850 --> 00:12:21.880
And so if I do a nsd-control zonestatus
I can see I'm working, right?

237
00:12:21.880 --> 00:12:25.060
So don't panic and go and
start editing your conf file or

238
00:12:25.060 --> 00:12:26.800
whatever, sometimes it
just needs to restart.

239
00:12:26.800 --> 00:12:30.080
And normally it's because you did what I
did, you let it sit there too long and

240
00:12:30.080 --> 00:12:31.310
fail too many times.

241
00:12:31.310 --> 00:12:33.260
It'll fail enough times and it'll stop and

242
00:12:33.260 --> 00:12:36.060
it won't retry until your
retry interval is up.

243
00:12:36.060 --> 00:12:40.502
My retry interval was 7,200
seconds when I defined this zone.

244
00:12:40.502 --> 00:12:42.280
I don't actually know
what that is in minutes.

245
00:12:42.280 --> 00:12:43.820
It's like an hour, isn't it?

246
00:12:43.820 --> 00:12:44.863
>> I don't know off the top of my head.

247
00:12:44.863 --> 00:12:47.240
[LAUGH]
>> So if we made a really long episode,

248
00:12:47.240 --> 00:12:49.550
eventually it would have sorted
itself out, but I'm impatient.

249
00:12:49.550 --> 00:12:51.740
So I just restart NSD, problem solved.

250
00:12:51.740 --> 00:12:56.010
Now I did restart my master, which could
cause a micro-outage on the network.

251
00:12:56.010 --> 00:12:58.760
You might not wanna do that, but if you're
just trying to force this in place,

252
00:12:58.760 --> 00:12:59.700
that's one way to do it.

253
00:12:59.700 --> 00:13:01.260
I could have forced a transfer also.

254
00:13:01.260 --> 00:13:03.620
I guess that's another way to go about it,
but this took care of it.

255
00:13:03.620 --> 00:13:04.920
So now I'm transferring, and

256
00:13:04.920 --> 00:13:08.450
more importantly,
I'm transferring with authentication.

257
00:13:08.450 --> 00:13:09.790
I'm handing off that key.

258
00:13:09.790 --> 00:13:13.210
And if somebody man in the middles this,
and they modify the zone and

259
00:13:13.210 --> 00:13:16.700
send it along,
the hash isn't gonna match anymore.

260
00:13:16.700 --> 00:13:20.620
When we rehash that zone file,
it doesn't match, I'll reject it.

261
00:13:20.620 --> 00:13:23.100
So now you can't tamper with my transfers.

262
00:13:23.100 --> 00:13:25.880
You can still intercept them and
read them, they're not encrypted, right?

263
00:13:25.880 --> 00:13:29.260
But they're digitally signed,
so you can't modify them.

264
00:13:29.260 --> 00:13:31.760
And that effectively kills
off the man in the middle.

265
00:13:31.760 --> 00:13:36.420
Remember, we don't need to encrypt because
it's not private data, it's DNS data.

266
00:13:36.420 --> 00:13:38.820
People can do the look ups and
get the information.

267
00:13:38.820 --> 00:13:42.530
If you insist on encrypting it, you can
do an IP set tunnel or whatever between

268
00:13:42.530 --> 00:13:46.550
the servers, an SSH tunnel, even, will
work just fine for encrypting the data.

269
00:13:46.550 --> 00:13:49.460
But a digital signature is what's
important and that's what those keys do.

270
00:13:49.460 --> 00:13:52.930
Now you should do key rotation,
every so often go and change it, right?

271
00:13:52.930 --> 00:13:57.250
Sha256 is pretty strong, but it can be
broken if you give somebody enough time.

272
00:13:57.250 --> 00:13:59.500
You give them a year,
two years, they can break it.

273
00:13:59.500 --> 00:14:03.060
So if we rotate every three months,
we don't have to worry about.

274
00:14:03.060 --> 00:14:05.990
So every three months, just go in there
and change the key, rotate them out.

275
00:14:05.990 --> 00:14:09.750
You can define more than one key, and so
all you're doing is changing which key you

276
00:14:09.750 --> 00:14:12.270
call in the zone and
then you've got it, right.

277
00:14:12.270 --> 00:14:16.452
So easy enough to do, but now we've got to
secure authentication, secure replication,

278
00:14:16.452 --> 00:14:17.340
and we're set up.

279
00:14:17.340 --> 00:14:19.800
We've got a nice, secure,
and stable master and

280
00:14:19.800 --> 00:14:23.060
slave replicated environment in an NSD.

281
00:14:23.060 --> 00:14:23.680
>> Don, thank you for

282
00:14:23.680 --> 00:14:27.950
taking the time to at least let us
see how to secure that NDS server.

283
00:14:27.950 --> 00:14:31.577
Now, does look like we're coming to
the end of this episode, but before we do,

284
00:14:31.577 --> 00:14:34.827
do you have any additional advice
you'd like to let somebody know about

285
00:14:34.827 --> 00:14:36.963
maybe securing or
really just NDS in general?

286
00:14:36.963 --> 00:14:37.976
>> NSD.

287
00:14:37.976 --> 00:14:39.350
>> NSD, very good, very good.

288
00:14:39.350 --> 00:14:40.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

289
00:14:40.870 --> 00:14:44.310
the other thing is we didn't
touch on DNS sec, right?

290
00:14:44.310 --> 00:14:47.750
So what I did right there is
I secured zone transfers.

291
00:14:47.750 --> 00:14:51.880
I didn't do anything to help clients
validate that my records are valid.

292
00:14:51.880 --> 00:14:54.300
So I'm still vulnerable there,
so we wanna do DNS sec.

293
00:14:54.300 --> 00:14:57.350
Stay tuned, cuz we're gonna have
an episode on configuring DNS sec and

294
00:14:57.350 --> 00:14:58.250
getting that put in place.

295
00:14:58.250 --> 00:15:01.310
You definitely wanna be implementing
that on your DNS servers these days.

296
00:15:01.310 --> 00:15:03.800
Absolutely something to tackle so
be sure to check that out.

297
00:15:03.800 --> 00:15:08.820
But this is the first step, DNS is
the second step, you put them together and

298
00:15:08.820 --> 00:15:09.970
now we're in business.

299
00:15:09.970 --> 00:15:12.490
>> Don, we appreciate you taking
the time to stop by the studios and

300
00:15:12.490 --> 00:15:16.440
show us that information, and we certainly
appreciate you, the viewers, watching.

301
00:15:16.440 --> 00:15:19.488
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

302
00:15:19.488 --> 00:15:20.341
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

303
00:15:20.341 --> 00:15:22.961
>> And we'll see you next time.

304
00:15:22.961 --> 00:15:29.105
[MUSIC]

305
00:15:29.105 --> 00:15:32.170
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.180
Welcome in ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.180 --> 00:00:06.417
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.417 --> 00:00:08.234
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.234 --> 00:00:09.899
You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:09.899 --> 00:00:14.385
>> Welcome to another great
episode here at ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:14.385 --> 00:00:15.765
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:15.765 --> 00:00:16.995
And in today's episode,

8
00:00:16.995 --> 00:00:21.835
we're coming back at you with more of that
fun series that is the DNS tech skills.

9
00:00:21.835 --> 00:00:24.565
Joining us back in the studios today
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:24.565 --> 00:00:25.615
Don, how are you doing, sir?

11
00:00:25.615 --> 00:00:26.495
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

12
00:00:26.495 --> 00:00:28.705
Ready to dive right back
into the world of DNS.

13
00:00:28.705 --> 00:00:30.445
And somewhat nervous
about today's episode,

14
00:00:30.445 --> 00:00:32.937
because we're jumping into
a controversial subject.

15
00:00:32.937 --> 00:00:36.650
We're gonna be taking a look
at Microsoft's DNS server.

16
00:00:36.650 --> 00:00:37.860
And I play it up a bit.

17
00:00:37.860 --> 00:00:39.260
It's not all that controversial.

18
00:00:39.260 --> 00:00:41.370
But if you're a hardcore
DNS guy out there,

19
00:00:41.370 --> 00:00:43.300
you probably already hit
the stop button on the video.

20
00:00:43.300 --> 00:00:44.870
So I guess I don't have
to worry about you.

21
00:00:44.870 --> 00:00:47.840
Out on the internet,
the public DNS servers.

22
00:00:47.840 --> 00:00:49.720
They're not gonna be
Microsoft DNS servers.

23
00:00:49.720 --> 00:00:53.800
They're going to be Linux
based almost always.

24
00:00:53.800 --> 00:00:57.120
We see a lot of VSD based, right but
it's some kind of Unix system and

25
00:00:57.120 --> 00:01:01.070
they're typically going to be buying and
NSD, maybe power DNS.

26
00:01:01.070 --> 00:01:05.130
Those guys are pretty much the ones that
cover the whole environment out there.

27
00:01:05.130 --> 00:01:08.650
But, once you get into a corporate or
enterprise network,

28
00:01:08.650 --> 00:01:12.570
when you get into a business network
that's dealing with internal zones,

29
00:01:12.570 --> 00:01:14.930
Microsoft DNS is actually
one of the most common.

30
00:01:14.930 --> 00:01:18.160
So while we might not see it out
there on the internet all that much.

31
00:01:18.160 --> 00:01:20.090
I mean, you do, but just not that much.

32
00:01:20.090 --> 00:01:23.590
On an internal business network,
you see it all over the place.

33
00:01:23.590 --> 00:01:27.945
And one of the big reasons for that is
the Microsoft Active Directory, right?

34
00:01:27.945 --> 00:01:32.680
In Windows Windows 2000,
I guess is when it all really started.

35
00:01:32.680 --> 00:01:34.930
They set it where the machines
could use DNS to find records and

36
00:01:34.930 --> 00:01:38.000
Microsoft spun up their own DNS
server to be able to handle that.

37
00:01:38.000 --> 00:01:40.260
Now, the DNS server
actually works really well.

38
00:01:40.260 --> 00:01:41.200
It's a good product.

39
00:01:41.200 --> 00:01:44.540
If you're an all Microsoft shop or
even you just have some Microsoft systems,

40
00:01:44.540 --> 00:01:48.240
the odds are you do, then it's a great
way serve up DNS in your environment.

41
00:01:48.240 --> 00:01:52.050
And, unlike a lot of the other products
that we go over in this series,

42
00:01:52.050 --> 00:01:55.090
it was built with a GUI
from the very beginning.

43
00:01:55.090 --> 00:01:57.770
So, it's got a nice graphical user
interface that makes it easy to work with

running and I am serving my entries.

687
00:33:04.780 --> 00:33:11.250
If I were to fire up a tool like NS lookup
and switch the server over to myself,

688
00:33:11.250 --> 00:33:16.400
let's see, if I type it right,

689
00:33:16.400 --> 00:33:20.130
I can connect to myself and I should be
able to look up any of those like mail one

690
00:33:20.130 --> 00:33:26.430
dot itpro itprotvdemo.org and
I get a result.

691
00:33:26.430 --> 00:33:34.020
Or www, remember that was the C name,
it resolves it.

692
00:33:34.020 --> 00:33:39.450
It actually mapped out that C name
to show me my dot info and exploded

693
00:33:39.450 --> 00:33:43.430
that to get the actual IP and we're
[INAUDIBLE] so all that process happened.

694
00:33:43.430 --> 00:33:50.290
If I set my type to MX I can say give
me the MX records for itprotvdemo.org.

695
00:33:50.290 --> 00:33:53.040
And it returns my mail servers.

696
00:33:53.040 --> 00:33:56.890
And if I, let's see, set type-any.

697
00:33:56.890 --> 00:34:02.130
And I pull up file.itprotvdemo.org.

698
00:34:02.130 --> 00:34:07.570
I can look that up and I get the IPv4 and
IPv6 address, all returning right

699
00:34:07.570 --> 00:34:11.300
back to me, the A and the AAAA records
all coming back, we're up and going.

700
00:34:11.300 --> 00:34:14.240
So creating zones,
super simple thanks to the GUI

701
00:34:15.300 --> 00:34:18.470
unless you need to make hundreds of
entries or thousands of entries, if you

702
00:34:18.470 --> 00:34:22.380
need to make bulk of entries, you're not
gonna like that GUI very much, right?

703
00:34:22.380 --> 00:34:25.450
And that's where we go back to
editing the file directly or

704
00:34:25.450 --> 00:34:28.320
using PowerShell commands to load that in.

705
00:34:28.320 --> 00:34:33.440
If you wanna edit the file directly
you've gotta stop the DNS server first,

706
00:34:33.440 --> 00:34:38.470
go back into your tool and
right click on the server.

707
00:34:38.470 --> 00:34:41.030
Go to All Tasks And stop.

708
00:34:41.030 --> 00:34:43.840
Stop the server, which takes it
offline and kicks everybody out.

709
00:34:43.840 --> 00:34:45.560
Everybody now hates you, right?

710
00:34:45.560 --> 00:34:46.070
And you get in there.

711
00:34:46.070 --> 00:34:47.780
And you make all your changes.

712
00:34:47.780 --> 00:34:49.040
Then you can start the server back up.

713
00:34:49.040 --> 00:34:49.880
And it will load them all.

714
00:34:49.880 --> 00:34:50.590
And you've got them in play.

715
00:34:50.590 --> 00:34:52.890
So if you do bulk changes,
sometimes that's faster.

716
00:34:52.890 --> 00:34:53.790
You can make typos.

717
00:34:53.790 --> 00:34:57.290
And there's no syntax checker in Windows,
so you've got to get it right.

718
00:34:57.290 --> 00:35:00.060
PowerShell's a little bit better because
there is a little bit of syntax checking

719
00:35:00.060 --> 00:35:01.830
that happens and
you can automate things faster,

720
00:35:01.830 --> 00:35:04.330
but definitely beyond the scope
of what I can cover in this show.

721
00:35:04.330 --> 00:35:07.150
But something to keep in mind
you're in bulk DMS changes.

722
00:35:07.150 --> 00:35:10.990
>> Still a lot of great information
on getting those zones configured and

723
00:35:10.990 --> 00:35:11.550
up and running.

724
00:35:11.550 --> 00:35:14.370
In fact, I thought it was kind of
fascinating to see the The file

725
00:35:14.370 --> 00:35:16.440
underneath, you'd still
see that bind structure.

726
00:35:16.440 --> 00:35:16.950
Well done.

727
00:35:16.950 --> 00:35:17.850
You've already mentioned it.

728
00:35:17.850 --> 00:35:20.210
It does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

729
00:35:20.210 --> 00:35:23.270
But do you have any additional word
you might like to tell our viewers?

730
00:35:23.270 --> 00:35:27.460
When it comes to configuring your
zones inside a Windows environment?

731
00:35:27.460 --> 00:35:29.570
>> There is a good bit more to this.

732
00:35:29.570 --> 00:35:31.630
I'm just covering what
I can in 30 minutes.

733
00:35:31.630 --> 00:35:34.670
But if you're doing things,
like, dynamic updates.

734
00:35:34.670 --> 00:35:37.400
Understand that there's a whole
permissions infrastructure in there that

735
00:35:37.400 --> 00:35:38.770
you can view.

736
00:35:38.770 --> 00:35:41.990
If you switch to the advanced
view inside of the tool.

737
00:35:41.990 --> 00:35:43.530
And even on our regular records.

738
00:35:43.530 --> 00:35:44.870
When I created my A records.

739
00:35:44.870 --> 00:35:47.920
It never asked me about what
Time- to- Live I wanted.

740
00:35:47.920 --> 00:35:50.010
You could override the Time-to- Live for
a record.

741
00:35:50.010 --> 00:35:51.600
But let me just show this real quick.

742
00:35:51.600 --> 00:35:52.330
I know we're out of time West.

743
00:35:52.330 --> 00:35:53.560
But let me show real quick.

744
00:35:53.560 --> 00:35:54.980
Cuz it's kind of important.

745
00:35:54.980 --> 00:35:58.170
If we take the dns1
record that I made here.

746
00:35:58.170 --> 00:35:59.530
And I double click on it.

747
00:35:59.530 --> 00:36:02.080
I can change the name of the IP.

748
00:36:02.080 --> 00:36:04.190
I can't change the time to live, right?

749
00:36:04.190 --> 00:36:05.940
But if I go up here to view and

750
00:36:05.940 --> 00:36:09.730
advanced, a lot of stuff starts to
show up that wasn't there before.

751
00:36:09.730 --> 00:36:12.380
And so I usually stay in
the advanced view all the time.

752
00:36:12.380 --> 00:36:16.150
And when you go into it now,
I see the three values I did a moment ago.

753
00:36:16.150 --> 00:36:21.060
I also see where I can set whether the
record becomes stale if it gets deleted I

754
00:36:21.060 --> 00:36:24.390
can over ride the time to live just for
this one record.

755
00:36:24.390 --> 00:36:27.130
You get a lot of the extra values
in here that you can modify.

756
00:36:27.130 --> 00:36:28.930
So don't forget the advanced view.

757
00:36:28.930 --> 00:36:31.770
It unlocks a lot of potential of the GUI.

758
00:36:31.770 --> 00:36:33.740
>> Well, Don, that's a,
a lot of great information.

759
00:36:33.740 --> 00:36:36.780
We definitely appreciate you being
here in the studios with us.

760
00:36:36.780 --> 00:36:38.830
And we appreciate you,
the viewer watching.

761
00:36:38.830 --> 00:36:40.820
We're gonna go ahead and
sign out here for IT Pro TV.

762
00:36:40.820 --> 00:36:42.760
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

763
00:36:42.760 --> 00:36:43.580
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

764
00:36:43.580 --> 00:36:46.065
>> And we'll see you next time.

765
00:36:46.065 --> 00:36:52.134
