766
00:36:52.134 --> 00:36:57.479
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue the process of DNS configuration on Windows Server. They will tackle DNS zone replication this time, while discussing the purpose, benefits as well as a demonstration in the configuration process.
episodes.title: Configuring Replication in Microsoft DNS
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:02.037
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.037 --> 00:00:08.301
[CROSSTALK]
[SOUND]

3
00:00:08.301 --> 00:00:11.969
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.969 --> 00:00:16.071
>> Welcome to another great episode here
at ITProTV, I'm your host Wes Bryan.

5
00:00:16.071 --> 00:00:19.273
And in today's episode, we're
continuing through our DNS text skills.

6
00:00:19.273 --> 00:00:22.931
And joining us yet again for
this very endeavour is none other than Mr.

7
00:00:22.931 --> 00:00:23.551
Don Pezet.

8
00:00:23.551 --> 00:00:24.820
Don, how're you doing, sir?

9
00:00:24.820 --> 00:00:27.534
>> I'm doing well, Wes, ready to
dive right back into Microsoft DNS.

10
00:00:27.534 --> 00:00:31.318
And in this episode, we're taking a look
at replication, which can be super easy,

11
00:00:31.318 --> 00:00:34.580
or it can be a little complex
depending on what you're trying to do.

12
00:00:34.580 --> 00:00:37.712
But we're gonna do it the complex
way today cuz that's more fun, but

13
00:00:37.712 --> 00:00:41.276
we'll get a chance to see how to get our
zones to show up on more than one server,

14
00:00:41.276 --> 00:00:43.725
which is kind of an important
thing cuz servers fail.

15
00:00:43.725 --> 00:00:46.374
And if a server goes offline, you want
somebody else to be able to jump in and

16
00:00:46.374 --> 00:00:47.380
take over for you.

17
00:00:47.380 --> 00:00:50.850
Or maybe one server just gets really
busy and starts answering too slowly,

18
00:00:50.850 --> 00:00:53.400
it'd be nice to be able to
reach out to a different one.

19
00:00:53.400 --> 00:00:56.975
A lot of people use replication to make
it where they have main servers that

20
00:00:56.975 --> 00:01:00.885
are at their headquarters and then
servers that are at each branch office.

21
00:01:00.885 --> 00:01:03.935
So that people are looking up
DNS records from a server that's

22
00:01:03.935 --> 00:01:05.235
right there in the building with them.

23
00:01:05.235 --> 00:01:06.765
That speeds up the lookup process.

24
00:01:06.765 --> 00:01:08.376
You don't want people waiting on DNS.

25
00:01:08.376 --> 00:01:10.944
You want them to wait on the servers so
when they go to a website or

26
00:01:10.944 --> 00:01:12.510
an email server or whatever.

27
00:01:12.510 --> 00:01:14.650
DNS shouldn't be our
bottleneck on this stuff.

28
00:01:14.650 --> 00:01:17.480
So, replicating is a key piece of that.

29
00:01:17.480 --> 00:01:18.930
Now, fortunately,

30
00:01:18.930 --> 00:01:22.990
there's two different types of replication
we can do on Microsoft servers.

31
00:01:22.990 --> 00:01:25.655
There's a super, mega easy,

32
00:01:25.655 --> 00:01:29.690
no-brainer way if we're in an Active
Directory integrated environment, and

33
00:01:29.690 --> 00:01:33.370
then there's the manual, hard way
that we do when we're not in the AD.

34
00:01:33.370 --> 00:01:36.950
The super easy way is
really just one check mark.

35
00:01:36.950 --> 00:01:39.630
So it's not even a great thing to
build a whole show around, but

36
00:01:39.630 --> 00:01:40.260
let me show you that way.

37
00:01:40.260 --> 00:01:41.330
We'll start with that one.

38
00:01:41.330 --> 00:01:43.190
And then, after that,
we'll do the fun way,

39
00:01:43.190 --> 00:01:44.840
which is actually
replicating the full data.

40
00:01:44.840 --> 00:01:47.380
So let's run through that process.

41
00:01:47.380 --> 00:01:50.646
Now if you've been watching
our Microsoft DNS shows,

42
00:01:50.646 --> 00:01:54.837
you know that I've already created
a zone called itprotvdemo.org.

43
00:01:54.837 --> 00:01:59.535
So I can go into my DNS manager and I've
got itprotvdemo.org sitting right there,

44
00:01:59.535 --> 00:02:01.020
it's on this one server.

45
00:02:01.020 --> 00:02:05.329
And I'm authoritative for it, if this
server goes offline, that's it, this zone

46
00:02:05.329 --> 00:02:09.712
doesn't exist anywhere else, nobody can
answer for it, I'm offline, all right.

47
00:02:09.712 --> 00:02:12.470
I don't want that, I wanna have
a second server that's backing me up.

48
00:02:12.470 --> 00:02:18.390
Well if I'm using my Active Directory
domain controllers as a DNS

49
00:02:18.390 --> 00:02:24.150
server, then I can take this zone, and
I can stick it in the Active Directory.

50
00:02:24.150 --> 00:02:26.540
And when it's in the Active Directory,

51
00:02:26.540 --> 00:02:31.090
any domain controller that I install the
DNS role on will now have a copy of this.

52
00:02:31.090 --> 00:02:34.510
And that's what a lot of companies do,
at my branch office,

53
00:02:34.510 --> 00:02:36.200
I want a domain controller
at the branch office, so

54
00:02:36.200 --> 00:02:38.790
that people are authenticating
it to local server.

55
00:02:38.790 --> 00:02:40.910
I want a DNS server at the branch office,

56
00:02:40.910 --> 00:02:44.240
so they can look up
names on a local server.

57
00:02:44.240 --> 00:02:47.216
It makes sense to put them together,
the two work together very closely anyway,

58
00:02:47.216 --> 00:02:48.590
so let's stick them on the same box.

59
00:02:48.590 --> 00:02:49.770
It's what a lot of people do.

60
00:02:49.770 --> 00:02:54.090
So you just go to each of your domain
controllers, and you add the DNS role.

61
00:02:54.090 --> 00:02:58.133
And then on your main server that's
up here at the headquarters,

62
00:02:58.133 --> 00:03:01.009
all you have to do is move
that zone into the AD.

63
00:03:01.009 --> 00:03:03.291
Now you can only do that when
you're on a domain controller,

64
00:03:03.291 --> 00:03:04.652
I'm not on the domain controller.

65
00:03:04.652 --> 00:03:07.819
So if I take this zone and
I pull up its properties and

66
00:03:07.819 --> 00:03:12.900
we take a look at these options right here
at the top, see how my status is running,

67
00:03:12.900 --> 00:03:16.825
my type is primary,
that's what we're gonna see either way.

68
00:03:16.825 --> 00:03:22.770
And then replication, not
an Active Directory integrated zone, okay.

69
00:03:22.770 --> 00:03:27.480
If it were Active Directory integrated,
I'd be able to hit this Change button, or

70
00:03:27.480 --> 00:03:29.200
even if it wasn't,
I'd be able to hit the Change button and

71
00:03:29.200 --> 00:03:31.080
make it Active Directory integrated.

72
00:03:31.080 --> 00:03:35.030
And when that happens,
it's now stored in the AD.

73
00:03:35.030 --> 00:03:38.530
And everybody else will get a copy of it,
and they'll have it up and running.

74
00:03:38.530 --> 00:03:39.750
That's it, it's one button.

75
00:03:39.750 --> 00:03:43.900
You hit this Change button, you check
off Active Directory, and you hit OK.

76
00:03:43.900 --> 00:03:46.790
Or you probably did it back when you set
the thing up in the first place, right?

77
00:03:46.790 --> 00:03:50.430
When you create a new zone,
in the Zone Wizard,

78
00:03:50.430 --> 00:03:54.670
it's right here on this first screen,
Store the zone in the Active Directory.

79
00:03:54.670 --> 00:03:59.546
And if you check that off, it's now
automatically replicating through the AD,

80
00:03:59.546 --> 00:04:02.843
and all you have to do is bring
up a domain controller and

81
00:04:02.843 --> 00:04:05.110
add the DNS role to it.

82
00:04:05.110 --> 00:04:06.440
And it gets all the zones.

83
00:04:06.440 --> 00:04:11.940
It's the no fuss way of replicating,
you don't have to worry about it.

84
00:04:11.940 --> 00:04:14.708
The DNS records actually replicate
alongside the Active Directory records.

85
00:04:14.708 --> 00:04:18.500
It's just using the standard
Active Directory replication processes.

86
00:04:18.500 --> 00:04:19.990
And everything spreads out, super simple.

87
00:04:21.130 --> 00:04:23.580
But it assumes several things, right?

88
00:04:23.580 --> 00:04:27.300
It assumes that you want all your
DNS servers to be Active Directory.

89
00:04:27.300 --> 00:04:29.870
It assumes that you have
the Active Directory.

90
00:04:29.870 --> 00:04:33.690
And it assumes that you don't mind running
your DNS servers on top of your domain

91
00:04:33.690 --> 00:04:35.520
controllers, right?

92
00:04:35.520 --> 00:04:37.030
What if you don't want that?

93
00:04:37.030 --> 00:04:39.570
What if I don't wanna run the DNS
server on my domain controllers?

94
00:04:39.570 --> 00:04:43.780
What if I wanna have a mixture of
Microsoft and Bind or other stuff, right?

95
00:04:43.780 --> 00:04:46.990
What if I wanna deviate from
that perfect all Microsoft world

96
00:04:46.990 --> 00:04:49.560
where they force me to buy
all their stuff, right?

97
00:04:49.560 --> 00:04:52.460
If that happens, [LAUGH] when that
happens, right, it's not really an if

98
00:04:52.460 --> 00:04:57.450
anymore, when that happens, we don't want
that to be Active Directory integrated.

99
00:04:57.450 --> 00:05:00.470
When you're Active Directory integrated,
it's a multi-master model.

100
00:05:00.470 --> 00:05:04.157
You can make changes on any server, and
they will all replicate together and

101
00:05:04.157 --> 00:05:05.086
it all works fine.

102
00:05:05.086 --> 00:05:07.462
But when you start bringing in Bind or
NSD or

103
00:05:07.462 --> 00:05:11.686
one of the other guys that are out there,
when you bring one of those guys in,

104
00:05:11.686 --> 00:05:15.060
they don't do that whole
multi-master thing.

105
00:05:15.060 --> 00:05:18.700
They come up as either a master or
a slave, as a changeable copy or

106
00:05:18.700 --> 00:05:22.660
a read only copy, and they can't
participate in this type of replication.

107
00:05:22.660 --> 00:05:25.430
So instead, we can go back to the standard

108
00:05:25.430 --> 00:05:29.660
form of replication that we have in
every other DNS server that's out there.

109
00:05:29.660 --> 00:05:32.830
And that's where we don't
store it in the AD.

110
00:05:32.830 --> 00:05:39.760
And instead, you have a primary and
then one or more secondary servers.

111
00:05:39.760 --> 00:05:43.470
And you can do this regardless of whether
you have the Active Directory or not.

112
00:05:43.470 --> 00:05:46.690
Just because you have the Active Directory
doesn't mean you have to store your

113
00:05:46.690 --> 00:05:47.800
zones in there.

114
00:05:47.800 --> 00:05:49.040
Cuz you might have the Active Directory,
and

115
00:05:49.040 --> 00:05:52.740
you just wanna run DNS on separate
servers, not your domain controllers.

116
00:05:52.740 --> 00:05:55.004
So you don't store them in
the Active Directory, and

117
00:05:55.004 --> 00:05:56.272
it works just fine, it does.

118
00:05:56.272 --> 00:05:57.960
It just takes a little more
work to get things set up.

119
00:05:57.960 --> 00:06:02.390
And when you make changes, the changes
all have to occur on the primary.

120
00:06:02.390 --> 00:06:04.480
That's a problem if you're
doing dynamic updates.

121
00:06:04.480 --> 00:06:07.320
Because all your dynamic updates
have to go to one server.

122
00:06:07.320 --> 00:06:09.210
Then it's kinda nice to
have multiple servers.

123
00:06:09.210 --> 00:06:13.000
But on a public DNS server,
you wouldn't want dynamic updates anyway.

124
00:06:13.000 --> 00:06:15.270
And I've got dynamic
updates turned off on mine.

125
00:06:15.270 --> 00:06:19.780
So if I want to replicate this,
I can't do Active Directory integrated.

126
00:06:19.780 --> 00:06:21.440
Instead, I'm gonna go to the standard way.

127
00:06:21.440 --> 00:06:24.240
Now if you pull up
the properties of this thing,

128
00:06:24.240 --> 00:06:27.830
you'll see where my status is running,
and my type is primary.

129
00:06:27.830 --> 00:06:32.240
And I can hit Change on that, and
I can change to a secondary if I want.

130
00:06:32.240 --> 00:06:36.770
A secondary is a replica of
a primary somewhere else.

131
00:06:36.770 --> 00:06:40.196
Well, I don't have a zone somewhere else,
but if I wanted to import one,

132
00:06:40.196 --> 00:06:41.261
I could go that route.

133
00:06:41.261 --> 00:06:43.710
But as it stands, I'm just a primary, and

134
00:06:43.710 --> 00:06:46.850
I can't really change that
without breaking things.

135
00:06:46.850 --> 00:06:50.600
I guess I could go to stub or whatever,
but this one's gonna be a primary.

136
00:06:50.600 --> 00:06:53.142
But here's where I could also change
my mind about being stored in the AD or

137
00:06:53.142 --> 00:06:55.030
not, if I really wanted to go crazy there,
all right.

138
00:06:56.102 --> 00:07:00.339
And notice it says available only if DNS
server is a domain controller, right.

139
00:07:00.339 --> 00:07:02.100
It's gotta run right on top of it.

140
00:07:02.100 --> 00:07:05.095
>> Don, have you ever seen a use for
taking something that you've already got

141
00:07:05.095 --> 00:07:07.926
configured as a primary and
bumping it down to a secondary?

142
00:07:07.926 --> 00:07:11.210
Maybe like a, or I don't know, maybe
a staff change where maybe you don't have

00:18:13.370 --> 00:18:15.900
And the mistake I normally
see is where we use

371
00:18:15.900 --> 00:18:19.410
the private IP of a server instead
of the public IP, or vice versa.

372
00:18:19.410 --> 00:18:22.300
And so it's trying to reach out
to something that is incorrect.

373
00:18:22.300 --> 00:18:27.590
>> When it pulls that zone transfer,
is that going over your basic DNS port?

374
00:18:27.590 --> 00:18:29.083
Is that gonna be like a port 53?

375
00:18:29.083 --> 00:18:30.811
No different than whatever
the clients would deal with if

376
00:18:30.811 --> 00:18:31.752
they were to query the server?

377
00:18:31.752 --> 00:18:34.554
>> It'll be a TCP port 53.

378
00:18:34.554 --> 00:18:37.010
Very, very rarely would it be UDP.

379
00:18:37.010 --> 00:18:41.951
What happens with DNS is it'll do UDP
53 unless the response needs to be

380
00:18:41.951 --> 00:18:43.412
more than one frame.

381
00:18:43.412 --> 00:18:45.419
And if it's two,
better more than one segment, really.

382
00:18:45.419 --> 00:18:48.476
If it's more than one segment,
like 1500 bytes.

383
00:18:48.476 --> 00:18:49.556
1500 bytes would be the frame.

384
00:18:49.556 --> 00:18:50.756
The segment would be a little bit smaller.

385
00:18:50.756 --> 00:18:53.488
And so let's say somewhere
in the 1400 byte range.

386
00:18:53.488 --> 00:18:56.463
Most of your queries
are just a name to an IP.

387
00:18:56.463 --> 00:18:58.880
And that fits in under 1400 bytes.

388
00:18:58.880 --> 00:19:00.208
It goes and uses UDP.

389
00:19:00.208 --> 00:19:03.970
But when you do a zone transfer, the odds
are you're gonna be over 1400 bytes.

390
00:19:03.970 --> 00:19:05.820
Which is not a hard number to exceed.

391
00:19:05.820 --> 00:19:07.110
So then it's gotta segment it.

392
00:19:07.110 --> 00:19:08.174
And UDP can't really do that.

393
00:19:08.174 --> 00:19:10.860
So we have to switch over to TCP,
that's what happens.

394
00:19:10.860 --> 00:19:12.360
So when you do a zone transfer,

395
00:19:12.360 --> 00:19:15.201
your zone's pretty much
guaranteed to break that limit.

396
00:19:15.201 --> 00:19:18.188
Just between the start of authority,
and the name server entries and

397
00:19:18.188 --> 00:19:19.720
the other things you add.

398
00:19:19.720 --> 00:19:21.313
And so when that happens, it uses that.

399
00:19:21.313 --> 00:19:24.650
So as long as you got that approved,
it's not a special port or anything.

400
00:19:24.650 --> 00:19:28.550
Although, I do know some people where
they'll set up things like SSH tunnels or

401
00:19:28.550 --> 00:19:31.910
IPsec or something to make sure
you've got an encrypted session

402
00:19:31.910 --> 00:19:33.530
between you and the server.

403
00:19:33.530 --> 00:19:36.880
Because remember,
all of this is in plaintext.

404
00:19:36.880 --> 00:19:38.210
DNS records are not secret.

405
00:19:38.210 --> 00:19:39.899
So they don't bother encrypting them.

406
00:19:39.899 --> 00:19:42.300
This is all sent in plaintext.

407
00:19:42.300 --> 00:19:46.638
Even when you have DNSSEC turned on,
all the hash signatures, they're hashes,

408
00:19:46.638 --> 00:19:47.830
they're non-reversible.

409
00:19:47.830 --> 00:19:50.050
So they're stored in
plaintext right there.

410
00:19:50.050 --> 00:19:51.200
It's not the private key.

411
00:19:51.200 --> 00:19:53.910
They're all public keys
that public knowledge.

412
00:19:53.910 --> 00:19:55.570
And that's it,
there's no security on this.

413
00:19:55.570 --> 00:20:00.840
So you might choose to implement IPsec
also to make sure that that's encrypted.

414
00:20:00.840 --> 00:20:03.233
But it's gonna reach out, and
I'm not gonna see anything right away.

415
00:20:03.233 --> 00:20:06.140
But if I hit the Refresh button is
where I'll normally get that update.

416
00:20:06.140 --> 00:20:10.350
And my status here, it shows that I'm
a secondary and that I'm running.

417
00:20:10.350 --> 00:20:12.897
And if I click on it, I've got records.

418
00:20:12.897 --> 00:20:14.920
That's exactly what I wanna see.

419
00:20:14.920 --> 00:20:17.605
If it failed, I would've got
the red circle with a white x,

420
00:20:17.605 --> 00:20:19.130
letting me know it didn't work.

421
00:20:19.130 --> 00:20:22.227
And then I think I'll go into the system
logs and start trying to dig in.

422
00:20:22.227 --> 00:20:25.780
And find out what the heck is happening
there and why it didn't work.

423
00:20:25.780 --> 00:20:29.280
But I now have a copy of that zone.

424
00:20:29.280 --> 00:20:32.690
I've got the records right here and
I'm getting it.

425
00:20:32.690 --> 00:20:37.030
And because I'm listed as
a name server right up here.

426
00:20:37.030 --> 00:20:40.730
dns2.itprotvdemo.net is
listed as a name server.

427
00:20:40.730 --> 00:20:44.590
When a change happens on the primary,
it will do a notify to me.

428
00:20:44.590 --> 00:20:46.947
And I'll go and
yank that record as soon as I can.

429
00:20:46.947 --> 00:20:49.956
But if I don't get a notify,
I'll still do a pull every so

430
00:20:49.956 --> 00:20:55.010
often to make sure that I get the zone and
that I stay up to date with the changes.

431
00:20:55.010 --> 00:20:59.410
But, If I come in here and
try and create a new record.

432
00:20:59.410 --> 00:21:01.800
In the last episode,
I would right-click on zone,

433
00:21:01.800 --> 00:21:04.420
and then I would choose
to create a new record.

434
00:21:04.420 --> 00:21:05.630
I don't have that option.

435
00:21:05.630 --> 00:21:08.500
I can't create an A record,
a four A or anything.

436
00:21:08.500 --> 00:21:11.864
All I can do is reload,
transfer from master,

437
00:21:11.864 --> 00:21:14.726
transfer new copy of zone from master.

438
00:21:14.726 --> 00:21:16.580
Well, those three sound similar.

439
00:21:16.580 --> 00:21:18.450
So let me tell you
the difference between each one.

440
00:21:18.450 --> 00:21:21.030
Reload has nothing to do with the master.

441
00:21:21.030 --> 00:21:25.500
Reload says,
I've got this zone stored in RAM.

442
00:21:25.500 --> 00:21:27.870
And I've got this zone
stored in the hard drive.

443
00:21:27.870 --> 00:21:30.541
Delete what's in RAM, and
pull up from the hard drive again.

444
00:21:30.541 --> 00:21:32.450
That was Reload does.

445
00:21:32.450 --> 00:21:34.814
On a master, that's pretty useful if
you feel like things got out of sync.

446
00:21:34.814 --> 00:21:38.600
Or things got corrupt, you can reload
it and you do it pretty quickly.

447
00:21:38.600 --> 00:21:41.090
On a secondary like this,
it's not terribly useful.

448
00:21:41.090 --> 00:21:44.130
Because in some scenarios,
you don't even store this zone on a drive.

449
00:21:44.130 --> 00:21:47.260
But usually, it does.

450
00:21:47.260 --> 00:21:48.250
So we can reload that.

451
00:21:48.250 --> 00:21:50.860
The second one is more useful,
Transfer from Master.

452
00:21:50.860 --> 00:21:55.309
But Microsoft's DNS will do
incremental zone transfers.

453
00:21:55.309 --> 00:21:59.620
There's two different types of
zone transfers, AXFR and IXFR.

454
00:21:59.620 --> 00:22:02.140
An AXFR is the whole thing.

455
00:22:02.140 --> 00:22:03.410
Give me the whole zone.

456
00:22:03.410 --> 00:22:04.823
That's what I just did a moment ago.

457
00:22:04.823 --> 00:22:06.370
We don't see it, it's on the background.

458
00:22:06.370 --> 00:22:08.450
I said, give me the whole
zone cuz I don't have it.

459
00:22:08.450 --> 00:22:13.081
But now that I've got the zone, I can say,
hey, my last serial number was this.

460
00:22:13.081 --> 00:22:14.380
This is my new serial number.

461
00:22:14.380 --> 00:22:16.050
Can you just give me the changes?

462
00:22:16.050 --> 00:22:16.746
Don't give me the whole thing.

463
00:22:16.746 --> 00:22:17.516
Just give me what changed.

464
00:22:17.516 --> 00:22:20.000
And that really helps to
optimize replication.

465
00:22:20.000 --> 00:22:24.150
>> Now Don, in this instance, your zone
doesn't allow for dynamic updates.

466
00:22:24.150 --> 00:22:25.560
You've turned that off.

467
00:22:25.560 --> 00:22:29.739
Is there really a reason to use, I know
I've asked you this question before,

468
00:22:29.739 --> 00:22:34.241
an incremental zone transfer if you're
not constantly updating that file through

469
00:22:34.241 --> 00:22:35.286
dynamic updates?

470
00:22:37.015 --> 00:22:38.104
>> My answer would be no.

471
00:22:38.104 --> 00:22:40.100
There's really no point worrying about it.

472
00:22:40.100 --> 00:22:43.080
But the official textbook thing is yes.

473
00:22:43.080 --> 00:22:47.860
Because what if you've got
10,000 records in that zone?

474
00:22:47.860 --> 00:22:49.090
And it's a big file.

475
00:22:49.090 --> 00:22:50.694
And every time you change one record,

476
00:22:50.694 --> 00:22:53.166
you gotta send the whole
stinking thing to the other side.

477
00:22:53.166 --> 00:22:57.606
And it's gonna rebuild its cache and
all that stuff, those things happen.

478
00:22:57.606 --> 00:23:00.783
My argument would still be,
hey, even with 10,000 records,

479
00:23:00.783 --> 00:23:03.550
your zone is probably under
one megabyte its size.

480
00:23:03.550 --> 00:23:07.022
And that's just trivial amounts
of data on modern computers.

481
00:23:07.022 --> 00:23:09.210
But back in the day,
that used to be a problem.

482
00:23:09.210 --> 00:23:10.409
It used to be stuff we worry.

483
00:23:10.409 --> 00:23:13.230
We have different problems these
days than we did back then.

484
00:23:13.230 --> 00:23:16.921
But back then, even a meg of
data was a substantial amount.

485
00:23:16.921 --> 00:23:18.860
And so it used to be a problem.

486
00:23:18.860 --> 00:23:20.060
Now, we don't worry about it.

487
00:23:20.060 --> 00:23:23.210
I don't really care about incremental
transfers on DNS anymore.

488
00:23:23.210 --> 00:23:24.540
But it did used to be a big deal.

489
00:23:24.540 --> 00:23:26.510
And that's really what my choice is here.

490
00:23:26.510 --> 00:23:30.490
When I see Transfer from Master or
Transfer new copy of zone from Master.

491
00:23:30.490 --> 00:23:33.170
Transfer from Master
triggers an incremental.

492
00:23:33.170 --> 00:23:34.400
Unless it's the very first one,

493
00:23:34.400 --> 00:23:38.760
which would only happen if it failed on
the first try and I fixed the problem.

494
00:23:38.760 --> 00:23:39.709
Then this one would actually do a full.

495
00:23:39.709 --> 00:23:41.467
But normally,
it's gonna do an incremental.

496
00:23:41.467 --> 00:23:43.750
The next one, though,
that's gonna do a full.

497
00:23:43.750 --> 00:23:47.340
This one's always gonna do an AXFR,
Transfer new copy of zone from Master.

498
00:23:47.340 --> 00:23:48.723
I don't trust what I've got.

499
00:23:48.723 --> 00:23:51.530
I'm gonna ditch it and
bring in the new copy.

500
00:23:52.630 --> 00:23:55.906
And that'll make sure that we're up to
date and we've got the latest data.

501
00:23:55.906 --> 00:23:59.215
>> Does your secondary DNS server,
Don, do recursion?

502
00:23:59.215 --> 00:24:00.887
>> Yeah, absolutely, yep.

503
00:24:00.887 --> 00:24:05.055
When a DNS server does a lookup
It looks for authoritative zones.

504
00:24:05.055 --> 00:24:08.760
This DNS server is authoritative,
itprotv.demo.org.

505
00:24:08.760 --> 00:24:10.170
So it'll answer right out of the zone.

506
00:24:10.170 --> 00:24:11.910
It can't change that zone,
but it'll answer out of it.

507
00:24:11.910 --> 00:24:13.170
It's authoritative.

508
00:24:13.170 --> 00:24:17.130
But anything it's not authoritative for,
goes to the normal lookup process, right?

509
00:24:17.130 --> 00:24:19.830
And that's why we have more
than one of these servers.

510
00:24:19.830 --> 00:24:24.058
Cuz, what's the bulk of our stuff
gonna be, we're cursive look ups.

511
00:24:24.058 --> 00:24:27.160
You know, people abuse the internet,
there's gonna be tons of lookup for

512
00:24:27.160 --> 00:24:30.270
crazy ads and stupid articles on
Facebook and things like that.

513
00:24:30.270 --> 00:24:33.320
Versus you've got a static
amount of file servers and

514
00:24:33.320 --> 00:24:35.920
mail servers that uses
part of actual work.

515
00:24:35.920 --> 00:24:39.019
So you're true work related DNS
look ups are not that significant.

516
00:24:40.260 --> 00:24:43.820
Maybe if you got Active Directory you do a
lot of look ups, find domain controllers.

517
00:24:43.820 --> 00:24:45.300
But your workstations cache that too.

518
00:24:45.300 --> 00:24:47.200
Most of them don't even
update until they reboot.

519
00:24:47.200 --> 00:24:51.240
So you're talking about a very small
amount of look ups for internal resources.

520
00:24:51.240 --> 00:24:53.050
So it's that external side
that's really important.

521
00:24:53.050 --> 00:24:56.880
And I might be a secondary for this zone.

522
00:24:56.880 --> 00:24:59.930
And then I might have another
zone that I'm the primary for.

523
00:24:59.930 --> 00:25:01.870
And another one on active
directory integrated.

524
00:25:01.870 --> 00:25:04.330
You can mix and
match these things like crazy.

525
00:25:04.330 --> 00:25:07.540
So the zones are really treated as
equal when it comes to a lookup.

526
00:25:07.540 --> 00:25:09.380
And it doesn't care if you're secondary or
primary.

527
00:25:09.380 --> 00:25:11.930
It's just when you make changes
that that matters, right?

528
00:25:11.930 --> 00:25:16.630
Now I can't make a change from here, but
if I jump back over to my other server,

529
00:25:16.630 --> 00:25:17.880
I can make a change on this one, right?

530
00:25:17.880 --> 00:25:22.470
So I'm going to add a new entry and maybe
I want an entry for Wes's laptop, right?

531
00:25:22.470 --> 00:25:25.870
So I'll just call this one Wes Laptop.

532
00:25:25.870 --> 00:25:27.280
And I'll give it an IP address.

533
00:25:27.280 --> 00:25:29.760
I always make one up, but
that's really somebody's IP.

534
00:25:29.760 --> 00:25:31.510
I have no idea who, but
we'll do it anyway.

535
00:25:31.510 --> 00:25:34.160
All right, so there we go.

536
00:25:34.160 --> 00:25:37.918
We've got an IP now for
Wes's laptop, 1.1.1.1, right?

537
00:25:37.918 --> 00:25:39.440
I made it here.

538
00:25:39.440 --> 00:25:43.480
In theory, in the background, my server
just sent a notify over to the secondary

539
00:25:43.480 --> 00:25:46.890
and it said, hey,
our serial number just changed, right?

540
00:25:46.890 --> 00:25:50.220
I think my serial number was 18 before,
so it should have bumped up to 19.

541
00:25:50.220 --> 00:25:57.730
If I pull up my Properties and go to
my SOA tab, where is my serial number?

542
00:25:57.730 --> 00:26:01.130
Up here, 18,
I guess It must have been 17 before.

543
00:26:01.130 --> 00:26:05.020
But it bumps that number, and it sends
the notify to the other side, right.

544
00:26:05.020 --> 00:26:07.900
I can manually increment if I want,
but that number goes up.

545
00:26:07.900 --> 00:26:11.690
I guess I could just seen the number right
there, which I didn't pay attention.

546
00:26:11.690 --> 00:26:12.550
So let's create a new entry,

547
00:26:12.550 --> 00:26:15.810
it's supposed to increment every
time we create new record.

548
00:26:15.810 --> 00:26:18.490
>> I just hit refresh, and now I see 19.

549
00:26:18.490 --> 00:26:20.570
The MMC,
you always got to remember to hit refresh.

550
00:26:20.570 --> 00:26:23.980
So I created Wes's laptop and
it went from 18 to 19.

551
00:26:23.980 --> 00:26:26.940
And then it should have sent
a notify to the other side, right?

552
00:26:26.940 --> 00:26:29.280
If it did,
the other side will update right now.

553
00:26:29.280 --> 00:26:33.003
If it didn't, the other side update
when it does it's next pull anyway, so

554
00:26:33.003 --> 00:26:34.937
it's going to periodically do a pull.

555
00:26:34.937 --> 00:26:38.052
And I should be able to jump
over to the other side.

556
00:26:38.052 --> 00:26:41.544
And if it got the notify and
it reached out and did the pull,

557
00:26:41.544 --> 00:26:45.560
I should be able to refresh this and
there's Wes' laptop.

558
00:26:45.560 --> 00:26:48.352
All I did was refresh my screen,
cuz the doesn't refresh for me.

559
00:26:48.352 --> 00:26:50.480
And I can see his entry made it over here,
right?

560
00:26:50.480 --> 00:26:52.410
And that, one of the two things.

561
00:26:52.410 --> 00:26:56.420
It was either the notify that worked,
or it just happen to hit it's interval.

562
00:26:56.420 --> 00:26:58.270
I'm pretty sure the interval
is 15 minutes and

563
00:26:58.270 --> 00:27:01.070
that interval may have happened
right there during that same time.

564
00:27:01.070 --> 00:27:03.120
But either way I got the record and
there we go.

565
00:27:03.120 --> 00:27:06.774
So we make all our changes on the primary
and they replicate over the secondary.

566
00:27:06.774 --> 00:27:07.943
Pretty straight forward.

567
00:27:07.943 --> 00:27:11.450
All right, now once that's done
I'm replicating, I'm in business.

568
00:27:11.450 --> 00:27:14.420
I can add more secondaries if I want,
you can even do multi-tiers.

569
00:27:14.420 --> 00:27:18.530
I have a primary and a secondary, and
then more secondaries that feed, so

570
00:27:18.530 --> 00:27:20.950
it'd be like tertiaries,
that feed off of the secondary.

571
00:27:20.950 --> 00:27:22.390
So you can build a hierarchy like that,

572
00:27:22.390 --> 00:27:24.690
but you can only make
changes at the primary.

573
00:27:24.690 --> 00:27:27.690
After it's done, It's kind of like that
rotisserie chicken, right, we set it,

574
00:27:27.690 --> 00:27:29.610
we forget it, and off it goes.

575
00:27:29.610 --> 00:27:32.400
>> Yeah, and I got to just gotta make
sure that I can get to your DNS server

576
00:27:32.400 --> 00:27:33.790
real quick and pull the power on it.

577
00:27:33.790 --> 00:27:35.090
So you clear the cache and

578
00:27:35.090 --> 00:27:38.450
you can't tell what I'm really doing
during my working hours there, Don.

579
00:27:38.450 --> 00:27:41.610
It does look like we're coming to the end
of another episode, but Don, before we do.

580
00:27:41.610 --> 00:27:44.540
When it comes to configuring
replications in your zones,

581
00:27:44.540 --> 00:27:47.050
do you have any words that you
might like to add to our viewers?

582
00:27:47.050 --> 00:27:50.020
Or give to our viewers before we sign off?

583
00:27:50.020 --> 00:27:52.820
>> Sure, I know I said set it and forget
it, but you do need to monitor it and

584
00:27:52.820 --> 00:27:54.000
make sure it's getting updated.

585
00:27:54.000 --> 00:27:56.680
There's nothing worse than having two
different DNS servers that give you two

586
00:27:56.680 --> 00:27:57.850
different responses.

587
00:27:57.850 --> 00:27:59.695
You gotta make sure that
replication continues on.

588
00:27:59.695 --> 00:28:02.420
Just monitor your vent logs and
the general health of the server.

589
00:28:02.420 --> 00:28:05.230
Keep an eye on it, so that if that
replication ever breaks that you're aware,

590
00:28:05.230 --> 00:28:06.550
you can get in there and fix it.

591
00:28:06.550 --> 00:28:09.720
All right Don, as always we appreciate
you being here in the studios with us and

592
00:28:09.720 --> 00:28:11.810
we appreciate you the viewer watching.

00:28:11.810 --> 00:28:14.980
Signing out for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host West Bryan.

00:28:14.980 --> 00:28:15.800
>> And I"m Don Pezet.

00:28:15.800 --> 00:28:18.399
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode Don and Cherokee discuss and demonstrate how to install a BIND (Berkley Internet Naming Domain) DNS Server. BIND is an older but very important reference DNS program which is available for a variety of operating  systems. We see how to edit the configuration file, start the service and allow BIND thru the firewalld.

00:21:24.500 --> 00:21:25.528
it's really important, all right.

00:21:25.528 --> 00:21:26.943

00:21:38.336 --> 00:21:39.989

00:22:04.670 --> 00:22:06.194

00:22:06.194 --> 00:22:07.455

00:22:16.151 --> 00:22:22.010

00:22:22.010 --> 00:22:25.460

00:22:25.460 --> 00:22:27.280

00:22:46.508 --> 00:22:47.720

episodes.description: Once BIND is installed you will need to configure zones if you do not intend to use it solely as a DNS cache server. You will see how to create separate zone files and link back into the configuration file to reference the zones that have been generated. Don demonstrates how to create a variety of records in the forward lookup zone.

knowing the right format for the file.

353
00:17:21.292 --> 00:17:21.800
All right.

354
00:17:21.800 --> 00:17:24.731
So if we parch through this real
quick we should be able to find

355
00:17:24.731 --> 00:17:27.153
error hopefully better
than the check files did.

356
00:17:27.153 --> 00:17:30.140
And looking down the line I'm not
seeing a lot of great stuff here.

357
00:17:30.140 --> 00:17:34.210
It failed to start,
that didn't take a genius to figure out.

358
00:17:34.210 --> 00:17:35.453
It's showing me that
the service has failed.

359
00:17:35.453 --> 00:17:38.436
So I'm seeing a lot of
detailed information here.

360
00:17:38.436 --> 00:17:42.397
You can scroll to the right in the journal
command to see what's off to the right of

361
00:17:42.397 --> 00:17:43.049
the screen.

362
00:17:43.049 --> 00:17:43.845
And here's my error.

363
00:17:43.845 --> 00:17:50.980
We got a zone 222.0.10.in-addr.arpa/in
not loaded due to errors.

364
00:17:50.980 --> 00:17:51.487
All right.

365
00:17:51.487 --> 00:17:52.880
>> Okay, obvious.

366
00:17:52.880 --> 00:17:54.690
>> Okay, figured that out.

367
00:17:54.690 --> 00:17:57.380
But the next one, that's the one
I'm looking for right there.

368
00:17:57.380 --> 00:18:00.170
So it's telling me that it was looking for
the zone.

369
00:18:00.170 --> 00:18:01.470
File Not Found.

370
00:18:01.470 --> 00:18:05.310
So I might have botched the filename or
put a bad path in or whatever.

371
00:18:05.310 --> 00:18:06.720
We double checked all the permissions.

372
00:18:06.720 --> 00:18:09.740
So I know it's not a permissions problem
cuz that can cause file not found also.

373
00:18:09.740 --> 00:18:11.320
But I know it's not that.

374
00:18:11.320 --> 00:18:13.020
But I probably just screwed it up.

375
00:18:13.020 --> 00:18:14.110
That happens.

376
00:18:14.110 --> 00:18:18.240
So let me look inside, var/named and I'm
gonna make sure I got that filename right.

377
00:18:18.240 --> 00:18:22.720
So I'm gonna copy that filename so
I know I've got it right.

378
00:18:22.720 --> 00:18:26.880
And then I'm gonna edit /etc/named.conf.

379
00:18:26.880 --> 00:18:29.974
And I'm gonna dive right down
to the bottom of that file.

380
00:18:29.974 --> 00:18:35.954
And I'm looking for
the line where I added in the zone.

381
00:18:35.954 --> 00:18:39.112
So here it is, and I've got the zone name.

382
00:18:39.112 --> 00:18:41.175
It didn't complain about the zone name,
it complained about the filename.

383
00:18:41.175 --> 00:18:48.064
The filenames down here and
I've got 222.0.10.in.addr.arpa.

384
00:18:48.064 --> 00:18:49.983
And, well there's our problem.

385
00:18:49.983 --> 00:18:53.460
The file ends in .dns cuz
that's what I like to do.

386
00:18:53.460 --> 00:18:55.660
I like to stick .dns on the end,
and then I forgot.

387
00:18:55.660 --> 00:18:57.214
But I'm gonna delete all that.

388
00:18:57.214 --> 00:18:58.362
And then just paste it.

389
00:18:58.362 --> 00:18:59.080
>> Paste it?

390
00:18:59.080 --> 00:19:00.200
>> Cuz then you know it's right.

391
00:19:00.200 --> 00:19:00.720
>> All right.

392
00:19:00.720 --> 00:19:03.460
>> But I left that .dns off,
so that would be a problem.

393
00:19:03.460 --> 00:19:06.790
All right so if that's the biggest problem
we have that would explain why I got

394
00:19:06.790 --> 00:19:07.750
errors.

395
00:19:07.750 --> 00:19:08.858
I was ready to blame.

396
00:19:08.858 --> 00:19:10.250
>> And they weren't ready to or

397
00:19:10.250 --> 00:19:13.190
they weren't able to recognize them
because it was just a naming convention.

398
00:19:13.190 --> 00:19:16.060
>> I was ready to blame named-checkzone.

399
00:19:16.060 --> 00:19:16.560
>> Or missing.

400
00:19:16.560 --> 00:19:19.860
>> It checked the zone file I told it
the right file but this guy didn't.

401
00:19:19.860 --> 00:19:27.210
So let's go ahead and
restart named, there we go.

402
00:19:27.210 --> 00:19:30.410
And now I should be able
to fire up nslookup.

403
00:19:30.410 --> 00:19:33.940
And I'll switch to myself as the server.

404
00:19:33.940 --> 00:19:36.440
And I was doing forward lookups earlier,
so

405
00:19:36.440 --> 00:19:41.920
like webserver01.lab.itpro.tv and
I get it's IPs back.

406
00:19:41.920 --> 00:19:46.220
I should now be able to do
reverse lookups, so if I look for

407
00:19:46.220 --> 00:19:50.445
10.0.22.101, I get that that's DNS one.

408
00:19:50.445 --> 00:19:55.296
Or if I do 10.0.22.99,
that's web server one.

409
00:19:55.296 --> 00:19:58.740
My reverse lookup zones are now
working and we're in business.

410
00:19:58.740 --> 00:20:00.580
So, configuring the zone file,

411
00:20:00.580 --> 00:20:03.470
not all that much different
than the forward lookup zone.

412
00:20:03.470 --> 00:20:06.990
And ultimately, the only challenge I had
here was typing in the right file name

413
00:20:06.990 --> 00:20:09.480
which is simply my problem,
not necessarily the technology's.

414
00:20:09.480 --> 00:20:11.050
So, but that's basically it.

415
00:20:11.050 --> 00:20:13.310
>> Perfect.
So, Don, you were able to go ahead,

416
00:20:13.310 --> 00:20:17.140
in the previous episode, show us how
to create our forward lookup zones.

417
00:20:17.140 --> 00:20:19.630
We see how to go ahead and
create our reverse lookup zones.

418
00:20:19.630 --> 00:20:21.140
I think replication is next.

419
00:20:21.140 --> 00:20:24.440
So thank you for being here today and
thank you guys for tuning in.

420
00:20:24.440 --> 00:20:28.310
But don't go anywhere we have some
replication headed your way, stay tuned.

421
00:20:28.310 --> 00:20:32.850
For this episode I'm gonna go ahead and
sign off as your host Cherokee Boose

422
00:20:32.850 --> 00:20:33.557
>> And I'm Don Pezet

423
00:20:33.557 --> 00:20:36.221
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

424
00:20:36.221 --> 00:20:42.850
[MUSIC]

425
00:20:42.850 --> 00:20:45.852
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don demonstrate replication of the DNS database. They show how to set up the master DNS server as well as setting up the slave DNS server to receive the DNS zone database.
episodes.title: Configuring Replication
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:03.122
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:03.122 --> 00:00:05.342
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco,

3
00:00:05.342 --> 00:00:06.628
California [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.628 --> 00:00:08.428
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.428 --> 00:00:10.590
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.180 --> 00:00:14.910
Welcome to another great
episode here of ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.910 --> 00:00:15.480
I'm your host,

8
00:00:15.480 --> 00:00:19.670
Wes Bryan and in today's episode we're
continuing through our series within DNS.

9
00:00:19.670 --> 00:00:22.570
Probably one of the most important
services out there in the internet.

10
00:00:22.570 --> 00:00:24.920
And joining us back in the studios
is none other than Mr Don Pezet.

11
00:00:24.920 --> 00:00:25.540
Don, how you doing, sir?

12
00:00:25.540 --> 00:00:27.200
>> Hey, thanks for having me back, Wes.

13
00:00:27.200 --> 00:00:29.010
Excited to jump back
into the world of BIND.

14
00:00:29.010 --> 00:00:33.880
And in this episode we're gonna be taking
a look at setting up replication in BIND.

15
00:00:33.880 --> 00:00:37.350
And the main reason is hey,
what's better than one BIND server?

16
00:00:37.350 --> 00:00:40.010
Two BIND servers or three or
four, let's go crazy.

17
00:00:40.010 --> 00:00:41.820
We'll see how many we can create.

18
00:00:41.820 --> 00:00:46.310
It's a good idea to have at least
two DNS servers on your network.

19
00:00:46.310 --> 00:00:47.760
I think everybody,
pretty much, knows that.

20
00:00:47.760 --> 00:00:51.890
And there's different reasons for it but
the main reason is simply, redundancy.

21
00:00:51.890 --> 00:00:53.790
You don't wanna have all
your eggs in one basket,

22
00:00:53.790 --> 00:00:56.900
if one DNS server fails,
now people can't do LOOKUPS.

23
00:00:56.900 --> 00:00:58.450
So ideally, we wanna have two.

24
00:00:58.450 --> 00:01:01.120
But we can also do load balancing and
performance, and

25
00:01:01.120 --> 00:01:05.640
other things, there's various reasons why
we might wanna have multiple DNS servers.

26
00:01:05.640 --> 00:01:08.117
But either way, if you've reached that
decision that you wanna have it for

27
00:01:08.117 --> 00:01:11.420
whatever reason,
its not that hard to get set up.

28
00:01:11.420 --> 00:01:16.790
What we do is we take the zones that we've
already created on our first server and

29
00:01:16.790 --> 00:01:21.080
we replicate those over to a second
server or a third or a fourth or

30
00:01:21.080 --> 00:01:23.420
as many as you want,
I don't believe there's a limit.

31
00:01:23.420 --> 00:01:27.000
Eventually you tax the CPU
on the main server, but

32
00:01:27.000 --> 00:01:31.680
it's really pretty negligible
because DNS zones aren't very big.

33
00:01:31.680 --> 00:01:36.230
Now when we set this up, we- actually,
you know what, let's back up.

34
00:01:36.230 --> 00:01:37.720
Let's take a look at the server
that we've already set up.

35
00:01:37.720 --> 00:01:39.970
I'm just going to steal the server
that we set up in the earlier episode,

36
00:01:39.970 --> 00:01:42.640
actually our very last episode
where we created zones.

37
00:01:42.640 --> 00:01:48.930
We created a zone for lab.itpro.tv and
it exists on one server.

38
00:01:48.930 --> 00:01:53.120
Now that one server is called the master
server although I didn't really mention

39
00:01:53.120 --> 00:01:56.100
that in the show because
It was just one server,

40
00:01:56.100 --> 00:01:58.440
it doesn't really matter that
it's the master of its domain.

41
00:01:58.440 --> 00:02:02.160
It would be like calling someone
a manager when they have no employees

42
00:02:02.160 --> 00:02:02.950
reporting to them.

43
00:02:02.950 --> 00:02:05.110
Like what do they manage,
they manage themselves.

44
00:02:05.110 --> 00:02:06.700
Well, that's exactly
what we're set up for.

45
00:02:06.700 --> 00:02:07.940
So, let me pull this up here.

46
00:02:07.940 --> 00:02:11.980
I've got DNS1, is the server I was
working on in the last episode.

47
00:02:11.980 --> 00:02:16.420
And we built up a server, now I'm gonna
elevate my privileges real quick so

48
00:02:16.420 --> 00:02:20.010
that I don't have to constantly
sudu every command that I do.

49
00:02:20.010 --> 00:02:23.950
And I'm gonna get into /var/named.

50
00:02:23.950 --> 00:02:27.060
And we can find the zone that
I built in the last episode.

51
00:02:27.060 --> 00:02:32.860
So if I pull up lab.itpro.tv.dns
here's the zone we made.

52
00:02:32.860 --> 00:02:35.490
I did a start of authority,
which is this server, DNS1.

53
00:02:35.490 --> 00:02:38.380
I did some named servers, DNS1 and DNS2.

54
00:02:38.380 --> 00:02:42.030
Now, I added DNS2 in there just to
give you guys an example of hey,

55
00:02:42.030 --> 00:02:43.310
here's a second server.

56
00:02:43.310 --> 00:02:47.740
Well, that server doesn't
actually have the zone.

57
00:02:47.740 --> 00:02:49.710
So I need to get a copy
of the zone over to it.

58
00:02:49.710 --> 00:02:53.920
Now, I could just take the zone file and
copy it to the other side, that does work.

59
00:02:53.920 --> 00:02:58.180
The challenge is, if I ever update
this server, I have to go and

60
00:02:58.180 --> 00:03:00.390
do the same update on the other server,
right?

61
00:03:00.390 --> 00:03:02.060
And the more servers you have,

62
00:03:02.060 --> 00:03:05.540
the more likely it is that you're gonna
forget to do that or fail to do that,

63
00:03:05.540 --> 00:03:09.280
and you're gonna end up with different
responses coming from different servers.

64
00:03:09.280 --> 00:03:13.150
So the whole point of setting up
replication is that we can have a master,

65
00:03:13.150 --> 00:03:15.460
which in my case is gonna be DNS1.

66
00:03:15.460 --> 00:03:18.030
And then we can have one or more slaves.

67
00:03:18.030 --> 00:03:19.050
And the slaves,

68
00:03:19.050 --> 00:03:24.070
which we'll start with DNS2 here, are
gonna get a copy of the zone from DNS1.

69
00:03:24.070 --> 00:03:26.840
So going forward,
I just modify the master,

70
00:03:26.840 --> 00:03:29.460
and then all the slaves
will get a copy from there.

71
00:03:29.460 --> 00:03:31.740
And they'll pull it down and
they'll have that copy.

72
00:03:31.740 --> 00:03:35.456
Now, why the master-slave terminology?

73
00:03:35.456 --> 00:03:40.410
The main reason is, the master is the one
who's actually in charge of the zone.

74
00:03:40.410 --> 00:03:42.640
You can get in there and
you can edit things, you can change it,

75
00:03:42.640 --> 00:03:46.230
you can do whatever you want,
because that's the master of the zone.

76
00:03:46.230 --> 00:03:49.070
The other guys are considered slaves
because they're not allowed to change

77
00:03:49.070 --> 00:03:50.420
the zone at all.

78
00:03:50.420 --> 00:03:54.130
All they can do is reach out and
grab a copy, okay?

79
00:03:54.130 --> 00:03:56.450
And they pull that copy down,
and that's it.

80
00:03:56.450 --> 00:04:01.350
If you change the record on a slave
server, the changes just go away

81
00:04:01.350 --> 00:04:03.800
because it goes and replicates
with the master and pulls it down.

82
00:04:03.800 --> 00:04:05.770
It's one-way replication.

83
00:04:05.770 --> 00:04:08.510
You replicate from the master
to all the slaves.

84
00:04:08.510 --> 00:04:10.460
So that's why they use
the slave terminology.

85
00:04:10.460 --> 00:04:13.780
You also see some people use primary and
secondary.

86
00:04:13.780 --> 00:04:15.755
Well, that's in third party DNS servers.

87
00:04:15.755 --> 00:04:19.480
In the official standard, it's the master
slave terminology so that's what we have.

88
00:04:19.480 --> 00:04:22.990
>> So Don, in theory, this goes back to
like maybe even the old IDE drives where

89
00:04:22.990 --> 00:04:25.940
you had a master, you know, we'd call
it primary drive, and a slave drive.

90
00:04:25.940 --> 00:04:27.860
The master was in charge
of the whole channel.

91
00:04:27.860 --> 00:04:30.380
And then the slave just kinda
waited on whatever the master was

92
00:04:30.380 --> 00:04:31.180
gonna update it with.

93
00:04:31.180 --> 00:04:34.760
>> That's exactly the same principle,
except here it's just text files.

94
00:04:34.760 --> 00:04:38.270
It's far less complex, but
it actually works the same way.

95
00:04:38.270 --> 00:04:40.500
Now when you look at my
name server records here,

96
00:04:40.500 --> 00:04:43.960
I don't denote whether one is a master or
a slave or anything like and

97
00:04:43.960 --> 00:04:48.520
that's because as far as the end users are
concerned, they don't know the difference.

98
00:04:48.520 --> 00:04:50.490
They don't know the difference
between one and the other.

99
00:04:50.490 --> 00:04:54.030
So inside the DNS zone itself they're
going to show up as the same.

100
00:04:54.030 --> 00:04:58.460
And then everything else that's in here,
these are all just records.

101
00:04:58.460 --> 00:05:00.780
Records that I put in
the populated the zone.

102
00:05:00.780 --> 00:05:05.480
So I need to get all of these records
over to my second server, over to DNS2.

103
00:05:05.480 --> 00:05:06.130
All right.

104
00:05:06.130 --> 00:05:11.030
Now, my server is already up and running
with this so if I do like an nslookup, and

105
00:05:11.030 --> 00:05:14.560
I switch to my own server, right?

106
00:05:14.560 --> 00:05:19.965
I can start doing lookups for like
mail1.lab.itpro.tv, and I get a response.

107
00:05:19.965 --> 00:05:25.990
Or I could do mail2, and so on and I'm
pulling responses right out of that zone.

108
00:05:25.990 --> 00:05:27.750
So I know its working,
and everything is good.

109
00:05:28.790 --> 00:05:29.610
On the master,

110
00:05:29.610 --> 00:05:33.380
there is not really all that much we
have to do to get ready to replicate.

111
00:05:33.380 --> 00:05:35.550
But, we do have to do something.

112
00:05:35.550 --> 00:05:38.510
What we have to enable are what
are called zone transfers.

113
00:05:38.510 --> 00:05:42.160
The secondary server that the slaves,
they're gonna reach in.

114
00:05:42.160 --> 00:05:46.400
And they're gonna request a zone transfer,
a copy of the zone in it's entirety,

115
00:05:46.400 --> 00:05:47.460
they want the whole thing.

116
00:05:47.460 --> 00:05:48.820
Give me that zone.

117
00:05:48.820 --> 00:05:52.770
Well, that's turned off by default,
it's not allowed, it's blocked.

118
00:05:52.770 --> 00:05:56.310
And the reason it's blocked is
because an attacker could come,

119
00:05:56.310 --> 00:05:58.700
connect to your DNS server and say "hey
give me a whole copy of your zone".

120
00:05:58.700 --> 00:06:02.620
And then they get the whole zone and now
they know every server mapped to every IP,

121
00:06:02.620 --> 00:06:05.910
now that's not true security.

122
00:06:05.910 --> 00:06:07.570
By turning this off it's
not hiding the server.

123
00:06:07.570 --> 00:06:08.600
It's still there.

124
00:06:08.600 --> 00:06:11.640
If the attacker knows the name,
they can still use it, right?

125
00:06:11.640 --> 00:06:13.310
But it does make their job more difficult.

126
00:06:13.310 --> 00:06:14.718
It's called obfuscation.

127
00:06:14.718 --> 00:06:18.310
Where just kinda hiding the data a little
bit and that is turned on by default.

128
00:06:18.310 --> 00:06:19.840
We are hiding that data.

129
00:06:19.840 --> 00:06:22.830
So on the master,
I need to change its configuration.

130
00:06:22.830 --> 00:06:27.680
I'm gonna edit /etc/named.conf and

131
00:06:27.680 --> 00:06:32.650
this is the file that we went into
when we originally defined our zone.

132
00:06:32.650 --> 00:06:36.650
So if I come in here and find it,
here's where I defined the zone.

133
00:06:36.650 --> 00:06:41.200
And I said, hey, lab.itpro.tv is a zone.

134
00:06:41.200 --> 00:06:42.550
It exists.

135
00:06:42.550 --> 00:06:45.710
The file for it is lab.itpro.tv.dns,

136
00:06:45.710 --> 00:06:51.000
that's where you can get all the records,
and then type master.

137
00:06:51.000 --> 00:06:53.780
I said that this one was the master,
it's in charge, and

138
00:06:53.780 --> 00:06:55.950
that means hey,
we're allowed to change it, and

139
00:06:55.950 --> 00:07:00.560
we can send changes to other people,
other people cannot send changes to us.

140
00:07:00.560 --> 00:07:04.380
There can be only one master,
and this is it, right?

141
00:07:04.380 --> 00:07:05.840
So that's what type master is all about.

142
00:07:05.840 --> 00:07:09.620
I bet you can guess what we're gonna
put on the other server, type slave.

143
00:07:09.620 --> 00:07:12.430
That'll let it know that, hey,
we're not allowed to make changes.

144
00:07:12.430 --> 00:07:14.170
We're not allowed to send changes.

145
00:07:14.170 --> 00:07:15.780
We can only receive changes.

146
00:07:15.780 --> 00:07:18.120
That's how it knows what
that zone is going to be.

147
00:07:18.120 --> 00:07:20.480
So that's kind of a key piece.

148
00:07:20.480 --> 00:07:24.660
Now, what I also need to add in here,
and it'll probably be faster for

149
00:07:24.660 --> 00:07:26.880
me to search to find it,
but in here somewhere,

150
00:07:26.880 --> 00:07:29.680
there's a little section where it'll
talk about the zone transfers.

151
00:07:29.680 --> 00:07:32.860
And the zone transfers

00:19:12.160 --> 00:19:13.410
There's any number of
things that can break it,

374
00:19:13.410 --> 00:19:17.260
but at least as far as my syntax, I
remembered the right amount of semicolons.

375
00:19:17.260 --> 00:19:17.980
So, we're good there.

376
00:19:19.140 --> 00:19:23.990
So, I'm pretty much done here,
except there is a little bit of

377
00:19:23.990 --> 00:19:26.900
security stuff I need to worry about,
before I really get this going.

378
00:19:26.900 --> 00:19:29.050
So, I do need to open up
the firewall on this system.

379
00:19:29.050 --> 00:19:32.050
So, I'm gonna do a firewall-cmd.

380
00:19:32.050 --> 00:19:35.100
If I didn't want people to
do lookups against this one,

381
00:19:35.100 --> 00:19:37.920
it's actually go enough to reach out and
get the zone from the other one.

382
00:19:37.920 --> 00:19:41.060
So, if I'm trying to use this as some
kind of crazy backup, I can do that.

383
00:19:41.060 --> 00:19:43.710
But typically, you want people to
do lookups against the secondary.

384
00:19:43.710 --> 00:19:46.430
The whole point is to take
load off the other server.

385
00:19:46.430 --> 00:19:53.620
So, I'll do
firewall-cmd--add-service Equals DNS,

386
00:19:53.620 --> 00:19:57.340
and I'm gonna run the same thing again,
and do a little dash dash permanent.

387
00:19:59.770 --> 00:20:02.950
And remember, I run the command twice
because one makes it take effect right

388
00:20:02.950 --> 00:20:05.720
now, the other one makes it
take effect after a reboot.

389
00:20:05.720 --> 00:20:08.300
I could just run the second command.

390
00:20:08.300 --> 00:20:09.650
And then restart the firewall, but

391
00:20:09.650 --> 00:20:12.008
anybody connected to the server
right now would get disconnected.

392
00:20:12.008 --> 00:20:15.100
On a brand-new server, that's not a big
deal, but if this is a production server,

393
00:20:15.100 --> 00:20:15.600
I don't wanna do that.

394
00:20:15.600 --> 00:20:18.631
So, I've just gotten in the habit
of always running those commands

395
00:20:18.631 --> 00:20:19.866
twice to take care of that.

396
00:20:19.866 --> 00:20:24.102
All right, then,
if I've feel like I'm done and good,

397
00:20:24.102 --> 00:20:28.801
I can go ahead and restart it,
and get the system up and online.

398
00:20:28.801 --> 00:20:32.292
Since this is the first
time I've installed bind,

399
00:20:32.292 --> 00:20:35.620
I need to do a systemctl
enable named.service,

400
00:20:35.620 --> 00:20:40.260
and that's gonna tell it to start
bind every time I boot up, right?

401
00:20:40.260 --> 00:20:42.710
Otherwise, when I reboot,
it's gonna be stopped.

402
00:20:42.710 --> 00:20:44.524
And then I can start the service.

403
00:20:44.524 --> 00:20:48.567
And a lot of times, it actually starts it
already, so it might already be started.

404
00:20:48.567 --> 00:20:50.969
It looks like it wasn't in this case,
so it went ahead and started it for me.

405
00:20:52.380 --> 00:20:54.020
Now, I'm probably done here.

406
00:20:54.020 --> 00:20:56.130
I'm probably done,
the secondary is up and going.

407
00:20:56.130 --> 00:20:59.090
When it boots up, it's gonna say,
I'm a secondary, I'm a slave for

408
00:20:59.090 --> 00:21:01.670
this other zone, I'm gonna reach out and
get a copy of it.

409
00:21:01.670 --> 00:21:03.935
And hopefully it worked,
right, I'm stalling.

410
00:21:03.935 --> 00:21:07.430
[LAUGH] So, so it reaches out,
it gets a copy of that zone.

411
00:21:07.430 --> 00:21:10.000
It brings it down, and
it saves it in that slaves folder,

412
00:21:10.000 --> 00:21:12.350
and now it's able to start
responding to that zone.

413
00:21:12.350 --> 00:21:13.840
It should have the data.

414
00:21:13.840 --> 00:21:15.630
That's happened ,to be
happening in the background.

415
00:21:15.630 --> 00:21:18.770
If it fails, I'm gonna have to dig through
the logs and find out why it failed, and

416
00:21:18.770 --> 00:21:20.050
see what's going on there.

417
00:21:20.050 --> 00:21:23.412
But assuming that everything worked,
we should be good to go.

418
00:21:23.412 --> 00:21:26.530
Now, I'll walk you through how to
trouble shoot some of that in a minute,

419
00:21:26.530 --> 00:21:29.163
but let's just see if we lucked out,
and everything worked.

420
00:21:29.163 --> 00:21:31.729
I'm gonna go in to /var/named And

421
00:21:31.729 --> 00:21:36.613
I've got that slaves folder right
here that I pointed out earlier.

422
00:21:36.613 --> 00:21:39.933
I'm gonna get into that slaves folder and
just take a look.

423
00:21:39.933 --> 00:21:44.098
And I've got lab.itpro.tv.dns.

424
00:21:44.098 --> 00:21:49.660
And if I take a look at that file,
that's not so good, is it?

425
00:21:49.660 --> 00:21:52.780
Take a look at the file, it's got an entry
for TV, and it's got an entry for

426
00:21:52.780 --> 00:21:55.720
mail1labitprotv.

427
00:21:55.720 --> 00:21:59.620
Well, that's not exactly in any
format that I'm used to, is it?

428
00:21:59.620 --> 00:22:00.730
That's okay.

429
00:22:00.730 --> 00:22:03.910
What it means is that I've caught
it while it's still transferring.

430
00:22:03.910 --> 00:22:06.180
It's still kind of getting the data.

431
00:22:06.180 --> 00:22:10.070
What bind does is it brings
the data into RAM first, and

432
00:22:10.070 --> 00:22:12.350
it likely has the whole zone in RAM.

433
00:22:12.350 --> 00:22:15.130
And then when it gets bored, it starts
writing stuff from the hard drive.

434
00:22:15.130 --> 00:22:16.840
Now, normally, I'd worry about that.

435
00:22:16.840 --> 00:22:21.440
I'd say, well, what if this ever has
a failure while the data's in RAM, right?

436
00:22:21.440 --> 00:22:22.460
Well, who cares?

437
00:22:22.460 --> 00:22:23.370
It's a slave.

438
00:22:23.370 --> 00:22:25.950
If it loses the data when it reboots,
what's it gonna do?

439
00:22:25.950 --> 00:22:28.300
It's gonna go and
get the data from the master again.

440
00:22:28.300 --> 00:22:30.580
So, I don't have to worry
about this one losing data.

441
00:22:30.580 --> 00:22:35.660
So, it is not uncommon to see the file
in the hard drive be wildly out of date

442
00:22:35.660 --> 00:22:37.580
from what's in RAM, okay?

443
00:22:37.580 --> 00:22:41.450
But we can test this against
what's in RAM and kinda see, and

444
00:22:41.450 --> 00:22:43.220
make sure it's actually pulling things.

445
00:22:43.220 --> 00:22:49.480
So, if I wanna do a lookup for something
like the WWW entry that we made, right?

446
00:22:49.480 --> 00:22:51.070
I'll use dig this time.

447
00:22:51.070 --> 00:22:51.810
When we use dig,

448
00:22:51.810 --> 00:22:55.470
you can specify what server you wanna
query against by using the add symbol.

449
00:22:55.470 --> 00:22:57.940
So, I'm gonna query
against my local system.

450
00:22:57.940 --> 00:22:58.790
I'm on DNS two.

451
00:22:58.790 --> 00:23:02.145
That's what I want to query against,
and I'm gonna do a lookup for

452
00:23:02.145 --> 00:23:08.580
www.lab.itproducttv, and if I query that,
I should get a response for what it is.

453
00:23:08.580 --> 00:23:11.530
And I picked a good one,
because it's a cname.

454
00:23:11.530 --> 00:23:14.528
When you have a cname, you don't just
do one lookup, you do two lookups.

455
00:23:14.528 --> 00:23:17.100
And I can see I did a second lookup for
what it pointed to.

456
00:23:17.100 --> 00:23:20.880
It pointed to webserver01, and here it is,
and there were two different IPs for

457
00:23:20.880 --> 00:23:22.150
webserver01.

458
00:23:22.150 --> 00:23:26.130
That lookup happened against this server.

459
00:23:26.130 --> 00:23:29.240
I didn't see those entries in
the file on the hard drive, but

460
00:23:29.240 --> 00:23:30.230
the lookup went just fine.

461
00:23:30.230 --> 00:23:32.960
That means it is in RAM, and it will get
written to the hard drive eventually,

462
00:23:32.960 --> 00:23:34.820
you just have to wait it out.

463
00:23:34.820 --> 00:23:36.080
And we don't normally care, right?

464
00:23:36.080 --> 00:23:37.511
Cuz again, if we reboot or whatever,

465
00:23:37.511 --> 00:23:39.497
we can just get the whole
zone from the master again.

466
00:23:39.497 --> 00:23:40.926
It doesn't really matter.

467
00:23:40.926 --> 00:23:44.884
Now, I could repeat that lookup
against the other server,

468
00:23:44.884 --> 00:23:47.438
if I wanted to find out if it was there.

469
00:23:47.438 --> 00:23:51.580
Let's see,
10.0.222.101 is the other server.

470
00:23:51.580 --> 00:23:53.700
And do the lookup there and see.

471
00:23:53.700 --> 00:23:55.752
If you're ever having a problem
where it doesn't resolve,

472
00:23:55.752 --> 00:23:57.008
this is a great way to troubleshoot.

473
00:23:57.008 --> 00:23:59.890
Because with dig,
you're overriding the DNS server.

474
00:23:59.890 --> 00:24:02.984
And you're not just using whatever
your system is set to use.

475
00:24:02.984 --> 00:24:05.760
So I can say, let me do this
lookup against the master and

476
00:24:05.760 --> 00:24:08.951
then let me repeat the lookup
against the slave and just verify,

477
00:24:08.951 --> 00:24:11.215
am I getting that response
back from the two?

478
00:24:11.215 --> 00:24:13.918
All right, so that's great way to do that.

479
00:24:13.918 --> 00:24:17.070
Another thing that you can do is
you can test the zone transfer

480
00:24:17.070 --> 00:24:18.580
functionality, right?

481
00:24:18.580 --> 00:24:23.220
The zone transfer functionality is really
built around the ls or the List command.

482
00:24:23.220 --> 00:24:25.040
And it's kinda like on a folder, right?

483
00:24:25.040 --> 00:24:27.570
If I wanna see everything in this folder,
I type ls, and

484
00:24:27.570 --> 00:24:29.252
I get a list of the files, right?

485
00:24:29.252 --> 00:24:31.240
Well there's not much here,
but I get a list.

486
00:24:31.240 --> 00:24:35.233
The same thing works with nslookup,
that you can use nslookup and

487
00:24:35.233 --> 00:24:36.766
you can switch a server.

488
00:24:36.766 --> 00:24:44.140
And so I am on the slave right now,
I'm on 10.0.222.102.

489
00:24:44.140 --> 00:24:48.713
And I'm now connected to
10.0.222.101 as my server.

490
00:24:48.713 --> 00:24:53.830
So here's my, wait, that's
the service address, and I'm on 102.

491
00:24:53.830 --> 00:24:58.800
Now, if I run ls, that's gonna say,
give me the whole zone, or you

492
00:24:58.800 --> 00:25:03.310
can even follow it up with a particular
zone if you wanna specify different ones.

493
00:25:03.310 --> 00:25:04.600
I'm saying, give me the whole zone.

494
00:25:04.600 --> 00:25:06.480
That's effectively a zone transfer.

495
00:25:06.480 --> 00:25:09.040
And that's blocked by default.

496
00:25:09.040 --> 00:25:12.800
And if I run that and it's allowed, shoot.

497
00:25:12.800 --> 00:25:15.070
There's more than one version of nslookup,
and

498
00:25:15.070 --> 00:25:17.020
in some versions you don't
have the ls command.

499
00:25:17.020 --> 00:25:20.690
And I've got one that doesn't
have the ls command, darn it.

500
00:25:20.690 --> 00:25:23.890
Like, on a Windows machine,
Microsoft's left ls implemented.

501
00:25:23.890 --> 00:25:28.520
On this one, even help command is
stripped down on this one, shoot.

502
00:25:28.520 --> 00:25:30.580
So I've got one of the stripped
down versions of nslookup

503
00:25:30.580 --> 00:25:31.670
that's missing all of this.

504
00:25:31.670 --> 00:25:33.830
But you can do ls, and
it will do a transfer,

505
00:25:33.830 --> 00:25:36.460
it'll basically pull the entire zone.

506
00:25:36.460 --> 00:25:38.450
We can do the same thing with dig.

507
00:25:38.450 --> 00:25:41.820
Let me pull up dig's
documentation here real quick.

508
00:25:41.820 --> 00:25:44.280
Dig has an option where you
can come in and tell it hey,

509
00:25:44.280 --> 00:25:49.180
just grab the whole stinking thing, and
it's effectively doing a zone transfer.

510
00:25:49.180 --> 00:25:52.560
So when we do a, here, like this.

511
00:25:52.560 --> 00:25:55.680
With dig you can do a -t,
to specify the type.

512
00:25:55.680 --> 00:25:59.770
And normally you'd say like, a,
I'm pulling an a record or whatever.

513
00:25:59.770 --> 00:26:04.270
But if you set that type to any,
where it's gonna grab everything,

514
00:26:04.270 --> 00:26:07.390
then it's the equivalent of doing a zone
transfer, it'll bring all that in.

515
00:26:07.390 --> 00:26:10.970
You can do it incremental, like IXFRs,
incremental zone transfers.

516
00:26:10.970 --> 00:26:13.070
Or AXFRs, if you wanna try and
grab the whole thing.

517
00:26:14.160 --> 00:26:16.340
So that's basically what
they're doing there.

518
00:26:16.340 --> 00:26:17.880
So if you see here where it says,

519
00:26:17.880 --> 00:26:22.100
a zone transfer can be requested
by specifying a type of AXFR.

520
00:26:22.100 --> 00:26:23.190
I can come in here and

521
00:26:23.190 --> 00:26:28.870
I can say dig @10.0.222.101,
so hitting the other server.

522
00:26:28.870 --> 00:26:34.920
I wanna pull lab.itpro.tv and
I'm gonna do a type of AXFR.

523
00:26:34.920 --> 00:26:36.690
I'm gonna do a zone transfer.

524
00:26:36.690 --> 00:26:39.770
And when it reaches out I
should get the whole zone..

525
00:26:39.770 --> 00:26:44.750
If I don't, then maybe I am not listed on
the approved zone transfer list, right.

526
00:26:44.750 --> 00:26:47.200
So this is a great way to test
whether zone transfers are allowed and

527
00:26:47.200 --> 00:26:49.580
even perform one outside of bind.

528
00:26:49.580 --> 00:26:52.990
Cuz bind is doing everything
in the background, right?

529
00:26:52.990 --> 00:26:54.190
We don't necessarily see its errors.

530
00:26:54.190 --> 00:26:57.240
We have to go dig through the syslog or
journalctl.

531
00:26:57.240 --> 00:27:00.500
And go in and
try to find out what happened there.

532
00:27:00.500 --> 00:27:02.450
Which, I mean, that's where you'd find it.

533
00:27:02.450 --> 00:27:06.852
If you do a journalctl-x will

534
00:27:06.852 --> 00:27:12.140
normally bring it up and I probably
should have tailed it, well anyhow.

535
00:27:12.140 --> 00:27:14.146
Let me just pipe that into tail.

536
00:27:14.146 --> 00:27:17.037
There we go, and you could see
the last handful of lines and

537
00:27:17.037 --> 00:27:20.890
the bind encountered an error,
we'd normally spot it right in here.

538
00:27:20.890 --> 00:27:27.250
I've got a start-up of a unit here which
is, well that's just system D starting up.

539
00:27:27.250 --> 00:27:28.180
Shoot, it's too late.

540
00:27:28.180 --> 00:27:31.110
I'd have to restart bind,
to get at kind of at the tail.

541
00:27:31.110 --> 00:27:32.440
Or we could jump in there and search.

542
00:27:32.440 --> 00:27:33.810
Maybe we can hunt it down.

543
00:27:33.810 --> 00:27:36.350
Digging through logs isn't fun though,
is indeed the point.

544
00:27:36.350 --> 00:27:39.850
So if I'm getting an error I can say, all
right, let me just stick bind to the side,

545
00:27:39.850 --> 00:27:44.480
and I'm gonna use dig and
I'm gonna do a zone transfer right here.

546
00:27:44.480 --> 00:27:47.400
I'm on the host, I'm on DNS2.

547
00:27:47.400 --> 00:27:49.720
So if it works for
dig it should work for bind.

548
00:27:49.720 --> 00:27:51.710
The difference here is that dig,

549
00:27:51.710 --> 00:27:54.620
if I get an error I'll actually
see it right here on the screen.

550
00:27:54.620 --> 00:27:58.360
It'll tell me what the error is and what
my problem is, and then we can try and

551
00:27:58.360 --> 00:28:00.130
sort it out and fix it from there.

552
00:28:00.130 --> 00:28:02.500
>> Lot of great information
on configuring replication.

553
00:28:02.500 --> 00:28:04.920
I can see where this can get you in
trouble just as much as it can help

554
00:28:04.920 --> 00:28:05.538
you, for sure.

555
00:28:05.538 --> 00:28:07.347
>> [LAUGH]
>> Don, it does look like it though,

556
00:28:07.347 --> 00:28:08.860
we are coming to the end
of another episode.

557
00:28:08.860 --> 00:28:11.760
But before we do, do you have any
additional words of wisdom about

558
00:28:11.760 --> 00:28:15.580
configuring your replication, or
verification, or even troubleshooting?

559
00:28:15.580 --> 00:28:17.230
>> You mentioned monitoring,

560
00:28:17.230 --> 00:28:19.780
right, that we need to keep an eye
on this stuff after it's done.

561
00:28:19.780 --> 00:28:22.780
You turn it on and you kinda walk away,
everything's working really well.

562
00:28:22.780 --> 00:28:24.370
But you do need to double
check from time to time,

563
00:28:24.370 --> 00:28:26.320
make sure that your
secondaries are healthy.

564
00:28:26.320 --> 00:28:29.650
And then be aware that you can use it for
load balancing.

565
00:28:29.650 --> 00:28:31.790
You can also use it for failover though.

566
00:28:31.790 --> 00:28:37.530
If the master were to fail and go offline,
I could jump over to a secondary

567
00:28:37.530 --> 00:28:42.580
and I could copy that zone file out of
the slave folder into the main folder and

568
00:28:42.580 --> 00:28:44.390
then add it as a zone in
that system as the master.

569
00:28:44.390 --> 00:28:46.710
I could turn a slave into
the master if I needed to.

570
00:28:46.710 --> 00:28:49.070
It is a manual process, though.

571
00:28:49.070 --> 00:28:50.810
Most of us never worry about it, though.

572
00:28:50.810 --> 00:28:54.360
You just leave it as a slave, because as a
slave, yeah, you can't make changes to it.

573
00:28:54.360 --> 00:28:55.920
Or you're not supposed
to make changes to it.

574
00:28:55.920 --> 00:28:57.820
But it'll still run and answer.

575
00:28:57.820 --> 00:29:02.110
So, the master is offline but
your DNS zone is still working.

576
00:29:02.110 --> 00:29:04.795
And now you can go and bring the master
back online, in your own time.

577
00:29:04.795 --> 00:29:06.150
[COUGH] Excuse me.

578
00:29:06.150 --> 00:29:08.210
You just can't add new
records in the meantime.

579
00:29:08.210 --> 00:29:09.750
So, that's basically it.

580
00:29:09.750 --> 00:29:11.820
It's a pretty straightforward process.

581
00:29:11.820 --> 00:29:15.560
>> Well Don, we appreciate you taking the
time to be here with us in the studios.

582
00:29:15.560 --> 00:29:18.060
And we appreciate you,
the viewer, watching out there.

00:29:18.060 --> 00:29:20.770
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

>> And I'm Don Pezet.

00:29:21.462 --> 00:29:22.584
>> And we'll see you next time.
