I override that all the time, true story.

456
00:22:06.220 --> 00:22:07.306
All right, anyhow, so.

457
00:22:07.306 --> 00:22:09.094
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

458
00:22:09.094 --> 00:22:10.959
>> So we should be up and going.

459
00:22:10.959 --> 00:22:12.778
I can test the caching, though.

460
00:22:12.778 --> 00:22:16.270
If I do a name lookup against the server,
it's got no zones.

461
00:22:16.270 --> 00:22:20.370
So it's got to rely on other
servers to get the answer.

462
00:22:20.370 --> 00:22:23.070
So if I fire up MS lookup and

463
00:22:23.070 --> 00:22:28.000
I switch my server to me, all right,
so I'm now connected to myself.

464
00:22:28.000 --> 00:22:31.416
And I do I lookup for
something like www.google.com, all right.

465
00:22:31.416 --> 00:22:33.840
It doesn't have a zone for
Google, does it?

466
00:22:33.840 --> 00:22:35.380
Cuz we haven't made any zones.

467
00:22:35.380 --> 00:22:38.970
But there it goes, it finds an address for
Google, all right?

468
00:22:38.970 --> 00:22:43.260
Now, it reached out to the root hand
server and said who controls com?

469
00:22:43.260 --> 00:22:47.040
It reached out to the com TLD servers and
said who controls Google?

470
00:22:47.040 --> 00:22:51.080
It reached out to Google's servers and
said, hey, I'm looking for www, and

471
00:22:51.080 --> 00:22:55.930
Google got a authoritative response back
to us saying, here's the IP address.

472
00:22:55.930 --> 00:22:59.630
Now when all that happened,
Unbound cached it.

473
00:22:59.630 --> 00:23:02.480
And so now whoever else comes and

474
00:23:02.480 --> 00:23:07.870
does a query, as long as that cache value
is still active, cuz the cache expires,

475
00:23:07.870 --> 00:23:11.060
then they'll look up against this cache,
they'll get a faster response.

476
00:23:11.060 --> 00:23:14.130
Bind does that as well,
Unbound just does it faster.

477
00:23:14.130 --> 00:23:18.710
So when it comes to a pure caching server,
Unbound is better than Bind.

478
00:23:18.710 --> 00:23:22.415
But when it comes to hosting records and
zones, Bind has a lot more power under

479
00:23:22.415 --> 00:23:25.330
the hood, and that's the one
you're gonna want to go with.

480
00:23:25.330 --> 00:23:28.986
So while Unbound is pitched
as a replacement to Bind,

481
00:23:28.986 --> 00:23:33.700
they actually do both have
a real-world use example right now.

482
00:23:33.700 --> 00:23:36.560
And a lot of people use both
of them in conjunction.

483
00:23:36.560 --> 00:23:40.720
So you've got Unbound handling your
cache and Bind handling your records.

484
00:23:40.720 --> 00:23:43.580
Personally, I hate splitting
stuff between services.

485
00:23:43.580 --> 00:23:46.900
So I usually run Bind over Unbound
if I have to make that decision.

486
00:23:46.900 --> 00:23:50.370
But this one's up, it's running,
it's doing it's job.

487
00:23:50.370 --> 00:23:52.500
And we're pretty much in business.

488
00:23:52.500 --> 00:23:55.997
I'm trying to think if there's anything
else that I wanna mess with on this one.

489
00:23:55.997 --> 00:24:00.014
That unbound-control command
that I used a moment ago,

490
00:24:00.014 --> 00:24:05.377
it has a lot of different stuff that it
can do if you pull up the man file for it.

491
00:24:05.377 --> 00:24:08.940
And so you'll can see where you can feed
all sort of different things into it.

492
00:24:08.940 --> 00:24:12.400
You can start, stop the server,
you can pull up the logs, the statistics.

493
00:24:12.400 --> 00:24:15.806
The stats are kind of nice,
my stats are disabled in the config file,

494
00:24:15.806 --> 00:24:18.567
but that's where you can see
how your cache is working,

495
00:24:18.567 --> 00:24:21.040
are you getting a lot of cache hits or
not.

496
00:24:21.040 --> 00:24:23.750
You can query local zones if you got them.

497
00:24:23.750 --> 00:24:26.090
That command is pretty powerful.

498
00:24:26.090 --> 00:24:29.240
Usually, what we're going for
are things like dump_cache.

499
00:24:29.240 --> 00:24:29.847
And my highlight is completely
ineffective on pink text.

500
00:24:29.847 --> 00:24:32.402
But if you want to dump the cache or

501
00:24:32.402 --> 00:24:38.076
flush out a particular name out of
the cache, you've got those options.

502
00:24:38.076 --> 00:24:40.569
So that utility,
if you're running unbound,

503
00:24:40.569 --> 00:24:43.950
you're going to become really
good friends with this utility.

504
00:24:43.950 --> 00:24:46.920
It's how you'll interact
with that to do things and

505
00:24:46.920 --> 00:24:52.030
avoid having to restart the server or
whatever.

506
00:24:52.030 --> 00:24:57.550
And if we look in /var/unbound,
wait, where am I.

507
00:24:59.420 --> 00:25:01.313
Or /var/log, there we go.

508
00:25:01.313 --> 00:25:05.460
/var/log/, well, actually,
where did I stick that log?

509
00:25:05.460 --> 00:25:07.036
Did I go to the wrong folder?

510
00:25:07.036 --> 00:25:12.783
/var/log I've got a little
bit of a problem.

511
00:25:12.783 --> 00:25:17.890
So when I configured the logging,
I pointed to a folder /var/log/unbound.

512
00:25:17.890 --> 00:25:18.492
It doesn't exist.

513
00:25:18.492 --> 00:25:20.207
That's going to be a slight issue for me,

514
00:25:20.207 --> 00:25:23.251
because that means unbound can't
write to a folder that doesn't exist.

515
00:25:23.251 --> 00:25:25.480
>> It won't generate its own file?

516
00:25:25.480 --> 00:25:27.420
>> It'll generate the file, but
it won't generate a folder.

517
00:25:27.420 --> 00:25:28.205
>> Okay.
>> In this case,

518
00:25:28.205 --> 00:25:31.094
I don't have the folder in place,
so I need to make that folder.

519
00:25:31.094 --> 00:25:32.000
So I'm going to make
the folder that I pointed to.

520
00:25:32.000 --> 00:25:34.272
I probably should have just
pointed it to /var/log instead.

521
00:25:34.272 --> 00:25:36.450
But I'm going to make that folder.

522
00:25:36.450 --> 00:25:39.100
Now, the problem I'm gonna have
when I make that folder is,

523
00:25:39.100 --> 00:25:42.470
if you look at it,
the permissions on it, root and root.

524
00:25:42.470 --> 00:25:45.170
Which the majority of everything
here has root and root.

525
00:25:45.170 --> 00:25:47.173
So that's okay for most things.

526
00:25:47.173 --> 00:25:53.100
But I'm gonna double check, /etc/unbound.

527
00:25:53.100 --> 00:25:57.150
Actually, let me just pull
up the main directory here.

528
00:25:57.150 --> 00:25:58.830
And I'm going to double-check and

529
00:25:58.830 --> 00:26:01.120
make sure, there we go,
that's root and root also, okay.

530
00:26:01.120 --> 00:26:03.873
I'm trying to make sure that the Unbound
process would to be able to write to

531
00:26:03.873 --> 00:26:04.406
that folder.

532
00:26:04.406 --> 00:26:07.424
And now that it has
permissions to that folder,

533
00:26:07.424 --> 00:26:11.110
as it generates logs,
they'll end up here, okay.

534
00:26:11.110 --> 00:26:15.068
So there's not really much going on in
the system right now for me to see that.

535
00:26:15.068 --> 00:26:19.756
But if I restart unbound, we can do that.

536
00:26:19.756 --> 00:26:24.876
And then if any errors occur, if other
events like that occur in the system,

537
00:26:24.876 --> 00:26:28.010
it'll start to log those
entries right here.

538
00:26:28.010 --> 00:26:29.470
So they'll show up eventually.

539
00:26:29.470 --> 00:26:30.638
I turned off my statistics and

540
00:26:30.638 --> 00:26:33.498
a few other things, so there's not
gonna be a lot that comes out anyway.

541
00:26:33.498 --> 00:26:35.190
But make sure you create that folder.

542
00:26:35.190 --> 00:26:36.595
It will not create the folder for you.

543
00:26:36.595 --> 00:26:39.270
It'll create the files inside of it,
but not the folder.

544
00:26:39.270 --> 00:26:40.170
>> All right.

545
00:26:40.170 --> 00:26:44.350
So now we were able to go ahead and
take a look at how to install Unbound.

546
00:26:44.350 --> 00:26:47.860
And I'm only assuming in the next
episode you're gonna go ahead and

547
00:26:47.860 --> 00:26:50.410
show us how to utilize it and
configure those zones.

548
00:26:50.410 --> 00:26:54.188
So stay tuned, guys, we have a lot more
headed your way, don't go anywhere.

549
00:26:54.188 --> 00:26:58.510
I'm gonna go ahead and sign off for
this episode as your host, Cherokee Boose.

550
00:26:58.510 --> 00:26:59.480
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

551
00:26:59.480 --> 00:27:00.820
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

552
00:27:05.912 --> 00:27:08.572
[MUSIC]

553
00:27:08.572 --> 00:27:10.485
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: After installing Unbound you will learn how to create override lookup values to customize your environment. You will see how Unbound functions faster, yet is limited in some ways such as not properly referencing a CNAME record.
episodes.title: Configuring Zones and Records
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.230 --> 00:00:01.333
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.333 --> 00:00:08.289
I'm your host, Don [CROSSTALK]
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.289 --> 00:00:11.950
>> You're watching ITProTv.

4
00:00:11.950 --> 00:00:14.890
>> Welcome to another
DNS Tech Skills show.

5
00:00:14.890 --> 00:00:17.200
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.200 --> 00:00:21.130
In this episode, we're gonna go ahead and
take a look at how to configure and

7
00:00:21.130 --> 00:00:22.190
create zones.

8
00:00:22.190 --> 00:00:24.968
In the last episode,
we installed Unbound, so

9
00:00:24.968 --> 00:00:27.683
I'm really excited to
see how we get started.

10
00:00:27.683 --> 00:00:28.321
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

11
00:00:28.321 --> 00:00:31.460
we have Don Pezet in studio with us
today to go ahead and help us with that.

12
00:00:31.460 --> 00:00:32.580
Thank you for being here today, Don.

13
00:00:32.580 --> 00:00:33.490
>> Thanks for having me back.

14
00:00:33.490 --> 00:00:35.940
And ready to continue on with
the Unbound configuration.

15
00:00:35.940 --> 00:00:38.070
If you watched the first episode,
we got it installed.

16
00:00:38.070 --> 00:00:41.030
But it's really just a glorified
caching server, right now.

17
00:00:41.030 --> 00:00:44.273
Which, I guess, is ultimately
the point of Unbound, so technically,

18
00:00:44.273 --> 00:00:45.600
we're kind of done.

19
00:00:45.600 --> 00:00:49.650
But many of you will have internal
records that you need to create.

20
00:00:49.650 --> 00:00:51.200
A records, PTR records,

21
00:00:51.200 --> 00:00:54.460
the forward and reverse lookup zones
that we did in other DNS servers.

22
00:00:54.460 --> 00:00:56.550
We can certainly do those in Unbound,
also.

23
00:00:56.550 --> 00:00:59.988
Now if you're using Unbound
as a caching server,

24
00:00:59.988 --> 00:01:02.720
then you wouldn't normally
create zones on it.

25
00:01:02.720 --> 00:01:05.020
But you might still wanna throw
some records when you want

26
00:01:05.020 --> 00:01:06.200
to override something.

27
00:01:06.200 --> 00:01:10.320
And a great example of that would be, I
might have an internal caching server, and

28
00:01:10.320 --> 00:01:11.990
I've got a public website.

29
00:01:11.990 --> 00:01:13.820
And if somebody out there in the Internet,

30
00:01:13.820 --> 00:01:17.790
I want them to go to the public
website via the public IP address.

31
00:01:17.790 --> 00:01:20.170
But if they're on the internal network,

32
00:01:20.170 --> 00:01:23.630
wouldn't it be nice if they got
the internal IP address, instead?

33
00:01:23.630 --> 00:01:25.980
That way they can go right to
the internal network adapter.

34
00:01:25.980 --> 00:01:27.754
Instead of having to go through
the firewall and bounce around.

35
00:01:27.754 --> 00:01:30.330
Yeah, it can shorten that path a lot.

36
00:01:30.330 --> 00:01:32.590
And make the experience even faster for
our users.

37
00:01:32.590 --> 00:01:35.190
Which is what a caching
service is designed to do.

38
00:01:35.190 --> 00:01:36.660
So in Unbound,

39
00:01:36.660 --> 00:01:42.940
we can override any lookup that we want
right inside of the Unbound configuration.

40
00:01:42.940 --> 00:01:47.640
And by doing that, by overriding those
configs, we can return any kinda response.

41
00:01:47.640 --> 00:01:52.450
It's great for development and testing,
lab environments, and for creating forward

42
00:01:52.450 --> 00:01:55.760
and reverse lookup zones, if you wanna
host them directly from Unbound.

43
00:01:55.760 --> 00:01:57.650
>> Could we also rely on this
as a form of redundancy?

44
00:01:58.740 --> 00:02:03.575
>> You sort of could except, people
would be looking to this Unbound server.

45
00:02:03.575 --> 00:02:04.960
They would get the override value.

46
00:02:04.960 --> 00:02:07.030
If the override value wasn't working,

47
00:02:07.030 --> 00:02:09.050
that would usually mean
the Unbound server isn't working.

48
00:02:09.050 --> 00:02:10.590
So you have a total failure.

49
00:02:10.590 --> 00:02:13.280
You could get redundancy in the way
of like a syntax mistake, I guess.

50
00:02:13.280 --> 00:02:16.310
But not necessarily from
a server standpoint, so.

51
00:02:16.310 --> 00:02:20.880
But you could introduce additional IPs
that maybe the public doesn't see.

52
00:02:20.880 --> 00:02:22.807
And so
now you do get redundancy out of it.

53
00:02:22.807 --> 00:02:23.823
Sky's the limit, so

54
00:02:23.823 --> 00:02:27.290
whatever you could think of and
jam into that config file, it'll work.

55
00:02:27.290 --> 00:02:29.377
Unbound has a lot of flexibility to it,

56
00:02:29.377 --> 00:02:32.613
even though it doesn't support
some of the stuff that we do.

57
00:02:32.613 --> 00:02:34.882
And just to give you an example
something that's not supported.

58
00:02:34.882 --> 00:02:40.390
Things like CNAMEs,
Unbound doesn't do CNAMEs.

59
00:02:40.390 --> 00:02:45.000
So when I request a CNAME, normally
what happens is the DNS server finds it,

60
00:02:45.000 --> 00:02:47.450
sees it as a CNAME, and
returns it back to me.

61
00:02:47.450 --> 00:02:49.449
But then it looks up the destination.

62
00:02:49.449 --> 00:02:52.651
And it does what's called expanding
the CNAME to find out what the actual

63
00:02:52.651 --> 00:02:53.290
IP should be.

64
00:02:53.290 --> 00:02:55.050
And it gives me the IP, also.

65
00:02:55.050 --> 00:02:56.420
Unbound won't do that.

66
00:02:56.420 --> 00:02:58.575
Unbound will say, hey,
it's a CNAME, here you go.

67
00:02:58.575 --> 00:03:00.260
And it'll give you the CNAME.

68
00:03:00.260 --> 00:03:04.368
So the client receives a CNAME,
and it's like, okay, it's a CNAME.

69
00:03:04.368 --> 00:03:07.420
Where's the IP, I need the IP.

70
00:03:07.420 --> 00:03:09.420
Unbound says, well,
you have to ask for it.

71
00:03:09.420 --> 00:03:12.370
And so the client has to know to
send a second lookup to say, okay.

72
00:03:12.370 --> 00:03:14.760
You just gave me the CNAME,
the actual host name.

73
00:03:14.760 --> 00:03:16.675
Now I need to look that one up and
perform it.

74
00:03:16.675 --> 00:03:18.450
Unbound won't do that for us.

75
00:03:18.450 --> 00:03:21.000
And unfortunately,
most clients won't do it either.

76
00:03:21.000 --> 00:03:24.620
WIndows, Mac OS,
pretty much every Linux distribution,

77
00:03:24.620 --> 00:03:26.860
they don't do that follow- up question.

78
00:03:26.860 --> 00:03:28.736
So from that perspective, CNAMEs,

79
00:03:28.736 --> 00:03:31.750
while supported in Unbound,
are effectively broken.

80
00:03:31.750 --> 00:03:32.860
But it's not Unbound's fault.

81
00:03:32.860 --> 00:03:36.450
It's the client's fault for not bothering
to ask, so it's a weird little catch.

82
00:03:36.450 --> 00:03:37.741
We don't have to worry about that in BIND.

83
00:03:37.741 --> 00:03:39.184
We don't have to worry
about that in PowerDNS.

84
00:03:39.184 --> 00:03:41.411
We don't have to worry about that
in Microsoft's DNS server, but

85
00:03:41.411 --> 00:03:42.100
in Unbound, we do.

86
00:03:42.100 --> 00:03:43.790
So know that there are limitations.

87
00:03:43.790 --> 00:03:46.080
>> Yeah, and just knowing those
limitations can really help you make

88
00:03:46.080 --> 00:03:47.870
the best decision for your environment.

89
00:03:47.870 --> 00:03:49.190
>> Right, absolutely.

90
00:03:49.190 --> 00:03:52.580
>> So Don, is this utility similar to BIND
in the sense that we would need to create

91
00:03:52.580 --> 00:03:54.360
separate zone files?

92
00:03:54.360 --> 00:03:55.810
>> Well, you can.

93
00:03:55.810 --> 00:03:58.040
You can create separate zone files,
if you want.

94
00:03:58.040 --> 00:04:01.800
But the neat thing about Unbound is it'll
actually read its entire config right out

95
00:04:01.800 --> 00:04:03.797
of the single central configuration file.

96
00:04:03.797 --> 00:04:04.810
And we just put everything there.

97
00:04:04.810 --> 00:04:07.320
So if you're just doing
a handful of little overrides,

98
00:04:07.320 --> 00:04:09.400
you can just go right into
the config file and be done with it.

99
00:04:09.400 --> 00:04:12.160
But if you're trying to do whole zones,
yeah, you'll want to do separate files.

100
00:04:12.160 --> 00:04:14.085
So let's start with just
a simple override, right?

101
00:04:14.085 --> 00:04:18.245
I'm gonna jump into,
let me edit that file,

102
00:04:18.245 --> 00:04:22.412
/etc/unbound/unbound.conf, right?

103
00:04:22.412 --> 00:04:23.680
And when you browse through there,

104
00:04:23.680 --> 00:04:26.470
we already saw several of these
options in the installing episode.

105
00:04:26.470 --> 00:04:30.210
I'm just gonna do a quick search for
local-zone.

106
00:04:30.210 --> 00:04:34.760
There's two commands that were gonna
be using, local-zone and local-data.

107
00:04:34.760 --> 00:04:39.200
And I'm looking for a particular section
where it gives some little examples.

108
00:04:39.200 --> 00:04:39.955
There we go.

109
00:04:39.955 --> 00:04:44.320
So search through the file and find the
spot where it says local-zone, local-data.

110
00:04:44.320 --> 00:04:46.590
Remember that this config
file is made up in sections.

111
00:04:46.590 --> 00:04:48.410
So you can't just throw
the commands in wherever you want.

112
00:04:48.410 --> 00:04:50.702
You do need to try and
get them in the right area, so

113
00:04:50.702 --> 00:04:52.131
that's why I search for that.

114
00:04:52.131 --> 00:04:55.400
But I'm gonna come in and
introduce just a few little breaks.

115
00:04:55.400 --> 00:04:59.530
And I'm gonna punch in a local-zone,

116
00:04:59.530 --> 00:05:03.416
and I'm gonna put lab.itpro.tv.

117
00:05:03.416 --> 00:05:06.300
And I'll chuck that one in there so
I've got a nice little local-zone.

118
00:05:06.300 --> 00:05:08.878
And I need to tell it that I'm
turning this into a static zone.

119
00:05:08.878 --> 00:05:13.330
In other words, I can override
entries manually right from here.

120
00:05:13.330 --> 00:05:14.850
There's a few other types of zones.

121
00:05:14.850 --> 00:05:18.920
Like dynamic, where it can auto update,
and forward, and all that mess.

122
00:05:18.920 --> 00:05:19.750
I'm just gonna do static.

123
00:05:19.750 --> 00:05:22.730
I'm gonna put it in,
right here, what I need.

124
00:05:22.730 --> 00:05:26.600
And after that,
I can start to put my entries.

125
00:05:26.600 --> 00:05:31.346
I can say, local-data,
and then I can put what is

126
00:05:31.346 --> 00:05:35.760
effectively an A record,
like we did in BIND.

127
00:05:35.760 --> 00:05:43.360
I can come in and I can say,
www.lab.itpro.tv is an Internet record.

00:17:34.670 --> 00:17:38.090
If I do a search for MX records.

00:17:38.090 --> 00:17:40.600

354

357
00:17:47.460 --> 00:17:50.030

they are served up very fast.

358
00:17:50.030 --> 00:17:53.050
Unbound can scale to handle
a huge amount of throughput,

359
00:17:53.050 --> 00:17:55.320
and I get that information back.

360
00:17:55.320 --> 00:17:56.310
On the configuration side,

361
00:17:56.310 --> 00:17:59.010
it's almost easier in a way
that how you write those files.

362
00:17:59.010 --> 00:18:01.980
It's a little bit more
forgiving in the syntax.

363
00:18:01.980 --> 00:18:05.580
But, for the most part,
once it's done it's now up and going.

364
00:18:05.580 --> 00:18:07.820
Just remember, these aren't real zones.

365
00:18:07.820 --> 00:18:09.140
They're overrides.

366
00:18:09.140 --> 00:18:10.190
We're treating them as zones.

367
00:18:10.190 --> 00:18:11.410
They work like zones.

368
00:18:11.410 --> 00:18:14.780
But we're really just overriding
some other recursive look up to

369
00:18:14.780 --> 00:18:16.110
provide the values we want.

370
00:18:16.110 --> 00:18:17.870
And we can change them to
whatever the heck we want.

371
00:18:17.870 --> 00:18:21.290

microsoft.com.

372
00:18:21.290 --> 00:18:25.040
And anybody who looks to my server

373
00:18:25.040 --> 00:18:29.130

prevent certain end users from
going to unauthorized sites maybe.

00:18:33.370 --> 00:18:35.332
Something like that.
>> Yeah, if you do a Google search for

A lot of people use on bound that way.

389

If you do a Google search, you'll find

390

malware websites.

16
00:00:41.020 --> 00:00:46.350
One of the cool things about Unbound is
it's not the greatest DNS zone server,

17
00:00:46.350 --> 00:00:47.280
which I know is funny for

18
00:00:47.280 --> 00:00:50.160
a DNS server it seems like what
a primary purpose would be.

23

So we can use that for all sorts of ways

25
00:01:11.870 --> 00:01:14.381

27

>> All right, yeah, so

36
00:01:43.210 --> 00:01:45.410
The problem is,
if you have a thousand computers,

37

38
00:01:49.580 --> 00:01:53.020

39

40
00:01:56.040 --> 00:01:57.570
just skipping right past it.

00:01:57.570 --> 00:01:59.500
And so that's not a reliable way to do it.

00:01:59.500 --> 00:02:01.560
It used to be great because
it was super fast and

00:02:01.560 --> 00:02:05.250
you had complete control over it but

44
00:02:05.250 --> 00:02:08.820
And the other challenge is, you've got
users that have iPhones and Android phones

45
00:02:08.820 --> 00:02:12.135

00:02:12.135 --> 00:02:14.685

00:02:14.685 --> 00:02:17.000
You don't wanna jailbreak
your corporate phones!

48
00:02:17.000 --> 00:02:18.250
It's not an option.

49
00:02:18.250 --> 00:02:21.800
So how can we protect
them from malicious hosts

if we don't have that access available?

51
00:02:23.410 --> 00:02:25.850
And the answer is to use DNS.

52
00:02:25.850 --> 00:02:28.823
Now we can do it through Bind, but with
Bind it would be really challenging cuz

53
00:02:28.823 --> 00:02:31.688
you'd have to maintain a zone file for
every single one of these domains.

54
00:02:31.688 --> 00:02:35.760
And it's just a nightmare, and
Bind collapses under it pretty fast.

55
00:02:35.760 --> 00:02:37.373
So it's really not even possible there.

56
00:02:37.373 --> 00:02:41.256
But on Unbound,
on Unbound I can do DNS name spoofing, and

57
00:02:41.256 --> 00:02:46.092
I can name spoof every single malware
advertising host or whatever, and

58
00:02:46.092 --> 00:02:48.330
I could point it wherever I want.

59
00:02:48.330 --> 00:02:51.370
I could point it at 12700 if I want.

60
00:02:51.370 --> 00:02:57.540
And now when somebody has an iPhone,
Android, Mac, Windows, Linux, whatever.

61
00:02:57.540 --> 00:03:01.000
They use DACP to get an address,
they get my DNS server, and

62
00:03:01.000 --> 00:03:03.000
it's all being filtered right there.

63
00:03:03.000 --> 00:03:06.080
Okay what are the challenges
of making this happen?

64
00:03:06.080 --> 00:03:09.160
Challenge number one, I need an unbound
server which we already have from

65
00:03:09.160 --> 00:03:11.860
the last episode, so
that's challenge one solved.

66
00:03:11.860 --> 00:03:18.460
Challenge number two, I need a way to
basically poison these DNS names, right.

67
00:03:18.460 --> 00:03:20.796
Well we can do that through
any simple mechanism.

68
00:03:20.796 --> 00:03:24.805
If you do dns spoofing we can take
a name and we can map it to an ip.

69
00:03:24.805 --> 00:03:27.136
We can override what's
actually out there in dns, and

70
00:03:27.136 --> 00:03:29.578
we can do that right through
local lookups and unbounds.

71
00:03:29.578 --> 00:03:32.975
So challenge number two,
that one's already solved in unbound.

72
00:03:32.975 --> 00:03:35.436
Challenge number three, I need a list.

73
00:03:35.436 --> 00:03:37.575
I need a list of all this junk.

74
00:03:37.575 --> 00:03:40.120
And this is the first one that

00:03:40.120 --> 00:03:44.360
Because I don't have a list, I don't know

00:03:45.980 --> 00:03:50.738
But there's a couple of people out
there in the Internet, in the tubes,

78
00:03:50.738 --> 00:03:53.783
that take the time to
accumulate these lists.

79
00:03:53.783 --> 00:03:57.854
Lists of bad hosts, hosts that serve up
advertisements, or malware, spyware, and

80
00:03:57.854 --> 00:04:00.460
they put it all out there and
they publish it.

81
00:04:00.460 --> 00:04:03.880
One of the most well known,
let me bring this up here.

82
00:04:03.880 --> 00:04:07.697
One of the most well known is,

00:04:07.697 --> 00:04:12.747
the website is somonewhocares.org.

00:04:12.747 --> 00:04:14.110
I'm trying to remember the guy's name.

85
00:04:14.110 --> 00:04:15.576
Let's just go there.

86
00:04:15.576 --> 00:04:19.243
Someonewhocares.org.

00:04:19.243 --> 00:04:21.753
Apparently the challenge is spelling it.

88
00:04:21.753 --> 00:04:24.686
And if I go to this website,
someonewhocares.org.

00:04:24.686 --> 00:04:26.598
Dan Pollock that's his name, sorry guys,

00:04:26.598 --> 00:04:29.345
sorry Dan if you're watching I

00:04:29.345 --> 00:04:33.368
So Dan Pollock, this guy,
[INAUDIBLE] Internet.

00:04:33.368 --> 00:04:38.070
Over the last 10 or 15 years he's been

00:04:38.070 --> 00:04:42.086
Of advertising and malware hosts, and
he gets some missions from other people.

94
00:04:42.086 --> 00:04:47.293

day clicking on every site he can find,

00:04:47.293 --> 00:04:51.255
but he has assembled it into a nice
big list which you can go and

00:04:51.255 --> 00:04:53.917

97
00:04:53.917 --> 00:04:56.937
Now this is the HTML view of it,
and when you look at it,

98
00:04:56.937 --> 00:04:59.690
how to make the Internet not suck as much.

99
00:04:59.690 --> 00:05:04.130
So what he's done is
he's put together a list.

100
00:05:04.130 --> 00:05:05.914
And it's in the host file format.

101
00:05:05.914 --> 00:05:08.950
And in the host file format,
you've got an IP mapped to a name.

102
00:05:08.950 --> 00:05:13.246
And so what you're gonna see are a lot of,
I'll just apologize now,

103
00:05:13.246 --> 00:05:15.481
there's a lot of bad sites in here.

104
00:05:15.481 --> 00:05:21.699
But you'll see a lot of sites in here and
it will map 127.0.0.1,

105
00:05:21.699 --> 00:05:27.028
the loop back into whatever
the site is that's being blocked.

106
00:05:27.028 --> 00:05:31.844
And so if you can think of, just about
any ad service, you'll find that ad

107
00:05:31.844 --> 00:05:36.586
service in here, including really
well known ones like Google ads, and

108
00:05:36.586 --> 00:05:38.850
the Google Adsense network.

109
00:05:38.850 --> 00:05:40.640
Facebook, Twitter, those guys.

110
00:05:40.640 --> 00:05:43.017
They've all got ad servers, and
they'll all be entered in here.

111
00:05:43.017 --> 00:05:46.103
I did try and find one block that
didn't have bad stuff in it.

112
00:05:46.103 --> 00:05:48.630
[LAUGH] It get kind of
freeze on the camera.

113
00:05:48.630 --> 00:05:52.280
But each one of these is a,
this one is statistics, right?

114
00:05:52.280 --> 00:05:54.968
So it's probably some kind of
telemetry gathering service

115
00:05:54.968 --> 00:05:57.923
that is recording your IP address,
and what site you're on, and

116
00:05:57.923 --> 00:06:01.277
how long you spend on it, and all this
stuff that we might not wanna share.

117
00:06:01.277 --> 00:06:05.166
And by mapping it back to you,
to 127.0.0.1,

118
00:06:05.166 --> 00:06:08.738
it makes your computer

119
00:06:08.738 --> 00:06:12.214
And then when It try's to reach out the ad

120
00:06:12.214 --> 00:06:14.887
when it reaches out to itself,
we're not a web server and so

121
00:06:14.887 --> 00:06:16.625
it just fail, it immediately fails.

122
00:06:16.625 --> 00:06:19.521
That's important because we don't
wanna slow down the end user,

123
00:06:19.521 --> 00:06:22.725
if you redirect it to a real web site

00:06:22.725 --> 00:06:26.220

125
00:06:26.220 --> 00:06:30.930

00:06:52.140 --> 00:06:58.920

our challenge here is going

Let me see if I can find that in here.

We overroad some of those things by

In Unbound, you can override

that's a drop in the bucket.

373
00:20:30.590 --> 00:20:34.960
Unbound is designed to do a hierarchical

374
00:20:34.960 --> 00:20:39.900
RAM and so the way that it works
actually doesn't really get affected

375

by the amount of records of the past

Roots over inside of itself and
saying okay you're looking for a,

00:20:53.470 --> 00:20:57.130

it's doing those kind of look ups already

00:20:57.130 --> 00:20:59.940
anyway, to see if it's got

00:20:59.940 --> 00:21:02.710

382
00:21:02.710 --> 00:21:06.230

to the forwarding server, after that.

383
00:21:06.230 --> 00:21:09.960
So, you'll find that it typically
doesn't effect performance much at all,

384
00:21:09.960 --> 00:21:12.560
aside from the little RAM loss,

When I rendered the page it rendered

If I were to do a netstat-an or something

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don show the viewers how to take advantage of the benefits of bringing Unbound into combination with BIND. They demonstrate how to set up Unbound to receive and forward DNS queries to a BIND server as well as combine both Unbound and BIND on a single server.
episodes.title: Using Unbound with BIND
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.170

2

3

4

[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.621 --> 00:00:10.529
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:10.529 --> 00:00:14.472
>> Welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.472 --> 00:00:16.705
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

8
00:00:16.705 --> 00:00:20.615
And in today's episode we are moving
through our series within DNS.

9
00:00:20.615 --> 00:00:22.115
And joining us back in the studio's for

10
00:00:22.115 --> 00:00:24.185
this endeavor is none other than Mr.
Don Pezet.

11
00:00:24.185 --> 00:00:25.205
Don, how are you doing, sir?

12
00:00:25.205 --> 00:00:26.105
>> I'm doing swell, Wes.

13
00:00:26.105 --> 00:00:27.315
Thanks for having me back on the show,

14
00:00:27.315 --> 00:00:31.485
and we're ready to dive back into the
world of, well, just DNS in general today.

15
00:00:31.485 --> 00:00:34.325
Cuz we're not gonna just hold ourselves to
unbound, we're gonna take a look at a few

16
00:00:34.325 --> 00:00:37.300
different pieces of this puzzle and
have some real fun.

17
00:00:37.300 --> 00:00:39.954
Now, if you've been watching
all of our episodes in order,

18
00:00:39.954 --> 00:00:43.646
you've heard me say various things about
bind, and various things about unbound,

19
00:00:43.646 --> 00:00:46.740
the Microsoft DNS, and
all the other ones that are out there.

20
00:00:46.740 --> 00:00:51.020
And each one seems to be strong in
certain areas and weak in other areas.

21
00:00:51.020 --> 00:00:54.730
And so what I wanna talk about
in this episode is taking

22
00:00:54.730 --> 00:00:59.700
more than one DNS product and
combining them, wonder twin powers unite,

23
00:00:59.700 --> 00:01:03.610
and creating the ultimate
DNS infrastructure, right?

24
00:01:03.610 --> 00:01:09.720
The most common scenario of this uses
unbound in conjunction with bind.

25
00:01:09.720 --> 00:01:12.830
Now, I talked about bind back
in the bind episodes, and

26
00:01:12.830 --> 00:01:15.010
how it did great as
an authoritative name server.

27
00:01:15.010 --> 00:01:16.730
It can host as many zones as you wanted.

28
00:01:16.730 --> 00:01:18.810
You can put all these different
zone records in there.

29
00:01:18.810 --> 00:01:19.630
It did a great job.

30
00:01:19.630 --> 00:01:24.015
Bind was the reference DNS server
that everybody designs on.

31
00:01:24.015 --> 00:01:24.750
It does a great job.

32
00:01:25.940 --> 00:01:30.860
But I also said that it's ancient,
and it's a little on the slow side,

33
00:01:30.860 --> 00:01:32.550
it doesn't cache very well.

34
00:01:32.550 --> 00:01:35.858
And if the caching database grows too big,
it crashes, right?

35
00:01:35.858 --> 00:01:37.120
That's what bind does.

36
00:01:37.120 --> 00:01:38.325
So, almost like it does it on purpose.

37
00:01:38.325 --> 00:01:41.080
Then we talked about unbound.

38
00:01:41.080 --> 00:01:47.090
And I said how unbound did
great at verifying domains and

39
00:01:47.090 --> 00:01:49.230
doing look ups, and cacheing.

40
00:01:49.230 --> 00:01:51.610
That it could have caches
that were massive in size.

41
00:01:51.610 --> 00:01:56.630
And it could look up at them very fast,
and very quick and do a great job of it.

42
00:01:56.630 --> 00:01:58.420
It just does an amazing job.

43
00:01:59.420 --> 00:02:04.410
But on the zone side of things,
Unbound is pretty weak.

44
00:02:04.410 --> 00:02:07.120
Simple records like a C
name break unbound.

45
00:02:07.120 --> 00:02:09.060
Unbound doesn't know hey,
when somebody asks for

46
00:02:09.060 --> 00:02:10.570
a C name don't just give them the name.

47
00:02:10.570 --> 00:02:13.790
Go and resolve the actual
IP name that it points to.

48
00:02:13.790 --> 00:02:15.000
Unbound doesn't do that.

49
00:02:15.000 --> 00:02:17.070
So unbound is worthless for C names.

50
00:02:17.070 --> 00:02:20.920
So I can sort of put zones into unbound,
but it just doesn't do a great job.

51
00:02:21.930 --> 00:02:24.370
Great at cacheing, bad at zones.

52
00:02:24.370 --> 00:02:27.770
Bind, great at zones, bad at cacheing.

53
00:02:27.770 --> 00:02:31.510
Wouldn't it be nice if we could put the
chocolate and the peanut butter together

54
00:02:31.510 --> 00:02:36.840
and get unbound handling my cache and
bind handling my DNS?

55
00:02:36.840 --> 00:02:38.840
Now I'd have the best of both worlds.

56
00:02:38.840 --> 00:02:40.730
And you can absolutely do that.

57
00:02:40.730 --> 00:02:44.170
You can do it, it's actually not even that
hard to do it to get it put in place.

58
00:02:44.170 --> 00:02:47.760
And that's the most common deployment
scenario when somebody's out there running

59
00:02:47.760 --> 00:02:51.200
Unbound, is that they'll deploy one or

60
00:02:51.200 --> 00:02:56.500
more unbound servers, and then maybe
just one bind or two bind servers.

61
00:02:56.500 --> 00:02:58.915
Two bind systems for redundancy.

62
00:02:58.915 --> 00:03:01.873
They'll store their zones
on the bind servers and

63
00:03:01.873 --> 00:03:05.900
all their clients will be configured
to look at the Unbound severs.

64
00:03:06.980 --> 00:03:09.740
Now by doing that,
the clients go to unbound.

65
00:03:09.740 --> 00:03:12.810
Unbound looks up against the Internet and
does all the cacheing.

66
00:03:12.810 --> 00:03:16.740
But we need to teach unbound hey,
when you're asking about a zone,

67
00:03:16.740 --> 00:03:20.650
don't look in your own data, look over
here, look at this other server over on

68
00:03:20.650 --> 00:03:23.790
the other side and reach out to them and
get the information from there.

69
00:03:23.790 --> 00:03:28.960
And we can do that, we can use forwarders
and stub zones inside of unbound

70
00:03:28.960 --> 00:03:32.440
to point to other DNS servers out there,
and it works really, really well.

71
00:03:32.440 --> 00:03:34.580
Now when I thought about this
episode originally, I thought hey,

72
00:03:34.580 --> 00:03:38.010
why don't I go ahead and
bring up a bind server and do all that.

73
00:03:38.010 --> 00:03:41.740
But we've kind of all ready done that in
other shows, so I'm just gonna recycle.

74
00:03:41.740 --> 00:03:43.570
I'm being very environmental today.

75
00:03:43.570 --> 00:03:46.930
And I'm gonna recycle a BIND server
that I've all ready got laying around.

76
00:03:46.930 --> 00:03:48.310
So here's DNS 1.

77
00:03:48.310 --> 00:03:51.730
If you go back and watch the installing
BIND episode and the configuring and

78
00:03:51.730 --> 00:03:55.790
creating zones episode for BIND,
this is the server that I set up in there.

79
00:03:55.790 --> 00:04:00.730
And when I set it up I configured it
as a DNS server and I gave it one zone.

80
00:04:01.980 --> 00:04:06.750
And that zone is lab.itpro.tv.dns.

81
00:04:06.750 --> 00:04:09.020
So that's the zone that it's carrying, and

82
00:04:09.020 --> 00:04:13.150
if I look at that zone file,
it's just got zone records, right?

83
00:04:13.150 --> 00:04:15.970
Zone records including
things like a CNAME,

84
00:04:15.970 --> 00:04:19.730
which we know don't work very
well inside of unbound, right?

85
00:04:19.730 --> 00:04:22.191
So it's set up, it's got the zone,
it's got everything that we want.

86
00:04:22.191 --> 00:04:27.280
Well, later on I created
an unbound server.

87
00:04:27.280 --> 00:04:28.450
This guy right here.

88
00:04:28.450 --> 00:04:31.630
And this server's up and
it's running unbound, so that's good.

89
00:04:31.630 --> 00:04:35.920
And I couldn't create a zone on it
cuz unbound doesn't have zones.

90
00:04:35.920 --> 00:04:37.980
So instead, on this one,

91
00:04:37.980 --> 00:04:42.930
I included a file that had a series
of host names defined in it.

92
00:04:42.930 --> 00:04:46.620
And so if I look inside of /etc/unbound,

93
00:04:46.620 --> 00:04:52.230
we'll find that file that I made,
lab.itpro.tv.dns.

94
00:04:52.230 --> 00:04:53.998
And if we look at that file,

95
00:04:53.998 --> 00:04:58.060
you'll see where I used the local
data commands to map these, right?

96
00:04:58.060 --> 00:05:02.430
Not actually creating a zone,
but kind of faking it, right?

97
00:05:02.430 --> 00:05:04.224
I dont have a start of authority.

98
00:05:04.224 --> 00:05:05.980

00:16:43.710 --> 00:16:45.970
The bigger the zone gets,
the bigger the cache is gonna get.

321
00:16:45.970 --> 00:16:49.370
But if you can't handle a couple
of megs worth of zone files,

322
00:16:49.370 --> 00:16:51.880
then your server's garbage anyway,
you got different problems to have.

323
00:16:51.880 --> 00:16:55.740
But in this case it binds cache,
you ignore.

324
00:16:55.740 --> 00:16:58.750
It just doesn't even exist anymore
as far as you're concerned.

325
00:16:58.750 --> 00:17:00.990
Unbound, on the other hand,
you do have to worry.

326
00:17:00.990 --> 00:17:03.390
And it properly sizes itself,
it does a great job,

327
00:17:03.390 --> 00:17:05.370
we don't have to worry about that there.

328
00:17:05.370 --> 00:17:07.540
And then the back end doesn't
have to be bind either.

329
00:17:07.540 --> 00:17:11.433
The back end could be PowerDNS or NDS,
Microsoft's DNS, it could be whatever.

330
00:17:11.433 --> 00:17:14.070
It's on a different server,
it could be anything and

331
00:17:14.070 --> 00:17:16.080
that helps to alleviate that too.

332
00:17:16.080 --> 00:17:16.760
But at this point,

333
00:17:16.760 --> 00:17:21.100
those are going to get forwarded and
now everything should work smooth.

334
00:17:21.100 --> 00:17:23.560
I said should,
because in IT we know what happens.

335
00:17:23.560 --> 00:17:26.926
Let me get out of my config,
I'm gonna check that configuration.

336
00:17:26.926 --> 00:17:30.849
And I'll just do a checkconf really
quick to make sure I didn't screw it up,

337
00:17:30.849 --> 00:17:32.290
I got no errors.

338
00:17:32.290 --> 00:17:38.600
I will do a systemctl restart unbound,
we'll get that one restarted.

339
00:17:39.740 --> 00:17:40.434
And then we can test it out right?

340
00:17:40.434 --> 00:17:43.945
If I do a look up against,

341
00:17:43.945 --> 00:17:48.640
I guess I'll do my local server.

342
00:17:49.810 --> 00:17:52.410
So I'm doing a look up
against my unbound server.

343
00:17:52.410 --> 00:17:57.300
And I'm gonna look for, let's just start
easy, I'll do webserver01.lab.itpro.tv.

344
00:17:57.300 --> 00:17:58.950
And when I do a look up for

345
00:17:58.950 --> 00:18:02.190
that, it's gonna reach out to unbound and
it's gonna get an answer.

346
00:18:02.190 --> 00:18:07.724
Now, in unbound, I disabled the include
that included my local data.

347
00:18:07.724 --> 00:18:11.800
So how did it get this information here?

348
00:18:11.800 --> 00:18:15.360
It forwarded to the other server and
it got it, right?

349
00:18:15.360 --> 00:18:20.230
And if I try and pull up that CNAME, and

350
00:18:20.230 --> 00:18:23.200
I reach out to it, it gets it.

351
00:18:23.200 --> 00:18:27.620
It exploded the CNAME, and
I get the CNAME entry right there

352
00:18:27.620 --> 00:18:33.140
followed by the actual IPs of
the machines I need to contact to.

353
00:18:33.140 --> 00:18:34.840
Unbound can't normally do that.

354
00:18:34.840 --> 00:18:37.930
Normally, if I ran this,
I would see www.lab.itpro.tv IN, and

355
00:18:37.930 --> 00:18:41.260
that's it, and it would stop right there.

356
00:18:41.260 --> 00:18:44.930
It wouldn't even tell me it's a CNAME,
it just kinda freezes, and that's it.

357
00:18:44.930 --> 00:18:46.621
So by putting it in this way,

358
00:18:46.621 --> 00:18:50.850
I now get where things function
the way that I expect them to be.

359
00:18:50.850 --> 00:18:52.860
And I never talked to bind, did I?

360
00:18:52.860 --> 00:18:56.960
I talked to unbound and
unbound talked to bind for me.

361
00:18:56.960 --> 00:19:01.630
All bind saw was a very simple query,
hey, give me www.lab.itpro.tv.

362
00:19:01.630 --> 00:19:05.190
And it didn't have to do forwards, it
didn't have to do lookups, it didn't have

363
00:19:05.190 --> 00:19:08.200
to go to root hints, it just went
right to its zone and answered me.

364
00:19:08.200 --> 00:19:13.930
So bind only sees one customer now,
the unbound server.

365
00:19:13.930 --> 00:19:17.580
And then unbound is handling everything
else, caching it, and moving on.

366
00:19:17.580 --> 00:19:20.270
Really straight forward, this is just
really not hard to set up, right?

367
00:19:20.270 --> 00:19:23.050
All I had to really do
is add that forwarder.

368
00:19:23.050 --> 00:19:25.810
Once you' have the folder in place,
the rest of it is done.

369
00:19:25.810 --> 00:19:26.690
That's it, it's over.

370
00:19:26.690 --> 00:19:29.320
So very simple,
very easy way to go about it.

371
00:19:29.320 --> 00:19:32.630
I've seen a lot of people use this for
different methods where, for example,

372
00:19:32.630 --> 00:19:35.690
they might have unbound setup as
their local caching DNS server.

373
00:19:35.690 --> 00:19:39.230
And then they use forwards that
point out to in that host for

374
00:19:39.230 --> 00:19:40.780
the zones that they care about.

375
00:19:40.780 --> 00:19:44.878
And then that way they are able to
maintain things out there on the Internet.

376
00:19:44.878 --> 00:19:48.408
Maybe if I registered something
through Hover.com, and so

377
00:19:48.408 --> 00:19:51.680
I might point right to Hover.com for
Lab.ITPro.TV.

378
00:19:51.680 --> 00:19:55.040
And now everything else I cache locally,
but then I forward to them for

379
00:19:55.040 --> 00:19:55.860
that one zone.

380
00:19:55.860 --> 00:19:57.720
Those are all different ways
that you can use this, but

381
00:19:57.720 --> 00:20:02.370
the point is by using forwarders in
unbound, you can create a super fast,

382
00:20:02.370 --> 00:20:07.300
super stable best of both worlds type of
deployment where you get great caching,

383
00:20:07.300 --> 00:20:10.710
and great zone support, and
that's really the best way to go about it.

384
00:20:10.710 --> 00:20:11.750
>> That's a really cool setup,

385
00:20:11.750 --> 00:20:15.200
using two pieces of software like that to
make your infrastructure a little better.

386
00:20:15.200 --> 00:20:18.290
Now Don, I know that we're coming
to the end of this episode, but

387
00:20:18.290 --> 00:20:21.530
before we do, do you have any additional
advice you would like to give somebody if

388
00:20:21.530 --> 00:20:26.670
they are gonna use unbound and bind,
and maybe even on a single server?

389
00:20:26.670 --> 00:20:27.820
>> Sure, two things to worry about.

390
00:20:27.820 --> 00:20:29.380
One, test it out.

391
00:20:29.380 --> 00:20:31.570
Always test it out, make sure it works.

392
00:20:31.570 --> 00:20:34.540
Make sure that you put everything in
place and that it actually does work,

393
00:20:34.540 --> 00:20:37.850
cuz there's all sorts of little things
that can cause a problem on this, right?

394
00:20:37.850 --> 00:20:41.310
Firewall, SELinux,
the services being started, all of that.

395
00:20:41.310 --> 00:20:45.390
The other thing is remember that now
I don't just need one DNA server,

396
00:20:45.390 --> 00:20:46.400
I need two.

397
00:20:46.400 --> 00:20:48.030
If one of them fails,
I'm gonna have a problem.

398
00:20:48.030 --> 00:20:50.568
If unbound fails,
it doesn't matter that bind is up and

399
00:20:50.568 --> 00:20:52.629
running, nobody's looking to it, right?

400
00:20:52.629 --> 00:20:54.510
So I don't get redundancy there.

401
00:20:54.510 --> 00:20:59.130
And if bind fails, unbound is up and
now we can't look up Lab.ItPro.TV and so

402
00:20:59.130 --> 00:21:00.760
my zone is offline.

403
00:21:00.760 --> 00:21:03.520
So both servers become important.

404
00:21:03.520 --> 00:21:06.380
They might be virtual machines, so
we don't worry about physical hardware.

405
00:21:06.380 --> 00:21:10.510
But still in software, a problem in one
will lead to a problem that affects

406
00:21:10.510 --> 00:21:12.240
the end users,
it doesn't matter that you have two.

407
00:21:12.240 --> 00:21:15.060
So this is not a solution for redundancy.

408
00:21:15.060 --> 00:21:19.470
I would wanna continue on and
set up multiple unbound servers, and

409
00:21:19.470 --> 00:21:24.310
then at least one more bind
server that has a replica, right?

410
00:21:24.310 --> 00:21:28.160
It has a copy of that zone on it,
so that we can set up a backup.

411
00:21:28.160 --> 00:21:31.120
So that when we have that forwarder
in place we can get to others, and

412
00:21:31.120 --> 00:21:32.560
get that redundancy there.

413
00:21:32.560 --> 00:21:36.930
So keep that in mind, what I just showed
you is great for functionality and

414
00:21:36.930 --> 00:21:39.500
performance, not great for redundancy.

415
00:21:39.500 --> 00:21:41.460
You still need to take extra steps there.

416
00:21:41.460 --> 00:21:42.290
>> Words of wisdom.

417
00:21:42.290 --> 00:21:45.320
Don, we appreciate you stopping by
the studio here, and we appreciate you,

418
00:21:45.320 --> 00:21:46.850
the viewer out there watching.

419
00:21:46.850 --> 00:21:50.220
Signing out for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

420
00:21:50.220 --> 00:21:51.080
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

421
00:21:51.080 --> 00:21:51.601
>> And we'll see you next time.

422
00:21:51.601 --> 00:21:59.419
[MUSIC]

423
00:21:59.419 --> 00:22:02.098
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don show the viewers how to take advantage of the benefits of bringing Unbound into combination with NSD. They demonstrate how to set up Unbound to receive and forward DNS queries to a NSD server on the same physical machine.
episodes.title: Using Unbound with NSD
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:02.397
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:02.397 --> 00:00:07.214
I'm your host, Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.214 --> 00:00:08.417
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.417 --> 00:00:12.200
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.200 --> 00:00:15.980
>> Welcome to another great episode here
at ITProTV I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

6
00:00:15.980 --> 00:00:19.430
And in today's episode, we are continuing
through our DNS tech skills.

7
00:00:19.430 --> 00:00:20.820
We got a great episode for you today.

8
00:00:20.820 --> 00:00:23.410
And joining us in the studios is
none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

9
00:00:23.410 --> 00:00:24.400
Don, how you doing, sir?

10
00:00:24.400 --> 00:00:25.700
>> I'm doing just swell, Wes.

11
00:00:25.700 --> 00:00:27.820
Ready to dive right back
into the world of DNS.

12
00:00:27.820 --> 00:00:32.290
And in this episode, we're gonna be
taking a look at what I call the new

13
00:00:32.290 --> 00:00:36.950
hotness in DNS, which is using unbound and

14
00:00:36.950 --> 00:00:40.050
nsd together to provide name lookup
services in your environment.

15
00:00:40.050 --> 00:00:43.020
I've mentioned it in several of the other
DNS episodes that we've done and

16
00:00:43.020 --> 00:00:47.310
this is kind of becoming the got to
solution for companies that are out there.

17
00:00:47.310 --> 00:00:51.290
And there's several of the root hint
servers that are already doing this.

18
00:00:51.290 --> 00:00:52.977
So it's all the way up at that level,

19
00:00:52.977 --> 00:00:55.885
where we're starting to see it
trickle out the rest of the way.

20
00:00:55.885 --> 00:00:59.550
Now, just to recap real quick why the heck
I would do this in the first place, right?

21
00:00:59.550 --> 00:01:04.560
Remember that unbound is a recursive and

22
00:01:04.560 --> 00:01:09.670
caching authentication
verifying type DNS server.

23
00:01:09.670 --> 00:01:11.840
It scales very well.

24
00:01:11.840 --> 00:01:15.220
It's written in modern programming
language that runs very fast.

25
00:01:15.220 --> 00:01:16.280
It's very stable.

26
00:01:16.280 --> 00:01:17.390
It's very small.

27
00:01:17.390 --> 00:01:19.160
It's not very resource intensive.

28
00:01:19.160 --> 00:01:22.180
And is really,
really good at what it does.

29
00:01:22.180 --> 00:01:25.550
But the thing it doesn't do, or
at least the thing it doesn't do well,

30
00:01:25.550 --> 00:01:26.750
are authoritative lookups.

31
00:01:26.750 --> 00:01:28.340
You can actually get it to
do authoritative lookups,

32
00:01:28.340 --> 00:01:31.200
I covered that back in the unbound show.

33
00:01:31.200 --> 00:01:33.220
But it doesn't do a good job with it.

34
00:01:33.220 --> 00:01:35.670
Meanwhile, we got this other product, NSD.

35
00:01:35.670 --> 00:01:39.680
And NSD,
it is an authoritative name server.

36
00:01:39.680 --> 00:01:40.820
That's what it does specifically.

37
00:01:40.820 --> 00:01:43.650
And it's written in a modern programming
language, and it scales really well.

38
00:01:43.650 --> 00:01:45.830
It's very fast, very stable.

39
00:01:45.830 --> 00:01:48.970
But it only does authoritative lookups.

40
00:01:48.970 --> 00:01:50.740
It doesn't do forwarders.

41
00:01:50.740 --> 00:01:53.590
It doesn't do cacheing and
recursive lookups.

42
00:01:53.590 --> 00:01:57.670
It only answers questions about
the domains that it actually hosts,

43
00:01:57.670 --> 00:02:00.050
which is part of why it's so
fast and stable, right?

44
00:02:00.050 --> 00:02:02.540
So neither one is a drop-in
replacement for Bind.

45
00:02:02.540 --> 00:02:08.150
Bind has been the go-to,
standby DNS server used for 30 years now.

46
00:02:08.150 --> 00:02:09.800
It's been around a long time.

47
00:02:09.800 --> 00:02:13.360
But if we take unbound and we take NSD and

48
00:02:13.360 --> 00:02:17.560
we put them together,
now we have a solution that's a fireball.

49
00:02:17.560 --> 00:02:24.020
Now it is stable, scalable, fast,
reliable, all the things that we want.

50
00:02:24.020 --> 00:02:25.640
All in an open source platform.

51
00:02:25.640 --> 00:02:28.160
So it really is the direction
that people are going.

52
00:02:28.160 --> 00:02:31.480
And it sounds complex to
have to use two solutions.

53
00:02:31.480 --> 00:02:33.500
And it doesn't have to be.

54
00:02:33.500 --> 00:02:37.590
So in a previous episode,
we saw how to use Unbound with Bind.

55
00:02:37.590 --> 00:02:39.630
And I used two completely
separate servers.

56
00:02:39.630 --> 00:02:42.000
One server ran Bind, and
one server ran Unbound.

57
00:02:42.000 --> 00:02:44.740
And I mentioned how you could
run them on the same box.

58
00:02:44.740 --> 00:02:49.000
Well, in this video, I'm gonna show
you how to run Unbound and NSD.

59
00:02:49.000 --> 00:02:51.080
And instead of running them
on two different boxes,

60
00:02:51.080 --> 00:02:53.500
I'm gonna run them on the same box,
on the same machine.

61
00:02:53.500 --> 00:02:55.430
And I know what you're thinking.

62
00:02:55.430 --> 00:02:57.410
Aren't you gonna take
a performance hit from that?

63
00:02:57.410 --> 00:03:00.390
Not really, cuz it is two separate
databases that are optimized

64
00:03:00.390 --> 00:03:01.370
different ways.

65
00:03:01.370 --> 00:03:05.020
If I were in a massive environment,
if I were a root hint server, yes,

66
00:03:05.020 --> 00:03:08.210
I would have separate boxes, and
I'd have many of them, right?

67
00:03:08.210 --> 00:03:12.440
But if you're deploying this for
your company, even a large enterprise,

68
00:03:12.440 --> 00:03:15.200
the load on the server's not
gonna be that significant.

69
00:03:15.200 --> 00:03:19.000
And so you could deploy two servers,
one running unbound on NSD,

70
00:03:19.000 --> 00:03:22.750
and another running unbound on NSD, and
replicating your zones between them.

71
00:03:22.750 --> 00:03:26.670
And now you've got an amazing DNS
lookup solution that all runs cn

72
00:03:26.670 --> 00:03:28.190
that small of a package.

73
00:03:28.190 --> 00:03:30.490
All right, well,
enough rambling on about it.

74
00:03:30.490 --> 00:03:31.850
Let's go and take a look at this.

75
00:03:31.850 --> 00:03:35.180
Now, the biggest obstacle we're
gonna bump into this challenge,

76
00:03:35.180 --> 00:03:37.740
if we were running these
on the two separate boxes.

77
00:03:37.740 --> 00:03:39.040
I wouldn't even film this episode.

78
00:03:39.040 --> 00:03:41.910
I'd say just go back and
watch the installing NSD episode.

79
00:03:41.910 --> 00:03:43.760
And go and
watch the installing Unbound episode.

80
00:03:43.760 --> 00:03:46.630
And do it on two different servers,
and you're done, right?

81
00:03:46.630 --> 00:03:50.310
But the challenge here is gonna be when
I run two services, two DNS services,

82
00:03:50.310 --> 00:03:55.530
on the same machine, they're both
gonna try to bond to port 53, right?

83
00:03:55.530 --> 00:03:59.690
DNS uses TCP, and UDP port 53 by default.

84
00:03:59.690 --> 00:04:04.530
Unbound does, Bind does,
NSD does, heck, even DNS Mask and

85
00:04:04.530 --> 00:04:08.000
some of the other utilities that
people run will bind to those ports.

86
00:04:08.000 --> 00:04:09.400
So how do you run them
both at the same time?

87
00:04:09.400 --> 00:04:10.970
And the answer is, carefully.

88
00:04:10.970 --> 00:04:14.470
So, [LAUGH] we just have to do a little
planning and kinda get it put in place.

89
00:04:14.470 --> 00:04:20.420
Now, the key thing to think about here is
who is going to answer on Port 53, right?

90
00:04:20.420 --> 00:04:24.430
When a client asks a question,
who's gonna answer?

91
00:04:24.430 --> 00:04:26.910
We don't want it to be NSD.

92
00:04:26.910 --> 00:04:32.030
Because if NSD answers, it can only answer
questions about the zones that it has.

93
00:04:32.030 --> 00:04:35.520
It can't answer any other zones,
just the authoritative ones.

94
00:04:35.520 --> 00:04:37.000
>> So if you want recursion,

95
00:04:37.000 --> 00:04:40.050
it's gonna have to be unbound
that's gonna be running on Port 53?

96
00:04:40.050 --> 00:04:41.710
>> Right, and
I like the way you said that.

97
00:04:41.710 --> 00:04:42.880
It has to be.

98
00:04:42.880 --> 00:04:44.380
Cuz the other ways just not gonna work,
right?

99
00:04:44.380 --> 00:04:47.690
If you do the look up against
a nonrecursive survey,

100
00:04:47.690 --> 00:04:50.910
if you do a look up against NSD,
you can only find those domains.

101
00:04:50.910 --> 00:04:54.060
You'd have to basically create every
domain right there inside of NSD.

102
00:04:54.060 --> 00:04:55.890
It's not possible, right?

103
00:04:55.890 --> 00:04:59.800
But if we do a lookup against Unbound,
Unbound will do a recursive lookup cuz

104
00:04:59.800 --> 00:05:02.750
it'll reach out there on the Internet,
it'll cache them and store them.

105
00:05:02.750 --> 00:05:06.810
And then, what we can do is
put a forwarder in Unbound

106
00:05:06.810 --> 00:05:11.800
that says whenever we do a lookup for
one of our authoritative domains,

107
00:05:11.800 --> 00:05:15.808
instead of sending it out to the Internet,
send it over to NSD.

108
00:05:15.808 --> 00:05:18.380
And if NSD's on a separate box,
we just point it to that IP.

109
00:05:18.380 --> 00:05:22.890
But if it's on the same box,
we've got to point it to NSD, and

110
00:05:22.890 --> 00:05:27.460
we've got to point it at the port
number that it's gonna be connecting,

111
00:05:27.460 --> 00:05:28.840
cuz it's gotta run on a different port,
right?

112
00:05:28.840 --> 00:05:30.090
So that's where things start
to get a little tricky.

113
00:05:30.090 --> 00:05:32.230
So that's what we're gonna take
a look at right here in this episode,

114
00:05:32.230 --> 00:05:34.600
is getting that up and going and in place.

115
00:05:34.600 --> 00:05:38.120
Now, when we start manipulating
port numbers and stuff,

116
00:05:38.120 --> 00:05:40.730
there's some challenges that we can bump
into that we always need to be aware of.

117
00:05:42.030 --> 00:05:44.200
If you're deploying this on Dbin or

118
00:05:44.200 --> 00:05:49.120
Ubuntu, it's really pretty simple,
you churn right through it and you do it.

119
00:05:49.120 --> 00:05:51.320
